HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN FINANCE: 1990/From Wall St. to Warsaw, Economic Storms Are Growing;
Richard G. Darman/Getting the Blame For the Budget Pain

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

 BODY:
When Richard G. Darman became budget director, his goal was to engineer what he called "the Grand Compromise," a sweeping deal in which Republicans and Democrats agreed to politically painful measures to reduce the budget deficit.
This year, Mr. Darman pulled off the deal, but he ended up getting little credit and taking most of the blame. 
 After tortuous negotiations lasting more than six months, Congress approved and President Bush signed the most significant deficit-reduction legislation in American history. Unless the law is changed, the cumulative deficit will be cut by nearly $500 billion over the next five years below what it would otherwise be.
In the process, however, President Bush reneged on his "no new taxes" pledge, broke his promise to insist on a capital-gains tax cut and allowed himself to be painted into a political corner by Democrats who portrayed him as the patron of fat cats.
Many Republicans faulted Mr. Darman for the resulting plunge in the President's popularity. Conservatives called for the budget director's resignation.
One weekend in midsummer, Mr. Darman slipped on wet steps at a McDonald's restaurant, cutting himself badly. But he may have been less bruised than he was by the conservatives' attacks. For example, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, called him a mere "technocrat" who did not grasp "the great romantic vision of being American." Still, there is no indication he has slipped from grace in President Bush's eyes.
Mr. Darman, who is 47 years old, has been in the Government most of his adult life. He clearly hoped to become Treasury Secretary some day, but that seems unlikely now. Few people would be surprised if he left the Government after the new budget is released in February.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN FINANCE: 1990/From Wall St. to Warsaw, Economic Storms Are Growing;
L. William Seidman/Banking Regulator Gains New Respect

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

 BODY:
L. William Seidman says one of his New Year's resolutions will be to figure out when he leaves his post.
It is an unusual resolution, considering that President Bush in May had already named Mr. Seidman's successor as head of two agencies that regulate more than 12,000 banks and run the bailout of the savings and loan industry. While he has often said he would resign before his term expires late next year, Mr. Seidman has for months continued to dominate the regulatory scene. 
 Administering what by all accounts is the least popular program in Washington, the multibillion-dollar rescue of savings associations, Mr. Seidman has earned the respect of both parties in Congress through deft and frank appearances on Capitol Hill and on news programs.
Over the last four years, Mr. Seidman has gradually transformed the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation from a second-tier agency to the nation's dominant banking regulator.
His fierce streak of independence has often found him at odds with the Bush Administration, although lately he appears to be getting along much better than earlier this year, when he said the Treasury Department and the White House were trying to push him out. Today, Treasury officials talk about how Mr. Seidman and the Administration have been putting together proposals to shore up the ailing bank insurance fund and reorganize the banking system.
The new spirit of cooperation marks a turnabout from just a few months earlier, when the Federal Reserve's chief banking regulator, William Taylor, was named to succeed the 69-year-old Mr. Seidman.
Asked what his uncertainty about the timing of his departure has meant for his annointed successor, Mr. Seidman, with characteristically cagey good humor, said: "Bill's a good man. He's also a young man."

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN FINANCE: 1990/From Wall St. to Warsaw, Economic Storms Are Growing;
Alan Greenspan/Fed Chairman Feels Chill of Recession

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
In his nearly three and a half years as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan has gone through the repertory of experiences that can befall a central bank chief -- inflation, a stock market crash and now recession. Trying to shake it off is likely to occupy most of Mr. Greenspan's time in the final months of his term, which ends in August.
The 64-year-old chairman has even avoided using the term "recession" in public to refer to the economic downturn. But the stepped-up efforts of the Federal Reserve Board last month to reduce interest rates made clear that the Fed is trying to reverse the economic decline. 
 The recession represents a defeat for Mr. Greenspan, one that could cost him reappointment. Since early 1988, he had tried to steer the economy between inflation and recession through gradual changes in interest rates.
For months, Mr. Greenspan and the central bank's other policy makers had been reducing rates, but many economists now say that the Fed moved too slowly and too gradually to avoid the recession. Some even say that the Greenspan Fed courted recession, to achieve a drastic reduction in the inflation rate. Mr. Greenspan has suggested that his approach would have worked, if it were not for the Persian Gulf crisis.
But whatever the case, Mr. Greenspan now faces a recession complicated by a bank crisis. Burdened with unpaid loans and not enough capital, the banks are reluctant to make new loans. And now that the Fed is lowering rates to encourage businesses and consumers to borrow and spend, the banks might not cooperate by lending them money.
Such foot-dragging could force Mr. Greenspan to take other, more drastic steps to bolster the banks and to revive the sinking economy.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN FINANCE: 1990/From Wall St. to Warsaw, Economic Storms Are Growing;
James D. Robinson 3d/Ambitious Leader's Costly Reversal

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
For James D. Robinson 3d, 1990 was the year to bite the bullet and admit that some of his strategic plans of the last decade had failed.
Mr. Robinson, the chairman of the American Express Company, was forced to inject more capital into its brokerage subsidiary, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., now called Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. 
 "The year started off with tremendous problems at Shearson," he said. "That led us to conclude that we had to do a total reversal and reacquire Shearson."
In doing so, Shearson became the first Wall Street firm to be bailed out by its corporate parent in 1990. It was followed by the First Boston Corporation, which received a capital injection from its parent, CS Holdings Inc. And Prudential Bache Securiites Inc. got new capital at the end of the year from the Prudential Insurance Company of America.
For Mr. Robinson, the Shearson bailout was a bitter personal disappointment. He led American Express's purchase of Shearson Loeb Rhoades, which he hoped would help him turning his travel card company into a financial supermarket.
In 1987, American Express sold about 40 percent of the firm to the public, and Mr. Robinson frequently said his company wanted to decrease its holdings to less than 50 percent. In that way, Shearson would not have to be counted on the American Express balance sheet.
But the intensity of Wall Street's recession and the collapse of numerous business lines scotched that plan.
In January, after months of conflict between them, Mr. Robinson asked for the resignation of Peter A. Cohen, who was then the chairman of Shearson.
In March, American Express said it would buy all of the publicly held shares of Shearson. Since then, Shearson has made many changes in its top management.

HEADLINE: Hard Times Spur Many to Help the Neediest

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
Ten months after losing his job as a managing director at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., Nicholas P. Heymann sent $3,500 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and wrote that he considered himself fortunate.
"Like many others, my past year has been filled with upheaval, shock and whirlwind change," Mr. Heymann, who lives in Stamford, Conn., wrote. "Yet unlike many less fortunate, whenever I needed it most, the sun always filtered through the haze of disbelief and despair. While I now have less to give than before, I offer more, knowing I'm more fortunate than ever." 
 Mr. Heymann, 34 years old, said yesterday in a telephone interview that he "barely knew what had hit" when he lost his job in February. But the experience caused him to reorder his priorities. This year he and his family cut back on their holiday celebrations and gave to more than 25 charities.
Now a corporate vice president on Wall Street at County NatWest Securities, he said he was getting paid less than before but felt "very lucky and grateful" for all he had.
It was a difficult year for many, but donors to the Neediest Cases Fund often say that the hard times and widespread poverty have made them appreciate the basic things in life.
In hundreds of letters that have accompanied gifts to the fund, people write that they are grateful for a job, for having lived a long life, for births and marriages, and for being surrounded by friends and family. A donation to the fund, they say, is a way of sharing their good fortune.
The 79th annual appeal for the Neediest Cases began at the end of November and will run through February. All money raised in the drive will be distributed to seven charities to aid the sick and the poor. The New York Times pays for the campaign's overhead.
 
 Donation for Homeless
 Joan M. Schumacher of Manhattan sent $500 and asked that it be used to help the homeless in New York. "During this time of severe job shortage and very tight economy," she wrote, "I am so grateful to be employed."
Another donor, Nancy Brozain, a nursing supervisor at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan, wrote that she was sending $200, "even though saddened by my father's death and my mother's illness."
In a telephone interview, Ms. Brozain said that her mother was battling cancer and that she worked every day with people who had the disease. Yet the tragedies that surround her have not stopped her from feeling fortunate.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN FINANCE: 1990/From Wall St. to Warsaw, Economic Storms Are Growing;
Thomas G. Labrecque/Rebuilding Chase After an Upheaval

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
When Thomas G. Labrecque was named chairman at the Chase Manhattan Corporation last year, he inherited more than just a new office. With the new title came a flood of problems that would make 1990 a dismal year for Chase and many other banking companies.
Grimly vowing that Chase would be a survivor, Mr. Labrecque attacked the problems of high expenses and heavy losses on commercial real estate loans. Eliminating 5,000 jobs and sharply increasing reserves to cover real estate loan losses resulted in a $603 million loss in the third quarter. But by the end of the year, Chase had returned to profitability, and Mr. Labrecque expects the measures will save $300 million this year. 
 After the cutbacks and write-offs, Mr. Labrecque is now faced with the more drawn-out task of expanding the company profitably. A reliance on its successful consumer banking business in the United States is clearly part of the strategy, but that does not guarantee Chase a place in the top tier of the world's largest banks.
"The financial-services industry is a lot bigger than banking," Mr. Labrecque said. Among the options he is exploring are various kinds of joint ventures with nonbanking companies that are strong in some of the same businesses as Chase is.
Another option for Chase and other big banks is to merge and improve profits by eliminating redundant computer systems, branches and executives. But analysts say mergers among banks the size of Chase may be unlikely unless their condition becomes so precarious that their top officers are willing to make some personal sacrifices.
"After spending 20 and 30 years working their way to the top, these guys are not about to step aside unless they are forced to," said Alex Sheshunoff, a bank consultant. "There are no mergers until there are agreements about who gets the top job."

HEADLINE: Prices Paid To Farmers Fall by 0.7%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
The prices farmers receive for raw products ended 1990 with a seven-tenths of 1 percent decline from November to December, the Agriculture Department said yesterday.
Farmers received lower prices for milk, hogs and lettuce, although higher prices for cattle, peanuts and eggs helped to ease the overall decline in prices. 
 The fruit and vegetable prices, however, were recorded before freezing cold hit California around Dec. 21, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said.
Record high monthly prices were reported for cattle, but hog prices were down again, the report said.
"Oats and wheat were each at their lowest level for the month of December since 1972," it said. "Corn increased slightly from November while the soybean price decreased slightly."
Most prices are mid-December averages, which will be revised next month.
No new figures were released to show how much farmers had to pay to meet expenses. Those are adjusted quarterly.
 
 Consumer Food Prices
 Department economists forecast that in 1991 consumer food prices will climb an average of 2 to 5 percent, compared with a 6 percent gain in 1990. Larger output of some major commodities is expected to help cool the price climb.
The net cash income of farmers in 1991 has been forecast by the Agriculture Department at $55 billion to $60 billion, which could be less than the record of $59 billion in 1990. Net cash income is simply the difference between gross cash income and cash expenses.
The Agriculture Department gave these prices in its report yesterday:
Cattle averaged $77.60 for 100 pounds of live weight nationally, up from $75.30 in November. A year earlier, cattle averaged $71 a hundredweight. Those are averages for all types of cattle sold as beef.
Hogs averaged $47.60 a hundredweight, down from $50.20 in November. A year earlier, hogs averaged $48.20.
Corn, at $2.18 a bushel, was up a penny from November but was down 9 cents from a year earlier.
Wheat prices at the farm, according to preliminary figures, averaged $2.38 a bushel, compared with $2.39 in November and $3.79 in December 1989.
Rice averaged $6.26 for 100 pounds, compared with $6.30 in November and $6.95 a year earlier.
Soybeans were $5.74 a bushel, compared with $5.78 in November and $5.64 in December 1989.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends 1990 Lower While Gold Is Up Slightly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower on the final day of 1990, finishing a year of marked weakening against other currencies attributed in large part to the reunification of Germany and a slumping United States economy.
Gold was marginally higher yesterday, but ended the year down moderately. The precious metal closed up 20 cents, to $394.20 a troy ounce, from Friday's close on the New York Commodity Exchange. That compared with gold's last quote on the final day of 1989 at $402.50 an ounce. 
 The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $393.25 a troy ounce, up 25 cents from late Friday but down from 1989.
Silver rose 2 cents a troy ounce on the New York Commodity Exchange to $4.192. That was down from the metal's last late bid of 1989 of $5.208 a troy ounce.
 
Loosening of Communism Cited
 Currency analysts said the loosening of Communism in Eastern Europe also contributed to the dollar's fall by strengthening the German mark.
"Germany is the big story in 1990," said David Marshall, currency analyst at MMS International. "The dollar did worse than people expected due to the quickness with which the reunification of Germany went through and the strength of the unwinding of Eastern Europe."
In addition, he said, "no one expected the U.S. economy to be as soft as it now seems to be."
Yesterday in New York the dollar closed against the German mark at 1.4885, compared with 1.6950 marks at 1989's end. Late Friday the dollar was quoted at 1.4935 marks.
 
 Conflict in Middle East Cited
 Analysts said the dollar's year-to-date loss against currencies other than the mark was not as pronounced, in part because the Middle East conflict seemed to hurt some other denominations more than the dollar.
In New York, the dollar ended the year at 135.50 Japanese yen, down from 143.85 yen at the end of 1989. But yesterday the dollar ended stronger than Friday's closing 134.90 yen.
The British pound also strengthened over all against the dollar, closing the year at $1.9345 in New York compared with $1.6105 at 1989's close. On Friday, sterling was quoted at a closing $1.9282. In London, the pound rose to $1.9280, from $1.9220 late Friday. The pound traded in London at $1.6115 at the end of 1989.
The dollar's slight fall yesterday was attributed partly to a fresh peace initiative from the European Community. Luxembourg's Foreign Minister, Jacques Poos, said he might meet with his Iraqi counterpart, Tariq Aziz. Luxembourg will take over the European Community's rotating chairmanship today.
Heightened peace prospects in the Persian Gulf tend to diminish the United States currency's value because the investment is considered a safe haven in times of war.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates and with 1989 year-end rates in parentheses, included: 1.2668 Swiss francs, down from 1.2745 (1.5420); 5.0685 French francs, down from 5.0810 (5.7805); 1.1599 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1601 (1.1588), and 1,122.75 Italian lire, down from 1,126.50 (1,267.00).

HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
An Opportunity Born Of Adversity

BYLINE: By JAIME DIAZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 31

 BODY:
The Fiesta Bowl, which pits Alabama against Louisville on Tuesday, won't have any impact on the national championship, but it has surely brought focus on the state of Arizona's bruised national image.
The days leading up to the tepidly anticipated encounter between the 7-4 Crimson Tide and the 9-1-1 Cardinals have been filled with a battle for the "spin control" on the Election Day defeat of propositions that would have made Dr. Martin Luther King's birthday a paid holiday for state workers. 
 Fiesta Bowl officials, university administrators and many Arizona politicians have taken pains to pay tribute to the memory of Dr. King and distance themselves from the election results.
 
Questions of Propriety
 For some black leaders, the game has been an opportunity to show the need for a King holiday and to question the moral propriety of academic institutions choosing to take home millions in Fiesta Bowl revenue from the state that voted not to honor King.
The local chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. announced it would stage a protest at Sun Devil Stadium immediately before the game. The chapter's president, the Rev. Oscar Tillman, said that because administrators of both schools refused to discuss their pending decision to send teams to Tempe with his chapter, "we want to put our stamp of disapproval on the proceedings."
"For Louisville and particularly Alabama, where Dr. King did so much, to completely ignore the oldest black organization in this city before making their decision is appalling," Tillman said today. "We are making a statement because after Louisville and Alabama leave, we in Arizona are still going to have a problem."
Tillman said the demonstration, which he said he will try to limit to fewer than 100 people, would take place for about 20 minutes before the game.
 
A Peaceful Statement
 "Our statement will be peaceful," Tillman said. "We will have a silent prayer, send our message and move on."
On the other side of the political line, officials have been straining to counter the financial and public-relation damage Arizona has undergone since the Nov. 6 vote.
"We are going to use this bowl game in a postive stance to talk about the causes of civil rights," said John Junker, the Fiesta Bowl's executive director.
Some of the damage control includes establishment by the Fiesta Bowl of $100,000 scholarships at both schools to honor King and assist minority-group students. Alabama plans to use at least $100,000 from its bowl receipts to improve academic programs relating to minority issues, while Donald C. Swain, the president of Louisville, is appointing a committee to recommend ways the university can use some of its Fiesta Bowl profits to honor the memory of King.
Bowl officials also expanded its halftime entertainment to include a tribute to King.
 
King Is Honored
 Meanwhile, local booster groups have taken pains to point out to visiting reporters that Phoenix, Tempe and more than 20 other cities in Arizona observe Dr. King's birthday as a paid holiday, and that the voters of Phoenix and its surroundings approved the proposition for the holiday. In addition, the city of Phoenix has provided a tape illustrating its affinity for the King holiday.
Such lengths may be necessary to repair some of the damage Arizona has suffered. Officials have projected millions in lost convention business. And the threat by the National Football League to pull the 1993 Super Bowl out of Phoenix could cost the state $200 million in economic benefits. The league's owners will vote on the matter in March, but approval appeared a virtual certainty.
 The Natioanl Collegiate Athletic Association has already turned down Arizona State's bid to host a portion of the 1994 men's national basketball tournament, and the National Basketball Association has said it will not not hold any All-Star Games or league meetings in the state as long as there is no King holiday.
Fiesta Bowl officials probably contributed to the problem when, six days after the vote, they attempted to move the game, which has been held in the Phoenix area for 20 years, to San Diego. But on Nov. 13, the N.C.A.A. ruled that it could not because the California city was already the site of the Holiday Bowl.
But the occasion of the game and the attention it has brought to the King issue is being perceived as valuable by those who want the holiday.
The Rev. Warren Stewart, who leads a statewide petition drive to get a nonpaid King holiday on the Arizona state ballot by 1992, used today's Fiesta Bowl parade to gain public support by asking citizens to sign the petition.
"This week will help us," Stewart said. "Out of adversity, Dr. King will be lifted up nationally, and that would have never happened."

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Some Things Change in a Year; Some Never Do

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

 BODY:
A pause this New Year's Day to update a few of the 1990 Our Towns columns:
In September people on the New Jersey bank of the Hudson were upset to be kept waiting two hours in line for the right to pay $6 a head to take a 10-minute ferry ride to Ellis Island -- particularly when there is a construction bridge nearby, making it an easy walk. As a result, a Congressional hearing in October looked into the bidding that awarded the ferry contract to Circle Line. Rep. Frank J. Guarini has worked out an agreement to keep the bridge in place for now with hopes that it will eventually become a free walkway. He plans legislation to revamp National Park concession bidding. Ferry officials are not retreating; at the hearing, a spokesman said the ride may go to $8. 
 An April column described the plight of Robert Lake, a Rutgers professor nationally known for his research on racial segregation, who was entangled in an apparently frivolous court case. The professor conducted a survey on behalf of a black man refused an apartment at Woodbridge Terrace in Woodbridge, N.J. It indicated racial steering. The landlords sued Mr. Lake, charging defamation, an increasingly common tactic used against civil-rights advocates; the professor countersued. A month after the column, the landlords settled. Mr. Lake and two others split $250,000.
Eli Finn, the 100-year-old man who drives in the passing lane on his way to his American history course at Fairfield University, begins a new semester Jan. 16.
The Our Towns reporter happened to be on hand for an inspection of a Brentwood, L.I., adult home run by Omega Pope and considered by mental health officials to be among the worst in New York. Doors fell off in inspectors' hands; medicine lit tered the floors; resi dents sat doing noth ing. The home has a long history of bad re views; for two yearsMs. Pope's license has been provisional. This week, the state Department of Social Services decided to give her another year to correct problems.
 News accounts of fabricated census data from the Hack ensack, N.J., office led to recounting 18,300 housing units, at a cost of $400,000. The result: Two-thirds of the units were incorrectly counted. Investigations continue.
The first new supermarket in Newark's Central Ward since the riots of 1967, a Pathmark, is prospering, a spokesman says. Tom Bradley, a gay Bayport, L.I., teacher who feared the worst when people discovered he had AIDS, says he has experienced the best. In October 2,000 people turned out for Tom Bradley Day. He is strong enough to do his administrative job three days a week. However, he has not been able to shake an eye virus. "I could stand losing one eye, but both -- I'd be scared."
Oscar Marchant -- who has continued to teach at Essex County Jail Annex for 22 years though there are days he can't hold class because guards use his chairs for new prisoners -- got 10 new chairs as a donation after a column. A report about the The Rainbow Foundation, a small children's charity threatened by the recession, resulted in "tens of thousands of dollars of gifts," according to its director. The charity will continue.
Good news for Fideau, a miniature pig, who was branded an illegal pet in Rutherford, N.J. Pig and owner are moving from their town house to semi-rural Orange County. "It's lovely," said Nick DiGiaimo. "Fideau will have his own room." The pig still faces a court date this month.
Last spring, State Senator Michael J. Tully Jr. filed a bill to stop new group homes for the mentally ill on Long Island. The legislation was a response to constituents who didn't want a home in their suburb. (Senator Tully was up for re-election.) After much publicity, the proposal went nowhere. (Senator Tully was re-elected.) However, state cuts may achieve what he couldn't. The state planned to finance 600 beds this year, but reduced it to 300.
Andrew Cuomo's Westhelp town houses for 108 homeless families open this month in Greenburgh in Westchester County after years of fierce opposition. Karl Hammer, who runs Moody Hill Farms, considered one of the best composting operations in New York, is beginning his fourth year battling neighbors trying to close him.
In September, Community Advocates opened a six-unit building in Roslyn Heights, the first permanent housing for the homeless in Nassau County (population 1.3 million). The two-year fight featured some astounding flip-flops by local politicians. Since the opening, business people, the clergy and the Junior League have all made donations. Marge Rogatz, the project director, says, "I'm convinced this housing could exist all over the county if our political leaders took the position we have to find a place for all our people." She's not holding her breath.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Is Sworn In for 3d Term Without Festivities

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 31

 BODY:
In a brief ceremony without the festivities or speeches that characterized his prior inaugurations, Mario Matthew Cuomo was sworn in today to a third term as New York State's Governor.
Reciting an oath administered by the state's Chief Judge, Sol Wachtler, the 58-year-old Mr. Cuomo began a year in which he will confront the greatest fiscal challenge of his tenure, a budget gap that by some accounts has reached almost $4 billion. It is also a year in which he is expected to decide whether he will seek the Presidency, although Mr. Cuomo has insisted that any such considerations are premature while the state remains in financial turmoil. 
 The six-minute ceremony was held in the ornate main room of the New York State Court of Appeals, where Mr. Cuomo began his legal career more than 30 years ago as a law clerk. About 80 people -- mainly relatives and members of his executive staff -- looked on.
 
Others Take Their Oaths
 Just before the Governor was sworn in, Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine took the oath for his second term of office. Attorney General Robert Abrams and Comptroller Edward V. Regan, who were both first elected in 1978, shunned swearing-in ceremonies for their fourth terms and instead said they planned to file written oaths of office with the Secretary of State in Albany.
The quiet mood here today contrasted sharply with Mr. Cuomo's 1987 inauguration, which attracted nearly 5,000 people and featured a 19-gun salute and symphony overtures. Mr. Cuomo announced earlier this year that he would forgo an elaborate ceremony this time, saving the state between $60,000 and $70,000 and acting in recognition, in the Governor's words, of the "inconvenience, sacrifice, even pain" forced by the state's fiscal straits.
"The months immediately ahead of us are going to be perhaps more difficult than any since the Great Depression," he said during brief remarks to reporters after he was sworn in. "But this state has overcome fires and floods and Depression and wars, always bringing us to a higher ground."
For New York governors, the formal swearing-in ceremonies have often been in private on New Year's Eve, although the festivities surrounding the inauguration, including a public re-creation of the oath of office, have generally been held on New Year's Day.
In holding the simple ceremony today, Governor Cuomo in effect merged the two occasions. He has no public appearances scheduled for Tuesday, his aides said today.
 
Gestures of Moderation
 In other gestures of moderation, Mr. Cuomo shunned his limousine today despite the Albany chill, and walked several hundred yards, accompanied by a handful of close aides, from his office in the Capitol to the Court of Appeals building.
Dressed in a black suit with a dark striped tie and placing his hand on a family Bible held by his wife, Matilda, Mr. Cuomo repeated after Judge Wachtler that he would support the Federal and New York State Constitutions. And, he said, he would "faithfully discharge the obligations of my office of Governor of the State of New York, according to the best of my ability, so help me God."
Mr. Cuomo, who has pledged to lay off up to 10,000 state workers and who dismissed holding a ceremony as unbecoming "at a time of national economic crisis," said today that he did not regret having to do without festivities.
"I've never been too good at pomp and circumstance," he said.
 
'Exactly Appropriate'
 Mr. Lundine, who was a five-term Congressman from the Jamestown area before winning the lieutenant governorship in 1986, was sworn in by Justice Joseph W. Bellacosa with his wife, Sara, standing next to him. Mr. Lundine said the low-key swearing-in was "exactly appropriate to the circumstances."
Relatives and some aides to the officials returned with them afterward to the Executive Mansion for a private reception.
Still, no Cuomo inauguration would be complete without questions about whether the Governor would make a bid for the Presidency, or without the Governor skirting the queries. Sure enough, Mr. Cuomo parried when asked today whether he agreed with a range of political pundits who say he must make a decision this year on running for President to have a credible chance of winning.
"If I were going to make plans, or plan to make plans, I would have to start with that question," Mr. Cuomo told reporters.
Asked what the answer to the question might be, he protested, "I haven't made plans to make plans." Mr. Cuomo then broke into a grin and said he answered that way "just to show you that nothing will be different in 1991."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo being sworn in yesterday for a third term by New York State's Chief Judge, Sol Wachtler, in a six-minute ceremony at the Court of Appeals in Albany. With him was his wife, Matilda. (David Jennings for The New York Times) (pg. 32)

HEADLINE: PATTERNS

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

 BODY:

A Little Nervous Music
The year in fashion should be taken with vodka, tomato juice and a dash of Worcestershire sauce. The industry's 12-month hangover began with cataclysmic retail bankruptcies and ended with holiday sales figures that showed once and for all that there is no Santa Claus.
Even Tiffany & Company, supposedly immune to recession, revised its profit expectations for the fourth quarter, citing poor domestic sales, and its stock dipped sharply last week. The resort season has been virtually ignored by the stores and mostly unadvertised amid the retail nervousness.
New perfumes, once sure profit makers, have been bombing with alarming regularity. One called California (finally, a fragrance named for a state!), which made its debut at Bloomingdale's in 1990, is already being sold at Duane Reade.
Walking down Seventh Avenue the week before Christmas, one could pick up handbills advertising a dozen showroom sales between Times Square and Macy's. The inside joke called "Saturday selling" has now become a seven-day event.
One retail analyst, Kurt Barnard, says the recession will not be nearly as deep and prolonged as that of 1982. In his Retail Marketing Report for December he points out that, unlike the situation in 1982, inventories now are low, and he says that energy prices, which cut into discretionary spending, will ebb in the spring, releasing pent-up demand.
In the meantime, fashion executives are tightening their belts, eliminating bonuses and laying off workers. Of course their chauffeurs will be the last ones to go.
 
 Enter Bodywear
 It was the year of the woman on Seventh Avenue. Donna Karan was named the designer of the year by the Council of Fashion Designers of America. She and a test-tube product called Lycra injected the only real vitamins into the fashion business.
But designers must face the bodywear look with trepidation. Besides leggings and a jacket, what else does anyone need? The look is easy and modern -- qualities designers have talked about for years -- but all one needs to buy are pieces. Leggings or a tube skirt cost $50. Add a jacket and a great haircut. Who needs to spend $600 on a gingham blouse?
Women have seemed less passionate about clothes. Many were no longer fain to wear their diamonds in public; the rich were hiding their furs.
Men, on the other hand, took fashion to an opposite extreme. The slang "to die for" and "fashion victim" gained frightening resonance as young men killed for "eight ball" leather jackets, "pump" sneakers and shearling coats.
 
The Ins and the Outs
 Nostalgia continued to influence the runways. Some fashion historians say that the end of a century summarizes and refines all its styles. So, in the 1980's, people dressed like the 50's. Now there is a rebirth of the 60's: vinyl skirts, bouffant hairdos and lots of eyeliner. The 1970's are certainly on their way, even if nobody wants to see leisure suits again.
So the trends of the 90's are old trends. Gingham and Doris Day. Audrey Hepburn and the Kelly bag. Superfly and hot pants. In the new Vogue, there are even Diane Von Furstenberg and Courreges. Who said they could come back?
The cycles in fashion get shorter and shorter. How many times have the 60's been revived since the 60's? They're never out long enough to be completely out. Soon all the decades will overlap dangerously. Soon everything in will simultaneously be out.
It will be the dawn of the millennium. New stores will open, everything will be fabulous and sell like crazy, and no one over size 14 will ever wear spandex again.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JANUARY 1, 1991

 BODY:
Markets
The toughest year since 1981 for investors in stocks ended with a slight gain for the day. The Dow industrials rose 4.45 points, to 2,633.66. The Dow's decline for the year was 4.3 percent. [Page 41.]
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose solidly in light trading. The long Treasury bond ended 1990 yielding 8.24 percent, down from 8.29 percent on Friday but up from 7.97 percent a year ago. [50.]
The dollar is expected to be a sideshow this year compared with the German mark, against which it fell 13 percent last year. [51.]
Soybeans staged a moderate comeback on the Chicago Board of Trade from contract lows reached Friday. [51.]
 
 The Economy
Gasoline prices have remained relatively high as crude oil prices have fallen steadily, giving rise to renewed allegations by consumer groups of price gouging. Industry executives and analysts disagree on who is making the killing -- service stations, refiners, or someone in between. [41.] Crude oil rose 87 cents, to $28.44 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. [53.]
Ways of preventing a banking disaster are being proposed by consultants outside the banking industry. [42.]
The prices farmers receive for raw products fell seven-tenths of 1 percent from November to December. [42.]
In 23 years in Detroit, Focus: Hope has grown into a citywide conglomerate that operates food banks feeding 80,000 hungry people a month and that employs about 180 inner city workers. [1.]
 
 Technology
What technologies will be most important in the next decade? Science and technology reporters from The New York Times have consulted with experts and chosen 10 of them. Special Report. [35.]
 
 Companies
USG will attempt an out-of-court restructuring to avert bankruptcy in the face of a deep downturn in its core Sheetrock business. Two other leading makers of wallboard are in bankruptcy. [41.]
In a likely blow to Northrop, the Pentagon will probably decide not to begin construction in 1991 of any new B-2 Stealth bombers, Government officials and industry analysts said. [41.]
Ex-workers on the U.S. nuclear submarine program charge that there have been serious safety lapses at its West Milton, N.Y., site and that they were disciplined for raising safety concerns. The program is run for the Government by General Electric. [1.]
An agreement at Sabena Belgian World Airlines fell apart. The deal was to have given British Airways and KLM each a 20 percent stake in the Belgian carrier. [41.]
An investment firm sold its 10 percent stake in First Executive at 14 cents a share, below the current quote of 37.5 cents. [42.]
Two cellular telephone companies announced agreements for their sale: Graphic Scanning will be sold to BellSouth and Celutel will be bought by the Continental Illinois Venture. [44.]
Data General has dropped a product development agreement with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone of Japan. [44.]
 
 International
Toyota is expanding at such a breakneck pace that the chief of operations at its Takaoka plant in Japan cannot find enough auto workers. Many Japanese manufacturers are investing heavily, even in the face of a U.S. recession and slower growth at home. [1.]
Commerzbank has made its strategy work far better than banking experts thought it could when it decided last spring to create its own network of branch offices in eastern Germany. [41.]
 
 Today's Column
Confidentiality rules are eroding as an indirect result of the growing concern with the cost and quality of health care. Milt Freudenheim: Business and Health. [42.]

HEADLINE: Bank Failures Dip, for Now

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
The number of bank and savings institution failures declined in 1990 for the first time in seven years, but the floundering economy may prevent any sustained improvement.
In 1990, 169 commercial and savings banks failed, including one bank that remained open only with an infusion of Government cash, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporatin said today. 
 In addition, 211 savings and loans went insolvent, the Resolution Trust Corporation said. That included 207 seized by the Government and put into conservatorship and four kept open with taxpayer money.
The failure total in 1990 -- 380 -- represents a 29 percent drop from 535 in 1989, a post-Depression high. It marks the first decline from the preceding year since 1983, when 84 of both types of institutions failed, compared with 105 the previous year.
Analysts, however, are drawing no encouragement from the improvement. The sharp deterioration in real estate values has yet to make its full impact on the failure rate, they said.
Although 1990's failures were spread among 38 states and the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico, more than a third -- 140 -- were in Texas. Ten other states had 10 or more failures. They were California and Florida, 21 each; Illinois, 18; Louisiana, 17; New Jersey, 14; Oklahoma, 13; New York, 12; Massachusetts and Colorado, 11, and Mississippi, 10.

HEADLINE: Detroit Priest Preaches Hope Through Job Training

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
Oakman Boulevard meanders across Detroit's tumbledown northwest side like a dry riverbed, past boarded-up storefronts and empty lots. But east of Linwood Avenue, the bleak roadscape suddenly comes to life: lights burn inside a row of deserted factories, and the street is filled with cars and delivery trucks.
Here, amid classrooms and offices carved from the heart of an abandoned industrial neighborhood, the Rev. William Cunningham, a tough-talking Roman Catholic priest, has created one of the nation's most eclectic and ambitious urban enterprises. It is a vast, nonprofit civic organization that is part charity, part business and part job training program. 
 Founded 23 years ago after the bloody riots that swept the city, Father Cunningham's organization, called Focus: Hope, has grown from a grass-roots group preaching racial harmony into a citywide conglomerate. The organization now operates food banks that distribute groceries to 80,000 people a month, employs about 180 inner-city workers in its homegrown manufacturing enterprises, and provides math, computer and machinist's training each day to scores of willing but poorly educated Detroit residents.
In December, the organization began the first stage of its most ambitious undertaking yet:-- a Center for Advanced Technology that will use a $15 million grant from the Defense Department to run a national center exploring ways to improve the production and technical skills of inner-city workers.
The center represents Father Cunningham's secular theology of economic salvation through hard work and high technology. Inside a gutted Ford engine factory, he has enlisted a cadre of retired automotive engineers and professors from Michigan engineering colleges in the hope of turning his brightest young recruits into skilled industrial technicians, fluent in high math, the intricacies of computer-aided design and manufacturing and even the rudiments of Japanese and German.
Government and industry experts say that the Focus: Hope programs could be a national model for training young people to address a critical shortage of highly trained machinists.
"There is a critical shortage of people with these kinds of skills," said James Koontz, a machine tool manufacturer who is president of the National Center for Manufacturing Sciences, a private coalition based in Ann Arbor, Mich., that supports research and training in advanced industrial technology. "I know I shudder every time one of our machinists retires, because all we have to choose from are a lot of young kids who, quite frankly, are not very good at reading and writing, let alone technical knowledge."
 
Power Through Job Training
 To help meet operating costs, Focus: Hope is negotiating contracts with local manufacturers to supply customized industrial parts. Last month, a group of students and faculty members turned out the first of several hundred pulley systems to be supplied to Detroit Diesel, an engine manufacturer, under a $2 million annual contract.
Father Cunningham, 60 years old, says his program teaches far more than job skills. "This is more than a jobs program, more than just helping blacks keep up," he said. "The issue here is to provide the tools and discipline and very best of training and equipment to bring minorities and poor whites into real positions of control, at the very center of the technological revolution."
Over the years, occasional critics have attacked the organization -- run by a white priest and a mostly white staff, and serving a mostly black community -- as drawing funds away from civic organizations run by blacks.
And many of Father Cunningham's longtime allies in the civil rights and anti-war community were sharply critical of him a year ago, when he agreed to accept Pentagon money to seed his Center for Advanced Technology. The Most Rev. Thomas Gumbleton, Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of Detroit, said taking money from the Pentagon represented "a very subtle subversion of our moral values."
 
The Sin of Not Helping
 But in a city that has become a national metaphor for urban decay, Father Cunningham has a powerful truth on his side: His organization works. For example, relying on millions of dollars in machinery donated by the Federal Government and private industry, the Machinist's Training Institute has managed to find jobs for about 95 percent of the nearly 800 people it has graduated since 1981.
Father Cunningham dismisses critics who say he took "tainted money" when he agreed to work with the Defense Department. "It's tainted money, all right," Father Cunningham replies. "It 'taint enough."
The greater immorality, he argues, would be to deny training to people who are otherwise lost without it, in a city where the only real economic choice confronting many young teen-agers is working at a fast food restaurant or selling crack.
"Sadly, in this country, there has been a tendency to regard as unfit for work a large proportion of our society, at the same time the best jobs require more and more education and technical training," said Father Cunningham, who still conducts Mass each Sunday at the inner-city parish he has served since 1970. "If we do finally fall behind Germany or Japan because we just don't have the skilled work force to keep up, it may have less to do with our productivity than our racism."
 
A Confirmed Pragmatist
 Over the last decade, Father Cunningham and his followers have cajoled and, at times, bullied elected officials, government workers, industrial leaders, university presidents, downtown bankers, civic organizers and foundation treasurers to spend time and dollars helping him.
Neal Shine, the publisher of The Detroit Free Press and a longtime friend of Father Cunningham, says his decision to take money from the Pentagon is not surprising. "Bill will deal with whomever he has to deal with, to get done what he feels needs to be done," Mr. Shine said. "If the devil showed up one day with a grant, Cunningham would accept it, with no strings. He'd even introduce the devil at a press conference, although he'd probably tell him not to take his hat off."
Of the men and women who come to him, eager to find a better future, he asks only three things: show up every day, show up on time, and pay attention.
Irving Knott is one who did. He got his first job at General Motors in 1977, two years after high school, and worked there, on and off, for 10 years, installing door handles on Cadillacs until the plant was closed for good. When he was laid off for the last time, he had a wife and three children and was making $13 an hour.
 
After the Plant Closed
 "Before, you would wait around, because you knew sooner or later they would call you back to work," said Mr. Knott, who is now 33. "But this was different. The plant was closed. We weren't going back." The best jobs he could find paid $4, maybe $5 an hour.
Down at his union hall, he saw a notice about the training at Focus: Hope. Like most of the 180 students enrolled there now, he gets public support to pay his $5,900 tuition and can expect to earn $8 to $10 an hour, most likely at a small machine shop.
Along with the machinist's training institute, the program offers an academic program called Fast Track that uses computers and strict classroom discipline to help high school graduates who can neither read nor write at a high school level.
And for those least able to find work, Father Cunningham finds jobs in his own factories, four small companies run by a for-profit arm of Focus: Hope.
 
No Church Connection
 Although individual church officials have voiced strong support for Father Cunningham's activities, there is no connection, financial or otherwise, between his group and the Archdiocese of Detroit.
The organization's annual budget of about $50 million comes from foundation grants, state and Federal grants and money earned by the sale of industrial parts they make.
All together, the organization sprawls over three city blocks along Oakman Boulevard, its enterprises divided among 18 different buildings. The total payroll consists of nearly 480 workers. Except for about 20 retired engineers who volunteer their time in return for a small stipend, the rest receive full salaries and benefits.
Father Cunningham, a lifelong Detroit native, was a 36-year-old priest who rode a motorcycle and taught English literature at Sacred Heart Seminary in the summer of 1967 when rioting broke out on Detroit's west side. He recalls watching the black columns of smoke rising above the city and thinking there was no longer much point in reciting Chaucer for high school students.
 
Bridging Racial Gap
 So he organized some volunteers and clergymen into a biracial organization that they called Focus: Summer Hope. They organized rallies, gathered food an clothing for riot victims and portrayed themselves as a kind of bridge across the growing gulf separating blacks and whites in Detroit. Their logo shows a black hand and a white hand, reaching toward each other.
It was the collapse of the city's economy in the early 1980's that broadened Focus: Hope's agenda. Stung by foreign competition and the press of technological change, the city's great auto plants laid off workers and closed down lines. Auto suppliers and other manufacturing plants that for generations had provided opportunity for blue-collar laborers abandoned the city. Around them, whole neighborhoods disintegrated.
Meanwhile, the number of people coming through Focus: Hope's food centers soared. " The realization began to dawn on us all that feeding the hungry is more than just giving them a meal," said Eleanor Josaitis, who joined the organization as a volunteer in 1967 and is now Father Cunningham's top aide. "If we really believe in human dignity, it is providing them with something more -- the wherewithal to provide for themselves."
 
Focusing on the Basics
 In the new Detroit, the factory assembly lines needed a different kind of worker. Manual jobs existed, but they went to the oldest workers, the line veterans with the most seniority. To get into the plants as a young man or woman now, you needed to know something about math. You needed to be able to read manuals and interpret technical drawings.
Aware of this problem, the Cunningham organization began the Fast Track program last year, recruiting high school graduates who lacked the math or verbal abilities to enroll in the machinists' course.
Test scores show that Fast Track has been able to raise the math levels of its graduates by nearly two full grade levels and reading skills by about a year. But the washout rate can be high. In some classes, nearly a third of those entering have been dropped for persistent tardiness or absences. Father Cunningham says it is a necessary cost. "We tell them that it's just like the real world. You come in late on your job, you get fired," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Rev. William Cunningham, center, founder of a nonprofit group in Detroit that has grown into a conglomerate. With him at a machinist training program were Edward Horton, left, and Raymond Armstrong. (Peter Yates for The New York Times) (pg. 1); Eleanor Josaitis, right, of Focus: Hope in Detroit, with Michelle McGee, one of the more than 80,000 people who receive food aid through the group each month. The 23-year-old nonprofit civic organization is part charity, part business and part job training program. (Peter Yates for The New York Times) (pg. 8)

HEADLINE: As U.S. Car Makers Cut Back, Toyota Is Expanding Briskly

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOYOTA CITY, Japan

 BODY:
At a time when the American automobile industry is laying off thousands of workers, shuttering factories and bracing for a recession, Kunihiko Minami, the chief of operations at the Toyota Motor Corporation's sprawling Takaoka plant here, says he has his own problems: he cannot find enough auto workers.
Even as the General Motors Corpo ration plans to close up to nine plants in the United States that employ tens of thousands of workers, Toyota is expanding at a breakneck pace and looking desperately for people to hire. 
 Japan's largest car maker is an example, if an extreme one, of the pace at which many Japanese manufacturers are investing in new plants, new products and new technology, even in the face of a recession in the United States and slower growth at home.
Japan's biggest industrial companies decided years ago that an economic slowdown is the best time to build more efficient manufacturing plants. Usually, though sometimes after considerable bruising from price-cutting battles, they have emerged with larger market shares when economic fortunes have reversed.
"It has happened before, and I suspect we are seeing it again," said Masaru Yoshitomi, the director general of the research institute of Japan's Economic Planning Agency. "Pioneering companies try to make investments during a recession, usually to reduce their labor costs. And in most cases, it has worked."
Toyota said recently that it would build three factories, including one expected to produce 200,000 luxury cars a year. The factories will be in rural corners of Japan where the competition for workers is less intense.
Last month Toyota announced that it would also double production in Kentucky, its flagship overseas manufacturing site where it is already producing 200,000 cars a year. And all over this drab city, which in the 1980's became a symbol of Japan's competitive challenge to the United States, engineering centers, laboratories and training centers are under construction.
In 1989, Toyota was second to G.M. in production, building slightly less than four million vehicles. Through October, production was running 6.5 percent ahead of 1989.
Certainly Japan, too, is beginning to feel te effects of harder times -- battered financial markets, worry about land prices and a sudden credit crunch. But what seems most surprising is that the troubles are having relatively little effect on its best manufacturers, which are less vulnerable than many small companies here.
The strategy of increasing capacity and cutting prices to gain market share certainly worked in the mid-1980's, when Japan's biggest electronics giants built enormous plants to make the most common type of memory chips. Despite huge initial losses, they emerged with an 80 percent share of the market. The prospect that the strategy could work again, and deepen conflicts between Japan and the United States, is something Japanese Government officials are increasingly describing as one of their biggest fears in the new year.
"The tension you have seen up to now between the United States and Japan came when both economies were expanding," a senior official in Japan's Foreign Ministry said recently. The image of Japan gaining a larger share of key markets in the United States during a recession "is one of our nightmares," he added.
Toyota's expansion plans have hardly been welcomed by the Government. Fearing that the car company would use its new capacity to export cars -- and thus increase Japan's trade surplus -- the Ministry of International Trade and Industry earlier put pressure on Toyota to curb its plans. In a rare act of public defiance, the company refused.
And Toyota is showing no signs of backing away, even as economists and the Government have been warning industry that the home market, which has provided the fuel for huge capital investments over the last three years, will grow only 3.8 percent in the next fiscal year as measured in gross national product after adjusting for inflation. That figure would be greeted as boom times in the United States but would mark Japan's slowest growth in four years.
Moreover, the days of easy access to cheap capital for Japanese companies are clearly over. Interest rates here have surged this year, and Japan's banks, which once fell over one another to lend money for plant expansions and research and development, are turning away borrowers as their profits tumble.
While many predicted that such changes would finally derail Japan's rapid growth, it is becoming clear that the huge majority of capital spending by Japanese companies is financed internally from their retained profits. While most plans for investment in plants and equipment call for less than half of the 14 to 20 percent growth in recent years, a period of remarkable strength, they remain ambitious by any international comparison.
Japanese executives offer two other important reasons why they can expand more easily than foreign competitors. First, they say, there is less pressure from shareholders for high profits, because most of the stock of the companies is owned by other closely affiliated companies rather than by individuals and unrelated institutions looking for big dividends. In fact, profits are expected to decline about 15 percent this year.
The second is that Japan's largest companies can spread the expense of expanding capacity to their tight network of suppliers and affiliated companies, which cannot refuse their largest customer. For example, Toyota has pressed important affiliates like Nippondenso, its chief supplier of electrical components, to invest heavily in more efficient manufacturing technology that will enable them to cut their prices to Toyota.
"It's coercive, but it works," an executive of a leading Toyota supplier said somewhat ruefully.
 
$18 Billion in the Bank
 And the companies that spent the 1980's amassing huge hoards of cash -- not only Toyota, which has $18 billion in the bank, but also the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the biggest members of the Mitsubishi Group and many other giant companies -- can finance their own ambitious expansion plans on a scale that few of their American competitors could think about these days.
Publicly Toyota's leadership likes to describe its investments in new plants and equipment as almost an international obligation. "Should the auto industry suffer a downturn in Japan, it will create problems all over the world," Shoichiro Toyoda, the president of Toyota and a member of its founding family, said in a recent interview.
The Nissan Motor Company is also expanding but not at Toyota's pace. "That is why we call them 'Toyota Bank,' " said Yukihiko Eguchi, a Nissan spokesman. "It is a bit different for the rest of us." Nissan, in fact, is more bearish than Toyota, and more dependent on borrowed money. Even so, it is adding capacity at one of its biggest plants in Japan, doubling its production in Tennessee to 450,000 cars a year and finishing a factory in England.
 
Expansion in Electronics
 Many large Japanese electronics companies are also expanding. The companies are racing to increase production of the four-megabit DRAM, the latest generation of memory chip, capable of storing more than four million bits of information.
Despite growing evidence that the market might be flooded with the new chips, Hitachi Ltd. and the Toshiba Corporation are both planning to produce two million four-megabit chips a month by spring. Once again, their biggest fear is losing market share. And the race is already on to ship samples of the 16-megabit chip, lest any company get a reputation for being a technological laggard.
Not every industry is preparing for such expansion. Steelmakers, after years of unexpectedly strong growth, say that in 1991 steel production will decline slightly from this year's production of 110 million tons, which was the highest in 11 years. Shipbuilders are also looking for a slowdown.
 
Growth in Autos Expected
 For Toyota, domestic car sales have grown 10 percent this year -- a huge figure considering that Toyota accounts for nearly a third of Japan's car market. And while the American automobile market is expected to be stagnant next year, both Toyota and the Honda Motor Company, the most successful Japanese manufacturers in the United States, say they expect growth.
What that means, but what few executives here want to discuss, is a further erosion of market share for the American auto makers.
No matter what happens in the United States, Japanese auto makers say they have a new form of insurance: the huge investment they have made in Southeast Asia, an area where American auto makers have little presence. Countries like Thailand are among the fastest-growing car markets in the world, and they are overwhelmingly dominated by Japanese producers. Yoshiro Kimbara, one of Toyota's senior managing directors and a member of its board, said that investment would begin to pay off, compensating for declines in the American and European markets.
 
Biggest Challenge to Americans
 Much of the more than $4 billion that Toyota will spend in the fiscal year that ends next June will be directed at remaking its existing plants -- and that may pose the biggest competitive challenge to American competitors.
The Takaoka plant, for example, served as the model for the Toyota-G.M. joint venture in Fremont, Calif. But the plant today bears little resemblance to the one that was copied in the most famous experiment yet in joint American-Japanese manufacturing.
Toyota has continued to pour tens of millions of dollars into the plant, installing a huge row of robots that can weld the main parts of a car body with almost no human intervention and can automatically be adjusted to handle several different kinds of car bodies.
Toyota is slowly using the plant to introduce technologies it developed to build its newest luxury car, the year-old Lexus. For example, over the next few years, Toyota officials say, all their cars will use a special laser-welding technique that allows different thicknesses of steel to be combined in the car body.
 
Building Design Centers
 All this has hardly made Toyota, or other Japanese companies investing heavily here, invincible. More than a few of the company's newest car models have underwhelmed Japanese car buyers, and some of its designs still look clunky, conservative or both. The company is worried enough about that to invest heavily in building design centers, including one in downtown Tokyo aimed at making cars that appeal to urban Japanese. Design centers are also expanding in the United States and Europe.
But in the end, Toyota and other Japanese manufacturers seem confident that recession or not, they are wise to invest heavily now. "The results of what we are doing now won't appear for four years," Mr. Kimbara said. "And though it is not our ultimate goal to expand our market share, it is good for us if more people think Toyota cars are what they want. Remember, only a third of the world's population is using cars. We have a long way to go."

HEADLINE: Gorbachev Admits Errors but Predicts Gains;
Bush Tidings Circumspect

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
In a friendly but circumspect New Year's Day message to the Soviet Union, President Bush applauded Moscow's cooperation in the Persian Gulf and encouraged a country troubled by ethnictensions and economic hardship to continue its "arduous journey" toward reform.
Mr. Bush's videotaped message, prepared for broadcast in the Soviet Union on Tuesday, was in some ways the warmest of the greetings in the exchange between the leaders of the United States and the Soviet Union that began in 1986.
This year's greeting nevertheless struck a more cautious note than Mr. Bush's message of 1989. It dropped the references to his personal relationship with President Gorbachev that marked last year's remarks.
This year Mr. Bush mentioned Mr. Gorbachev, but only to wish him a happy New Year. Instead, he made more general comments about Soviet-American ties.
"This year, our two countries, as well as those around the world, have much to be grateful for -- first and foremost the improved and strengthened relations between the United States and the Soviet Union," Mr. Bush said.
On the Persian Gulf crisis, he said, "I applaud, the world applauds, the decisive action of the Soviet Union in strongly opposing Saddam Hussein's brutal aggression in the gulf."
Unlike Mr. Gorbachev, who videotaped a message to the American people for broadcast here, Mr. Bush made no reference to the summit meeting that is to take place in Moscow from Feb. 11 to 13. Administration officials said the omission was not intended to signal a possibility that the meeting would be called off.
Cable News Network planned to show both messages at about 1 P.M. on Tuesday, a spokeswoman said. Officials at the broadcast networks said portions of the tapes were likely to be used as news items on Tuesday's evening broadcasts.
The officials said the shift in emphasis between last year's message and the one Mr. Bush taped this year reflected new uncertainties about the Soviet leadership.
But they said Mr. Bush's comments were not intended to be specifically critical of Mr. Gorbachev, to whom American policy toward the Soviet Union is closely tied.
The officials said Mr. Bush's message had been taped before Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze resigned. While Administration officials have expressed concern about how the resignation might affect Soviet foreign policy, Moscow has emphasized continuity in its ties with Washington.

HEADLINE: Transforming the Decade: 10 Critical Technologies;
Mighty Chips Reinventing Silicon Circuits

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

 BODY:
Microelectronic circuits embedded on pieces of silicon are the building blocks of modern electrical devices, from computers and communication equipment to consumer electronics goods. They are also critical components of weaponry, automobile-engine control systems to improve fuel efficiency and factory automation systems.
The performance of these vital components will continue to improve over the next decade, rippling through the economy. The number of transistors that can be put on a chip will increase from about one million to close to 100 million. As that happens, more and more of the value of a computer will be contained in the chip. Complex chips, specialized for particular tasks, hold out the best hope of achieving long-sought goals like computers that can understand speech or interpret scenes. 
 The United States still leads in designs of clever circuitry but lags in the ability to manufacture chips. Sematech, the consortium financed by the Government and the semiconductor industry, is seeking to redress that balance. It is also trying to keep alive the endangered American manufacturers of chip-making equipment.
But Sematech alone, even if it is successful, will not be enough, experts say. A big problem for the United States is not technology but capital. Most American companies can no longer afford to build advanced manufacturing plants, which cost several hundred million dollars now and promise to keep getting more expensive.
 
Making Innovation Affordable
 Krishna C. Saraswat, a electrical engineering research professor at Stanford University, said one goal should be to use computer automation and other techniques to develop low-cost factories affordable by the small companies that often lead the industry in innovation. "If we can provide that opportunity, there will be many more companies willing to stay in business," he said.
Several particular technologies should get increasing emphasis in the 1990's. One will be increasing computer speed by connecting many chips together in modules. Another will be new technology for testing chips with millions of transistors.
Printing circuit patterns on silicon with beams of light is a technology that now appears likely to last through the decade. But new techniques, using X-rays or electron beams, might be needed after that. Efforts to explore all these techniques might be warranted until the course becomes clearer.

GRAPHIC: Photos: In 1961 this complex array of wires and vacuum tubes, a room-sized "mechanical brain," was built by the International Business Machines Corporation. (I.B.M.)
 
By the late 1970's electronic circuits had been drastically shrunk. For example, these four silicon chips, built in 1978 by I.B.M., could hold the equivalent of 15 pages of text. (I.B.M.)
 
By 1989 technology had advanced so far that a chip the size of a thumbnail, like the Intel 486 microprocessor below, could be installed in desktop computers, giving them the power of the million-dollar machines of the 1970's.(C & I Technologies)

HEADLINE: Transforming the Decade: 10 Critical Technologies;
Fiber Optics New Networks For the Nation

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
The "gigabit network" would make it possible to transmit computer data and video images among the nation's supercomputer centers, research laboratories and universities, as well as to businesses and homes. This network of fiber-optic cables, which would completely replace existing copper lines, is viewed by many scientists and executives as both a vital research tool and an essential part of the country's "information infrastructure" for the next century.
Despite vocal support from both Democratic and Republican legislators and from the Bush Administration, Federal financing to develop a high-speed nationwide computer network failed in Congress this fall. But this setback is probably temporary. 
 A gigabit network would permit researchers to share vast amounts of scientific and technical data. Doctors in their offices could view medical imaging animations produced by advanced diagnostic equipment in hospitals. A huge array of information, entertainment and business services would be created.
For example, a high-speed digital network could make the materials stored in the nation's best libraries instantly available to readers in thousands of community libraries around the country.
Or a home television viewer could choose to view whatever movie he or she wanted by selecting from a library of thousands of possible choices. In businesses, holding conferences by video, now expensive and inconvenient, would become commonplace, making it possible to minimize business travel.
 
A National Data Highway
 "It will unleash a tremendous amount of creativity and innovation which will lead to capabilities we can't even imagine today," said Robert E. Kahn, a scientist at the Corporation for National Research Initiatives, a Reston, Va., research organization that is coordinating consortiums of corporations, research laboratories and universities developing extremely fast computer networks.
For example, one of the high-speed network projects now being coordinated by scientists at the California Institute of Technology would use the network to link different types of supercomputers separated by thousands of miles into a single machine many times more powerful.
Replacing the nation's copper telephone wiring with a network of fiber-optic cables would also have a dramatic impact on the nation's economy, say advocates like Senator Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee. Just as the national highway system, constructed in the 1950's, brought about unexpected new economic activity all over the country, a national data highway could spawn dozens of research services and businesses. Both in Europe and Japan large efforts are under way to modernize older telecommunications networks to permit them to carry high-speed computer communications.
Researchers estimate that to install a similar network reaching into all of the homes and businesses that now have telephone service in the United States might ultimately cost $200 billion.

HEADLINE: Heavy Fighting Erupts in Somali Capital

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 31

 BODY:
Fighting between Government and opposition forces intensified today in the Somali capital, Mogadishu, amid reports that the President, Mohammed Siad Barre, had taken refuge at the international airport.
The position of the President, an ally of the United States, appeared increasingly vulnerable, officials in Washington said. But they said that they had no confirmation that the President was at the airport preparing to flee the country, and that they had no clear idea who had the upper hand in the fighting. 
 The President has a bunker near the airport and has often used it as part of his routine of rarely staying in one place for any length of time, the officials said.
In the last few days, the fighting had moved to the area of the Presidential residence, known as Villa Somalia, and to the downtown area of the city that fronts onto the Indian Ocean, an official in Washington said. Mortars, machine guns and hand-held rocket launchers were being fired.
 
A Tribal Conflict
 "The fighting is between the Presidential guard and security forces and the people in the city, presumably United Somali Congress supporters," a Washington official said. The United Somali Congress is a rebel group that controls territory in the center of the country, closest to the capital.
The congress is made up largely of members of the Hawiye tribe of central Somalia, while Mr. Siad Barre is the leader of the dominant Marehan tribe. A State Department official said the attempt to unseat Mr. Siad Barre was a tribal affair without international implications. "Superpower competition is a thing of the past in the Horn of Africa," he said.
The official said that assertions by rebels that they had taken the presidential palace could not be confirmed because it was too dangerous for American officials to travel around the city.
"A lot of people are putting out claims to say they are controlling this or that," said the official. "Nobody really controls anything. It's a free for all. There is a lot of thuggery and robbery."
 
Troops 'Running Amok'
 He said Somali army officers had lost control of their troops, who are now "running amok."
President Siad Barre presides over a country of six million people on the eastern edge of the Horn of Africa. He became an ally of the United States in 1978 when Moscow and Washington switched clients in the Horn, then a theater of the cold war.
Ethiopia, at one time an American ally, became a client of the Soviet Union and Somalia, once pro-Soviet, became a large recipient of American military and economic aid. Since 1980, after Soviet advisers were expelled from Somalia, the United States has had military access to Berbera, a northern port on the Gulf of Aden.
 
Relations With U.S. Cool
 In the last 18 months, however, Washington has become disenchanted with the Somali leader, who came to power in a military coup in 1969. In July 1989, army officers led a massacre of civilians on a beach outside the capital, which raised many criticisms by human rights groups in Europe and the United States.
Since then, military and economic aid from Washington has been reduced to virtually nothing. The American Embassy, a compound of buildings and swimming pools completed 18 months ago, is now staffed by about 30 employees, down from 200 last year.
[ A State Department spokesman in Washington, Adam Shub, said there are about 80 Americans, including 37 embassy staff members, in Somalia, The Associated Press reported.]
Unable to hold back three rebel movements operating in the north, center and south of the country, the President had virtually ceded power in most of Somalia and had become known as the Mayor of Mogadishu. Because the fighting is seeen as mainly clan-based, attempts by President Siad Barre to ameliorate it by introducing reforms like a multiparty system have been scoffed at by the rebels.
The Siad Barre Government is also being challenged by the Somali National Movement, a force dominated by the northern Isaaq tribe. Africa Watch, a human rights group, has estimated that 50,000 people have died in the fighting between the Government and the United Somali Congress, mostly in army bombing and artillery attacks and shootings by execution squads.
