HEADLINE: As Violent Year Ends, India Pleads for Peace

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Dec. 31

 BODY:
In the closing days of a year that will be remembered as the most violent in four decades of Indian history, artists and intellectuals are coming out into the streets and meeting halls of this capital city to plead for peace and an end to the politicization of religion.
At least 7,000 people have died in India this year in civil strife in the states of Punjab, Assam and Jammu and Kashmir, in the Muslim neighborhoods of Agra, Aligarh, Hyderabad and a dozen other cites, and on the streets of New Delhi and Chandigarh, wherestudents set fire to themselves to protest affirmative action programs that threatened the privileges of the few in a land where population is fast outstripping opportunity. 
 "The situation is infinitely worse than it has ever been before," said Prem Pandhi, director of the International Management Institute in New Delhi and a founder of Touch India, a group that held its first news conference here today. He and others criticized politicians for using disaffected religious groups, including the Hindu majority, as voting blocs.
"Politicans have not given us the most important thing: economic development," said Harish Mahajan, an educator and member of the new group. "So now it's a matter of all the hungry people of one community fighting the hungry people of another community."
On New Year's Day, more than a hundred musicians, dancers, actors and popular entertainers calling themselves Artists Against Communalism plan a 12-hour "performing sit-in" in New Delhi to promote understanding. Communalism is the Indian term for religious prejudice and violence perpetrated in the name of one faith or another.
A film maker, Chanda Prem, said today that she had been offered all the help she needs from Bombay movie stars in making cassettes and videotapes to distribute to villages carrying the message of tolerance. Ms. Prem recently produced a film about Ayodhya, where Hindus want to build a temple on the site of a mosque, in which she gave both Muslims and Hindus equal opportunity to state their cases.
In Calcutta over the weekend, scholars of the Indian History Congress called on the Government to neutralize the Ayodhya temple site by declaring the whole area a national monument.
Last week, a group of prominent Indians revived an organization called Citizens for Democracy and marched through central New Delhi to demonstrate their opposition to the increasing use of violence in politics.A leader of that march, Khushwant Singh, a Sikh historian and journalist, said in an interview with India's national news agency, the Press Trust of India, that "corruption, muscle power and money" were leading to intolerable strains on democracy.
The theme of lost values also ran through today's meeting of Touch, or The Organization for Universal Communal Harmony. The movement was founded in Chicago in October by a retired American librarian, Nazar Hayat Tiwana.
On Thursday, Touch India will assemble a panel of intellectuals from several Indian communities to discuss new ways to restore peace. "By 1997, the 50th anniversary of independence," we want to see a happier, more peaceful, less divided India," Mr. Tiwana said.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Presidency on the Brink Of a Make or Break Year

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
George Bush begins the new year with his Presidency poised between success and failure. The country begins it with bated breath.
Should the crisis in the Middle East turn into a blood bath, or become the kind of prolonged stalemate that Mr. Bush has promised to avoid, it could prove as damaging to him as Vietnam proved to Lyndon B. Johnson. If weeks or months of heavy American casualties would hurt, so would further disruption of oil supplies, which would force up gasoline prices and damage the already weak economy. 
 Like Lyndon Johnson, President Bush could find it devilishly hard to deliver either of the two things that matter most to the American electorate -- peace and prosperity. That's why the next few months, in the plain words of Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, look like "make or break time for George Bush."
The prospect of another crippled President, one would think, would cast a pall over Washington, to say nothing of the prospect of war. But no real anxiety grips the capital. In fact, the most notable things about the city as the final hours of 1990 slipped by were empty sidewalks, silent telephones and offices vacated hours before quitting time.
Most policy makers have found little reason to cancel vacation plans, even though Jan. 15, the date after which the United Nations has authorized the use of force against Saddam Hussein's forces in Iraq, will arrive in a matter of only two weeks.
"If there is a sense of crisis in this city," said a State Department official who has spent the holidays here, "I haven't been able to find it. The prevailing mood seems to be, 'Something will turn up to get us out of this.' No one can say what the something will be, but that doesn't stop them from thinking it will come."
Mr. Bush himself would appear to share the city's hunch that Saddam Hussein will decide to withdraw from Kuwait at the 11th hour and make a big American offensive unnecessary. In a year-end interview, he told Time magazine, "My gut says he will get out of there."
But the President also conceded, "I do not have that much of a feel." And there are powerful Washington figures who fear that Mr. Bush may be heading for trouble. Mr. Dole, Republican, tough-minded and usually a hawk, is one of them; he said over the weekend that "the American people are not yet committed to war" and urged that another effort be made to arrange a meeting between Mr. Hussein and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in Baghdad.
Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, a moderately hawkish Democrat who heads the House Armed Services Committee, also warned that the American public was uneasy. They "want to make sure," he said, "that we've tried every alternative before going to war."
The lack of electricity in the air, the President's comments and Mr. Dole's and Mr. Aspin's remarks all suggest that at least one more round of political and diplomatic activity is likely before any final decision to fight.
It is hard to believe, for example, that a meeting with Mr. Hussein will be passed up simply because of a disagreement on dates, especially with the home front as nervous as it seems to be. It is hard to believe, likewise, that Mr. Bush will opt for force without at least trying to win Congressional authorization for such a move in a resolution similar, perhaps, to the one the United Nations Security Council approved late last month.
According to his aides, Mr. Baker will travel to Europe and to the Middle East in the next 10 days to consult with leaders of countries allied with the United States in the gulf. He could easily head for Baghdad on short notice. And the European Community is planning some sort of peace effort of its own, which would involve assurances to Baghdad about "what would happen if Iraq leaves Kuwait," as one minister put it.
The White House insists that there will be "no negotiations." So the Iraqis and the Europeans talk instead about "establishing a dialogue."
Whether it will work is far from clear, because no one -- not the other Muslim leaders, not the intelligence-agency psychiatrists and certainly not George Bush -- is sure what Saddam Hussein's state of mind is. But with two weeks to go, the situation does not yet look hopelessly stalemated, and most of official Washington, at the dawn of a new year, does not yet look upon war as inevitable.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Europeans Expect Session on Friday to Lead to Talks With Iraqis

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 31

 BODY:
Foreign ministers of the European Community expect their special session in Luxembourg on Friday to lead to direct discussions with Iraq, European officials said today.
 The officials said that Jacques Poos, the Foreign Minister of Luxembourg, which takes over the rotating presidency of the community on Tuesday, would probably be asked to enter into immediate contact with Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz. 
Friday is the last possible day when something meaningful can happen," Mr. Poos said in apparent reference to the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait.
 But the officials said there was still no consensus among the 12 nations of the community countries over whether Mr. Poos will simply reiterate the demand for an end to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait or whether he will also promote some face-saving formula to ease a withdrawal.
 
Alarm Over War Threat
 Alarmed by the mounting threat of war, Germany and France called for Friday's special session after the United States and Iraq failed to agree on a date for their own direct talks. But Britain has cautioned against any independent move by the community that might weaken the anti-Iraq alliance.
 "The only initiative is to call a meeting on Friday," Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said today. "I think there's a chance, not a good chance, there's a chance for peace as long as the issues are clear: that Saddam Hussein knows that if he stays in Kuwait, he will be attacked and that if he withdraws completely and unconditionally, he will not be attacked."
 In a year-end television address, President Francois Mitterrand said France was ready to use force to apply United Nations resolutions demanding Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. "Iraq must realize this," he said. "With Kuwait under occupation, nothing is possible. With Kuwait evacuated, everything is possible."
 "But I still believe in the chances of peace," the French leader went on, "and France will work for peace right up to the last moment, as long as we stand by our principles. That's what we did with the hostages. Today they are free. It could also be the same for Kuwait."
 
Middle East Agenda
 In an interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation today, Mr. Poos said he would be ready to discuss all pending Middle Eastern problems, including the Arab-Israeli conflict, with Mr. Aziz. But he rejected attempts by the Baghdad authorities to link settlement of the gulf crisis to resolution of the Palestinian question.
 He added that, if the opportunity arose, he would tell Mr. Aziz that Iraq would have to carry out all United Nations resolutions on the Kuwait question "without any restraint" if the way is to be opened for discussion of other Mideast problems.
 A senior official in Luxembourg's Foreign Ministry said there would be "no linkage" between the issues by the community, but he noted, "The situation is such that, even if there is no linkage for us, there is linkage for lots of Arab countries, including allies of the United States."
 Mr. Mitterrand, who has long promoted the idea of an international peace conference on the Mideast, said an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait would create the conditions for broader discussions, "where no question would be avoided."
 
No Issues Excluded
 "Neither Israel's right to security nor Palestinians' right to a homeland," he said. "Neither the right of Lebanon to be whole again, nor the rights of everyone, of Iraq and Kuwait, to live in peace in a region that would have the wisdom, as we have had in Europe, to choose entente over constant confrontation."
 French officials emphasized today that, by calling for the meeting on Friday, the Europeans were not trying to undercut the United States. They noted that community foreign ministers agreed last month to meet again on Jan. 4 if no talks had been held between Washington and Baghdad by Jan. 3, the date proposed by President Bush.
 The officials recalled that the foreign ministers had also authorized a meeting with Mr. Aziz after he had met Mr. Bush. "The idea has been around for a while," a French official said, adding that France's Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, had raised the possibility of making a trip to Baghdad himself.
 Germany's Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who on Saturday formally proposed the community foreign ministers' meeting, also strongly favors a new diplomatic initiative, reportedly fearing that a gulf war would not only aggravate the economic troubles of Eastern Europe's new democracies but also complicate relations between Washington and Moscow.
 Political experts in Germany noted further that there is strong support for a European initiative on the gulf crisis inside Mr. Genscher's Free Democratic Party, which is currently negotiating formation of a new coalition government with Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic party.
 The senior Luxembourg official said the community much preferred that the United States and Iraq engage in direct discussion before Mr. Poos meets Mr. Aziz. "But there is now a greater sense of urgency because of the stalemate between the United States and Iraq," he said, adding that Washington was being kept closely informed of the community's moves.
 
Jordanian to Visit Europe
 AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 31 (REUTERS) -- King Hussein of Jordan will travel to Europe this week for talks on the Persian Gulf crisis while the European Community decides whether to seek peace talks with Iraq, Jordanian officials said today.
 They said the King would leave Wednesday on a tour to include Paris and London as well as other Western capitals. Details of his schedule were still being worked out, they said.
 Officials said Hussein, one of the few Arab leaders still on speaking terms with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq after Baghdad's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, is working with the Algerian President, Chadli Benjedid, to find an internationally backed peaceful solution to the crisis.
 Mr. Benjedid toured the region earlier this month for talks with Iraq, Iran, Syria, Egypt, Omanand Jordan but failed to arrange meetings with Saudi leaders on the crisis.

HEADLINE: Needed: Middle East Peace Talks

BYLINE: By Jimmy Carter; Jimmy Carter, the former President, is founder and chairman of the Carter Center.

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
"Linked" or not, there is no way to separate the crisis in the Gulf from the Israeli-Palestinian question. Following a settlement with Iraq, either through peace or war, even greater pressure will emerge within the international community to convene a peace conference. United Nations rsolutions on the Middle East, from four decades ago to the present, have been given a new vitality and will not go away again.
Now is a propitious time for Israel to come forward with a genuine peace initiative, and President Bush and congressional leaders should do everything possible to encourage such a move. Present difficulties are formidable, but real progress is possible. 
 Before Iraq invaded Kuwait, Prime Minister Shamir of Israel rejected talks with a Palestinian delegation, the Israeli Government fell and intifada violence escalated. Since then, alignment of Syrian and other Arab forces with the U.S. against Iraq, economic calamity for Jordanians and Palestinians, the Temple Mount tragedy and massive immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel are all increasing friction in the occupied territories.
Historically in the Middle East, stalemates or localized tensions have tended to deteriorate into broader conflict. Having long been involved in the peace process, I realize how important it is that setbacks not deter exploration for new ideas and opportunities. I was distressed when Menachem Begin became Prime Minister in 1977, based upon his previous statements and his first speeches as Israel's leader. However, it was his willingness to negotiate with President Anwar Sadat at Camp David that made the Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty possible.
In my meetings last year with Likud leaders in Israel, they re-emphasized their opposition to an international conference, claiming that the United Nations and the Soviet Union would always support Arab positions. This concern about Soviet attitudes has been mitigated by the remarkable emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel and resulting diplomatic exchanges between the two nations.
Although the subtle differences are significant, Arab and Israeli leaders actually have a lot in common. While calling for mutual security, peace and economic interests in the region to be addressed, Israelis have insisted on bilateral negotiations with Arab neighbors instead of with a phalanx of adversaries. Among Palestinian leaders and those in Lebanon, Syria, Jordan and Egypt, I have found uniform support for a peace conference, and willingness under its auspices for direct talks with Israel. President Hafez al Assad of Syria confirmed that, under such conditions, he is willing to negotiate directly with Israel to resolve the Golan Heights dispute.
Both Israeli and Arab leaders have now called for a regional conference to reduce arsenals of mass destruction. Another surprise development in the area has been encouraging. In Lebanon, militia groups have withdrawn from Beirut and are finally negotiating with each other. A viable central government is evolving with more representative participation.
A carefully crafted peace conference under the bi-lateral sponsorship of the United States and the Soviet Union -- if not the United Nations -- could overcome Israelis' objections about inherent bias against them. President Gorbachev has assured me that this would be acceptable, and that the Soviets would not try to impose solutions or veto agreements reached by the Middle East negotiators in their direct talks.
The principles of the Camp David Accords can provide a framework on which the opposing forces might focus their efforts. Laboriously negotiated and adopted by an overwhelming vote in the Israeli Knesset, its basic premises have subsequently been approved, with only slight variations, in various Arab statements and in President Reagan's speech of September 1982. This was quickly accepted by King Hussein of Jordan. P.L.O. Chairman Yasir Arafat and others, who originally rejected these agreements, now claim willingness to accept them as a general basis for peace initiatives.
There has to be good faith on both sides. Tragically, the P.L.O. charter remains intact in its call for the destruction of Israel. Likud leaders, while professing support for Camp David, reject some of its crucial tenets and those of U.N. Resolution 242, apparently not yet willing to negotiate with representative Palestinians or to relinquish control over any areas taken in the 1967 war.
Differences over specific Camp David tenets are already well defined. This is what peace talks are all about: to resolve such disputes and to modify adamant positions of adversaries. There is no doubt that the people of the region want peace. This brings us to the fundamental question: Will the Middle East leaders respond to the will of their people? An international conference may be the only chance.

HEADLINE: Somali Forces Clash With Rebels for 3d Day as Both Report Gains

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 1

 BODY:
Fierce fighting between rebel forces and the Government continued for a third day in the Somali capital today but there were conflicting reports about how much of the city and what strategic elements the two sides controlled.
The rebels, a clan-based group, said in a statement from Rome that their forces in Mogadishu controlled the palace of President Mohammed Siad Barre and had surrounded the leader at his airport bunker. 
 But the Somali Foreign Minister, Ahmed Mohammed Aden Qaybeh, said in an interview during a visit to Qatar that the Government continued to control most of the city. He said the President remained in his residence and that the rebels had been repulsed.
The state-run radio made regular broadcasts today, despite a claim by the rebels that they had taken both the television and radio stations.
 
Hundreds Killed, Diplomat Says
 An Italian diplomat in Mogadishu, quoted by the Italian Foreign Ministry in Rome, said hundreds had died in the fighting, which involved mortar and hand-held rocket launchers. The diplomat said Mr. Siad Barre was directing his defense from the fortified bunker at the airport.
A human rights group, Africa Watch, reported that the Government's armed forces were singling out civilians of the Hawiye clan, whose members form the backbone of the rebels' United Somali Congress, dragging them from their homes and shooting them. The executive director of Africa Watch, Rakiya Omaar, said that in one such incident over the weekend, 61 civilians were shot.
She said callers to her office in London from Mogadishu on Monday had described the city as being in a state of anarchy and terror. Hospitals were overflowing with wounded and some of the casualties were being treated at hotels, she said.
A State Department spokesman, Adam Shub, said that American citizens in the capital were summoned to the fortified United States Embassy compound. He said 37 embassy employees were at the compound. Evacuation of all non-essential United States Government employees and their dependents was ordered on Dec. 12 after an escalation of random violence. The United Nations has also evacuated its employees.
 
Five Rebel Groups Involved
 The fighting is the latest development in the attentuation of power of President Siad Barre, who took control of the African continent's easternmost country 21 years ago. Once supported by the Soviet Union, he became an American ally in 1978 and has since received military and economic aid. Rebel insurgencies against him escalated two and a half years ago. Five rebel groups are said to be arrayed against him, all of them based on clan loyalties.
The United Somali Congress, which controls most of the center of the country, is composed of Hawiyes. The Somali National Congress, made up of Isaak clansmen, control the north of the country. President Siad Barre is from the Marehan clan and the vast majority of his Government has been selected from his clansmen, an exclusion that has motivated much of the rebel activity.
The Siad Barre Government has allowed the country, once relatively well off, to fall into economic ruin. People who have fled Mogadishu in recent weeks describe it as an armed camp, with weapons readily available for purchase at outdoor markets.
Several United States officials have said in the past several days they were surprised that it had taken so long for the warfare in the capital to break out. "The question is not why all this is happening, but why it hasn't happened sooner," said one official, a specialist in the Horn of Africa.
 
Critical Report From Attache
 The military attache at the United States Embassy from 1987 to mid-1989, Col. Alfred F. Girardi, wrote in a September 1989 letter later circulated to Washington congressional offices that the Siad Barre Government was "corrupt, incapable and uninterested in resolving the problems of the nation." He described the American-supplied Somali armed forces as having "performed poorly" and being "poorly led by inept officers."
After a massacre by Government troops in mid-1989, Washington cut virtually all aid to the country.
The Egyptian Government said today that it was trying to convene peace talks in Cairo that had been scheduled for early last month but were postponed because one of the rebel groups had declined to participate.

HEADLINE: TROUBLED TIMES ON WALL STREET;
In Foreign Exchange, Stay Tuned to the Mark

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The foreign exchange story to watch in 1991 is the strength of the German mark and how its European colleagues cope with it.
The dollar, which fell 13 percent against the mark last year, will be a sideshow to this drama, following the lead of the German currency. The dollar is expected to slide further early this year as interest rates in the United States fall and the economy slumps further into recession. 
 But the dollar outlook for 1991 as a whole is unclear. Some analysts expect it to rally later in the year, but others forecast that the value of the dollar will be no higher and perhaps even lower at the end of this year than it was on the last day of 1990, when it closed at 1.4920 against the mark. Still, the dollar could get a boost from developments in Europe.
The German mark and the Bundesbank dominate the European Monetary System, which ties together the value of the region's 10 major currencies in fixed trading ranges. In the last half of the 1980's, when European economies in the system were growing, following Germany's lead was less painful politically and economically.
 
A Collision Course
 But now economic paths are diverging. The German economy is growing as others are slowing, or in Britain's case, falling into a recession. And now the German central bank's insistence on high interest rates at home to blunt the inflationary impact of paying for the unification of Germany is already on a collision course with the need to lower interest rates in France and Italy to avoid a recession, and in Britain to end one.
There are two possible outcomes. One is that leaders in the slower-growing countries decide to stomach the higher interest rates to prevent their currencies from dropping below the monetary system's trading range. But the higher interest rates would slow their economies further.
John Lipsky, director of international bond research at Salomon Brothers in London, said he thinks this is the likely outcome because leaders will not want to endanger the progress toward a single European central bank and a single currency later in the 1990's.
"There is so much political capital tied up in political and monetary union it is hard to imagine any of the authorities giving up on their goals," he said.
In the second possible outcome, Europe's leaders decide that the economic cost of maintaining high rates and the discipline of the monetary system is too high. To get lower interest rates at home, France and the other countries would accept a realignment of the monetary system under which their currencies would be devalued in relation to the mark.
 
Little Help for the Dollar
 This alternative would open the way for lowering interest rates, without threatening to breach the trading ranges of the monetary system.
"It's going to be quite difficult for the French and the others to accept the need for a revaluation against the mark," said George Magnus, chief international economist at S. G. Warburg Securities in London. "But despite the sour taste it leaves in the mouth, I think everyone will have to accept a revaluation of the mark."
This outcome would give the dollar a little help. While its relationship with the mark would not change much, the lowering of interest rates in other countries would help the dollar climb some against the French franc, the Italian lira, the British pound and other European currencies.
But Mr. Lipsky said that this alternative would also undermine the progress toward a single currency. "By admitting the possibility of the shift in currencies as a policy option it may indeed lower the sense of commitment to irrevocably locked exchange rates," he said.
In addition, he argued, the revaluation would slow the movement toward the lowering of inflation in countries like Britain and Italy to the levels in Germany. This so-called convergence is needed as part of the economic harmony that makes the functioning of an economically unified Europe much easier.
 
U.S. Deficit a Factor
 As for the dollar, most analysts think it will be headed even lower as the new year begins because American interest rates are lower than those in Germany and Japan, whose economies are growing and have lower inflation. Thus, investors find holding dollars to be less attractive than at any time since the end of the 1970's. The continuing deficit problems in Washington add to the risk of holding the dollar.
Interest rates in the United States, now in a recession, are expected to decline further. But interest rates in Germany are expected to remain high or even move up another notch. Japanese interest rates will remain high for some time, although they could begin to decline in the spring.
Against the mark, the dollar could fall from the current level of about 1.49 to below 1.40 in the first part of the year, setting record lows as it goes. The dollar will also be weak against the yen, but may not now fall to its post-World War II low of 120 because of the new expectation that interest rates in Japan will fall soon. The dollar ended 1990 against the yen at 135.40.
Some analysts expect interest rates to have peaked in Germany and Japan by the end of 1991, and to have stopped declining here. With a relatively short recession, S. G. Warburg and Goldman, Sachs & Company are forecasting a dollar rally to 1.60 to 1.70 marks, a gain of 7 percent to 14 percent.
But Michael R. Rosenberg, manager of international fixed-income research at Merrill Lynch, is much more pessimistic because he is not expecting a significant decline in German interest rates soon. So he forecasts the dollar at 1.45 against the mark at the end of next year, a 2.7 percent decline.

HEADLINE: Newsstands On 5th Ave.? Battle Opens

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Nine feet tall. Twelve feet wide. Six feet deep. Could it mean the end of Fifth Avenue as we know it?
Ralph Destino, the chairman of Cartier, believes that, yes, a newsstand in front of his elegantly appointed store at 52d Street would go a long wy toward undermining Fifth Avenue's international reputation as a deluxe thoroughfare. 
 But Mohammed Ibrahim Mohmand of Queens, who wants to build the stand, believes it would be a service to passers-by, who might be as much in need of a daily newspaper as a diamond necklace.
 
Half Dozen Applications Pending
 His is one of a half dozen applications before New York City authorities for newsstands along Fifth Avenue, from 34th to 59th Street, where now there are none. If there ever was an implicit city policy against newsstands in this area, it was lifted two years ago. Today, applicants hope to build stands in front of Tiffany & Company, the Empire State Building and the General Motors Building, among other places.
These plans are being fought by established business interests, represented by the Fifth Avenue Association, which is still smarting from a state court decision last year that protected disabled veterans from a city ban against sidewalk peddling.
"If we lose these battles back to back,"said Thomas Cusick, president of the association, "Fifth Avenue is going to suffer to such an extent that the city is going to experience a very negative economic impact."
Mr. Destino sees the avenue's very essence, as well as its economy, threatened.
"Fifth Avenue, for a hundred years, has been one of the premier shopping streets of the world," he said. "The phrase 'Fifth Avenue' is synonymous with quality, with style, with luxury. That's a real asset.
"You tamper with that asset when you begin to stain Fifth Avenue with vast amounts of hawking on the sidewalk, whether you're hawking food or neckties or counterfeit watches or even The New York Times."To other eyes, however, Fifth Avenue has no claim to an exemption.
"The only reason to deny newsstands there is a sense of snobbery -- a misplaced sense of snobbery -- on the part of Fifth Avenue stores," said Robert S. Bookman, counsel to the New York City Newsstand Operators Association.
"Newsstands are an attraction," he said. "They provide change for buses. They give directions. They often sell tourist-type maps. At night they're a beacon of safety. They pose no economic competition. I can't imagine a more appropriate place."
"Finally," Mr. Bookman said, "the First Amendment -- which is what news stands are primarily about -- is just as important on Fifth Avenue as it is on Broadway."
Mr. Destino bridles at such a notion. "To frame it as a First Amendment issue is to make a mockery of the First Amendment," he said. "The First Amendment protects our rights to write, to publish, to be heard. I don't know of any constitutional right that insures our freedom to buy a Coca-Cola and a lottery ticket on Fifth Avenue."
At the center of the debate is Mr. Mohmand, who arrived in this country from Afghanistan eight years ago and lives with 10 of his children in Flushing, Queens. (His oldest son, Fereed, was killed two years ago battling Russian troops.) Until his retirement, Mr. Mohmand had been a policeman in Kabul.
 
Pitched-Roof Stand Proposed
 He proposes to erect a pitch-roofed stand 15 feet in front of Cartier. There would be an eight-foot-high magazine rack and an array of shelves for newspapers and candy. The air-conditioned shed, clad in galvanized aluminum, would have a soda machine and a side window for the sale of lottery tickets.
Why Fifth Avenue and 52d Street? "Because I want to serve the people," Mr. Mohmand said. "Because there's no newsstand there, no store or supermarket."
There is another reason. "I am retired but still I want to help my children," he said. "If I have such a job that I can help my sons, they can study, they can be educated and have a job. Every parent wants the children to be educated."
And he cannot imagine the stand creating a problem. "It's not in front of the door of any store or any office," he said. "The walkway is so wide that it's possible to put a newsstand there."
A translator who asked that he not be further identified said on Mr. Mohmand's behalf: "He's running his business, and Cartier is running its business. Cartier doesn't sell newspapers, magazines and candies. I'm not sure why people are against it."
 
Landmarks Issue Raised
 But Mr. Destino made his reasons plain in a letter to city officials, in which he noted that City Planning Department guidelines specify that "a newsstand should not obstruct the view of landmarks."
Moreover, he said, such a shed "would constitute a public safety hazard for the vast number of pedestrians walking Fifth Avenue in the 50's every day of the year."
Mr. Mohmand's application has been cleared by the city's Transportation Department, which analyzes proposals for their impact on pedestrian and vehicular traffic. The matter is now before the Landmarks Preservation Commission because the Cartier Building, a renovated town house dating from 1905, is a designated landmark. Eventually the application will arrive at the Art Commission, which will pass on the stand's esthetic merits.
If the other city agencies agree, approval for the newsstand would be granted by the Consumer Affairs Department.
 
Several Applications Pending
 More applications are in the works. According to Consumer Affairs records, the Transportation Department has approved a newsstand in front of the Empire State Building, at 34th Street. That proposal is before the landmarks commission.
Still pending before transportation officials are requests to build in front of Tiffany's, at 57th Street, and the General Motors Building, at 59th Street, as well as on the southeast corners of 44th and 53d Streets.
Exactly why there are no newsstands on the midtown stretch of Fifth Avenue is open to different interpretations.
Mr. Cusick said it was "largely a function of prior administrations setting a policy not to see any on Fifth Avenue."
Mr. Bookman said the practice of routinely rejecting applications for Fifth Avenue stands began "many, many years back" and ended two years ago, when the policy was brought to the attention of Angelo J. Aponte, then the Commissioner of Consumer Affairs.
The Consumer Affairs Department maintains that any earlier rejections occurred because applicants were unable to meet the city's criteria. "Today, and for many years, it's definitely been the law and the practice of the agency to accept any applications," said a spokeswoman, Patricia Cohen.

HEADLINE: TROUBLED TIMES ON WALL STREET;
Some Sectors Advance Despite a Deep Slump

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Companies whose stocks were unaffected by the Middle East and by the recession ended 1990 as the big winners on the American Stock Exchange. Health-care and drug companies, for instance claimed 4 of the top 10 spots.
"Health-care was a good place to be last year," said Ken Abramowitz, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, who ascribed the group's performance to the aging of the population and to consumers' insensitivity to the cost of their care. 
 Those success stories aside, companies on the American exchange generally had a poor year, as investors fled to markets with a higher concentration of blue-chip stocks.
"It was headed for one of the best years, and when Saddam Hussein came in, investors got nervous," said James R. Jones, chairman of the exchange. But the exchange's poor performance started long before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The Amex's market-value index hit its high for the year, 382.45, on Jan. 5, months before the other big markets peaked.
The market-value index finished the year at 308.11, down 18.49 percent, well beyond the Dow Jones industrial average's 4.4 percent decline, the Standard & Poor's 500's 6.6 percent decline, the 7.5 percent decline on the New York Stock Exchange composite index, and even more than the 17.8 percent decline recorded by the Nasdaq composite index, all of which peaked for the year on July 16.
Hardest hit were companies with exorbitant debt loads or companies involved in the crumbling real estate market. NVR, for instance, is a homebuilder that compounded its problems by having borrowed heavily in 1987 to acquire Ryan Homes.
Standouts in a disappointing year were OEA and Tech/Ops Sevcon. OEA makes the electrical devices used in 70 percent of all American-made airbags and stands to benefit from laws that will require airbags in all new cars by 1992. Tech/Ops Sevcon makes speed controls for battery-powered vehicles like forklifts. Their stocks gained 162.7 percent and 72.4 percent, respectively.
"Seventy percent of our business is overseas," said Paul B. Rosenberg, treasurer of Tech/Ops Sevcon. "So the slowdown in America affects us proportionately less."
Sure enough, a humble, recession-proof story, backed by solid earnings, seemed to be the way to investors' hearts. Viatech, a packaging company that placed 16th in the rankings, is one example. The company said it believes it is prospering from consumers' willingness to prepare more meals at home in hard times, a shift that bodes well for packaged food.
In a change from previous years when splashy takeovers caused the biggest run-ups in publicly traded stocks, only one company, GW Utilities showed up on the winner's list because of an outstanding tender offer. The company's majority owner, Olympia & York Developments, wants to take the Toronto-based conglomerate private, and has agreed to pay $40 (Canadian), or $34.50 (American), a share for the 11 percent it does not already own. The offer helps explain why the stock spiked to $31.50, from $20.625 last year.
In a reversal of fortune, Stevens Graphics, a maker of printing presses that was a favorite last year because it had landed some contracts in the Soviet Union, this year found itself 18th from the bottom. One reason: The company reported that it was having trouble collecting $29 million owed by a Soviet customer.

HEADLINE: TROUBLED TIMES ON WALL STREET;
Experts Were Wrong: Small Stocks Lagged

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
It was supposed to be the year of the small stock, with spectacular predictions by analysts and market watchers that 1990 would provide a bull market in stocks with small market capitalizations.
But the experts were wrong. Rather than taking off, small stocks once again lagged the performance of the large-capitalization issues. Since the small-capitalization boom of 1982-1983, when the United States was coming out of a recession, small issues have generally underperformed the overall market. 
 "They systematically lagged in 1990," said Scott Black, president of Delphi Management, a Boston money management firm, which invests about $700 million. "But if you look at them over the last 10 years, as a homogeneous risk-asset class small caps have always lagged."
 
Off 17.8 Percent
 For 1990, the Nasdaq composite was down 17.8 percent, compared with a 4.3 percent fall in the Dow Jones industrial average or the 6.56 percent drop in the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks.
Certain segments of the small stocks fared even worse: The Nasdaq bank stocks were down 34.81 percent in 1990. The few bright spots were in the technology stocks and the energy issues, which benefited from the surge in oil prices that began in the summer.
Since the October 1987 market crash, the broad market indexes have more than recouped their losses, but small stocks have lacked the momentum to rebound. The Nasdaq composite has lost 8 percent of its value since the 1987 collapse, while the S.& P. 500 has gained 16.81 percent. The Dow has advanced by 17.22 percent.
There are many reasons why small stocks disappointed investors for yet another year and probably as many opinions on whether the outcome will be different this year. But one undisputed reason was the run-up in oil prices caused by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
"Stocks were performing well in the first half of the year, and after Saddam Hussein invaded, the market shifted to energy and utilities and those two sectors were driving the S.& P.," said Claudia Mott, senior quantative analyst specializing in small-capitalization stocks at Prudential-Bache Securities. "Energy and utilities are underweighted on the Nasdaq.
And when the economy is going into a recession, she said, small stocks tend to do very poorly in the first half of the recession and better when the economy is rebounding.
"Smaller-cap companies are mostly domestic, and they have not benefited from the plunge in the dollar which has inflated foreign source earnings of those companies with foreign operations," said Joel Tillinghast, who runs the Fidelity Low-Priced Stock Fund.
 
Commputer Stocks on Top
 Technology issues, particularly computer stocks, were the best performers in the over-the-counter market. Atop the list of winners was AST Research, an Irvine, Calif, manufacturer of high-performance desktop computers and a wide range of products for business and professional computer use. AST ended the year at $37.25, a 258.9 percent increase.
In May, the company announced that it had signed an agreement with I.B.M., giving each company a nonexclusive license from the other for patents relating to computers, peripherals, advanced computer technologies and other related products. AST has branch offices through Europe and Asia and sells directly to retailers in more than 89 countries. The company's international sales have grown steadily in recent years.
Among the other big computer winners were Dell Computer, which ended the year at $18.50 a share, a 236.4 percent increase. Dell designs and manufactures high-performance personal computers compatible with I.B.M. standards.
With the performance of Borland International, which designs software, the computer companies took the top three spots among Nasdaq gainers.
Among the big losers were banks and savings and loan associations that were victims of troubled real estate loans and speculative investments made in high-yield securities.
Topping the losers was Abraham Lincoln Federal Savings Bank, which is reporting losses as it takes special charges and increases its loan-loss reserves. The bank's stock ended the year at 13 cents, down 99 percent from the $12.75 at the start of 1990.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1440 words

HEADLINE: TROUBLED TIMES ON WALL STREET;
Future Buzzwords Rise From Ashes of the 80's

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
Forget "L.B.O.'s" and "M.&A.," those code words of the 80's takeover boom. These days, center stage belongs to those who talk of "inflection points," of "enhanced indexing," of "prepackaged bankruptcies" -- the investment buzzwords likely to dominate the intellectual landscape of Wall Street in the year ahead.
Demography, with its attention to turns, or inflection points, in population trends, is gaining wider attention in investment circles. The new census results should give investing based on demographics further impetus. 
 The asset-management business is bracing for an escalation of the duel between "active managers," who build their portfolios stock by stock, and "passive managers," called indexers, who simply try to match the overall market's performance. With active managers hoping that this bear market will help them regain lost ground, the indexers are fighting back with enhancement techniques.
On the trading front, Wall Street is moving from the "Age of Excess" to the "Age of Distress." Once a risky little niche, the distressed securities market is booming, and a new cottage industry of newsletters, lawyers, computer data bases and other special services is springing up to serve the institutional investors getting into the business.
Here are the people and the thinking behind these three trends:
 
Some Rethinking Of Population Trends
 Richard F. Hokenson is the economic demographer for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a title that is still a rarity on Wall Street. Since the 1987 crash, Mr. Hokenson said, Wall Street's interest in his craft has boomed.
"I've seen a tremendous increase in the level of sophistication among our client base from three or four years ago," he said. "That may be because there are more people on the Street thinking about these issues."
Those people include Edward Yardeni, the Prudential-Bache economist, and a handful of analysts and researchers at giants like Merrill Lynch, Citibank and Goldman, Sachs. In addition, various demographic consultants -- from the trendy to the academic -- are finding a larger audience in the investment community, said John L. Steffens, executive vice president for the private client unit at Merrill.
Mr. Hokenson says the 1990 census results will intensify Wall Street's preoccupation with demography by debunking many widely held assumptions about the economic behavior of the baby-boom generation, the outsized cohort of people born in the years after World War II.
"The prevailing forecast was that the baby-boom generation was characterized by 'delay,' that given sufficient passage of time they will behave 'normally,' " he said. But the new census data, he predicted, will show that for many baby-boomers, "later" really means "never" when it comes to economically important events like marrying, having children and buying homes. Those are decisions that can sharply change the investment outlook for a host of industries ranging from baby-food manufacturers to homebuilders. Moreover, a much smaller generation of workers will be coming of age in the 1990's, intensifying the pressure on business to substitute capital for scarce labor, and giving an edge to those that do so quickly and successfully.
All in all, Mr. Hokenson said, "it is an utterly different world" -- one that Wall Street, increasingly, will rely on demography to decipher.
 
A Paradoxical Feud That Can't Be Won
 Indexing, the technique of maintaining a portfolio that matches the behavior of broad market barometers like the Standard & Poor's 500, is not new. About $200 billion, or roughly 7 percent of a domestic capital market estimated at $3 trillion, is being indexed already, said Tom Allen, president of Advanced Investment Management in Pittsburgh. Since indexing is less expensive and more predictable than more active forms of pension-fund management, Mr. Allen said, "I think that could go to 20 to 25 percent in the years ahead."
Byron R. Wien, a portfolio strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company, disagrees. The poor investment performance expected in this bear market "is key to the changes that are coming for Wall Street," Mr. Wien said. "And one of the shibboleths that will be shaken here will be indexing. Most people think we are going to return to the era of stock pickers -- and I do, too."
Not surprisingly, Mr. Allen is an indexer and Mr. Wien a stock picker. They might just as well be Hatfields and McCoys -- except that in this paradoxical feud, which is intensifying as this bear market deepens, the indexers cannot survive if they totally vanquish the stock pickers.
"If you think about it, only half of us can be passive, and the rest have to be seeking a way to do better," Mr. Allen said. "I mean, when I'm ready to buy a stock, if there isn't somebody out there with the opposite opinion, you don't have a market."
The herd behavior of index funds is already affecting the liquidity and breadth of the equity markets, funneling money toward major stocks in the indexed roster of shares and away from non-index stocks. And that trend will make it easier for stock pickers to find outstanding values in the market shallows where indexers do not fish, said Mr. Wien of Morgan Stanley.
Recent mutations in asset management suggest that the indexers themselves realize that matching the market may have less appeal when the market is ambling slowly sideways. These days, they are offering clients the option of enhanced indexing, a strategy aimed at beating a market index by one- or two-tenths of a percentage point.
How do they do that? Through trendy new techniques like "alpha captures," Mr. Allen explained. "You watch for situations where one stock diverges from its historical relationship with other stocks, and you act to capture the profit that arises when that anomaly ultimately corrects itself."
Sounds a little like stock picking, doesn't it? "Well, yes," he said. "We're being forced into being more active passive managers. Ultimately, there will be this entire gradient from passive to semipassive to semiactive to active -- a continuous line, where the fund sponsor decides where he wants to be. It's going to be an interesting decade."
 
Potential Growth From Adversity
 Like indexing, investing in distressed securities is not new to the 1990's. A handful of bankruptcy workout specialists like Martin J. Whitman of Whitman Heffernan Rhein & Company in New York have long made careers of bottom-fishing. But the news these days is that the technique is attracting so much attention from main-line Wall Street investors.
Institutional investors are flocking to new partnerships and "vulture funds" that try to take advantage of the fire-sale prices on the securities and other obligations of bankrupt or nearly bankrupt companies. These new funds, whose recent sponsors include leading brokerage firms like T. Rowe Price and Goldman, Sachs, attracted at least $1 billion in fresh capital to the distressed securities market last year, and Wall Street clearly expects the trend to continue.
"Any bankruptcy lawyer knows there are two great bankruptcy waves in this country," said Thomas M. Mayer, a New York lawyer. "The first was the Great Depression; we are living through the second."
Big investment houses are not alone in riding this trend into the new year. Law firms that once specialized in Wall Street deal making are elbowing their way into the once-cozy bankruptcy bar, representing a new breed of investor-creditor and devising innovations like prepackaged bankruptcies whose details are negotiated before the debtor company walks through the courtroom doors.
Broker-dealers that have long specialized in distressed securities -- R. D. Smith and Seidler-Amdec are among the best known -- are now facing new competition from mainstream Wall Street firms. Serving them are computerized data services, like the Bankruptcy Datasource in Boston, and new publications like Bankruptcy Values, an institutional investment letter published by John C. Boland & Company in Baltimore, Turnarounds & Workouts, an industry newsletter published by the Beard Group in Washington, and The Turnaround Letter, put out by New Generation Investments in Boston.
The industry even has its own investor relations firms and transfer agents, like Donlin, Recano & Company of New York, specializing in Chapter 11 cases.
But while all this may give the investors in distressed securities more information and better liquidity, veteran bottom-fishers warn that no amount of preparation can eliminate the fundamental riskiness of sailing into a recession in the leakiest boats in the fleet.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1288 words

HEADLINE: TROUBLED TIMES ON WALL STREET: AS THE BEAR WANDERS, AN INDUSTRY REMAKES ITSELF;
Impact of Easing of Credit May Be Most Vital '91 Issue

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
As bear markets go, this one so far has been much more alarming to the brokers than to the investors. But if the current recession ends up lasting longer, and going deeper, than is currently expected, that relatively happy outcome could change.
To be sure, 1990 was no fun for anyone involved in the stock market, with the possible exception of the short-sellers, who seek to profit from lower prices. For the first time since 1981, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index showed a loss for a year, falling 6.6 percent before dividends. 
 In 1991, the most important issue for investors may be just how much impact the Fed's easing of interest rates has on the economy.
 
Rebound or Lag
 If it helps to shorten the recession by getting businesses and consumers to step up spending, then the rebound that began last October may be not just a bear-market rally but the beginning of a bull market. But if the pressures of debt, and the banks' new-found fear of bad loans, keep a lid on economic activity, then this bear market could have a way to go.
The carnage last year was worse for the brokerage industry than for investors. On Wall Street, the leveraged escapades of the 1980's left one big firm bankrupt and several others dependent on rich parents for capital infusions. With trading volume down and institutional commissions measured in pennies a share, few equity desks on Wall Street are making money. There are rumors of many more pink slips in this new year.
 
Worst Showing Since 1974
 Wall Street's problems are more accurately reflected in the performance of the vast majority of stocks, whose owners can only look at the narrower gauge of the S.& P. performance with jealousy. The Nasdaq composite, which measures stocks traded over the counter, fell 17.8 percent in 1990, its worst showing since it plunged 35.1 percent in 1974.
The dismal performance seems not to have concerned a lot of investors much. It has become commonplace to note that many institutions are invested a lot more bullishly than their managers talk, and individual investors poured money into stock mutual funds for almost the entire year, although there were reports of a slowdown in the final weeks of December. In the aftermath of the 1987 crash, many investors concluded that the crash created great investment opportunities, and that bottom-fishing mentality has remained alive.
Only a year ago, the conventional wisdom on Wall Street was that the economy was slowing, but a recession would be avoided. Now the general expectation is that there is a recession that began sometime this summer or fall, but that it will be relatively mild.
 
'A Complacent View'
 "I think investors now are taking a complacent view," said Abby Joseph Cohen, who began 1990 as chief investment strategist at now-bankrupt Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and ended it with the title of co-chair of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs. "They think the recession will be short and sweet, but we don't know how much damage it will do to corporate profits."
Historically, stocks have performed poorly early in a recession, but have tended to rise in the last half of the downturn, as the market anticipates the recovery. Optimists have hoped that the rebound that began after most stocks bottomed in October might be evidence that the economic downturn will be a mild one, but Mrs. Cohen is among the analysts who think that the huge debt burden confronting corporate America may serve to extend this downturn.
Those who are pessimistic recall the 1973-74 recession, where large stocks also outperformed the market as a whole in the early going. In 1974, the S.& P. 500 fell by 17.4 percent, while the Nasdaq composite was off 31.1 percent. The next year, the S.& P. dropped 29.7 percent, while the Nasdaq index plunged 35 percent.
 
Depressed Industries Lifted
 In 1990, big was best in stocks, and small was worst. Financial stocks were out of favor, and makers of consumer staples -- toothpaste and soft drinks and the like -- were the Wall Street darlings for their profits that kept rising despite economic problems. But the late rally tended to lift such depressed industries as banks and home builders more than other shares, though not nearly enough to allow them to break even for the year.
Among the major gauges, the Dow Jones industrial average, composed of only 30 large stocks, was the best performer for 1990. In July, long after indexes of smaller stocks had peaked, the Dow average topped 3,000 in several sessions, but never was able to close that high, hitting 2,999.75 on two occassions. But it started down even before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, stirring war fears and driving up oil prices.
For the year, the Dow fell just 4.3 percent before dividends, and less than one percentage point if those payouts are included. The Dow gets the most publicity, and its action may help to explain the relative lack of investor reaction.
 
Index Up 2.9 Percent
 Of the 20 largest companies in market capitalization at the end of 1989, 11 saw their share prices rise in 1990, and a capitalization-weighted index of the 20 was up 2.9 percent.
By contrast, the Russell 2,000 measures the performance of the companies that rank from 1,001 to 3,000 in market capitalization. That index fell 21.5 percent in 1990.
For fans of small stocks, the recent past has been a dreary history of underperformance, beginning in the summer of 1983, when seven years of outperformance by the small stocks came to an abrupt end. The Nasdaq industrial index is down six-tenths of a percent from where it stood on June 24, 1983. By contrast, the Dow industrials are up 112.1 percent over that period.
But in the last couple of months of 1990, the losers early in the year started to do better. Some of the hardest-hit areas of the market rallied, among them the banks and the homebuilders. And the Russell 2,000 gained 11.2 percent in the final two months, while the S.& P. 500 added just 8.6 percent.
The average New York City bank stock fell 39.5 percent in 1990, but it was up 21.1 percent over the final two months. Regional banks, which had not fallen as far, also did not bounce as high. The Nadsdaq bank index, down 34.8 percent for the year, gained 7.7 percent in the final two months.
 
Expectations Confounded
 As 1990 began, the general expectation was for lower interest rates, but rates confounded those expectations and rose early in the year. Rates came down in late 1990 as the Federal Reserve tried to contain recessionary pressures, but long-term rates nonetheless were up for the year. The rate on 30-year Treasury bonds, at 7.97 percent a year ago, now is 8.29 percent. But the rate on three-month Treasury bills dropped from 7.60 percent to 6.44 percent.
The rise in long-term interest rates may help to explain the relatively poor performance of utility stocks. The Dow utility average was down 10.8 percent for the year, despite the reputation of the stocks as the kind to own in downturns.
Charles Clough, the chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, argues that utilities now represent the best values in the market, simply because their dividends appear to be safe at a time when the pressures of debt and recession are likely to make many other companies cut payouts. "Income may be the thing that is in short supply in the 1990's," he said, forecasting that interest rates will decline sharply.
As it is, 1990 was one of the worst years for dividend payouts in recent years, although final figures are not in. The fact that many large companies did acceptably well helped overall dividend payments to rise, but more companies cut their payouts than in any year since 1982.

HEADLINE: TROUBLED TIMES ON WALL STREET;
Credit Analysts Expect A Drop in Interest Rates

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
With the economy in recession and the Federal Reserve Board moving to prevent the downturn from being deep and prolonged, most credit market analysts anticipate that interest rates will fall, perhaps by a percentage point or more, in the first half of the new year.
After that, they expect rates to stabilize or move higher. 
 At the moment, the economic numbers and the Fed's determination give credence to those forecasts. Signs of weakness abound. The manufacturing sector is slipping badly, and showing few signs of resurgence. The construction and housing industries are on their knees. Real estate values in many parts of the country are sliding.
Perhaps most worrisome, the banking sector is in serious trouble. The borrowing binge of the 1980's has exhausted the capacity for leveraged economic growth, analysts said.
Above all, "this is a recession which is financially related," said Richard M. Kelly, chairman and chief executive of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, primary dealers of Government securities. "The implications of that are possibly more serious and less clear, because the last time we had a financially related recession was in the 1930's."
 
Reason to Worry
 Edward J. Hyman Jr. vice chairman at C J. Lawrence Morgan Grenfell, was blunt in his assessment.
"The economic climate is going to be bad," he said, "and Fed policy is the only tool we have to offset the downturn. But one of the things that troubles me most is that everybody else expects interest rates to come down. It is unusual for rates to perform in line with a strong consensus."
Based on recent history, Mr. Hyman has reason to worry.
A year ago, when the economy was merely soft and the Fed already beginning to ease monetary policy, most analysts forecast that interest rates would decline in the first half of the year. The prediction went awry, however: a bitterly cold winter pushed up inflation, and interest rates along with it, in the first six months of 1990. It was not until July that rates began to settle back down again.
Indeed, despite manifest evidence that the economy contracted sharply during the fourth quarter, 30-year Treasury bond yields were slightly higher at the end of last year, 8.29 percent, than they were when 1989 drew to a close, 7.97 percent.
Available economic evidence and the demonstrable willingness of the Federal Reserve to push down short-term interest rates make it unlikely that 1991 will be a repetition of the year just ended, economists said.
Since July the Fed has lowered the overnight Federal funds rate by 1.25 percentage points, to 7 percent and has shown a willingness to push it lower still. Analysts said that further declines will be necessary.
 
Reaction to War
 "For securities like those of the United States Government, weakness in the economy will drag those rates down, about one percentage point across the board by spring," said Neil M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation. "That might be enough to stop the economy from falling any further."
Almost certainly, however, there will be bumps along the way.
Most immediately there is Saddam Hussein, and the attendant uncertainty about the consequences of a shooting war in the Persian Gulf.
The outbreak of war and a disruption in oil supplies from the region would undoubtedly push up interest rates and rekindle inflation fears, which over the last few months have been evaporating. The size of the market's reaction to open warfare would depend completely on the conflict's duration and the extent of the damage done to oilfields in the gulf states.
There is also the chance, however small, that the economy is not as weak as it currently appears. Fourth-quarter output contracted sharply, almost all private analysts say. But planned-for increases in auto production during the first quarter of 1991 could generate a recovery of sorts, and push up interest rates a bit.
"At some point in the first half of 1991, and perhaps sooner rather than later, we could see an uptick in the economy," Mr. Kelly of Lanston said.
 
'Trouble and Stagnation'
 "Those periods will be accompanied by a sharp upward correction in interest rates," he added. "I am a proponent of significant declines in interest rates over time. But it is not going to happen in a straight line."
Given the current state of the economy, modest upticks in activity should be regarded as an aberration, analysts said.
"At best, this will be a year of continued trouble and stagnation," said Gail Fosler, chief economist at The Conference Board.
Reflecting that view, the consensus forecast of 52 economists surveyed by Blue Chip Economic Indicators in mid-December was that the economy would expand at a mere three-tenths of 1 percent rate from the fourth quarter of 1990 to the fourth quarter of 1991. Almost half of those surveyed projected zero growth or an outright contraction.
The next 12 months will be a period when corporations, states and municipalities, all facing cash flow problems and huge amounts of outstanding obligations, try to start digging themselves out. But only the most creditworthy will be able to begin the task, analysts said, even if interest rates fall further.
"It used to be ratings were the only thing that mattered" in the corporate bond market, said Jessica Palmer, a managing director and head of the capital markets department at Salomon Brothers. "Now the market is thinking more about companies that will survive recession."
 
Concerns Among Investors
 Banking companies, whose bonds were hammered in 1990 as investors became increasingly aware of the extent of their problems, provide a case in point.
Last year banks issued just $4.5 billion in debt, said Robert A. Schwartz, a vice president and senior financial economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, about one-third the $13.7 billion in securities sold in 1989.
"There will continue to be a lot of quality concerns among investors," Mr. Schwartz said, "as a consequence, a lot of cyclically sensitive corporate borrowers won't find the market terribly receptive to new debt."
Still, Mr. Schwartz and Ms. Palmer agree that stable or lower interest rates will lead to a flood of new corporate debt issues during the early months of the new year.
Importantly, much of that new issuance could represent a refinancing of old securities, many carrying much higher interest rates. That development, if it happens, would help to reliquify corporate balance sheets.
 
Refinancing High-Cost Debt
 "Under $12 billion in corporate debt was called last year, down from $17.5 billion in 1989," Mr. Schwartz said. "I look for this to rise to about $25 billion this year. But if we don't get the rate drop and we have a shooting war, that will only serve to exacerbate the deterioration in corporate balance sheets."
Efforts to refinance high-cost debt will also be a feature of the tax-exempt municipal bond market this year.
"Perhaps as much as $25 billion to $30 billion worth of bonds originally issued in 1981 will be called this year," said George Friedlander, a managing director and fixed income strategist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
"And that number will increase as we move into the mid-1990's. Between now and 1995 $200 billion worth of bonds, or more than 20 percent of the entire municipal bond market, will be called."
As in the corporate bond market, Mr. Friedlander said a deep or prolonged recession would put further pressure on the credit quality of most states and municipalities, many of which already face severe financial problems. Debt issued by those who weather the problems best will carry much lower interest rates than those who experience real trouble.
"Quality spreads should widen," he said.
 
Defaults at a Record Clip
 Conditions in the market for high-yield "junk" bonds figure to improve in 1991, if only because it is difficult to imagine how they could get much worse.
With defaults running at a record clip, new issuance in the market dried up. A declining stock market and a weakening economy made a disastrous year even worse.
As a consequence, by the end of 1990 the difference between yields on 10-year Treasury notes and an index of 336 high-yield bonds compiled by the First Boston Corporation had widened to a record 11.05 percentage points, from 7.75 percentage points at the end of 1989. By the end of last year, the bonds in the First Boston index had an average yield of 18.97 percent, up from just over 15 percent at the end of 1989.
Even so, at negative 6 percent the return on high-yield bonds was no worse than on the Standard & Poor's 500 index, said Robert Long, director of high-yield research at the First Boston Corporation.
"This year is a recession year," Mr. Long said, "so high-yield bonds will probably not be leading the charge into the next bull market. But it is not an overstatement to say the high-yield market is oversold."

HEADLINE: Prime Is Cut By the Bank Of America

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Bank of America said late on Monday that it was cutting its prime rate to 9.5 percent, from 10 percent. It was the first of the nation's 10 largest banks to reduce its prime lending rate in the wake of several credit-easing measures by the Federal Reserve Board.
Bank of America, based in San Francisco, is the nation's third-largest banking company. 
 A handful of smaller lenders have reduced their prime rates in the last several weeks, the largest of which was the First National Bank of Chicago, No. 13 in the nation, which trimmed its rate on Dec. 20.
Banking analysts said yesterday that the big New York-based banks might not be quick to follow suit, as they try to profit from the difference between their borrowing costs and the interest borrowers pay them.
"The important banks are the New York banks," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with IDEA, a New York consulting firm.
Many New York banks "are perceived to be more financially pressed than other large regional banks," he said. By delaying cutting the prime rate, banks are trying to bolster their balance sheets, which have been weakened by bad real estate loans as well as losses on loans to Third World countries.
At most of the nation's banks, the prime rate has held steady at 10 percent since Jan. 8, 1990, when it was lowered from 10.5 percent.
Although large corporations negotiate rates on their bank loans, the prime rate is a closely watched barometer of interest rates because rates charged to smaller businesses and many consumer loans are pegged to it. Small businesses generally pay interest rates a few percentage points above the prime. Many home equity loans and credit card loans carry interest rates that are adjusted according to changes in the prime.
 
Cut in Discount Rate
 A day before First Chicago reduced its lending rate, the Federal Reserve cut the discount rate, its loan fee to financial institutions, to 6.5 percent from 7 percent. It was the first cut in that key rate since August 1986. The Fed has also gradually been lowering the Federal funds rate, the rate banks charge one another on overnight loans.
New York banks may be waiting to see how the Fed responds to the coming report on the nation's jobless rate. The Labor Department is scheduled to release December unemployment data on Friday.
Several analysts say they expect the Fed to trim the Federal funds rate if the unemployment report is particularly weak.
"If the Fed eases the Fed funds, then we will see some money-center banks cut prime," Mr. Chandler said.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
TOP BUSH ADVISERS CALLED IN TO MEET ON IRAQ STRATEGY

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1

 BODY:
President Bush met with senior advisers tonight to discuss the military and political strategies for the final push leading to the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait, Administration officials said.
"We are going to start to talk about what we are going to do," a senior Administration official said before the meeting. "This is the first time the whole team will be back together since Dec. 18 to compare notes and review the whole range of strategic issues." 
 The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the meeting was not prompted by any particular development but that Mr. Bush wanted to review the situation and get updates from those who had recently visited the gulf region, including Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin L. Powell. Vice President Dan Quayle is currently touring the gulf area.
 
Meetings Begin Early
 Also attending the dinner at the White House were Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu. The dinner meeting broke up after about an hour and a half and no statement was issued.
Mr. Bush had scheduled a meeting with the same advisers for Wednesday, and it came as something of a surprise when he returned to Washington this afternoon and summoned them. The talks came amid increasing speculation about efforts to resolve the crisis, although there is no firm indication that American-Iraqi negotiations are taking place. But a peace initiative may emerge from a European Community meeting scheduled for Friday.
The senior official said the discussions, which are expected to continue on Wednesday, would focus on whether it would be useful to dispatch Mr. Baker on another tour of the gulf and Europe in the next week or two. He would seek to coordinate military and diplomatic policies and insure that the international alliance is firm.
 
Occupation of Iraq on Agenda
 The discussions will also involve how to deal with Iraq after the crisis is resolved, including how best to check its nuclear-weapons potential, the official said. And he noted that there is also the possibility of an allied military occupation of the country.
Also on the agenda will be how the Administration can best consult with Congress, which begins its 102d session on Thursday.
Mr. Cheney, General Powell and Mr. Quayle were expected to sum up their recent trips to the Persian Gulf, giving their assessments of the readiness of the international force and the willingness of gulf allies to grant further financial aid to the coalition effort.
The senior official said there was no reason at the moment to expect that Mr. Baker would travel to Baghdad to meet with President Saddam Hussein if he tours the region. The official said the prospects for a Baker tour of the gulf were "good, but nothing firm has been decided." If it is decided to send Mr. Baker, an announcement will probably be made by Friday.
The official said the main objective of Mr. Baker's trip would be "to hold the coalition together, to seek a peaceful solution, and if Saddam Hussein fails to accept the message that he must unconditionally leave Kuwait, we want to consider the use of force."
If he should make the trip, Mr. Baker, as he has in the past, would request new financing, especially from Saudi Arabia and the exiled Government of Kuwait, to pay for the deployment of 400,000 American military personnel in the region and relieve the economic burdens of Egypt, Turkey and other developing nations that have contributed military units or suffered by honoring the international economic sanctions against Iraq.
 
Iraq in 'a Regional Structure'
 Mr. Baker would also take with him preliminary Administration thoughts on Iraq's position in the Middle East following either a diplomatic or forced resolution of the crisis.
"We have to consider how Iraq will fit into a regional structure," the official said. "And if they withdraw peacefully, how to put their military structure better in balance with the rest of the region." The Administration and its allies have expressed the concern that even if Iraq were to withdraw peacefully from Kuwait, it would remain a potentiallly dangerous political power with some of the most sophisticated weapons in the Middle East.
Administration officials have said they realize that an occupation of a defeated Iraq would not only be costly but also could leave American forces open to guerrilla attack.
A State Department official said the Administration hopes to avoid an occupation of Iraq, preferring to force Iraqi troops out of Kuwait and possibly replace Mr. Hussein with a more moderate leader.
"The main problem is that many Arab countries have indicated already that if we should cross the border into Iraq, that it would be a whole new ball game," the official said. "There have been indications that if there were fighting inside Iraq, there could be a rising up of emotions and public demonstrations all over the Arab world."
 
Parrying Congressional Criticism
 Mr. Bush and his advisers will also plan how best to consult with Congress without restricting the Administration's authority and options. Mr. Bush is due to meet with Congressional leaders on Thursday, and he will urge them to refrain from criticism that Mr. Hussein might perceive as a wavering of American resolve.
The President is also expected to assure them that he is making every effort to seek a peaceful solution and that he has not lost all hope that Iraq might still withdraw from Kuwait.
A White House spokesman said he was not aware of any reconsideration of previously stated Administration policy not to request a resolution from Congress similar to the one adopted by the United Nations Security Council authorizing the use of force to remove Iraq from Kuwait. And Congressional officials have said that no such resolution was planned.
The leaders said earlier in the week that Americans would not support a war until they had been persuaded that all opportunities for a peaceful settlement had been exhausted. The Senate minority leader, Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, and the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, made it clear that they would like to see further efforts to arrange a Baker-Hussein meeting beyond the Thursday date proposed by the White House.
 
A Prediction by Quayle
 JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Vice President Dan Quayle told United States forces today that "1991 will be the year Saddam Hussein gets out of Kuwait."
He advised sailors on the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy and later pilots at a desert air base in southwestern Saudi Arabia not to listen to "the naysayers" and proclaimed that "the American people are behind you."
Mr. Quayle began the new year by having breakfast with sailors on the Kennedy and speaking to personnel on the flight deck.
He also met with a group of Kuwaiti pilots who now fly F-1 Mirage fighter-bombers. Mr. Quayle then traveled to Taif, Saudi Arabia, where he met the deposed Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah.
Mr. Quayle told the Emir that as the American military presence grows, more money will be needed from allies to help pay for it. The Emir did not object to Mr. Quayle's request for greater support, an American official said.
