HEADLINE: TROUBLED TIMES ON WALL STREET: AS THE BEAR WANDERS, AN INDUSTRY REMAKES ITSELF;
Wall Street Paring Down To the Basics

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Wall Street's painful shift from the takeover era to the hangover era is not over, but the securities industry last year finally started making the tough choices to transform itself into a smaller and healthier industry.
The change under way goes well beyond laying off thousands of workers and cutting back salaries and bonuses for Wall Street's survivors. Instead, financial executives and analysts see a reordering of their industry, with the investment houses adopting new strategies and attitudes. 
 The Wall Street houses, the executives and analysts predict, should emerge from their difficult times as smaller and more specialized firms. Each will choose its strengths and then focus on those businesses -- retail brokerage, investment banking, foreign exchange or whatever. More and more firms are likely to cooperate by forming joint ventures to save costs, like merging the back-office clerical work. And the logic of joint operations is expected to go even further with stronger firms combining with weaker ones, thus reducing the number of brokerage houses.
 
Focus on Traditional Role
 Moreover, financial executives see the Wall Street attitude toward their basic role changing. In the heady 1980's, deal making was all -- set up a takeover, collect the multi-million-dollar fees and get on to the next deal. But with the takeover binge over, Wall Street firms are returning to their roots to focus on the traditional investment banker's role of serving as a trusted adviser to corporate clients.
"Wall Street is probably coming back to a basic reality from the insanity of the 80's," said Felix G. Rohatyn, an investment banker with Lazard Freres & Company. "It is supposed to provide a service and not just sell a product."
In 1991, the financial community enters its fourth year of recession, a collapse that began with the 1987 market crash. The troubles intensified last year, sometimes frighteningly so, as one firm after another collapsed or teetered on the brink of insolvency. Essentially, with several top firms requiring bailouts from their parents in 1990, the financial advisers for America went bankrupt.
Today, the American securities industry employs about 60,000 fewer people than it did before the crash, putting the total at about 200,000, close to the level of employment in 1984. But industry executives say the years of cutbacks are likely to continue in the early 1990's, with thousands more layoffs required for financial reasons, and improving technology making large numbers of jobs obsolete.
Although Wall Street firms have been trimming their operations for years, the fundamental change began in earnest last year, as Street executives shelved their egos and optimistic expectations. Over the last year, business principles preached by Wall Street firms to their clients in the 1980's were finally applied to themselves: Prune back excess capacity, limit perquisites and focus on core businesses.
"What's going on right now on Wall Street is a change that is very much structural and not cyclical at all," said Thomas Carroll, the director of the securities industry in New York for KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting firm. "The Wall Street that is rebuilt after this hurricane has gone through is going to be a much different kind of an animal than we have seen in the past."
 
Preparation for New Growth
 Most Wall Street executives insist that the new order will be more healthy for the securities industry and the nation's economy in the long run. "There is excess capacity and these adjustments must happen," said James D. Robinson 3d, the chairman and chief executive of the American Express Company, which owns the firm that is now named Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. "But as they do, there will be a healthier, sounder money and capital market environment and the institutions will be better off for it."
Indeed, analysts say the painful retrenchment is preparing the industry to grow again when the American economy and its financial markets strengthen.
"These layoffs are certainly painful and disruptive to a lot of people's lives, but what is left after the pruning is still very substantial," said Samuel L. Hayes 3d, a professor of investment banking at Harvard Business School. "The firms are protecting the seed corn for the next upturn."
The globalization of the world's main financial markets and new competition from commercial banks are forcing change as well. The globalization trend, analysts say, is likely to result in more links between American and foreign firms, such as between Credit Suisse and CS First Boston. And several money center banks, like J. P. Morgan, Citicorp and Bankers Trust, are expressing eagerness to expand further into the securities business, and as the likelihood for global financial liberalization grows, the possibility of larger competition from such institutions is becoming more tangible.
 
One Shock After Another
 In 1990, the view that the securities industry is unavoidably destined for sweeping change became widely, if grudgingly, accepted on Wall Street. Few senior brokerage executives now speak about being saved by a market rebound, as they had in earlier years, and returning to the fast-money days of the 1980's.
"What everyone has caught onto this year is that the 1980's were the exception," one senior investment banker at a large firm said. "This is what the business can really be like, for an extended time."
The acceptance of the true depth of Wall Street's problems came after it received one sharp shock after another last year. At the beginning of the year, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the powerhouse of 1980's, disappeared from Wall Street's radar screen overnight, filing for protection from its creditors.
Other firms, including Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., now Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., and the First Boston Corporation, faltered badly, requiring bailouts by their corporate parents. Prudential Bache Securities Inc. also needed an end-of-the-year capital infusion from its parent, the Prudential Insurance Company of America.
"Drexel was a watershed event, but it was not isolated," said Daniel P. Tully, the president and chief operating officer of Merrill Lynch & Company.
 
Trouble at the Bottom Line
 Merrill was among a number of firms, including Prudential Bache and Shearson, that were forced to take losses of hundreds of millions of dollars to pay for restructurings of their businesses to overcome mistakes of the 1980's.
The troubles showed clearly on the bottom line. Through June, profits for all members of the New York Stock Exchange barely broke $200 million, which a few years ago would not have been considered a decent-sized bond issue. By the end of September, profits had fallen even further to just $22 million, less than some individual bonuses paid by Drexel in 1989.
The steady stream of bad news shook Wall Street executives out of their confidence that they could continue to pay high fixed costs for real estate and employees in the hopes that market conditions would improve. Still, the structural changes needed to allow most firms to operate profitably have apparently just begun.
Productivity levels per employee are about $10,000 lower than the peak levels for core securities revenue, and while transaction volume has declined significantly, back-office costs have not, according to Booz Allen & Hamilton Inc., a management consultant.
But several firms have decided what they cannot afford to do. Prudential Bache abandoned much of its failed investment banking effort, as well as its risk arbitrage division. Shearson began to combine its huge back office operation with another firm to decrease costs. And firms that had charged into once juicy businesses such as high yield "junk bonds" beat a quick retreat.
 
New Focus on Nurturing
 "Wall Street is saner, and it is not as ego driven as it was," said George L. Ball, the chairman of Prudential Bache. "Firms such as ours are more concentrated on the things that they do to competitive advantage."
The turmoil on Wall Street has also brought a new focus on nurturing stable relationships with corporate clients -- a sharp break with the prevailing mentality of the 1980's when investment banks often seemed willing to side with anyone if the fee was large enough.
In a speech to securities industry professionals late last year, William H. Donaldson, the new chairman and chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, said that clients of the firms were expressing dissatisfaction with the service they received in recent years. "They want us to get back to basics." Mr. Donaldson said.
Indeed, Wall Street executives said that the industry in general failed to remember client needs in the 1980's. "There was not enough focus on clients at too many firms," Mr. Tully of Merrill said. "There were too many with transactional, short-term one-shot approaches. Some of that short-term thinking hopefully will be set aside and the world will come back to sanity and understand the underlying principles and credos of our business."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Drexel was a watershed event, but it was not isolated," said Daniel P. Tully, president and chief operating officer of Merrill Lynch.; "Wall Street is probably coming back to a basic reality from the insanity of the 80's," said Felix G. Rohatyn, an investment banker with Lazard Freres. (The New York Times) (pg. D8)

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Why Only a Few Big Airlines Prosper in a Deregulated Sky

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Continental, Pan Am, T.W.A., Midway: The list of distressed airlines reduced to selling precious assets, courting merger partners or throwing themselves on the mercy of bankruptcy courts grows ever longer.
The run-up in oil prices just as the economy was slouching toward recession has certainly compounded the industry's problems. But many economists, including some who were early champions of deregulation, now believe that the resulting cash squeeze merely hastened the inevitable trend toward consolidation. 
 Like many industry experts, Michael Levine, the former president of New York Air, who is now dean of the Yale School of Management, says there may simply not be room for more than five or six huge national airlines. "We thought the industry would be full of hungry piranhas," he said. "It turns out this is shark and tuna country."
But what is bad news for weaker airlines is not necessarily bad for consumers. Competition, argues Daniel Kasper, a consultant at Harbridge House, a consulting firm in Boston, depends on the number of carriers vying for passengers on each route. And in spite of industry consolidation, the percentage of travelers with a choice is greater than ever.
In 1978, Mr. Kasper notes, 17 percent of all passengers had a choice of three or more airlines on the route they were seeking to fly. In 1984, when new carriers were flying highest, 61 percent could choose among three or more. And in 1988, in spite of growing concentration, the figure had reached 65 percent. The increased choice available, however, comes with the drawback of far fewer direct flights to many destinations.
The key to preserving the increased flight frequency that business travelers value and the low fares that have made American vacationers so mobile, many experts say, is preserving route flexibility for the airlines that do survive. While each analyst has a different list of fixes, most agree on two. Airlines need assured access to the big city airports where landing rights and gates are scarcest. And they need the right to make alliances with financially strong foreign carriers eager to expand into the American market.
Permitting investment by foreign airlines could bring the bonus of greater competition on international routes. For as the price of foreign entry, Washington may well be able to open Europe, Canada and, eventually, Asia and Latin America, to United States carriers hungry to gain market share by slashing fares.
Today, the rules for flying on most international routes are set by bilateral government agreements. In most cases these limit the number of airlines and, typically, the number of weekly flights. Such agreements protect inefficient Latin American, Japanese, French, British and Italian airlines, and in the process generate windfall profits for more efficient United States carriers designated by Washington to serve the routes. Not surprisingly, such restrictions mean crowded aircraft and very high fares -- often twice the rates charged Americans on transcontinental routes of comparable length.
Twelve years after the regulators acted to open competition, the American airline industry has taken on the look of a battlefield near the end of a terrible war of attrition. The corpses of regional carriers -- Western, North Central, Empire, Ozark, Muse, Air California, Frontier, PSA, Piedmont, Air Florida, Presidential, Southern and Republic -- litter the ground. They are gone, swallowed by larger airlines that coveted their planes and airport gates. People Express, the upstart airline that broke all the rules, and Braniff, revived briefly by the Pritzker family of Chicago, have skidded into oblivion.
Eastern, after two decades of labor strife, has retreated to its last stronghold, in Atlanta, after selling its highly successful East Coast shuttle and its lucrative Latin American routes. Pan Am is also living off the proceeds of asset sales while it searches for a sugar daddy. And the survival of three smaller airlines, Midway, America West and Hawaiian, is far from assured.
Carl C. Icahn, the swashbuckling financier who gained control of T.W.A. in a leveraged buyout in 1985, has plenty of cash and an undisguised ambition to buy -- or be bought out. But T.W.A. is burdened by heavy debts, aging aircraft and a hub in St. Louis that originates relatively little traffic. Few analysts are betting on the airline's survival.
Three strong, profitable national airlines -- American, United and Delta -- are left, as well as three weaker ones -- Northwest, USAir and Continental. Edward Starkman, an analyst at Paine Webber, notes that a few regional carriers -- Southwest, Alaska, Midwest Express -- still make money, but only by avoiding confrontation with the majors.
The airline industry as a whole is dogged by excess capacity, the product of the long-held view that only those that expand the fastest will make it. Delta Air Lines, a conservative and generally successful airline, has seen traffic stagnate this year, even as available seats rose by 6 percent.
 
Theory
 
Big Expectations For Deregulation
All these shifts have proved a rude surprise to early proponents of deregulation, who believed that the national industry would thrive on the no-holds-barred competition that worked so well to reduce fares and improve service in unregulated Texas and California in the 1960's.
"We thought an airplane was nothing but a marginal cost with wings," said Alfred Kahn, the economist who, as chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board in the late 1970's, presided over a braintrust of deregulators whose familiarity with economic jargon exceeded their knowledge of the nuts-and-bolts of the airline business.
It was assumed that airlines would be quick to enter and leave routes as demand for service fluctuated. Established carriers could never gouge consumers because they would be challenged by new ones, which needed only a few million dollars and a few leased aircraft to go into business. Indeed, carriers of the pre-deregulation era would be especially vulnerable to competition because they were locked into expensive union contracts.
But economists underestimated the ingenuity of the big carriers -- most notably, American -- in guarding their traditional markets and swamping competitors in new ones. Computerized reservation systems, vital to every travel agent operating in a world of multiple fares and rapidly changing routes, allowed American and United, the owners of the biggest systems, to keep track of rivals and charge hefty fees to competitors. Frequent-flier programs, promising disproportionately large rewards to the most tireless business passengers, bought the loyalty of the travelers who were least sensitive to high fares.
Many economists also missed the implications of the rapid evolution of hub-and-spoke route systems. Once freed from regulation, virtually every carrier discovered it could keep more planes flying more hours each day and fill a higher percentage of the seats by basing all flights out of one or two airports.
That meant far fewer nonstop flights, perhaps the most common complaint about air travel in the deregulated era. It is no longer possible, for example, to fly to Toledo from New York without a stop in Pittsburgh, Cleveland or Dayton, Ohio. But the hubs also assured frequent service; today there are an incredible 14 daily connections from New York to this city of 350,000 people.
Toledo is no exception. A 1986 study by Steven Morrison of Northeastern University and Clifford Winston of the Brookings Institution showed that much of the estimated $12 billion consumers saved from deregulation (in today's dollars) came from this vastly increased choice of flights.
The catch, Mr. Levine notes, is that hubs generated far greater economies for big carriers. More flights to more cities makes it possible for an airline to offer convenient connections for travelers. Once a carrier is committed to a hub, there is a compelling economic logic to adding flights through the hub. That is why almost every important airport is now dominated by a single airline.
A small carrier cannot easily go with the hub flow by scheduling parallel flights to a giant's; travelers seem to dislike changing airlines en route. Even commuter airlines with monopoly routes from hubs to small cities have discovered that it pays to borrow the corporate identity of a major carrier -- hence the rise of American Eagle, United Express, Delta Connection and Northwest Airlink and others which share the names of their large partners but are independently owned.
 
Competition
 
Smaller Airlines No Longer Needed
Despite their worries about high oil prices, most airline executives are wary of seeking help from Big Brother -- a release of oil from the Government's Strategic Petroleum Reserve, for example, to depress the price of jet fuel. Robert Aronson, the head of the Air Transport Association, notes that the industry as a whole has not endorsed Government intervention beyond the level of jawboning.
Washington is implicitly subsidizing the weaker carriers by allowing them to sell valuable rights granted without charge by the Government. But Mr. Levine worries that while such asset sales give the weak a few more months' respite from the creditors, the long-term effect will be a less competitive market. For example, he sees little public merit in Midway's sale of gates at Philadelphia to USAir, which already dominates the only hub in eastern Pennsylvania.
One reason that experts are less than alarmed about the fate of smaller airlines is that they no longer see them as critical to competition. Mr. Morrison and Mr. Winston discern no trend in fares or profits that would suggest the big carriers have much power to charge monopoly prices.
Fares are indeed historically high on short flights, where regulation served as a rigid cap on airline pricing policies. But on average, they estimate, fares are 18 percent below the "standard industry fare level," the formula used by regulators to set tariffs before 1978.
What has saved consumers -- apart from the chronic overcapacity -- is the fact that fares are largely driven by competition on individual routes. Even carriers with hammerlocks on their own hubs must still compete with airlines that fly the same routes through other hubs. Des Moines, for example, has no nonstop service from Los Angeles. But travelers have a choice of America West, United and T.W.A., which among them offer flights through Las Vegas, Phoenix, Denver and St. Louis. If they need more choices, American offers connections through Chicago and Northwest through Minneapolis.
The only travelers who are apparently paying consistently higher fares are residents of cities that have become hubs for single carriers. In compensation, Mr. Winston says, they have a windfall in nonstop service, to distant small cities and even abroad. Travelers from Raleigh, N.C., where American Airlines has a hub, have a choice of three nonstop flights a day to Albany; three to Daytona Beach, Fla.; three to Harrisburg, Pa.; three to Providence, R.I., and one a day to Paris.
 
Problems
 
Some Restraint Is Called For
None of these trends imply, though, that competition could not be increased by a well-financed secondary carrier hungry to expand -- or seriously undermined by the failure of a major carrier. That is why most economists would like see the Government ease entry to new markets.
Mr. Levine of Yale would prohibit the airlines that own computer reservation systems from requiring travel agents to use just one system. If travel agents were free to shop around the computers, he argues, competition among the systems would curb the booking rates the systems could charge to have-not carriers. And it would inhibit subtler forms of discrimination that some airline experts say have made it difficult for have-nots to break into new markets.
Mr. Kahn worries that airport authorities are being pressed to protect their dominant carriers in return for guaranteed financing of airport improvements. At the very least he would increase antitrust surveillance over questionable financing arrangements, like the one between USAir and the Pittsburgh authority that requires the abandonment of the old terminal when a new one is completed.
A broader problem, most analysts argue, is access to crowded airports like Washington's National and Chicago's O'Hare, which are forced to ration landing rights. Many other airports -- including those in Atlanta and Philadelphia, for example -- have no spare gate capacity.
It is possible for a new airline to buy into a full airport. Since 1986 the Transportation Department has permitted carriers to buy and sell the right to, say, land at LaGuardia Airport in the same way that developers buy and sell land. This policy, in effect, assures that markets rather than bureaucrats determine who values access the most. Similarly, and less controversially, long-term leases on airport gates are freely traded.
But the expense and delay involved in adding routes to the nation's most crowded airports is still an anti-competitive barrier. The best way to reduce it, contends Mr. Winston of the Brookings Institution, would be to ration scarce landing rights with high peak-hour charges, and then use the revenue to expand airport and air traffic control capacity. The direct benefits in reduced travel time and lower aircraft operating costs, Mr. Winston estimates, would exceed $10 billion a year. The indirect benefits of increasing competition would be pure gravy.
Not surprisingly, though, the airlines that already control scarce landing rights have no interest in paying for them. Nor do private plane owners, who have lobbied fiercely against congestion-related fees.
 
Foreigners
 
Exchanging Cash For New Access
A very different and perhaps more politically acceptable means of beefing up competition would be to encourage foreign investment. A number of United States airlines are already partially financed by foreigners -- notably Continental (SAS), Northwest (KLM) and America West (Ansett of Australia). But Federal law prohibits both foreign control and ownership in excess of 25 percent. The biggest losers are USAir and Northwest, which are reportedly eager to make foreign alliances that would allow them to go head to head with American, United and Delta.
Mr. Levine favors outright repeal of the prohibition for the airlines of countries that accept wide-open competition on international routes.
Clark Onstad, a former regulator who later was a vice president of Continental, says he thinks such ambitious change will have to wait until 1992, when the European Community drops its internal trade barriers and is better prepared to cut grand deals on air transport. But according to Mr. Kasper there is more immediate pressure for simpler, case-by-case liberalization of foreign investment restrictions.
British regulators are reportedly reluctant to approve the requested transfer of landing rights at London's crowded Heathrow Airport from Pan Am and T.W.A. to American and United, two strong airlines that would give British Airways a far tougher run for its money on North Atlantic routes. The likely price for approval of those deals is a chance for British Airways to buy into a United States carrier that could feed it trans-Atlantic traffic -- a move that might be possible without legislation if the Bush Administration were inclined to fudge the issue of control.
Pressure is also building for a deal that transforms the United States and Canada into a single airline market. American carriers would probably settle for deregulating flights between the countries. But Air Canada is reportedly opposed because it could not establish an efficient hub on its side of the border. The price of open competition, much desired by some American carriers, may well be an agreement to allow Air Canada to merge with a United States airline.
Competition in the airline business is hardly dying. But its character is certainly changing rapidly. The unanswered question is whether Washington is up to the task of protecting consumers in the melee.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Perestroika For Renters

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WITH New York real estate in the dumps and unoccupied condos flooding the rental market, could the city's 43-year-old "emergency" rent controls be vulnerable?
Peter Salins, a professor of urban planning at Hunter College and co-author of a new analysis of rent regulation, is not particularly optimistic. He fears that middle- and upper-income renters in Manhattan, who benefit at the expense of almost everyone else in New York City, still call the shots in Albany. 
 But Mr. Salins, writing in NY, the conservative Manhattan Institute's journal of city affairs, offers plenty of evidence that rent control is no defense against gentrification. And he notes that the simplest of compromises, deregulation of vacant apartments, could leave both renters and landlords better off. The trickiest part to formulating a deal, he suggests, is persuading the tenant lobby to abandon the pretense that it is championing the interests of the poor.
To most economists rent control is the poisoned apple, a seductive idea that undermines the symbiosis between free people and free markets. Rent is the largest item in the budgets of most people. Thus in a city of renters, rent control is bound to be popular. No one, after all, wants to pay more than they must for housing. And hardly anyone thinks it is fair to ask people to move just because others are willing and able to pay more to live in their homes.
The catch, which New Yorkers have been slower to accept than Poles or Nicaraguans, is that prices determined by government rather than by supplyand demand are bound to distort economic incentives and erode productivity. And when the controls affect a big-ticket item like housing for a very long time, the damage is likely to be serious.
Landlords who cannot raise the rent skimp on quality: Only New Yorkers take for granted that professionals with graduate degrees on their resumes and Volvos in the corner garage still live in grime-coated buildings with exposed plumbing and 70-year-old boilers. According to the Census Bureau, the heating is broken in 26 percent of New York's rental apartments, compared with just 9 percent in Chicago.
But subtler misincentives, say Mr. Salins and his co-author, the economist Gerard Mildner, may generate greater distortions. Once ensconced in apartments with rents far below market rates, tenants become lifers in a prison for the privileged. Thousands of six- and seven-room apartments in space-short New York are occupied by retirees who cannot afford to make way for large families.
True believers shrug off such distortions: It's asmall price to pay to keep New York affordable for long-time residents with modest incomes. But according to a 1989 study by Henry Pollakowski at Harvard's Joint Center for Housing Studies, the average rent on controlled apartments is only $44, or 15 percent, below the average uncontrolled rent.
Only in Manhattan -- really only below 110th Street -- where controlled rents average about $400 below uncontrolled rents, does the system bite. Not surprisingly, almost all the windfall goes to the affluent. By the city's own accounting, the richest 10 percent of renters in 1987 paid 13 percent of their incomes to their landlords, while the poorest 10th paid 58 percent.
It is naive to assume that such truths could make New Yorkers free. Renters paying $181.16 a month for three bedrooms with riv vu are not about to give up their sinecures without a fight. And it is a truism of democratic societies that a thousand well-organized people with a clearly defined interest have the power to veto change that is mildly desired by millions. The real question is whether government is up to the task of arranging a way for landlords to buy out tenants.
Mr. Salins's preferred route is "vacancy decontrol" -- eliminating controls when tenants move voluntarily. That would create a market for the right to charge free-market rents; a landlord could, in effect, buy back an apartment from a tenant who had mobilized state power to confiscate a portion of the property.
The problem with vacancy decontrol, Mr. Salins says, is that it "would unmask the property rights issue." Those who settled for a handful of silver could no longer assert that they were fighting to save mixed-income neighborhoods from a blight of yuppies. And if the ideological justification for rent control were lost, the whole logic of allowing the luckiest renters to walk away with their windfalls might unravel.

HEADLINE: 45 CREDIT UNIONS AND BANKS SHUT BY RHODE ISLAND

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The new Governor of Rhode Island yesterday ordered the immediate closing of 45 state-chartered banks and credit unions until they have arranged Federal insurance for their deposits.
Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun took the step after a private insurance fund ran low on money to guarantee the institutions' deposits and asked to be taken over. 
 "I am declaring a bank emergency in Rhode Island," Mr. Sundlun said in a statement issued a few hours after taking office.
The 45 institutions, about three dozen of them credit unions, were closed by the Governor have a total of $1.7 billion in deposits, in 300,000 accounts. Depositors will not have access to their money until the banks and credit unions reopen.
All but two institutions have already applied for Federal insurance, the Governor said. He said the other two were essentially inactive.
 
Reopening Possible This Week
 Some closed institutions are expected to open later this week, with Federal deposit insurance, David E. Preston, Governor Sundlun's communications director, said. Others will probably not reopen as quickly, he said.
L. William Seidman, the chairman of the F.D.I.C., said last night that his agency's examiners had been visiting the privately insured Rhode Island banks for several weeks. He said the agency would offer insurance only to those institutions that meet its standards for financial stability and would not impose any additional burdens on the agency or its members.
"Obviously given the problems here, there will be some institutions that will not qualify," Mr. Seidman said, adding that the state of Rhode Island would have to decide what to do with them.
In the worst possible case, some financial institutions could be liquidated and depositors might not recover all of their money. Mr. Seidman said the F.D.I.C. would not step in to cover any losses that depositors may face.
Mr. Seidman said the demise of the Rhode Island fund was of particular concern because it involved a large number of accounts in a state with a population of one million. The failure, he said, "is one of the largest we've seen in several decades," and appears to involve more depositors than failures of private deposit insurers in Maryland and Ohio nearly six years ago.
Mr. Seidman also suggested that the Rhode Island fund's troubles showed that Federal deposit insurance was needed to protect small depositors who are not likely to keep track of the soundness of their banks.
Most states began requiring Federal insurance for state-chartered banks after the troubles with private insurance in Ohio and Maryland. But many credit unions are still privately insured, including the three dozen in Rhode Island that were shut yesterday. Another 130 credit unions in neighboring Massachusetts are insured by a private fund.
Mr. Preston noted that Rhode Island had a large budget deficit and had not yet decided whether it could afford to cover any losses that depositors might suffer if any of the 45 institutions were forced to close permanently for lack of insurance.
"We will do whatever we can do prudently to help the depositors," he said.
Rhode Island is also home to 38 financial institutions, including some large commercial banks. They are insured either by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or the National Credit Union Administration and are not affected by the Governor's order.
Rhode Island officials are also discussing the situation with the Federal Reserve Bank in Boston and the National Credit Union Administration.
 
A Troubled Industry
 The announcement in Rhode Island comes amid growing troubles for the nation's banking industry. Many institutions face potentially huge losses on real estate loans and are announcing reductions in dividends and staff layoffs.
But the problems in Rhode Island, while likely to contribute to the general public anxiety about the soundness of banks, do not directly reflect the same issues.
The state's troubles apparently began in early November, when the Heritage Loan and Investment Company, a two-branch bank in Providence, failed. Its deposits were insured by the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Fund, which also insures the deposits in the 45 state-chartered institutions that Governor Sundlun shut yesterday. The fund distributed much of its reserves to Heritage's depositors.
The bank's president, Joseph Mollicone Jr., has since been missing and has been accused of embezzlement in state and Federal arrest warrants.
The insurance fund's directors met on Monday, and yesterday they asked the state to name a conservator to direct its operations. Mr. Preston, the Governor's aide, said this effectively meant that the fund would go out of business.
 
Problems in Other States
 Rhode Island is not the first state to face a deposit insurance crisis because of problems at a private fund.
In 1985, the Governors of Ohio and Maryland closed privately insured savings and loan institutions under strikingly similar circumstances. As in Rhode Island, a single financial institution failed in each state amid accusations of misconduct by executives, and the resulting losses drained the reserves of the private insurers.
The Ohio and Maryland incidents involved many more financial institutions and more money than Rhode Island's current problems. Coming in 1985, at a time of strong economic growth and high public confidence in the banking industry, those problems raised questions about the adequacy of private insurance funds.
Despite the failure now of three private insurance funds in nearly six years, some economists contend that they are preferable to Federal insurance. Private funds are better able to charge premiums that reflect the riskiness of banks' investments, which helps to restrain bank managers from making unwise loans in an effort to expand rapidly, said Steven H. Hanke, a professor of economics at Johns Hopkins University.
 
Exact Assets Unclear
 The exact assets of the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Fund are unclear. "They have in the high teens millions of dollars of assets," Mr. Preston said. "Now the question is how much of that is liquid and available."
Peter Novela, the insurance fund's president, did not return a telephone call yesterday to his home. A woman identifying herself as Mr. Novela's wife said he was sick in bed and could not come to the phone.
In a telephone interview yesterday with The Associated Press, Mr. Novela said the fund was worth $17 million to $18 million, having replenished its reserves by reassessing its membership after the collapse of Heritage. Mr. Novela told The Associated Press that he had missed Monday's board meeting because of illness and did not know why the board decided to seek conservatorship.
 
No Commercial Banks Affected
 No commercial banks are affected by Governor Sundlun's order because they are all Federally chartered and are not under state control, said Leonora S. Cross, a spokeswoman in Washington for the Comptroller of the Currency, the Federal agency that regulates commercial banks.
Mr. Preston said the law required that banks and credit unions have deposit insurance and that the Governor was obliged to close the institutions when the fund filed for conservatorship.
Rhode Island's ability to respond to its sudden banking crisis is severely crimped by the state's budget troubles. It faces an estimated $162 million deficit on its $1.5 billion budget for the year ending on June 30 and must close the gap within six months because of an amendment to the state Constitution requiring a balanced budget.
 
New Governor Acts Quickly
 Closing the institutions was one of Mr. Sundlun's first acts in office. The former Governor, Edward D. DiPrete, a Republican whom Mr. Sundlun defeated in elections in November, did not return a telephone call to his answering service last night.
When Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio ordered the closing of 71 state-chartered savings and loans institutions on March 15, 1985, it took 11 days for all of them to reopen, and some institutions limited withdrawals to $750 at first. The state Legislature created a separate $92 million fund to protect deposits.
On May 15, 1985, Gov. Harry R. Hughes of Maryland ordered 102 privately insured savings and loan institutions to limit depositors' withdrawals to $1,000 a month. Assets of some institutions were sold to help pay for their transfer to Federal deposit insurance.
 
New England Deal
 PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 1 (REUTERS) -- Citizens Savings Bank and the Citizens Trust Company said on Monday that they had completed the acquisition of certain assets and liabilities of Bank of New England-Old Colony N.A., a unit of the Bank of New England Corporation. Citizens Savings Bank and Citizens Trust operate jointly as Citizens Bank and are owned by the Royal Bank of Scotland Group.
Citizens Bank said it had paid a premium of about $25 million, which is the difference between the liabilities it assumes and the assets it receives. The transaction adds Old Colony's 22 branches to Citizens 30 branches in Rhode Island. Citizens is also acquiring about $900 million in deposits.

HEADLINE: Aid for Child Care Opens Worlds of Some Adults

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RUSSELLVILLE, Ark.

 BODY:
Four years ago, Ruby Hinman, a high school dropout and mother of three, rarely ventured beyond her front porch and the smoky blue pines that surround it. She was a hermit, she said, shy and insecure, and nervous at having to meet people.
Then came Susan Lynch and "Hippy," the Home Instruction Program for Preschool Youngsters. Was Mrs. Hinman interested in a program that would prepare her 4-year-old daughter, Mandy, for kindergarten? 
 "I was reluctant at first," said Mrs. Hinman. "But Susan kept visiting and talking about 'Hippy' and finally I thought, 'I'll do this and I'll get it over with and I'll go back to the way I've been.' "
Nothing has been the same since.
Two of the Hinman children have completed the program and are straight-A students at the local elementary school. Mrs. Hinman got a job and her high school diploma, and now, with her husband's encouragement, she plans to enter Arkansas Technical College here this spring to study psychology.
 
Window Opens for States
 Like most states, Arkansas has a great need for two kinds of programs that aid working parents: child care education and day care programs. Arkansas has also been among the leaders in developing such programs, in part because of Gov. Bill Clinton's interest in the issue.
Now, Arkansas and the rest of the states will have an opportunity to expand child care assistance and to initiate innovative programs like Hippy, with money from the Child Care and Development Block Grant, passed by Congress last fall. The legislation -- the first comprehensive Federal program to help working families find affordable, quality day care -- gives the states $2.5 billion over the next three years to subsidize child care for working parents, regardless of income.
Nationwide about 750,000 children, and their parents, are expected to be helped by the grants. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, 56.1 percent of women with children under age 6 were employed outside their homes in 1988, up from 30.3 percent in 1970.
The next few months are critical for states. They have to submit a plan to the Federal Government showing how they will use the funds, coordinate with existing programs, insure priority for low-income children and children with special needs, and pay or reimburse child care providers.
 
Channeling the Aid
 A crucial question is how the child care money will be delivered. States can either distribute money to day care centers or issue vouchers to families to help them pay directly for child care, including day care provided by religious organizations. The grants also require states to maintain state health and safety standards for all participating child care centers.
Partly because of the interest of Governor Clinton and his wife, Hilary, Arkansas already has the beginnings of a system that could be used to funnel Federal funds. A voucher system for day care is nearly two years old, and state officials anticipate it will be used to deliver the grant block money.
"Right now, we have many more parents apply for vouchers than we have money for," said Linda Reasoner, the assistant director of Child Care Developments Inc., the largest child care provider in the state.
Jo Ann Williams, the executive director of the company, said its various day care and parenting-education programs are financed through 15 sources, including fees paid by those who can afford them and government grants.
 
A Carload of Sleepy Children
 When the Federal block grant money begins to flow next September, Arkansas will receive $9.5 million. Seventy-five percent is earmarked for activities to increase the availability, affordability and quality of child care. But 25 percent can be used for improving quality of programs ranging from day care to early childhood education efforts like Hippy.
The country around Russellville, where Child Care Developments is centered, is full of the working poor. Most women work or want to work. Auto insurance, required by the state, is often dismissed as one expense too many. At the same time, people are so proud that social workers have difficulty persuading eligible families to apply for Medicaid for a sick child.
In the hills and hollows of Polk County, just on the edge of the Ozark Mountains, people work in factories, lumber mills or processing plants. Often husband and wife work in the same plant, the wife the early shift, the husband the late. It is not uncommon during shift changes to see a car with a back seat full of sleepy-eyed, pajama-clad children as one parent goes to work and the other takes over the child care.
Just how many working mothers there are who may need child care is hard to tell, said Mrs. Reasoner, because of the informal, and often inadequate, child care system of family and neighbors that many use.
 
Value of Crayons
 Though most of these parents want the best for their children, they are often not equipped to provide the best early childhood care.
"We have children out here who have never held a pencil or a crayon or scissors," said Mrs. Lynch of Hippy. "Their parents won't get them crayons because they say the child breaks them or he'll just tear it up. Through Hippy, I try to help parents relearn, or learn, the value of purchasing paper, books and crayons."
Developed by an Israeli education council at The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, the Hippy program focuses on improving a child's total environment, child care advocates say.
The first Hippy program in the United States was established in 1984 in Tulsa, Okla. Now 11 states have programs, including New York with two programs, one in Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn and one in Yonkers. Arkansas started the program in 1986 and now has Hippy programs in 18 cities, more than any other state. Russellville's is the largest.
Mrs. Lynch says she knows how important it is for these parents to recognize the value of early childhood learning. "I grew up like these families," she said. "We lived on food stamps. I dropped out of school at 16 to have my first son. I know how important it is to help people help their children."
 
Lifting Parent With Child
 Ruby Hinman's voice gets an edge of excitement as she explains to a visitor her own liberation through the first lessons for young Mandy. The program includes twice-monthly meetings of parents who play the role of child and parent during sessions with an instructor. Mrs. Hinman recalled that she dreaded that first meeting, but once there, she enjoyed it, and soon found her confidence around other people growing.
"It made me brave enough to put in an application for a job at Tastee Freeze," she said.
Come spring, Mrs. Hinman, who works as a waitress, will be using another Child Care Developments program, day care for working student mothers.
"My husband, Keith, really encouraged me to go to college," she said. "I was surprised and I was scared. I asked him wasn't he afraid I'd change. He said I'd change anyway. And if I get through college and get a decent paying job, why, maybe he'd go back to school."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ruby Hinman prepared her daughter for kindergarten in Russellville, Ark., with a system that uses one-on-one sessions to instruct parents who are hesitant about their parenting skills how to teach their children. Above, Mrs. Hinman with Mandy, who is now 9 years old. (David Gottschalk for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The 90's Woman: How Fat Is Fat?

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
BITE by bite, American women dutifully serve the reigning image of body beautiful. Men have been almost blissfully immune from the vicissitudes of body style, but in the United States women have borne the burden with gusto.
In the late 19th century, when the fleshy physique dominated, the generous Gibson Girl contours were sought with a flurry of forks. "The lean are restless and irritable in mind, rarely contented, never quiet," admonished "How to Be Plump: Or Talks on Physiological Feeding," an 1878 handbook by Dr. T. C. Duncan. "They form the complaining element of society, and are unstable as a nation." When thin came in, women used their forks to push food primly from one side of the plate to the other. "It makes me feel powerful to be hungry," an emaciated Ivana Trump told reporters in 1986. 
 Today, forks across America are poised somewhere between plate and mouth. After a 20-year reign of an anorexic esthetic, arbiters of haute couture and doyennes of popular culture, along with health and fitness experts, have begun to reconsider the question "How fat is fat?"
For the moment, American women aren't sure whether to feast or fast.
"The Twiggy look is definitely over," said Dr. Katherine Halmi, director of the Eating Disorders Clinic at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center's Westchester Division. The full female figure is blooming again. Hourglass forms are bursting from the pages of fashion magazines and proudly taking a place in the front row of low-impact aerobic classes. What was once "fat" can now be "fit," -- at least in mass market images of women.
It is not clear how much the ideal American female formwill grow -- or how healthy the rounding of America is. "People in our country are already heavier than people in any other country in the world," Dr. Halmi said. "To say that obesity is beautiful is to ignore the fact that morbid obesity is unhealthy."
For now individual women hesitate to beef up the hips, breasts and round limbs that have been verboten since the invasion of sticklike British models in the 1960's. "Women raised under the specter of Twiggy have a morbidly obese image burned in their unconscious like a horror movie," said Carol Bloom, a psychotherapist who is co-founder of the Women's Therapy Institute in Manhattan. "The fear fuels yo-yo dieting, bulimia and anorexia, disorders that are potentially much more threatening to health and well-being than a few extra pounds."
Dr. Jean Rubel of Anorexia Nervosa and Related Eating Disorders, in Eugene, Ore., estimates that more than half the women ages 10 to 30 suffer an eating disorder. Beginning in the 1970's, the decade of svelte, that number skyrocketed, she said.
At the same time the country witnessed a renaissance of quick weight-loss diets and diet-related maladies that didn't even off until last year. No wonder health professionals demanda physiological appraisal of body fat that considers heredity, age and body composition in setting weight goals.
In 1983, the height and weight table tabulated by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company moved in that direction. Used by most American physicians to determine "normal" weight, the charts showed an increase of 5 to 10 pounds in most categories. "Since our benchmark study in 1959, it was the first significant increase in healthy Americans," said Stanley Kranzer, a demographer who compiled results of the 4 million Americans who were polled. In the 1990 Dietary Guidelines by the United States Departments of Agriculture and Health and Human Services, suggested weight ranges were even more generous and distinctions between healthful weights for men and women of the same height were nearly eliminated.
Physicians who specialize in weight loss advocate another approach to determining how fat is fat. "Total weight is not as important as the proportion of lean body mass like muscle and organs to fat body mass," said Christine Wolaver, director of exercise physiology at the Doral Saturnia Health Spa in Miami. By using calipers to measure body fat, she helps individuals set weight goals. "I often advocate a weight far above the height and weight chart," she said. "Research shows that active people need weight to maintain their life styles. The anorexic look is unhealthy and unsustainable."
Fitness instructors at the Doral Saturnia today are 5 to 10 pounds heavier than they were three years ago. "We want to see muscle not bone," said Ms. Wolaver.
The more robust female image is consistent with fashion. After 25 years of aping Twiggy and Jean (the Shrimp) Shrimpton, runway models recently began to flaunt hips and breasts. Later-day Junos appear in movies, television and advertising.
The shift from the tubular-shaped woman who recalls an adolescent boy to a round figure reminiscent of Marilyn Monroe is the latest chapter in an age-old bifurcation of the female form. In "The Nude," the art historian Kenneth Clark wrote, "Prehistoric images of women are of two kinds, the bulging statuettes from paleolithic caves, which emphasize the female attributes till they are little more than symbols of fertility, and the marble dolls of the Cyclades, in which, already, the unruly human body has undergone a geometrical discipline."
Hence, a voluptuous Roseanne Barr, posed like Botticelli's Venus on the cover of the December Vanity Fair magazine, doesn't necessarily signal that chubbettes are chic. But it is emblematic of a shifting esthetic. In a society where women's appetites are typically set by an external standard of beauty rather than a physiologic craving, the change gives pause at the table. But the shift doesn't surprise theoreticians. "Throughout history, the ideal women's body size has gone up and down like an economic barometer of culture," said Ms. Bloom.
Linda Weintraub, director of the Edith C. Blum Art Institute at Bard College said that in any society, the ideal female form generally changes in reaction to economic conditions. "In a culture where food is scarce, the rounded female form is glorified as a symbol of security and affluence," she said. "In a culture where food is abundant, the lean body is glorified for its discipline."
Her colleague at Bard, Richard A. Gordon, a professor of psychology, furthers the argument. "In historical periods in which women have felt under pressure to prove their intellectual ability and competence, the slender body ideal has been dominant," he writes in "Anorexia and Bulimia, Anatomy of a Social Epidemic," (Basil Blackwell, 1990). Full figures, on the other hand, abound during home-centered eras.
Dr. Blackwell notes that the idealization of thinness didn't take a firm hold in the United States until the early 20th century, when women entered the workplace. That image was then unseated by the hourglass figures of Marilyn Monroe and Jayne Mansfield in the postwar period of domestic retrenchment. "Dieting and thinness attained the status of a mass cultural obsession," he said, in the last two decades as more women than ever before entered the American work force.
And the re-blooming of the female figure coincides with the largest baby boom since the Baby Boom.
Fertility and nurturance are not the overt message in Madonna's look. Implanted breasts seen on runway models seem more like toys than parts of the procreative female biology. But even caricatures can be bellwethers.
"They say 'health,' " said Fran Weiss, a psychotherapist who specializes in treating body image distortions at the Obesity Research Center at St. Lukes Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. "People are getting very leery of thin. Thin could be sick. It could be the sickness. A little more bulk means health."
So far, women on a mass binge have not stampeded Main Street U.S.A. Specialists in eating disorders say that it will take a generation to reverse the disorders that flourished during the recent Reign of Svelte. But the popularity of books like "Fat as a Feminist Issue" (Berkley, 1979) and "Making Peace With Food: A step-by-step guide to freedom from diet-weight conflict" (1990, Amity Publishing) signal a slight loosening of the dietary corset.
American women are once again being extolled to aim their forks at healthful portions of healthful food.
"To be healthy we want to know what to eat, so that we may observe the golden mean -- florid plumpness, which is the picture of health the world over," wrote Dr. Duncan in 1878.
At the Doral Saturnia Health Spa, Alix Landman, a dietitian told 23 female guests several weeks ago: "Look at food as fuel for building a healthy, strong body.Basically firm food like vegetables and grains will make firm tissue. Fatty food like butter, cheese and meat will make fatty tissue."
Plump may still be a four-letter word, but as long as fat is firm, fat is the golden mean today.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL

 BODY:
IT'S the time of year when even normally prudent people lose all sense of caution and succumb to the urge to predict things. For futurologists, amateur and professional, who have had some measure of success in the past, it's a particularly dangerous time; they are expected to repeat their accomplishments yet again.
 For those who have never had any luck predicting anything, the task is much less burdensome. What the heck: they have nothing to lose. Accordingly, we hereby scramble far out on a limb to disclose some of the more important wine events that will almost certainly come to pass over the next 12 months. The dates, it must be said, are only approximate.
 
 JAN. 26: Four more bottles of wine bearing Thomas Jefferson's initials will mysteriously turn up at a wine auction in Zurich. No one will profess to know whence they came. Collectors will accept the three bottles of Chateau Lafite 1776 as authentic but will voice considerable reservation about a single bottle of nonvintage Ridge zinfandel. They will point out that Jefferson's diaries frequently alluded to his strong distaste for the variety.
 FEB. 3: The new owner of one of the 1776 Lafites will display it to some friends. When they question his probity, he will hit one of them with the bottle and smash it. An insurance company will refuse to pay off, noting that Jefferson bottles have been turning up every few weeks.
 MARCH 14: A band of masked men will board the controversial Napa Valley Wine Train just as it passes Mustard's Restaurant, north of Yountville, Calif. After frightening some elderly tourists from Iowa who think they are headed for Disneyland, the men will invade the galley and turn up the heat under the pintadeau desosse, simply ruining lunch for everyone.
 Witnesses will later testify that some of the masked men sounded like winery owners who are opposed to the operation of the train, but charges will be dismissed for lack of evidence.
 APRIL 7: In Paris, LVMH, the Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton conglomerate, will announce that it has acquired Chateaux Lafite-Rothschild and Mouton-Rothschild. The announcement will say that the two will be combined into a new entity known as Chateau LRMR. A spokesman will say that the new subsidiary will embark on an aggressive, vertically integrated acquisition program that will provide new outlets for its wine. Included will be fast-food chains, international vacation clubs and cruise lines, the spokesman will say.
 APRIL 8: In Tokyo, Mitsubishi will announce that it has acquired LVMH.
 MAY 15: Robert Mondavi will disclose that he has been doing a little home wine making since his retirement "to pass the time." First-year production, just for family and friends, will be about 80,000 cases, an aide will report.
 JUNE 12: A six-foot-tall, 300-gallon bottle of cabernet sauvignon will top the bidding at the annual Napa Valley auction. It will be knocked down for $300,000 because it's such good wine and because it comes wrapped in its own BMW mini-van. The story will get immense play on food pages and on televison and will convince approximately one million potential wine drinkers to stick to beer.
JULY 20: The Environmental Protection Agency will announce that it holds to its earlier conclusion that the amount of the fungicide procymidone in some imported wines is not harmful. But the agency will say that it has decided to continue its tests for a year or so. "We'll keep everybody posted," a spokesman will say.
 Meanwhile, to mollify a few strident critics, the agency will release some 1988 Beaujolais nouveau that had been withheld from the market for its tests. A prominent New York retailer will immediately take out full-page newspaper ads announcing a 1988-91 twin pack: "Two nouveaux practically for the price of one."
 AUG. 18: The Domaine de la Romanee-Conti will announce -- with deep regret -- that the 1990 Romanee-Conti will cost $5,000 a bottle. Mme. Bize-Leroy, an owner of the D.R.C., will acknowledge that the price does not exactly reflect production costs but will explain that the Domaine always tries to position itself slightly behind Chateau Petrus.
 AUG. 19: In Tokyo, Mitsubishi will disclose that it has acquired Chateau Petrus.
 SEPT. 15: Grape pickers in Bordeaux will tell reporters that because the summer was so hot and there was so little rain, the 1991 vintage should be quite good.
 OCT. 15: Orley Ashenfelter, the Princeton University soothsayer, will announce that, using his econometric model and the Cray supercomputer at the Institute for Advanced Study, as well as the information that the Bordeaux summer was hot and relatively rain free, he has concluded that the 1991 vintage should be quite good.
 NOV. 2: The Bush Administration will propose an additional $6-a-bottle tax on table wine. Overriding industry objections, the White House will point out that the tax will come to no more than a measly $1 a glass, using a four-ounce glass, of course.
NOV. 4: Questioned on the ABC program "Nightline," John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, will read from a Budget report showing that using a two-ounce glass will bring the tax down to a minuscule 50 cents a drink. Irritated by Ted Koppel's aggressive questioning, he will characterize six-ounce and larger glasses as "holdovers from the self-indulgent Reagan years."
 DEC. 5: The E. & J. Gallo Winery, the world's largest, will announce that it is moving from furnace-like Modesto, in the Central Valley of California, to leafy-green Sonoma County in an effort to enhance its image as a producer of fine wine. This plan could be changed next year if the Legislature in Sacramento approves a longstanding Gallo proposal to move Sonoma County to Modesto.
 DEC. 10: The Beaujolais impresario Georges Duboeuf, who in recent years has moved aggressively intothe bottling and shipping of Rhone Valley wines, will announce that he has acquired the Rhone Valley.
 DEC. 11: In Tokyo, Mitsubishi will announce it has acquired Georges Duboeuf.
 
TASTINGS
 
Bourgogne Passetoutgrains 1988, Domaine Jayer-Gilles; about $12.
 The rules say that all red Burgundy must be made from the pinot noir grape. All except one, the one called passetoutgrains. It can be made from up to two-thirds gamay grapes and one-third pinot noir.
 Things have come a long way since the 14th century when Philip the Bold banned gamay from Burgundy, calling it that "tres mauvais plant." Gamay, the staple of the Beaujolais, crept back into Burgundy over the centuries, particularly after a phylloxera epidemic in the 19th century.
 Twenty years ago, when good Burgundy sold for $4 a bottle, passetoutgrains was little more than a curiosity, especially in export markets. Now, given the extortionate prices of even the simplest Burgundies, passetoutgrains has begun to gain a little respect. Lighter than a full pinot noir Burgundy, to be sure, a good one still conveys the texture and bouquet of the Cote d'Or.
 Robert Jayer-Gilles heads yet another branch of the remarkable Jayer family of Burgundian wine makers and this is an attractive example of his work.

HEADLINE: Embassies Turning to Cultural Concerns

BYLINE: By BARBARA GAMAREKIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1

 BODY:
In the world of diplomacy, culture mostly ranks a distant third behind political and economic concerns. But some countries have begun to give new emphasis to promoting their cultural wares through their embassies in Washington.
"We deal as government to government, but the relationship on the bottom line is people to people," said Ambassador Gustavo Petricioli of Mexico as he discussed the Mexican Cultural Institute, which opened last summer. "As an economist I deal with the World Bank and other financial institutions, but this cultural center is really, really the face of Mexico." 
 Most embassies have a cultural counselor, and ambassadors entertain at a continual round of receptions and dinners for artistic compatriots passing through Washington in performance. But a growing number of countries are not waiting on institutions like the Kennedy Center and the National Gallery of Art to present their artists. They are establishing venues of their own.
Peru has exhibited archeological treasures, ceramics and textiles at its new Cultural Center in a wing of the Peruvian Ambassador's Tudor-style residence. The French have incorporated theater and gallery space in their embassy, known as the Maison Francaise. Brazil has its Brazilian-American Cultural Institute, which offers not only the study of the Portuguese language and Brazilian literature but concerts, movies and art exhibits as well.
 
Showing Canada Off
 Canada's new marble-and-chrome embassy on Pennsylvania Avenue has a high-ceilinged art gallery as well as a striking 175-seat theater that has presented a series of Canadian artists, film makers, musicians and writers since its opening more than a year ago. "The embassy and its cultural component were planned to make a statement," said Terry Colli, the director of public affairs. "We wanted to have a building that would show Canada off, and we have found our location across from the National Gallery and the Smithsonian a considerable challenge. We set out from the very beginning to put together shows which would make people aware of Canadian culture without the hard sell. It is really a learning and educational process and an opportunity to present the work of Canadian artists that people would not get to see unless they were visiting Canada."
As Manuel Cosio, the director of the Mexican Cultural institute, and Dr. Pablo F. Marentes, the cultural affairs attache at the embassy, guided a recent visitor through the new institute, known popularly as Mexico House, Dr. Marentes explained: "We are a country of enormous history and culture, but we are known in the United States primarily through our pre-Columbian objects or by old newsreels and movies about the Mexican Revolution."
That will change, he predicts, once programming gets into full swing with exhibitions ranging from traditional Mexican crafts to the avant-garde work of contemporary Mexican artists.
 
Former Mexican Embassy
 The four-story, 1912 mansion on 16th Street N.W., with its 20-foot ceilings, crystal chandeliers, marble fireplaces and grand staircase murals by a Mexican artist, Roberto Cueva del Rio, was bought by the Mexican Government 68 years ago and was the embassy until it was outgrown last year. The first floor has been turned into a series of galleries and was the setting for its opening exhibition of paintings and sculpture by Diego Rivera, Rufino Tamayo, Frida Kahlo, David Alfaro Siquieros and others. That was followed by an exhibition of 19th-century Mexican engravings and lithographs. On Jan. 15, the paintings of Francisco Toledo, a noted contempory Mexican artist, will go on view.
Musical events at the institute have been held in a replica of the ornate music room at the palace at Fontainebleau near Paris, and over the coming year a series of lectures, conferences and exhibitions is scheduled. "We plan to have poets, scientists and intellectuals in residence," Dr. Marentes said. "Our library will have a computer link with major Mexican libraries and archives, and we want to organize thematic traveling shows that will be offered to regional and Midwest museums in the United States. We want to become a center for the distribution of goods and services."
At the Maison Francaise, a telephone service offers callers a rundown of the cultural calendar, which has included events like an evening of jazz and tap dance with "the world-famous French tap-master Chris Belliou" and readings of translations of French playwrights.
 
The Political Component
 That art can have political as well as cultural impact was dramatically demonstrated here with a recent exhibition of rare Cypriot art and artifacts. The tiny embassy of Cyprus has no exhibition space of its own, so a suite of rooms was rented at a local hotel for a display of ancient Cypriot art, originally from Famagusta, a community taken over by Turkish troops when they invaded in 1974.
"I speak as a citizen of Famagusta who has not been able to visit my hometown for 16 years," said the Cypriot Ambassador, Michael E. Sherifis, as he offered a toast to celebrate the exhibition of the 92 priceless artifacts that had never traveled to the United States before. "This is not only about art and history," the Ambassador said. "It is a cry of agony from Famagusta and from Cyprus as a whole."
The Canadian art exhibition, on view through March 16, is "The Canadian Landscape, 1915-39," which presents the work of seven of Canada's earliest environmental artists. The exhibitions change every four months and have drawn an average of 7,000 visitors each.
The embassy's gray, black and silver theater with its scarlet seats and modernistic curtain of aluminum strips has been the setting for chamber music, jazz and folklore programs as well as lectures and readings by Canadian artists, critics and literary figures. The concert series has been very successful, Mr. Colli said: "In fact, we are suffering from an excess of success and have had to turn some people away."
Asked why the two countries that share borders with the United States are leading the effort to communicate more about their cultural values, Ambassador Petricioli of Mexico said that proximity did not necessarily lead to understanding.
"Although we share 2,000 miles of border with 250 million legal crossings each year, we still deal in cliches about each other," he said. "Although we breathe the same air, drink the same water, have the same goals of democracy, progress and schools for our children, we are different in culture, history, institutions and language.
"But we believe we can complement each other, respect each other, learn from each other, get to know each other better."

HEADLINE: Reviews/Television;
President and Mrs. Bush and an Amiable David Frost

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
"No price is too high to pay to stop Iraqi aggression," George Bush declares in "President and Mrs. Bush Talking With David Frost." The first half of tonight's hourlong program, at 8 on Channels 13 and 49 and at 10 on Channel 21, gives the President, who concedes that eloquence is not his strong point, an opportunity to make as coherent a case for his policy in the Persian Gulf as he has yet offered on television.
 Under the placable questioning of David Frost, Mr. Bush cites graphic examples of Iraqi atrocities in Kuwait from a recent Amnesty International report as evidence of the "clear moral case" against Iraq; asserts that Saddam Hussein would have moved on Saudi oil fields if not stopped; says he is not convinced that sanctions alone will bring the Iraqi ruler "to his senses," and promises that if war is necessary, it will not be another Vietnam and that American ground troops will not remain in the region after Iraq departs or is driven out of Kuwait, although measures must be taken to control Iraq's military prowess. 
 The interview is the first of a new PBS series, "Talking With David Frost," that will be shown once a month through June; future interviewees will include Margaret Thatcher and Robin Williams.
In tonight's meeting, filmed last month, Mr. Frost and Mr. Bush, in matching armchairs, face each other in the Oval Office. They seem at ease together, pals who have got used to chatting under the camera's eye. A fire adds its warmth to the occasion, and a bowl of flowers is in evidence.
 The interviewer leads but never presses. For example, when Mr. Frost raises an uncomfortable point -- why "some in the West" were slow to recognize President Hussein's intentions -- he does not get personal about the Bush State Department. He broaches disputed matters, such as whether air power alone can compel Iraq to back down and whether the White House needs the authority of Congress to start a war, but does not get unpleasant about demanding hard answers. "I would leave it somewhat hypothetical," Mr. Bush says about seeking Congressional approval, and Mr. Frost leaves it.
He has a way of picking up the President's thoughts and returning them to him. "It's genocide in a way," Mr. Frost says of the reported ravaging of Kuwait, and the President does not demur. The closest Mr. Frost comes to an adversarial note is in a few questions about Washington's new amity with Damascus, when he asks whether the United States is now treating Hafez al-Assad, the Syrian President, as it recently treated Mr. Hussein, on the principle that the enemy of our enemy is our friend. Mr. Bush says he had "a good talk" with Mr. Assad in Geneva and emphasizes their "common ground."
After a brief intermission, during which Barbara Bush accepts Mr. Frost's invitation to deliver a commercial for her husband's concern about race relations and her own efforts on behalf of literacy and AIDS patients, the President is back, and the conversation turns to the Administration's record on such advertised priorities as education, crime and drugs. "It's going all right, it's going all right," says Mr. Bush; Mr. Frost goes onto the next question.
The President predicts that the recession, if one wishes to use so definite a term, will be mild and the country will come out of it "in not too many months." He reminds Mr. Frost of the 1981 economic downturn, from which the nation recovered "and everybody lived happily ever after."
 Mr. Frost daringly asks whether the President's hope for a kinder, gentler nation is not contradicted by his opposition to new taxes for social programs. The President reiterates his confidence that economic growth, not Federal spending, is the key, despite the demands of "the political left."
The hour ends with George and Barbara Bush together, agreeing on the importance of family and faith. They make a comfortable couple. "What does prayer give you both?" Mr. Frost asks, as though he were trying to be Bill Moyers. Mr. Bush says it gives strength, and reveals that Mrs. Bush prays while lying in bed and not on her knees. The camera moves away on a note of mild inspiration and deep contentment.

SECTION: Section A; Page 17; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
To Fight in the Gulf?

BYLINE: By Leslie H. Gelb

 BODY:
In April 1954, President Eisenhower told the French he would launch air strikes against Vietnamese Communist troops surrounding French forces at Dien Bien Phu only if two key conditions were met: that U.S. intervention had to be part of a strong international coalition, and that Congress had to support the action.
 Ike may have made the conditions tough in the correct expectation that they would not be met. But he understood that a President does not jump into a black hole without extensive international backing and a unified nation.
 
 In other words, Ike was following an essential rule of politics and good sense when a decision concerns lives and enormous costs -- and saying it depends.
 It is not clear that President Bush understands this. He is content merely to recite the reasons for using force against a tyrant like Saddam Hussein: his record of brutal aggression, his use of chemical weapons and pursuit of nuclear weapons and his fist thrust against the oil thorax of the world's economy. And he is right on the fundamental issue: If war is not justifiable here, then where?
 But to grant that a war against Iraq would be just does not justify actually going to war. Even just wars must be measured by their costs and consequences. It depends.
 In the first instance, it depends on the alternatives. The only realistic one is economic sanctions. But its advocates cannot convincingly show that Iraq will crack before the alliance crumbles; and its opponents cannot make the opposite case persuasively. We're all guessing -- George Mitchell, George Bush, you, me.
 To me, the argument unfortunately turns on one critical factor: the 1992 Presidential election. Sanctions advocates concede that the squeeze will take at least one year to approach full effect.
 But waiting one year really means delaying two years, since Saddam Hussein will use the explosive mix of international crisis and Presidential politics to handcuff George Bush militarily the way Hanoi stymied Lyndon Johnson in 1968 and Ayatollah Khomeini neutered Jimmy Carter in 1980.
By 1992 Mr. Bush will no longer be able to credibly threaten employing force. And with the threat to Saddam Hussein's regime removed, some of our allies will have to snuggle up to their entrenched neighbor as before.
 Yet even with these defects, sanctions cannot be dismissed without looking at the costs and risks of war.
 To begin with, as Ike knew in 1954, war should depend on a far larger commitment by our allies of troops and money. The present distribution of risks and pain is outrageously unfair.
 Mr. Bush cannot allow the Saudis to make a windfall oil profit of about $4 billion monthly while we defend them, their unlikely denials of this notwithstanding. Nor should we have forgiven the $7 billion Egyptian debt in return for some 25,000 troops. Japan, Germany and France ought to be ashamed of their efforts; and they are not ashamed.
 What's more, the Saudis, French and Egyptians have to participate in all military operations, including especially the bombing of Iraq. A reckoning will come for scorching that country, and America and Britain cannot be left alone to absorb the hatred.
 Saying yes to war should also depend on Mr. Bush holding down casualties. The Pentagon insists on massive land, sea and air attacks. But it is far from clear why offensive action cannot be limited to air attacks, and ground action restricted to defense. Given the open desert terrain, air power should be able to sever resupply of Iraqi troops in Kuwait and starve them out. And to temper Arab hostility after the bloodshed, Washington must not target Iraqi civilians.
In addition, Mr. Bush, like Ike, should seek the blessing of Congress. More than one million armed personnel with the most modern weapons will be poised to do battle. This is not a police action like Panama or Grenada; it could become a mini-world war.
 At worst, Congress would say not now, continue sanctions. This would be very damaging, but not as bad as making war without Congress. My guess, however, is that if Congress were reassured about costs and consequences, it would give Mr. Bush as much authority to fight as the U.N. has.
 He would thus gain what he and his aides fear he lacks most -- credibility with Saddam Hussein. A declaration of war, or its equivalent, is the best way to shock Iraq into submission without fighting, and if shock should fail, to fight.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
