HEADLINE: Economists Say New Jersey Can Weather the Recession

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
As the metropolitan region slips into recession, New Jersey appears better positioned to weather an economic slowdown than other states in the Northeast, economists say.
But the end of years of euphoric growth in 1990, combined with sharp tax increases imposed by Gov. Jim Florio, have created a bitter political environment that restricts the options of Mr. Florio and other Democrats in leading the state through more difficult times. 
 In the next few weeks Mr. Florio and the Democratic leadership must confront a series of vexing problems: cutting state government departments and laying off thousands of workers, solving a major financing crisis for hospitals and revising a complex school-aid formula to win back the support of alienated middle-income homeowners.
 
Unemployment Up to 5.5%
 "We expect the economy to do reasonably well compared with other states," said Steven Hochman, the vice president and assistant director of state ratings at Moody's investors service. But he added, "One thing we are interested in is how this political process eventually works itself out."
Like the rest of the Northeast, New Jersey in 1990 saw job growth drop and real-estate prices plummet. And a state of suburban homeowners suddenly realized that owning a home no longer meant they were growing richer without saving.
The state's unemployment rate, which had dropped to less than 3.8 percent in 1988, rose to 5.5 percent by November. The growth of new jobs, which averaged nearly 100,000 a year in the mid-1980's, is now predicted by the State Labor Department to grow by about 20,000 a year in the 1990's.
According to an econometric model of the New Jersey economy developed by the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University, the state will have a moderate recession in 1991, with an unemployment rate reaching 6.4 percent and recovery beginning in 1992. The model assumes no jarring, unpredictable events, like war in the Middle East, which could throw the nation into a severe recession.
But despite the dreary prospects for 1991, economists say the New Jersey economy is better structured to weather the recession than many states.
 
A Wide Range of Industries
 In the 1970's New Jersey suffered the decline of aging manufacturing industries and high unemployment. But over the last decade the state found prosperity in a wide range of industries, including chemicals, pharmaceuticals, communications, health care and legal and other services.
The severe downturns in the financial, real-estate and construction industries, although damaging to New Jersey, are not expected to be as devastating as they have been to New York City and Massachusetts. Their economies were far more dependent on real-estate and financial services during the 1980's. And unemployment is not expected to reach levels in New Jersey that it did before the 1980's boom.
Although the New Jersey government still faces severe revenue shortfalls and cutbacks, fiscal experts say the tax increases pushed through the Legislature last year by Governor Florio generally make New Jersey's fiscal problems more manageable than those in New York and Connecticut.
In the longer term, economists say, the state has a highly educated work force, a generally well-maintained transportation system and a location well suited to benefit from increased trade with Europe, all of which should attract moderate growth in the next decade.
 
The Wager Had Failed
 "The state's economy has some underlying bedrock," said James W. Hughes, a professor of Urban Planning at Rutgers University. "The embellishments just won't be there."
Last spring, Governor Florio decided to confront a growing budget shortfall and problems with financing education with a $2.8 billion tax rise. It was a risky wager that the public would eventually laud him for being decisive. But by November it appeared that the wager had failed dramatically.
The Governor's decision to raise taxes just as the state was starting to tip into recession sent his poll ratings and public attitudes about the future into a tailspin. Several polls have shown that only about one in five voters approve of their Governor. In one poll, conducted by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers in late September, 74 percent of New Jerseyans polled said the state "had pretty seriously gotten off on the wrong track." The poll, of 800 residents, had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.
So closely is Mr. Florio associated with the onset of dire news that critics say he is at risk in 1991 of becoming "the Velcro Governor," to whom bad news sticks even if it is not of his making.
 
Predisposed Not to Believe
 This week, for instance, many taxpayers will suffer increases in both New Jersey and Federal income taxes, a distinction that may be lost on people who know only that they are taking less money home.
"The Governor and the Democratic leadership are going to spend this year trying to restore their credibility," said Senator William Gormley, Republican of Atlantic County. "Whatever he says at this point, people are predisposed not to believe."
A plan being hammered out by the Florio administration and representatives of John Lynch, the Democratic president of the Senate, would restructure Mr. Florio's school-aid program.
Although the details are still not settled, officials familiar with the discussions say they are focused on a new mechanism to shift hundreds of millions of dollars originally designated for poorer school districts to middle-income suburban municipalities. The plan under discussion would also include tighter caps on what school districts can spend and a freeze for two years on a controversial shift of pension costs from the state to local school districts. The overall effect, legislators say, would be to keep homeowners' property taxes from rising.
 
Reducing the Work Force
 The Florio administration is also planning hundreds of millions of dollars in public-works projects that should create tens of thousands of construction jobs at a time the construction industry is suffering heavily.
Since raising taxes has become a politically impossible alternative, the administration is now drawing up plans to contend with a more than $600 million shortfall by laying off state workers -- one official estimates 4,000 -- and by reducing the work force by several thousand more through early retirements and attrition. The cutbacks, which may include the merging of some departments, are expected to be announced in the next month.
Also in the next month, the Democrats are expected to demonstrate their new commitment to realpolitik by refusing to renew a fund that pays hospitals for caring for the uninsured, thereby letting hospitals approach the brink of crisis.
Originally, Governor Florio's health experts had proposed a new tax on employers as the best solution. But in the current environment, Democrats in the Assembly and the Governor's office agreed to let the fund lapse yesterday so that leaders in the health-care field would be forced to step forward with solutions. In the end, the hospital crisis will be solved, the Democrats say, but in 1991 it will not be them and them alone who take responsibility for the bad news.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 3, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a chart yesterday with an article about the New Jersey economy misstated the state's annual unemployment rate for 1990 in some editions. The rate, calculated for the first 11 months of the year, was 4.9 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Vice Chairman Named Midlantic Bank Chief

BYLINE: By Eben Shapiro

 BODY:
The Midlantic Corporation has named Desmond P. McDonald president and chief executive of its lead bank, the Midlantic National Bank.
Mr. McDonald, who is 63 years old, has replaced Robert Van Buren, the chairman and chief executive of the parent company, who has relinquished his titles at the bank to concentrate on the parent company. 
 Mr. McDonald continues to serve as vice chairman and a director of the parent company. In its announcement last week, the company described the shift as a long-planned change in senior management.
Mr. McDonald was born and educated in Carlow, Ireland. He came to the United States in 1953 and joined the National Newark and Essex Bank, a predecessor of Midlantic National. He is a graduate of the school of consumer banking at the University of Virginia. He and his wife, Margaret, live in Essex Fells, N.J.
Midlantic, a regional interstate bank holding company based in Edison, N.J., has assets of more than $24 billion. It has been hurt by the economic downturn in the Northeast and the problems in the real estate sector in particular. The company has recently taken a number of steps to reduce operating costs, including omitting its dividend payment, freezing hiring and curtailing most bonus payments.
The corporation operates 512 offices, mostly in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and New York. Midlantic National has $9 billion in assets. The parent is the 31st-largest banking company in the country, and the second-largest in New Jersey, following the First Fidelity Bancorporation.
The company lost $159 million in its third quarter, which ended Sept. 30. It also posted a large loss in the second quarter of 1990 after adding significantly to its reserves to provide for declining real estate values in New Jersey.
The company sold its credit card portfolio and other assets to offset the additions to its loan-loss reserves. The Standard & Poor's Corporation said that although Midlantic was well capitalized, its exposure to risky real estate loans was substantial.
Mr. Van Buren has said that the company will have a profit in the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
It Wasn't a Good Year for Dividends

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Big banks caught the most attention for slashing dividends last year, but they were not alone.
Figures released by Standard & Poor's yesterday showed that 143 companies decreased their dividends in 1990, while 266 omitted them entirely. Each figure was the highest since 1982, the final year of the last recession, and was up about 40 percent from 1989's level. 
 As is usually the case, many more companies raised dividends than cut them, but there too the trend also emphasized the worsening economic situation. The 1,263 dividend increases announced was the smallest total since 1971, and dropped 24 percent from 1989's level.
Negative dividend actions typically trail bad corporate results, as boards of directors hesitate to send out such graphically bad news until there seems to be no alternative, and the numbers tend to increase in the second year of a recession. If that pattern holds, the dividend picture for this year could be even bleaker.
The heaviest action on dividends usually takes place around year-end, as companies assess their annual results. But in December, only 88 dividend increases were announced, S.&P. said. That figure was down 36 percent from a year before, and was the lowest for any December since 1957. In keeping with the same trend, 32 companies announced dividend omissions in December, the most for any December since 1960.
"The numbers look terrible," said Arnold Kaufman, the editor of S.&P.'s Outlook newsletter, which compiles the figures. But he said he hoped the trend would reverse by mid-1991, when he expects the economy to turn up.
"They come back pretty strongly when it is clear the recession is over," he said. "The companies that were unduly tight-fisted will open up and be willing to increase dividends."
By one measure, dividend actions last year were the worst since S.&P. began compiling statistics on them in 1955. The number of good events -- increases, resumptions of dividend payments and declarations of extra dividends -- totaled 1,687, down 24 percent from 1989. The previous low for that figure was 1,837, in 1971.
The dividend actions recorded by S.&P. come from a universe of more than 7,000 public companies, some of them quite small. But while such large banks as Chase Manhattan and Citicorp have cut their payouts this year, most of the dividend damage occurred among smaller companies.
By one traditional way of looking at dividends, 1990 was not a bad year at all. Preliminary figures released yesterday showed that the dividends on the S.&P. 500 stock index for 1990 were $12.10, up 9.5 percent from 1989. That compared with a 13.6 percent increase in 1989 and was the smallest increase since 1987, but still a healthy one. The S.&P. 500 is dominated by large companies, many of which have done relatively well.
But Mr. Kaufman said that much of that increase could be attributed to dividend increases in mid-1989, for which 1990 was the first full year of payment. He forecasts that this year's increase will decline to about 5 percent.
The current payout rate on the S.&P. 500 -- the dividends that would be paid in a year if all companies in the index maintain their current dividend levels -- is $12.37, up 6.4 percent from a year ago.
It is unusual for the dividends on the S.&P. 500 to decline. That last happened in 1970 and 1971. Even in the recessions of 1974-75 and 1981-82, the S.&P. 500 was able to post small dividend increases. In those recessions, however, inflation was relatively high and the payouts, though an increase in nominal dollars, did not keep pace with inflation. This year, however, inflation is relatively low, which may make it more difficult for companies to maintain payouts if the economy continues to weaken.
One reason that some analysts have hesitated to turn bullish is that the dividend return on stocks is still relatively low. Based on year-end prices and actual annual dividends for the S.&P. 500, the yield on that index was 3.66 percent, much better than the 3.13 percent recorded a year ago, but not high by historical standards. It is only a bit higher than the 3.57 percent at the end of 1987. By contrast, in previous recessions stock prices have bottomed with dividend yields at much higher levels. At the end of 1981, for example, the dividend yield stood at 5.49 percent, while it was 5.23 percent at the end of 1974.
If Mr. Kaufman's forecast of a 5 percent increase in S.&P. dividends this year is accurate, that would raise the payout to $12.71. For the dividend yield to reach the levels of previous recessions, stock prices would have to fall much further. For example, to obtain a 5.23 percent yield with dividends at $12.71, the S.&P. 500 would fall to about 243, or 26 percent below the current figure for the index of 326.45.

HEADLINE: Crude Oil Prices Are Down $1.95, to $26.49

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Oil prices fell nearly $2 yesterday, dipping below $27 a barrel, on speculation that Washington and Baghdad will reach a last-minute diplomatic solution to avoid a war in the Persian Gulf.
Traders said selling was spurred by the news that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d may soon visit the gulf and the refusal of the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, to rule out direct talks between United States officials and Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader. 
 In trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for delivery in February fell $1.95 to close at $26.49 a barrel.
Gasoline and heating oil prices also fell.
"In the back of people's minds is the view Saddam is going to do something in the 11th hour," said Tom Blakeslee, oil industry analyst with Pegasus Econometric.
Iraq faces a United Nations deadline of Jan. 15 to pull out of Kuwait or risk an armed invasion by the United States and its allies.
But traders warned of further volatility ahead in the energy markets.
"One day it feels like peace and one day it's war," one trader said. "There's no way to call this market. It just follows the headlines."
In other trading, heating oil for February delivery tumbled 5.90 cents, to 73.30 cents a gallon, and February gasoline fell 3.26 cents, to 68.10 cents a gallon, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Traders said early selling was spurred by speculation that a peace initiative may emerge from a European Community meeting scheduled for tomorrow.
Price swings were exaggerated by thin volume, they said.
In trading overseas, North Sea Brent crude for February loading closed at $26.90 a barrel on London's International Petroleum Exchange, down $1.37 from Monday's close.
But experts warned the market could turn back up quickly.
"The prevailing sentiment as we get closer to Jan. 15," said Alan Sinclair of Smith New Court, is that "the United Nations will lock horns with Iraq."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Fall on Reports Of Mideast Peace Initiatives

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Reports that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d could meet soon with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq caused gold prices to drop yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange.
Talk that President Bush might be willing to negotiate helped push gold prices lower, said Frederick Demler, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc. in New York. The possibility of decreased tensions put pressure on crude oil prices, with the February crude oil contract falling $1.95 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, which in turn depressed gold futures. 
 There was also some profit taking, as traders took advantage of a recent run-up in prices to bail out of the market, Mr. Demler said.
Further weakness in the economy also had an impact on the markets. Mr. Demler pointed to a survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management that found the nation's economy had declined in December for the third consecutive month. The survey is considered a sensitive barometer of the economy's direction.
Gold settled $5.10 to $6.30 lower, with the active contract for delivery in February at $391.10 an ounce. The January contract fell $5.10, to $389.10. Silver was 7.8 cents to 8.9 cents lower, with January at $4.114 an ounce.
 
Grain and Soybeans Drop
 In other commodity markets, grain and soybean futures closed lower in quiet trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. "There was a negative attitude in the market because of the lack of demand for U.S. goods," said Dan Cekander, an analyst with Rodman & Renshaw Inc. in Chicago.
Soybean futures reached contract lows in the face of continued sluggish export demand. Also weighing on the market are perceptions that Brazilian and Argentine soybean crops are off to a good start because of favorable weather.
Wheat prices were relatively stable on word that China has entered the market for 600,000 metric tons. Corn futures were lower on slim export sales and expectations that farmers will increase the marketing of corn.
Heavy selling pushed sugar futures to life-of-contract lows on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange. "The selloff was largely technical in nature, with nothing outside the ordinary" to account for this, said Harry Schwartz, an analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc. in New York.
Livestock and pork futures were lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Opens '91 With Drop; War Fears Limit the Loss

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Grim economic news sent the dollar stumbling yesterday, but traders said that concerns about war in the Persian Gulf helped to minimize the drop.
Currency trading in the year's first session was unexpectedly light, apparently because of a hesitation to take new positions in the days before the United Nation's Jan. 15 deadline for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. 
 Markets were closed Tuesday in observance of New Year's Day.
"If it wasn't for the Middle East, the dollar would be much lower now," said Thomas J. Palladino, a currency trader in New York for Oesterreichische Landerbank of Austria. "Nobody's going to look to go short dollars with the deadline approaching."
The resolution passed by the United Nations Security Council last fall clears the way for a military attack if Iraq does not leave Kuwait by the middle of this month.
Because the dollar is considered a safe-harbor investment in times of war, the currency was partly insulated yesterday against several signs of a slumping United States economy. They included a lowering of the prime lending rate by leading American banks, a drop in nationwide construction spending and a decline in a survey of purchasing managers to the lowest level since the last recession. All pointed to lower interest rates in the United States, which makes the dollar less attractive relative to other currencies.
The dollar rallied briefly in the morning on reports that Eduard A. Shevardnadze said he had resigned as Soviet Foreign Minister because he feared bloody violence in his country. Traders interpreted the news as a sign of instability that could undermine neighboring economies.
Other than that, though, "today was strangely quiet," said Walter Simon, a vice president for Bank Julius Baer & Company "You are seeing a kind of December market where no one is putting aggressive moves before the deadline."
The dollar fell to a closing 134.30 Japanese yen in New York from Monday's closing 135.30 yen. In Europe, the dollar fell to 134.35 Japanese yen, from 135.40 yen at the close of trading Monday in Tokyo. The Tokyo markets remained closed yesterday.
In New York, the pound strengthened against the dollar. Sterling fetched $1.9445, compared with $1.9345 late Monday. In London, the pound was quoted at $1.9420, up from $1.9280 late Monday.
Other late American dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.4872 German marks, down from 1.4885; 1.2613 Swiss francs, down from 1.2668; 5.0635 French francs, down from 5.0685; 1,112.00 Italian lire, down from 1,122.75, and 1.1555 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1599.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Control Data Sells A Chip Factory

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2

 BODY:
The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation said it had purchased an advanced semiconductor manufacturing plant from the Control Data Corporation for $14.7 million.
T.J. Rodgers, chief executive of Cypress, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said his company was able to buy the "gold plated" factory at a bargain price and had hired 75 of the employees that work there. He said the factory, in Bloomington, Minn., cost $60 million to build and was used, among other things, to produce chips for the National Security Agency, the Government's code-breaking organization. Control Data had previously said it would leave the semiconductor business.

HEADLINE: White House Advisers Agree on Fed Nominee

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
President Bush's top economic advisers, resolving a months-long disagreement, have recommended that the President nominate Lawrence B. Lindsey, a conservative economist on the White House staff, to the vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board, Administration officials said today.
The officials said Mr. Bush had also been advised to promote David W. Mullins, whom he placed on the board last year, to be vice chairman of the Fed. 
 The vacancies occurred when the vice chairman, Manuel H. Johnson, resigned in August. The changes do not suggest any change in Fed policy is in the offing.
At the White House today, Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, did not deny the probable changes at the Federal Reserve but said, "We don't have a nominee to announce yet."
Because it controls the money supply and to some extent interest rates, the Federal Reserve has more influence over the economy than any other part of the Government. That is especially true now because the large budget deficit means that the President and Congress cannot afford to reduce taxes or increase Government spending, the fiscal weapons have sometimes been used to fight recessions.
 
A Harvard Professor
 Mr. Lindsey, who is 36 years old, was a professor of economics at Harvard before he joined the White House staff last year as a deputy assistant to the President for economic and domestic policy. He is most prominent in professional circles as an outspoken advocate of supply-side economics -- espousing the view that low taxes encourage people and businesses to work, save and invest and that they are the best medicine for the economy.
His book, "The Growth Experiment," which was published last year, lauds the tax cuts of the Reagan Administration and argues for a further cut in tax rates.
The Federal Reserve is not involved in tax policy, and Mr. Lindsey's views on monetary policy, the main purview of the Fed, are not well known. But other economists in the Administration who have talked with him say that he taught general economics courses at Harvard and that he is comfortable with monetary policy, even though it is not his main field of expertise.
The likelihood of Mr. Lindsey's nomination and Mr. Mullins's promotion was first reported this week by the syndicated columnists Rowland Evans and Robert Novak.
 
Executives Interviewed
 Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady had originally hoped the President would put someone with experience in business on the Federal Reserve Board, Administration officials said, and several business executives were interviewed for the job. But the officials said Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, preferred an economist, while John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, was most interested in picking a person with conservative credentials.
The selection of Mr. Lindsey, whose nomination would be subject to confirmation by Congress, would clearly satisfy Mr. Boskin, Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Sununu. The promotion of Mr. Mullins, who was an Assistant Treasury Secretary and a Brady favorite before he was named to the Fed, was said to please Mr. Brady.
The Treasury Secretary harbored "some concern that the person should have some real world business experience," one of his aides said. But "there was no adversarial issue here," the aide continued, and Mr. Brady is happy with the outcome.
The promotion of Mr. Mullins does not suggest that he will become chairman of the Federal Reserve Board; no vice chairman ever has. As a rule, the Fed chairman dominates the other six members of the Board.
Mr. Greenspan's term as chairman expires this summer. Presumably he wants to be reappointed for another four years, although he has been careful not to say so, and the White House has given no hint one way or another whether it would like him to stay on the job.
The prevailing view is that Mr. Greenspan's future depends in large part on the state of the economy this summer. If the recession turns out to be shallow, and a recovery has begun, a reappointment is likely. On the other hand if the economy is still mired in recession, Mr. Greenspan might be a scapegoat.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lawrence B. Lindsey, an economist on the White House staff, was recommended for the vacant Federal Reserve Board seat. (Laura Wulf/Harvard University)

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Decline by 19.1% in Midmonth

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Sales of cars and trucks made in the United States fell by 19.1 percent in mid-December, as demand for vehicles sank to the lowest level since 1982.
"It takes two to three months for a collapse in real income to hit home in the auto sector, and that is what we are seeing," Scott Merlis, an automotive analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, said today. 
 Tom Webb, the chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, a industry group in McLean, Va., said the sales plunge was "worse than I expected." He linked the drop in vehicle sales to the nation's depressed real estate markets, which he said have eroded personal wealth and caused consumers to postpone purchases of new vehicles.
 
More Factory Closings Seen
 If the slump in car sales persists into the spring, as many analysts believe, the result will be a depressing effect on the economy, "because it means more pressure to lower inventories by keeping factories closed," Mr. Merlis said.
The major domestic automobile makers have resorted to widespread plant shutdowns to keep inventories from ballooning.
The 10 manufacturers that produce vehicles in the United States said today that they sold 206,983 vehicles from Dec. 11-20, compared with 255,757 in the corresponding period a year earlier.
Car sales fell by 17.7 percent, to 127,933 cars in mid-December. Seasonally adjusted, cars sold at an annual rate of 5.1 million, representing the lowest level of demand since 1982, compared with an annual rate of 6.5 million during the same period in 1989. The annual rate for the last 30 days was 5.6 million. Through the middle of last year, cars have sold at an average annual rate of about 6.9 million.
Sales of light trucks, which account for about a third of all vehicles sold, declined to 79,050 pickups, mini-vans and four-wheel-drive vehicles, a drop of 21.2 percent.
 
A Broad Decline
 The mid-December downturn in sales was broad, affecting American as well as foreign-based auto makers with plants in the United States. Sales of small models were just as depressed as those of large ones.
The Big Three domestic auto makers reported a collective decline of 20.6 percent, with light trucks faring slightly worse than cars.
The Japanese car companies with American plants showed overall sales declines of 9.9 percent for cars, while those of light trucks rose by 51.9 percent, reflecting increased production.
The Toyota Motor Corporation, the only foreign auto maker to report sales of imported vehicles every 10 days, posted a decline of 8.5 percent in sales of its imported cars, and showed a drop of 2.7 percent in imported truck sales. Other foreign auto makers report such sales figures at the end of the month.
Sales of cars made at Toyota's two American factories, in Georgetown, Ky., and in the venture with the General Motors Corporation in Fremont, Calif., fell by 10.6 percent, to 6,270 cars.
 
G.M. Sales Fall 18%
 General Motors sold 59,978 cars made in the United States and Canada, down by 18 percent from a year earlier. Among its stronger sellers were Chevrolet's Geo Metro, G.M.'s most fuel-efficient car; its full-size Park Avenue, intermediate Regal and compact Skylark, all sold by Buick, and the Pontiac Grand Prix.
G.M. also posted weak sales of several models that have sold relatively well earlier in the year, including the Geo Prizm, Chevrolet Lumina and Cutlass Supreme.
The luxury tax that took effect on Tuesday, imposing a 10 percent surcharge on the portion of retail prices exceeding $30,000 for cars, apparently did little to enhance sales of G.M.'s Cadillac cars. The division reported an overall sales decline of 23.7 percent for its five models. The Ford Motor Company reported higher sales of its Lincoln Town Car in mid-December, but analysts suggested the gain reflected higher fleet sales rather than private retail customers.
Ford sold 32,364 cars in the 10-day period, a decline of 20.5 percent. The auto maker also posted sharp declines in sales of its Tempo and Festiva models, and sales of the Taurus and Mercury Sable also fell sharply.
Ford's light-truck sales fell by 21.4 percent, to 25,582.
 
Chrysler Off 19.2%
 The Chrysler Corporation's car sales declined by 19.2 percent, to 16,278. The sales of Chrysler mini-vans, Jeeps and pickup trucks plunged by 36.9 percent, to 16,000.
Two weeks ago, the No. 3 domestic auto maker said it planned to offer rebates on its 1991 model mini-vans for the first time, a move that some analysts regarded as a concession that sales of Chrysler's most important single vehicle were slipping.
The Honda Motor Company sold 6,384 cars in mid-December, down by 43.2 percent. A Honda spokesman attributed the slump to "consumer uncertainties and concerns about the Middle East."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
For Muscovites And Gothamites, Shared Insights

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
It's a one-party town. Party bosses dictated the choice of the City Council leader. Just once in his five-year tenure was legislation passed that he had strongly opposed personally -- a human-rights bill -- and only after he deigned to allow a vote. The Council's elected president is largely a figurehead.
The Moscow City Council? No, Moscow on the Hudson. 
 New York City's emboldened legislature is only slowly emerging from its authoritarian tradition since last year, when a revised City Charter abolished the City Board of Estimate. The Soviet Union, meanwhile, all but abolished its underlying approach to government; changes wrought by the newly elected government of its capital city have been nothing short of revolutionary. Yet, all politics being local, Moscow hopes to learn from New York.
Last month, Ronnie M. Eldridge, a City Council member from Manhattan, was invited to confer there with her Soviet counterparts. Soviet local officials visited New York. And Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York was interviewed on the radio with Yuri Luzhkov, a Moscow Council official.
Both local legislatures are gaining power, although Moscow's seems infused with enough naivete or idealism so that some legislators would grant Muscovites the power to recall Council members (under the misguided presumption that it would never be invoked against the enlightened incumbents who proposed it).
Moscow's fledgling democrats constitute a majority, but only when they coalesce. Otherwise, they are consumed by bickering over procedure or previous political ties. Pavel Zhukov, a 32-year-old member of a Christian Democratic faction, complained the other day that many former Communists have re-emerged as Republicans -- "a strange name," Mr. Zhukov suggested, "because they are more socialist than Republican."
Insurgents in both councils, quickly grasping that talk is cheap, are struggling to transform speeches into concrete gestures that voters can appreciate, whether in responding to the shortage of cigarettes in Moscow or the abundance of cigarette smoke in New York.
 The political evolution in Moscow was likened to the early days of New York's Democratic reform movement by Ms. Eldridge, who offered an incisive impression of modern Soviet society: "It reminded me," she lamented, "of the Department of Motor Vehicles."
 New York's Council is growing, to 51 from 35 members. ("In three to five years, you're not going to know this place," its spokeswoman, Peg Breen, said yesterday, implying more quality than quantity.)
But Ms. Eldridge advised the unwieldy Moscow Council to contract, from its nearly 500 members. Also, to remember that seemingly arcane bills are better read than unread. And to differentiate between visionary proposals for parceling out road repairs to private contractors that have earned Moscow's Council a reputation for daring, and the illusion of power -- selectively erasing the Communist legacy by changing street names (new nomenclature, backed by community boards, accounted for more than 4 in 10 local laws approved by New York's Council last year) and venturing into foreign policy (a petition circulated in the Moscow Council proclaimed that Li Peng, the Chinese Prime Minister, was unwelcome).
"That democrats are in power does not at all mean that they wield any power," said Gavriil K. Popov, the Moscow Mayor.
With Mr. Popov ailing, Mr. Dinkins was joined by Mr. Luzhkov on last month's radio program, in which they expressed camaraderie, shared frustrations and lobbied for more help from their national governments. Mr. Dinkins expressed hope that the urban compact adopted by the gathering of United States mayors he convened last fall could be discussed with President Bush before he confers next month with the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. "I hope we get to see our President before yours does," Mr. Dinkins said.
New York and Moscow share many urban problems, Mr. Luzhkov said, though officials in the Soviet capital are scrambling to supply food and housing to citizens whose basic needs may have seemed less pressing before their votes became more coveted.
That Councilman Zhukov and his 54-year-old Republican colleague, Dr. Igor Yeremeyev, stayed at the old New Yorker Hotel in Manhattan, a headquarters for the Unification Church, may help explain Dr. Yeremeyev's observation that New York, in some respects, "seems very well organized." Ever diplomatic, they were noncommittal about just what they might learn from their counterparts at City Hall.
"We will be facing problems with the unemployed and the poor," said Mr. Zhukov, an intense former scientist. "The problems of New York are our future problems."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
In Rhode Island, there was anger and frustration at the closing of 45 credit unions, banks and investment companies. The Governor said 7 would reopen on Monday. [Page A1.]
More than 1,400 credit unions with $18.6 billion of deposits in more than half the states have their own insurance programs. [D4.]
Federal regulators said many of the 45 closed Rhode Island institutions were were too weak to be eligible for Federal deposit insurance. [D4.]
The nation's largest banks lowered their prime rate to 9 1/2 percent. It was their first drop in nearly a year. [D1.]
The country is in a recession, the White House acknowledged for the first time. It was a judgment reached weeks, if not months, ago by most private economists. [D1.]
For the vacant Fed seat, Bush's top economic advisers have reportedly recommended that the President nominate Lawrence B. Lindsey, a conservative economist on the White House staff. [D2.]
The energy industry expects to increase worldwide spending to find and produce oil and natural gas by nearly 14 percent this year, a survey shows. [D3.]
The 1988 sales by Federal regulators of failed savings and loans were flawed by an unfair competitive process, according to a new study ordered by Congress. [D4.]
Purchasers' index of economic activity fell to 40.4 percent in December from 41.3 percent in November. It was the weakest showing since November 1982. [D8.]
Construction spending fell by 0.6 percent in November to its lowest level in two years, the Commerce Department said. [D8.]
Sales of vehicles made in the U.S. fell by 19.1 percent in mid-December, as demand sank to the lowest level since 1982. [D8.]
 
Companies
U.S. chip makers gained market share in 1990 at the expense of the Japanese, for the first time in more than a decade. [D1.]
St. Martin's Press said it would not exhibit at the American Booksellers Association convention in New York in June because of the high cost. [D5.]
A dissident Hollywood Park shareholder said he had won a proxy fight to oust the company's board, but the race track concern said his claim was premature. [D3.]
 
Markets
Oil prices fell nearly $2, dipping to $26.49 a barrel, on speculation that Washington and Baghdad will reach a last-minute diplomatic solution. [D3.]
Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply and interest rates fell after a flurry of negative economic reports. [D6.]
Stocks sagged broadly despite a jump in bond prices and a drop in oil prices. The Dow lost 23.02, to 2,610.64. [D8.]
Grim economic news sent the dollar stumbling, but traders said war concerns lessened the drop. [D14.] Gold prices fell. [D14.]
 
Today's Columns
Big banks caught the most attention for slashing dividends last year, but they were not alone. Figures show that 143 companies decreased their dividends. while 266 omitted them entirely. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
The excesses of the takeover years may be coming back to haunt Wall Street and investors in a new way: Firms and stockholders that profited from buyouts that subsequently failed could be forced to give their money back. Talking Deals. [D1.]
Turning packages into elaborate ads may be the best way for many marketers, especially those with limited budgets, to stand out in the clutter of advertising in supermarkets. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D5.]

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money-Fund Yields Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
For the week ended yesterday, yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report were up for the first time in six weeks, as a result of year-end pressures on short-term interest rates.
Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's said the widespread cuts in the prime rate by banks yesterday showed that the Federal Reserve Bank's efforts to reduce short-term interest rates were finally taking hold. 
 In the next few weeks, as short-term interest rates fall, yields offered by money market funds, which generally fall more slowly than other money market investments, will look more attractive, analysts said.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist at Donoghue's, said that until the bottom of this economic downturn was evident, the pressure would be on the Fed to continue easing credit. He also cautioned investors about how they interpret the drop in short-term rates in January. "Part will be real, and part a return to normalcy after seasonal year-end pressures tightened credit," he said.
In tax-exempt money funds, the average number of days that securities are held in portfolios fell by 2, to 53 days. Assets declined by $2 billion, to $83.5 billion.
The average seven-day tax-exempt compounded yield was up sharply for the week, reflecting an abundant supply of municipal securities and little demand from investors. The average was 6.41 percent, up 59 basis points. For the 30-day compounded average yield, the increase was 24 basis points, to 5.81 percent.
The current seven-day tax-exempt yield is equivalent to 8.90 percent for investors in the 28 percent Federal tax bracket, and 9.56 percent for investors in the 33 percent bracket.
Among tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million that are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Michigan Daily Tax-Free Income fund produced the best return, at 7.84 percent. The fund is managed by Reich & Tang L.P., New York City.
Assets on taxable funds fell a sharp $9 billion, to $409 billion, with institutional funds down by $5.4 billion, to $90.8 billion, and consumer funds down by $4.3 billion, to $318.7 billion.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield rose by 23 basis points, to 7.65 percent, while the 30-day rose by 4 basis points, to 7.51 percent.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, which compete with the funds as reported by The Bank Rate Monitor's national index, are down by a basis point, to 5.90 percent, and six-month certificates of deposit fell by 5 basis points to 7.21 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
St. Martin's to Miss Big Convention

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
In a break with publishing tradition, St. Martin's Press said yesterday that it and its subsidiary Tor Books would not exhibit at the American Booksellers Association convention in New York in June because of the high cost of doing so.
In addition, a number of publishers whose books are distributed by St. Martin's said they agreed with the decision and also would not exhibit. They include J. P. Tarcher, Rodale Press and Pharos Books. 
 St. Martin's, which last year had two big best sellers -- "September," by Rosamunde Pilcher and "By Way of Deception," by Victor Ostrovsky and Claire Hoy -- will be the first large publishing house to pull out of the annual convention since Avon Books did so in 1982, before returning the next year.
 
Association Is Disappointed
 Bernard Rath, the executive director of the association, expressed disappointment at St. Martin's decision. "Certainly, every publisher has the right to determine how they wish to spend their marketing dollars, and I respect St. Martin's decision to experiment with spending theirs in other ways," he said. "In the past, when people have chosen to bypass the A.B.A. convention, they have generally found that the loss in exposure for their titles and authors was significant to return in future years."
The association recently predicted that attendance at the four-day convention, scheduled for the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center from June 1 to 4, could surpass the previous record of 25,589 participants in 1988, when it was held in Anaheim, Calif.
And association officials said the sale of exhibition booths is running ahead of last year at this time, with only about 100 of the 2,550 booths available still unsold. All 170 booths in the small-press section, for instance, have already been sold.
Thomas McCormack, the chairman of St. Martin's, which is based in New York, said he regretted having to make the decision. "But we've been thinking about it for a couple of years," he added. "We sent 55 people to the convention in Las Vegas last year, and it cost us $250,000, and we sent 65 people to the convention in Washington the year before. Even though it might cost less this year in our own backyard, you're still looking at a handsome six-figure cost because you have to fly in sales reps from around the country and put them up in hotels."
 
Looking for Cutbacks
 Publishers have long lamented the cost of attending the four-day convention each spring, at which books scheduled for publication in the fall are displayed for booksellers from around the nation. In recent years, publishing houses have tried to economize by cutting back on the number of people in attendance and taking fewer booths than usual.
Last year, St. Martin's, which is owned by Macmillan Publishers Ltd. of Britain, took about 30 booths at the convention.
But the same publishers who complain that not enough individual booksellers attend the convention have also concluded that exhibiting at the convention buys good will and thus is a necessary cost of doing business. Just about every head of a publishing house attends part of the convention.
When Avon withdrew, it did so at a time when it was embroiled in a lawsuit with the Northern California Booksellers Association. Avon's president then felt that the national association was partial to the California group. But Avon returned the next year and has exhibited each year since.
 
Reason for Withdrawal
 Mr. McCormack said his decision to withdraw was unrelated to St. Martin's assigned booth location -- locations are determined months ahead by lottery -- or by the recession.
"I can honestly tell you that 1990 was by far the most profitable and successful for the company during my 20 years here, and our 1991 projections are for another good year," he said. "We're just looking for cost-effective ways of using the money that now goes to airlines and hotels to sell more books."

HEADLINE: The White House Agrees: It's a Recession

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
The White House today acknowledged for the first time that the country is in a recession, a judgment reached weeks, if not months, ago by most private economists.
In a television interview this morning, Michael J. Boskin, chairman of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, said, "It does appear that after the longest economic expansion in the peacetime history of the United States, the country probably has entered a recession." 
 In another interview later, Mr. Boskin left no doubt that he believed the country was in a recession and that he had intended to convey that message on the television broadcast.
Until now, the top figures in the Bush Administration had used words like "lull," "slowdown" and "downturn" to describe the state of the economy but had avoided the word "recession." They have repeatedly maintained that the problems would soon be over and that the economy would quickly rebound, a position Mr. Boskin held to today.
Mr. Boskin's comments came amid a spate of negative economic reports. The nation's manufacturing economy declined in December, to its lowest point since the recession of 1982, a survey of purchasing managers found. Construction spending fell six-tenths of a percent in November to its lowest level in two years, the Commerce Department reported. And sales of cars and trucks made in the United States fell 19.1 percent in mid-December, as demand for vehicles sank to the lowest level since 1982. [Page D8.]
With the flurry of negative reports and a 4.18-point drop in the Commodity Research Bureau index, the prices of Treasury securities rose sharply and interest rates fell. [Page D6.]
President Bush, in an interview with David Frost taped Dec. 16 for broadcast tonight on the Public Broadcasting Service, said some regions were clearly in a recession but that he was not prepared to declare one nationwide. The President also said, "I happen to believe, and I think that most economists believe, that the recession will be mild and that the whole country will come out of it in not too many months from now."
Mr. Bush's view that the recession will not be severe reflects the thinking of Mr. Boskin and others in the Administration but does not suggest significant policy changes.
The data on the severity of the recession are not yet conclusive. Some private economists agree with the Administration. But others cointend that even if oil prices fall soon, the strains in the banking system and the unusually high levels of debt held by companies and individuals presage a long and deep recession.
At the regular White House briefing for reporters today, Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, conceded, "We're in a recessionary kind of period."
Mr. Fitzwater said officials were "reluctant to give some official kind of name for it when it hasn't met all the economists' prerogatives."
But an Administration economist said that Mr. Boskin had decided to speak out and that other top officials would soon follow suit because they did not want to look foolish by denying the obvious.
The popular definition of a recession is two consecutive quarters of contraction in the economy as measured by the gross national product adjusted for inflation. In the most recent quarter for which complete data are available, July through September, the G.N.P., the total output of goods and sevices, grew at an annual rate of 1.4 percent, the Commerce Department reported last month.
 
Preliminary Forecast
 A preliminary forecast by Administration economists in preparation for next fiscal year's budget, estimates that the economy shrank at a 3.4 percent annual rate in the last three months of 1990 and will drop an additional 1.3 percent in the first three months of this year.
Officials who provided those figures, which have not made public but were reported today in The Wall Street Journal, said the official forecast to be prepared late this month would not differ much, unless the Persian Gulf situation changed markedly.
The Dating Committee of the National Bureau of Economic Research, the official arbiter of when recessions begin and end, has not made a formal decision yet, but issued a statement last month that a recession probably began between June and September.
The Administration's preliminary economic forecast is in line with those of many private economists. After shrinking for two quarters, the economy is expected to grow at an annual rate of a paltry three-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter of this year, at a 2 percent rate in the third quarter and a 2.8 percent rate in the fourth quarter.
 
Oil Prices Blamed
 In his interview this morning on the "Today Show" on NBC, Mr. Boskin put most of the blame for the recession on the uncertain military situation in the Persian Gulf and the rise in oil prices after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. He said the recession would be short and mild.
Interviewed later in his office, Mr. Boskin said he expected that the recession would be less serious than other recent ones because the Federal Reserve was pushing down interest rates and because business inventories were not so large.
Lower interest rates should encourage businesses to expand, and lean inventories should mean that businesses will produce more goods.

HEADLINE: U.S. Chips' Gain Is Japan's Loss

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2

 BODY:
For the first time in more than a decade, American semiconductor companies gained market share in 1990 at the expense of their Japanese competitors, a market research company reported today.
The figures, based on sales in dollars, suggest that after years of decline, American computer chip manufacturers might finally have stopped the erosion in their competitiveness, which has become a national concern. However, experts cautioned that the figures could represent not the start of a long-term trend, but an aberration caused by a decline in prices for memory chips, which are made primarily by the Japanese. 
 "It's encouraging, but certainly not a permanent sign of a turnaround," said Andrew A. Procassini, president of the Semiconductor Industry Association, the trade group representing American semiconductor companies.
Others were more encouraged, saying that the American decline was at an end. "I believe we've hit the bottom, I really do," said T. J. Rodgers, chief executive of the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation, a chip manufacturer in San Jose, Calif.
 
A Matter of Concern
 American companies garnered 36.5 percent of the worldwide semiconductor market in 1990, up from 34.9 percent in 1989, according to the figures released by Dataquest Inc., a market research firm in San Jose. That was the first time the American market share has increased since 1979.
Worldwide market share of Japanese companies fell to 49.5 percent, from 52.1 percent in 1989, the first drop since 1982. Over all, worldwide sales of semiconductors in 1990 rose 2 percent, to $58.4 billion, according to Dataquest, whose figures are widely relied upon by the industry and the Government.
In 1979, American companies had 57.9 percent of the world market for computer chips while Japanese companies had 25.8 percent.
The steady erosion of the American position since then has become a matter of concern because semiconductors are considered vital for the nation's economic health and military preparedness. The silicon chips etched with microscopic electronic circuits are the basic building blocks of all electronic machines, including computers, videocassette recorders, robots, missiles and radar systems.
 
'A Change in the Slope'
 The Government has taken a number of actions to help the American chip producers, including an investment in Sematech, a consortium in Austin, Tex., that is developing advanced techniques in chip manufacturing, and the negotiation of a trade agreement in 1986 that aimed to open Japanese markets to American semiconductors and stop the selling of Japanese chips at prices below cost in the United States.
Jerry Banks, director of the semiconductor group at Dataquest, said it was too soon to say the figures represent "a reversal of the tide." However, he said, "we may see a change in the slope," with American declines and Japanese gains in market share coming far more slowly than in the past.
Japanese companies lost market share in 1990 because of the same product that has been responsible for their gains over the last decade -- memory chips.
Japanese companies have come to dominate production of dynamic random access memories, the main type of chip used to store information in computers. But in 1990, prices for D-RAM's fell as Korean producers tried to break into the market while demand for such chips did not grow appreciably, Mr. Banks said.
As a result, overall revenues from D-RAM's fell 30 percent in 1990, hurting the Japanese companies. Mr. Banks said it appeared that pricing pressure on D-RAM's would continue, depriving Japanese companies of a major source of profit.
 
Two Companies Dominate
 By contrast, the American companies made their gains largely on the basis of increased sales of microprocessors, the chips that act as the "brains" of personal computers.
Two companies in particular, the Intel Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., and Motorola Inc. of Schaumburg, Ill., dominate the market for the microprocessors used in personal computers, and neither company is allowing other companies to manufacture their most advanced chips. That minimizes price competition and allows the companies to keep all the revenues from sales of their chips.
Intel rose to become the world's fifth-largest semiconductor company in 1990, up from eighth place in 1989, with its semiconductor revenues growing 29 percent, according to Dataquest. Motorola retained its ranking as the fourth-largest semiconductor company in the world, with its revenues rising 11 percent in 1990.
By contrast, the NEC Corporation, the Toshiba Corporation and Hitachi Ltd., all of Japan, retain their standings as the world's three largest chip producers. Each, however, suffered a decline of about 1 percent in semiconductor revenues.
Another factor that appears to be helping the American companies is that they are selling more chips in Japan, partly as a result of the 1986 semiconductor trade agreement between the United States and Japan.
The Semiconductor Industry Association has said that American market share in Japan climbed to about 13 percent of the Japanese market from about 8.5 percent before the trade agreement was negotiated. However, Dataquest figures show that the market share of American companies in Japan rose only to 10.4 percent in 1990 from just under 10 percent in 1989.
 
Impact of the Yen
 Some experts say the American semiconductor industry still faces grim prospects. Michael Borrus, deputy director of the Berkeley Roundtable on the International Economy at the University of California, said Japanese companies continued to heavily outspend American companies on new plants and equipment and on research and development, meaning they will advance at a faster rate than American companies.
However, others argue that the decline in market share of American companies has been exaggerated because the Dataquest figures do not take into account the strong rise in the yen against the dollar that occurred starting in 1985. Because Japanese companies get most of their revenues in yen, a rise in the yen translates into a gain in revenues as measured in dollars, even if a Japanese company sells the same number of chips.
Mr. Rodgers of Cypress Semiconductor said that if currency exchange rates were held constant, the American market share loss and Japanese gain since 1981 would be about 7 percentage points instead of the 15 percentage points or so commonly reported.
"I think the actual fact is that we have been at par with the Japanese -- nobody gaining or losing ground -- since 1985," he said.
In all, six of the world's 10 largest semiconductor producers are Japanese, three -- including Texas Instruments Inc. of Dallas -- are American and one is European, according to Dataquest. The International Business Machines Corporation, which is one of the largest semiconductor producers in the world, is not counted because it does not sell its chips.

HEADLINE: German Drug Makers Refuse To Lower Prices in the East

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Major drug companies in western Germany are refusing to ship their products to the eastern part of the country because of a clause in the German reunification treaty that says that as of the new year, their products must be sold there for 45 percent of the prices in the western part of the country.
In turn, pharmacists in some parts of eastern Germany closed their shops in a one-day protest against the measure, which called on the drug producers, alone among manufacturers, to effectively subsidize the cost of economic unity by charging less in the region that used to be East Germany. 
 In the state of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, pharmacies in major cities like Schwerin and Rostock remained closed in response to a call by local pharmacists' associations to protest the measure by western German companies like Hoechst and Bayer, which rank among the largest chemical and drug companies in the world.
Spokesmen for the companies said they would refuse to deliver products at reduced prices in the east.
The industry's action comes at an unsettling time for Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who has not yet concluded talks with his Free Democratic partners on forming a new Cabinet.
The new year is expected to test the patience of Germans in the east, who, like other people in Eastern European lands formerly ruled by the Communists, are seeing their hopes and expectations mired in unemployment and insecurity.
Drug prices are a particularly sensitive issue in Germany, since manufacture and distribution is a highly regulated industry and retail price levels tend to be far higher here than in the United States or other European countries. Indeed, some officials argue that the prices foreseen for eastern Germany, even with the 55 percent rebate, are still at a level above wholesale prices the industry charges some of its other European customers.

HEADLINE: MAYOR AND UNIONS AGREE ON 5% RAISE IN NEW YORK PACT;
Cost Is $233 Million

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration and two large municipal unions announced a tentative labor agreement yesterday that would provide 150,000 city workers with a wage and benefit increase of 5 percent over 15 months, less than city teachers are to receive but more than some fiscal experts say the city should pay.
The proposed contract appeared to reflect a decision by the administration or union leaders or both to trade a reduction in the city work force, expected to be outlined later this month by city officials, for higher wages for those who remain. That approach, along with the cost of the proposed new contract -- $233 million -- and its reliance on pension fund savings, came under immediate criticism from some financial experts and politicians. 
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who last week warned that the city's finances were running out of control, did not address the specifics of yesterday's agreement but took the opportunity to "reaffirm" his previous comments.
 
Concern Over Layoffs
 "It's just going to mean more layoffs," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, an independent research organization financed by businesses.
Like the teachers' contract on which it is modeled and which generated a barrage of criticism, the new agreement depends in large part on savings from reduced city contributions to the workers' pension fund, a strategy that could one day add to the city's budget problems if the fund's earnings fail to match the new assumptions.
But at a City Hall news conference, Mayor David N. Dinkins defended the proposed contract, arguing that since it relied on money either already in the budget or on the pension fund savings, it did not increase the size of the spending gaps the city must close in the coming years, which estimates put in the billion-dollar range.
"They're satisfied with it and we're satisfied with it, and it serves our people well," said Mr. Dinkins, who was supported by municipal labor unions during the 1989 election campaign but who since taking office has angered those unions by asserting that layoffs would be necessary to balance the city's books.
The agreements with District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees and Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, along with the teachers' union, would bring to two-thirds the total of the city's work force under new contracts.
As terms of the deal circulated around the city yesterday, several of New York City's fiscal monitors, including Allen Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board, and Elinor B. Bachrach, Deputy State Comptroller for New York City, joined Mr. Horton of the citizens budget group in questioning aspects of the proposed contract, including why the administration was using the pension savings for raises, rather than to keep more workers on the payroll and maintain services.
There were also worries about cutting pension contributions while the performance of financial markets in which pension funds invest is uncertain. And there were questions about how much money a similar maneuver would generate for use in settling contracts for uniformed city employees like firefighters and police officers, who traditionally receive slightly higher raises than other city workers.
At the news conference, Mr. Dinkins, perhaps anticipating more of the criticism that the teachers' contract has generated, asserted that he would freeze the wages of the unions' members for the rest of the 1992 fiscal year after the proposed agreement expired.
 
'All That Could Be Expected'
 But the union leaders, who joined the Mayor yesterday at City Hall, immediately rejected a freeze, saying it would be part of the bargaining next time.
"We extracted from these negotiations all that could be extracted," said Barry Feinstein, head of the teamsters union local. "There was nothing left to take from the table."
The proposed contract would cost the city $232.8 million in the 1991 and 1992 fiscal years. About half of that is already in the city budget, which provides for a 1.5 percent annual raise for city workers; the rest would result from raising earnings assumptions for the workers' pension fund investments to 9 percent from the current 8.25 percent. That would require the city to contribute less money to the fund.
Under the new contract, workers would get a 3.5 percent pay increase in the first year and an additional 1 percent increase at the start of the second. Also at that time, the city would contribute $100 per worker to the health and welfare fund and more vacation days for new workers. That would amount to increases of three-tenths of 1 percent and two-tenths of 1 percent respectively, according to Eric J. Schmertz, the city's Labor Relations Commissioner.
The teachers, in contrast, received a 5.5 percent raise in a one-year contract. Increased benefits brought the total to 5.8 percent.
When that agreement was reached in October, some feared it would set the pattern for the rest of the labor talks and add to the city's growing fiscal problems. Yesterday, city officials seemed to emphasize the differences between the teachers' contract and the new settlement, repeatedly stating that the most recent agreement would not cause added budgetary strain.
But the settlement also seemed structured to allow union leaders to emphasize how close they came to the teachers' raise. The leaders said yesterday that they expected union members to approve the settlement.
Legislative leaders, through spokesmen, did not indicate any reason why the pension adjustment would not be approved.
 
Similar Arrangement
 When he signed legislation approving a similar pension arrangement in the teachers' contract last week, Mr. Cuomo took the occasion to warn of grave fiscal pressures on the city, angering some municipal officials. In a statement yesterday, the Governor, who is embarking on major salary negotiations of his own with unions representing state workers, said:
"It is the Mayor's responsibility to decide what contracts to make and he has done that here. My interest is the larger financial plan that the Mayor says accommodates the contracts he has made."
The contracts cover a wide range of city workers, from accountants to zookeepers, at salaries running from $16,000 to about $60,000 a year. The teamsters contract would expire at the end of September 1991; the District Council 37 contract would expire at the end of that year.
"It would have been fiscally more reassuring if there had been a longer-term contract," said Nancy Barbe, an assistant vice president at Moody's Investors Service. "Now we're faced with the prospect of going through this whole thing again in fiscal 1992."
The settlement comes as the city's economy continues to falter, job losses mount and tax revenues suffer. In two weeks, the Dinkins administration is to unveil a fiscal plan for the coming years that is expected to call for cuts in the municipal work force of perhaps 10,000 or more positions as the city struggles to close huge budget gaps.
So the new agreement, like the teachers' contract, would seem to guarantee that some union members would be getting raises while others would be losing jobs. But union leaders said yesterday they had no assurance that taking lower raises would have insured that more members keep their jobs.
Victor Gotbaum, a labor-management relations professor at the City University and former head of District Council 37, called the situation "a Hobson's choice" for union leaders.
 
'Already a Beating"
 "People are taking a cut in terms of real wages of 4 or 4.5 percent," he said. "How much of a beating can you expect your members to take?"
Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said he supported the proposed contract. "A smaller, more efficient, reasonably paid work force is better than a larger, underpaid work force," he said.
But Mr. Horton said the city should have stuck the 1.5 percent raise it had included in its budget.
"We're not playing accounting games here," he said. "The city is short on money, that's the real issue. However they phrase it, the city needs the money. And they just decided to give it away."

HEADLINE: About 10% of Credit Unions Are Privately Insured

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The collapse of a private Rhode Island deposit insurance concern on Tuesday is a reminder that although Federal deposit insurance is taken as a given in banking in most parts of the country, it is not a given for credit unions. One out of every four Americans is a member of a credit union.
Indeed, about 10 percent of the credit unions -- more than 1,400 with $18.6 billion of deposits in more than half the states -- have chosen to create their own insurance programs. 
 The National Credit Union Administration in Washington operates a federally backed credit union insurance program, which consumers can readily identify by their display of a rectangular sign showing the N.C.U.A. initials, that covers the rest of the industry. The coverage is the same as that for banks and savings and loan associations, with accounts up to $100,000 protected. The credit union fund holds about $1.30 of reserves for every $100 of insured deposits, more than twice the level of reserves at the Federal insurance fund for banks.
 
Nine Private Insurers Left
 The credit unions without Federal insurance are in states whose laws have also sanctioned the use of private deposit insurers. The nine remaining credit union insurance funds say they are solvent. Still, the future of private insurers has been clouded by the Rhode Island experience.
Even though credit unions have avoided the losses that have plagued banks and saving and loan associations recently, the experience of the last 10 years shows that when trouble strikes, private deposit insurance funds have lacked the strength and credibility needed to survive.
"The private insurance funds are well intentioned, but they are fundamentally flawed by inadequate capital and the lack of a sound reinsurance policy," said Bert Ely, a banking consultant and an expert on deposit insurance in Arlington, Va. "Anytime one of their large insured institutions fails, they have shown a lack of staying power."
 
Difference From Failed Fund
 Mr. Ely, who is an advocate of private deposit insurance, said the remaining private insurers had not coordinated their businesses so that the losses of one could be absorbed by others. The remaining nine private insurers back only credit-union deposits, unlike the Rhode Island fund. It also insured deposits of loan and investment companies, which were allowed to make risky loans to businesses.
Since the first American credit unions began early this century, the cooperative spirit of savers, who would pool their deposits to make loans to each other, has been a successful formula. Even during the Depression, credit unions fared better than banks. During the 1980's, credit unions have been expanding rapidly, while avoiding the losses from bad real estate loans that have plagued banks and savings institutions.
"The attitude of the credit union movement has been to take care of itself," with the private insurers staying close enough to the industry to spot problems early, said Charles Filson, president of Callahan & Associates, a consulting firm for credit unions and representative for the nine corporations that insure credit union deposits.
But in Rhode Island the private insurer failed to spot problems that were severe enough that 11 of the 35 credit unions it insured have been found by Federal authorities to be insolvent or deeply troubled. One key problem was regulations allowing the privately insured credit unions to make up to half their loans for various kinds of businesses. Nationally, business loans account for less than 1 percent of all credit union loans.
 
Vulnerable to Losses
 Depositors in credit unions and the nine other deposit-taking organizations insured by the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation are vulnerable to losses. The state government, which had oversight responsibility for 35 credit unions and 11 other institutions, including banks insured by the insurance corporation, has not promised to cover any possible depositor losses.
Indeed, none of the states that allow local credit unions to operate without Federal deposit insurance have pledged state money to repay depositors should the insurance plan fail.
The failure in 1985 of private insurance companies backing deposits at state-chartered savings and loan associations in Ohio and Maryland alerted state officials to the danger of local insurance funds. Wisconsin, Connecticut, New Mexico, Utah and Virginia are among the states that have stopped allowing private deposit insurance in recent years.
"The private funds suffer from a perception problem," said Richard W. Ottow, credit union commissioner in Wisconsin, where a cooperative insurance program financed by credit unions was ended in 1985. "We knew our credit unions and fund were strong, but we kept getting members asking, 'Is our money federally insured?' To the members that was the bottom line."
The N.C.U.A. said yestereday that it expected that 22 of the Rhode Island credit unions would be allowed to join the other 13,103 credit unions in the Federal insurance program. Seven of the 22 were approved to reopen on Monday.
 
N.C.U.A.'s Assessment
 "The credit union industry as a whole is in very good shape," said Roger W. Jepsen, chairman of the N.C.U.A. But at 11 Rhode Island credit unions, which the N.C.U.A. is not expected to accept for Federal insurance, he added, losses were great enough that they were insolvent, or else "they had such severe problems that they were not insurable."
Mr. Jepsen said he expected the events in Rhode Island "to cause more state-chartered credit unions to apply for Federal insurance," even though it generally costs more than the private programs. The $2 billion insurance fund operated by the N.C.U.A. has never experienced a year of loss, unlike the Federal deposit insurance fund for banks, which has suffered four consecutive years of losses.
Mr. Jepsen said that the problem in Rhode Island was state laws that allowed credit unions to make riskier loans than are normal in the industry, including commercial real estate loans. In addition, in the past six weeks N.C.U.A. examiners have found "a lot of things going on there which we don't permit," Mr. Jepsen said, as well as high levels of delinquent loans and improper records.
In Massachusetts, which is suffering from the same economic recession as Rhode Island, the Massachusetts Credit Union Share Insurance Corporation has not been experienced any unusual losses, said Robert J. Maietta, chief executive. "We are doing quite well," he added.
The Massachusetts fund has $1.50 of reserves for every $100 of deposits, making it one of the strongest deposit insurance funds by that measure.
 
Insuring Credit Unions
 
The nine private groups that insure state-chartered credit unions. The Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation was closed Tuesday. Credit unions covered by these nine insurers are not backed by Federal insurance funds.
 
The California Credit Union Share Guaranty Association, based in Pomona, insures $412 million in 140,462 accounts.
 
The Credit Union Insurance Corporation is based in Baltimore. The group did not return calls seeking information about its accounts.
 
The Florida Credit Union Guaranty Corporation, based in Orlando, Fla., insures $1.6 billion in 559,086 accounts.
 
The Georgia Credit Union Deposit Insurance Corporation, based in Atlanta, insures $1.2 bilion.
 
The Massachusetts Credit Union Share Insurance Corporation, based in Boston, insures $3 billion at 140 credit unions in the state with 548,000 accounts.
 
The Mutual Guaranty Corporation, based in Chattanooga, Tenn., insures $2 billion at 324 credit unions in five states.
 
The National Deposit Insurance Corporation, based in Dublin, Ohio, insures $5.4 billion at 420 credit unions in 22 states.
 
The Texas Share Guaranty Credit Union, based in Austin, insures $2.4 billion at 286 credit unions.
 
The Washington Credit Union Share Guaranty Association, in Bellevue, insures $1.4 billion in 670,000 accounts at 100 credit unions.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk
