HEADLINE: Where Is Congress on the Gulf?

 BODY:
Will Congress debate and vote on President Bush's war policy in the Persian Gulf? Will Mr. Bush ask it to? These questions belong at the top of the agenda when Congressional leaders meet with the President today.
Until now, the Congress has shirked its constitutional duty to debate a declaration of war. This week some members intend to introduce a resolution to allow six months more for economic sanctions on Iraq and diplomacy to work. But Congressional leaders want to dodge the issue by putting off a vote. 
 That's unconscionable. While hundreds of thousands of young Americans gird for battle in the deserts of Arabia, their elected representatives can't summon up the courage to confront their responsibilities at home.
The leaders' reason for their silence won't wash: that a debate could be divisive, easing the pressure on Saddam Hussein. Debate is not divisive unless the policy being debated is. Better to know that now, before Americans are called upon to die for it. That Mr. Bush's brinkmanship is debatable is no secret. Debate over the wisdom of war is raging everywhere in America except where it's supposed to -- in Congress.
 During Vietnam, when Presidents took it upon themselves to wage war, Congress thought it necessary to enact the War Powers Act -- really a "War Responsibility Act" -- forcing the President and Congress to face up to a war decision in full public view. But Mr. Bush shied away from invoking the act, asserting that U.S. troops are in no imminent danger of hostilities. Closing its eyes, Congress accepted his claim, then left town just as he put aside Desert Shield and picked up Desert Sword.
Now Congress is back, but its leaders still duck a debate. Take Lee Hamilton, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, for example. In one breath he cogently argues against a war anytime soon: "So long as there is a reasonable opportunity that the present strategy of the threat of the use of force, the economic sanctions and the diplomatic activity will . . . get Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait, then I think you ought to stick with it and not go to war."
In the next breath he opposes a vote now to stay Mr. Bush's hand: "I think the name of the game at the moment is to ratchet up the pressure on Saddam Hussein in every way that we can. You do not want to put a resolution or a declaration on the floor of the House or the Senate . . . because that will send a signal of divisiveness."
By this tortured logic, the need to maintain a credible threat of war would mean that the time will never come for Congress to vote.
The leadership's position would be more understandable if there had been a behind-the-scenes deal. The rumor around Washington was that in return for unfettered authority to threaten war, Mr. Bush had pledged not to wage war without Congressional approval. Last weekend the House Armed Services Committee chairman, Les Aspin, scotched that talk: "The Administration has not in any time, any forum, ever committed to that."
A deferred debate on a declaration of war invites divisiveness at the worst possible time -- after Mr. Bush takes the country to war. Mr. Bush's brinkmanship is running out of time to show results. If Congress prefers sanctions and diplomacy to an early war, why not vote to give them a reasonable chance to work?

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
State of the State of the Union

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It all started with Edmund Burke's 1769 essay on the "present state of the nation"; our Constitution-writers then required that the President report to the Congress information of the "state of the Union" along with "such measures as he shall judge necessary and expedient."
Now, every January, governors intone their "State of the State," mayors their "State of the City" and executives everywhere their states-of-the-whatevers. As a result, the state of the audience is bored to the point of stupefaction. 
 With characteristic bumption, White House chief of staff John Sununu stole a hallowed tradition from the Speaker of the House and announced that the President would be the Congress's guest on Jan. 27.
That's less then two weeks after the Jan. 15 U.N. Kuwait deadline. The National Security Council staff can't start on the foreign-affairs part yet because it doesn't know what Saddam (defiantly pronounced SAD'm by Mr. Bush, to annoy Sa-DOM) Hussein will do.
The Domestic Council's Roger Porter, however, knows that the President is getting knocked for do-nothingism at home, and is busily circulating a memo with a dozen potential "initiatives."
He enlivens one with a couple of facts: (1) about the same number of students, 45 million, attend primary and secondary schools as did 10 years ago, and (2) in constant dollars, adjusted for inflation, $79 billion more is being spent on education in 1990 than in 1980. Has this added state and local spending helped education all that much?
Then come choices for ideas, including: (a) vouchers, to let parents and students choose their schools, introducing competition; (b) alternative certification of teachers, and (c) site-based management. (My source would have explained those last two but heard Sununu footsteps.)
When the President makes his choices, the hard part comes for the State-of-the-Unionists: using the President's speech to energize and motivate school reform, not subsidize it. The Feds pay only 7 percent of the education bill, which is proper in a diverse nation; besides, the old revenue-sharing has now become deficit-sharing. The President must exhort, knowing he will be zapped by educators for not proposing more spending.
Other areas on the domestic list range from a few thoughts on oil conservation (to be called a "national energy strategy") to some necessary specifics on rebuilding the deposit insurance system for banks ("banking reform").
But what about the great debate that is supposed to be going on in the Bush Administration, pitting the neo-neocon "New Paradigm" empowerment-choice-enterprise crowd against the root-canal social Darmanism of the budget pragmatists? (I would explain those catchy terms, but I hear Sununu footsteps.)
The intellectual ferment is not all that profound. Budget boss Richard Darman mocked the packaging of ideas put forward last year by Jim Pinkerton, the gangling Bush wunderkind who takes government seriously, which happily propelled his "New Paradigm" out of obscurity -- at least to political-philosophy freaks.
But the Darman diatribe was smart-alecky, not substantial; he has since made his peace with the earnest Bushies who have a creditable approach to coping with social welfare in a time of austerity. "Empowerment" -- Jack Kemp's term for offering bootstraps in place of shoes -- has not been seriously challenged, even by Democrats. It ain't new, but it ain't bad, and has no competition.
From these ideas, the President's men will submit "decision memos." If Mr. Bush wants to pacify Congress, he will include the proposals in a speech that praises the Clean Air Act and hails the way the leadership took him to the cleaners on the budget.
If he decides to take the Congress on, Mr. Sununu will direct the speechwriters to adopt an abrasive tone, demanding a "recovery package" including a revenue-producing capital gains tax cut, and putting a thumb in every incumbent's eye with a call for a limitation on the years a representative can serve.
Today, the unabrasive writers will put those decisions into an upbeat speech draft, or updraft, destined to be rewritten to reflect the triumphant, apologetic or resolute Persian Gulf section of the address -- the heart of the matter.
And that's my State of the Speech report on the state of the decisions on the state of the draft of the State of the Union.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Boat Luxury Tax Drives an Industry Aground

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I have been in the boat business since 1972. The luxury tax that came into effect this year is in general unfair, but as it pertains to boats, grossly so. My industry was singled out and is being crushed by this tax. This will translate into lost jobs for about 600,000 people if something is not done quickly.
The luxury tax on new boats is a cruel hoax played on the public at the expense of those who work in the industry. The United States boat industry, and the 600,000 workers employed directly in manufacturing, were served as the sacrificial lamb to appease those who insisted on soaking the rich during Federal budget negotiations.
The Treasury Department has acknowledged that the 10 percent luxury tax on boats will not produce tax revenues to help solve the budget crisis. The luxury tax revenue will not even cover the income tax revenue lost to unemployed workers and bankrupt manufacturers.
The general thinking is that the rich can afford it, and an extra 10 percent tax isn't going to stop the fat cats from indulging in their toys. What most people don't realize is that those able to buy a new boat also have the ability to decide not to buy. And that is what they have done.
Since the luxury tax came into effect last Sept. 30 for newly ordered boats, nobody has bought a new boat on which the tax would apply! The National Marine Manufacturers' Association, the industry association that tracks such things, can't find a single sale in the whole country! Not one! However, the association has been able to document in excess of 100,000 layoffs (blue-collar workers -- not fat cats) and numerous boat manufacturers going out of business. All during which not a single dollar of luxury tax has been collected.
Let's leave for the moment that the boat luxury tax produces negative revenue and discuss the unfairness of such an excise tax. A great number of people who buy boats are not rich but simply buy a boat to live on, in lieu of a house. A significant number who buy a boat that costs more than $100,000 do live on board. Should they be penalized for such a life style?
Or, why is a new boat a luxury, but a used boat not? Why is a new boat in excess of $100,000 a luxury, but a $500,000 vacation home in Aspen, Colo., not? Plenty of $100,000-plus motor homes are bought every year. Why aren't they a luxury? Why isn't a $250,000 airplane or a $10,000 fur coat a luxury?
All excise taxes are regressive by nature. The politicians tell us that they are socking it to the rich, but all the while it is the average worker who is damaged the most. Don't be fooled by all the political posturing that took place last October. The real fat cats are in Washington, piloting a ship that is sinking as the result of their 20-year spending binge.
Repeal of the boat luxury tax in the budget package passed in October can save an industry and 600,000 jobs. Your senators and representatives can balance the budget by cutting their spending, not by increasing your taxes.
 
JOE MEGLEN
Dana Point, Calif., Dec. 27, 1990

HEADLINE: BOAT LUXURY TAX DRIVES AN INDUSTRY AGROUND;
Small Business Owners

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Reports of declining retail activity seem to ignore the largest retail segment: small business owners. While many large retailers have been adversely affected by the recession, many more are able to survive the crisis. But this does not hold true for small business owners, many of whom do not have cash reserves and are unable to make cuts from their small resources.
Small business owners are the backbone of many neighborhoods in New York City, and they need to be preserved. Increases in commercial real estate assessments, escalating rents and crime are making them an endangered species.
Commercial strips throughout the city are seeing an increase in small business turnover and are concerned about eventual vacancies. The neighborhoods in the outer boroughs rely on commercial strips as a measure of a neighborhood's vitality. A faltering commercial strip is usually the first sign of an eroding neighborhood.
Commercial real estate assessments must be brought down to realistic levels, so that small business owners can survive this crisis. Many small business owners are commercial tenants and have long-term leases with property owners. Many of these leases stipulate that the commercial tenant pay the real estate tax, exclusive of the rent. As the leases come up for renewal, the commercial tenant will be unable to pay the steep real estate tax. This will create more vacancies, and a decrease in revenue for New York City.
The city administration must examine the long-term effects of the increase in commercial assessments and its potentially destabilizing effect on the economy and neighborhoods of our city.
 
DAVID E. GOLDBERG
Brooklyn, Dec. 19, 1990
 
The writer is executive director of the Woodhull Community District Management Association.

HEADLINE: Time to Change U.S. Policy in Somalia

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am concerned and dismayed by American foreign policy and aid to Somalia. In 1985, and in 1986-88, I was an administrator for refugee and training programs funded by the Agency for International Development in Somalia. American newspapers have given little coverage to widespread governmental atrocities and the lack of effectiveness of aid.
The virtual collapse of our development and relief programs was evident in the removal of personnel by the United Nations, the United States Embassy and other donor agencies because of widespread violence and civil strife in the capital, Mogadishu (news article, Dec. 12). Formerly, Somalia obtained major funding because of its poverty, refugee influxes, and "strategic" ports on the Indian Ocean. Unfortunately, most of this development aid, perceived as another form of military assistance by the Mohamed Siad Barre regime, has had little impact on the rural poor or governmental reform.
United States foreign policy has been ambiguous, officially emphasizing military support, economic development, refugee assistance and human rights. "Strategic interests" have predominated, however, and severely constrained development and humanitarian programs. In response to increased "genocidal" oppression and killing of Isaaks (the largest clan in Northern Somalia), civil war broke out between the Isaaks (Somali National Movement) and Government troops in May 1988.
The United States Embassy approved provision of military supplies to government forces, which subsequently prevailed. United Nations observers estimated that 60,000 people were killed in the conflict, many of them unarmed women and children.
President Siad Barre is reported to be holed up in a military bunker near the airport, while Mogadishu and the rest of the country are in chaos. I urge that our Government distance itself immediately from a policy generally perceived to be neither strategic nor in our long-term interests.
It is past time to cut off aid and other forms of support to the Siad Barre Government and work within the United Nations for a peaceful resolution.
 
STANLEY B. ANDREWS
Boca Raton, Fla., Dec. 19, 1990

HEADLINE: Canceled Condo Plan Had Flaws From Start

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It would be fair to say -- as you chronicle in your Dec. 18 report on Mayor David N. Dinkins's wise decision to cancel the Tibbets Gardens condominium housing project -- that politics, the recession and a drastic slump in the New York City real estate market all played a substantial part in that outcome. However, having thoroughly analyzed this program more than a year ago, I believed -- and hoped -- the venture's financial riskiness would cause the city to abandon this taxpayer albatross.
My office reported last January that the project's financial package involved risks that were much too high. Our analysis showed that not a single unit in Tibbets Gardens would be affordable to households with the minimum income levels proposed. Public subsidies would have averaged $91,000 a unit for apartments sold for $64,000 to $136,000. And because an original apartment buyer could resell to anyone after five years regardless of income, the public interest in providing large subsidies for affordable housing was not likely to be served very long.
Even in boom times, a financial albatross like this should never get off the ground.
 
EDWARD V. REGAN
State Comptroller
New York, Dec. 20, 1990

HEADLINE: Big Banks Cut Prime By 1/2 Point

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
The nation's largest banks, almost in lockstep, lowered their prime lending rate yesterday by half a percentage point, to 9 1/2 percent. It was their first drop in nearly a year and reflects efforts by the Federal Reserve Board to push interest rates lower.
Among the New York banks lowering the prime were Citibank, Morgan Guaranty, Chase Manhattan, Chemical, Manufacturers Hanover and Bankers Trust. They were joined by a number of regional banks, including NCNB, based in Charlotte, N.C., and Mellon Bank, based in Pittsburgh. 
 The drop in the prime rate, a benchmark for the pricing of many consumer and small-business loans, comes more than a month after the Federal Reserve began to ease money market rates to stimulate the economy. This, in turn, helped reduce the banks' cost of funds -- money they borrow and re-lend to customers at a higher interest rates.
 
Cuts in Discount and Funds Rates
 Two significant determinants of most banks' cost of funds have fallen recently, making it only a matter of time before banks would cut their prime rates, analysts said. On Dec. 19, the Federal Reserve cut its discount rate to 6 1/2 percent from 7 percent. This is the rate the Fed charges member banks for loans. Another key rate, the Federal funds rate, the short-term rate on unsecured loans between banks, recently fell to 7 1/4 percent.
"Banks are responding to the decline in their cost of funds," said Ronald Mandle, an analyst with Sanford Bernstein & Company. Mr. Mandle added that banks had been slow to reduce prime rates so they could "rebuild profitability" by taking advantage of the wide spreads between their cost of funds and what they charge customers.
There had been some speculation that for this reason New York banks would be slow to move. But Christopher Mahoney, an analyst with Moody's Investors Service, said the wide spread between money market rates and the prime rate put political pressure on the banks to reduce the prime rate.
 
'Impossible to Sustain'
 "From an earnings perspective," Mr. Mahoney said, "banks would rather not reduce the prime. But when it's wide enoug, it becomes impossible to sustain a difference."
The cost of funds varies among banks, according to proprietary formulas at each bank. It is usually made up of the cost of borrowing money from depositors along with the cost of borrowing from the Fed, from other banks and from other sources.
The current drop in the prime was set off by Bank of America, which reduced its rate to 9 1/2 percent on Monday. The move by the Bank of America, the main subsidiary of the San Francisco-based BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's third-largest banking company, made it difficult for other banks to maintain a higher lending rate, Mr. Mahoney said. "With B. of A. moving, that made it impossible. So they all had to go."
The First National Bank of Chicago cut its prime rate to 9 1/2 percent on Dec. 20, about a week after two smaller banks, the First Fidelity Bancorporation of Lawrenceville, N.J., and the Norwest Bancorporation of Minneapolis, each cut their rates to 9 3/4 percent.
Carole Berger, an analyst with C. J. Lawrence, said that the fall in the prime rate should have little impact on profitability at many banks. Whether it does depends on the size of a bank's consumer lending operations, she said. At most banks, large commercial loans are not priced off the prime rate, but rather off other indicators such as the Federal funds rate or the rate on short-term Treasury securities.
As a result, at a bank like Morgan, which has little consumer business, a drop in the prime is largely symbolic. It is, however, more significant at a bank like Citibank, which has a large consumer lending operation. A falling prime rate should help lower the cost of home-equity loans, auto loans and other consumer products.
"This is not a big deal for bank profitability at many banks because most of the variable-rate lending is pegged to something other than the prime rate," Ms. Berger said. "At some very large commercial banks, profits have already been squeezed."
The last time the prime rate was set at 9 1/2 percent was on July 14, 1988. At that time, it rose from 9 percent, and the prime continued to climb until it reached 11 1/2 percent in February 1988. The prime's lowest level since January 1985 was in August 1986, when it fell to 7 1/2 percent.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 4, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: Stocks Retreat Broadly As Dow Falls by 23.02

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks sagged broadly yesterday on the first trading session of the new year, despite a jump in bond prices, a big decline in crude oil prices and widespread feeling that the Fed will continue to cut interest rates.
Oil prices slumped $1.95 a barrel, to $26.49, normally enough of a reason for stocks to pick up, but the Dow Jones industrial average slid 23.02 points, or almost 1 percent, to 2,610.64. 
 The broader market, as measured by the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, fell slightly more. Trading volume rose to a listless 126.3 million shares, from 114.1 million on New Year's Eve.
Many Wall Street brokerage firms maintain that they are unable to make much money on stock commissions unless trading volume hits 150 million shares a day.
New economic numbers, which are expected to prompt the Fed to ease monetary policy and stimulate business, showed that the nation was rapidly sinking into troubling times:
*The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its monthly index on the economy fell in December, for the third month, to 40.4 percent -- the lowest level since the bottom of the 1982 recession.
*Sales of American-made cars fell about 20 percent in mid-December from last year's levels.
*Commodities prices, as measured by the Commodity Research Bureau index, fell to their lowest point in 13 years.
Asked about the drop in commodities prices, Stuart Shinbein, senior technical editor of the C.R.B. index, said, "It means that any attempts by business to raise prices for nonessential and high-priced items and make them stick are doomed to failure because the consumer is topped out."
In a decline of close to 2 percent, the C.R.B. fell 4.18 points yesterday to a new low of 218.46, indicating, as one trader remarked, that "inflationary pressures are slowly being whittled away."
Except for wheat prices in Kansas City, Chicago and Minneapolis and copper prices, 19 of the 21 commodities in the C.R.B. fell, from gold and silver to sugar, coffee. orange juice and heating oil.
 
Outlook On Unemployment
 Moreover, traders said, unemployment numbers coming out tomorrow are expected to show further economic deterioration.
Commenting on the outlook for further easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve, H. Erich Heinemann, chief economist for Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, said, "The Fed has to put some money into the marketplace and to do this it is going to move to lower short-term interest rates very substantially from present levels."
Among the movers, Amgen, the drug producer, rose 1 1/2 on the Nasdaq to 63 3/4, after it said the Food and Drug Administration had expanded approval for a product to be used with AZT to treat AIDS patients.
Johnson & Johnson, the drug producer whose Ortho unit will sell the drug here as Procrit, fell 1 3/4 in heavy Big Board trading, to 70, although it traded during the day as high as 72 1/4. Analysts said the approval was expected.
Schering-Plough slid 1 1/8, to 43 1/4, with 1.3 million shares changing hands. The company was not listed among F.D.A. year-end approvals for pending drugs, analysts said.
Paramount Communications rose 1 1/2 in heavy trading to 42 3/8 even after it denied reports in Tokyo by Nikkei News that the company was trying to sell its motion picture business.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 5, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Thursday about the daily stock trading misstated the year in which the Commodity Research Bureau index reached its previous low. It was 1987, not 1977.

HEADLINE: Joseph Spengler, 88, Economics Professor At Duke University

BYLINE: By JOAN COOK

 BODY:
Joseph J. Spengler, the James B. Duke Professor Emeritus of Economics at Duke University, died yesterday at a nursing home in Durham. He was 88 years old and lived in Durham, N.C.
Dr. Spengler died of Alzheimer's disease, a spokesman for the family said.
He joined the faculty of Duke in 1932 and became James B. Duke Professor of Economics in 1955. His principal interests were population and the history of economic thought and economic development.
Dr. Spengler also taught at the Universities of Arizona, Chicago, Pittsburgh, and North Carolina, as well as the University of Kyoto in Japan and the University of Malaya.
He was the author or co-author of 13 books and many articles on economics, including "Facing Zero Population Growth" (1978; Duke University Press) and "France Faces Depopulation, Postlude Edition" (1979; Duke University Press).
He was a recipient of the John F. Lewis award of the American Philosophical Society and of a distinguished fellow award from the History of Economics Society.
Dr. Spengler was a past president of the American Economic Association, the Southern Economic Association, the Population Association of America, the History of Economics Society and the Atlantic Economics Society. He was a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and a distinguished fellow of the American Economic Association.
He was born in Piqua, Ohio, and graduated from Ohio State University, where he also received a master's degree and a doctorate.
In World War II he was southeastern regional price executive for the Office of Price Administration.
Dr. Spengler is survived by his wife, the former Dorothy Kress, and two sisters, Gertrude Arbegast of Cincinnati and Elizabeth Boston of Naples, Fla.

HEADLINE: New Senator From California Is Named

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 2

 BODY:
In a characteristically pragmatic move, Pete Wilson today chose a state Senator noted for his fund-raising abilities to succeed him in the United States Senate when he is sworn in as Governor of California next Monday.
Mr. Wilson's successor, John F. Seymour, a 53-year-old moderate Republican from Orange County who made his fortune as a real estate entrepreneur, was praised today by the Governor-elect for the "intelligence, energy and toughness of mind that made him a millionaire in business before he was 30 years old." 
 State law requires that the new Federal lawmaker face election for the balance of Mr. Wilson's term in 1992, the next general election, and, if elected, to then go through the whole expensive process again for a full term in 1994. The two campaigns, Mr. Wilson and others said, will cost $30 million to $40 million.
"Without a major war chest, you can't be in this game," Mr. Wilson said.
 
A Big Contributor
 Observers agree that Mr. Seymour knows about war chests: The California Political Almanac says he was one of 50 Californians to contribute $100,000 to George Bush's 1988 Presidential campaign.
Mr. Wilson, 57, a moderate Republican who was Mayor of San Diego when he won his Senate seat in 1982, had set out to find a successor who was his ideological twin, as well as well-heeled and well-connected. Since beating Dianne Feinstein in November to win the governorship of the nation's most populous state, Mr. Wilson did little to discourage speculation that he would choose a woman or a member of a minority group, or a lawmaker from the party's liberal wing. Although Mr. Seymour's current positions are nearly identical to Mr. Wilson's, his name was little mentioned by prognosticators.
Many of Mr. Seymour's positions have gradually shifted toward the center since 1982, when he left the Mayor's post in Anaheim to serve in the State Senate. Under the political-term limit approved by California voters in November (and supported by Mr. Seymour), he could have served in the State Senate until 1996.
In recent years, Mr. Seymour has voted to ban assault weapons, to outlaw discrimination against people with AIDS, and to increase spending for social programs including education and mental health benefits.
"He is what I call a compassionate conservative," said Mr. Wilson, who appeared with his successor at a news conference here.
In 1989, Mr. Seymour switched sides on two touchy issues of prime importance to Mr. Wilson -- abortion rights and offshore oil drilling. On both, Mr. Seymour parted company with many in his party to side with Mr. Wilson and the majority of Californians, who support a woman's right to choose abortion and who oppose drilling off the Pacific Coast.
 
Recalls 'Sad Lesson'
 Mr. Seymour opposed abortion until the summer of 1989. Then, after a Supreme Court decision that gave the states new power to restrict abortion, he said that he was personally opposed to abortion, but that he did not believe the state was entitled to interfere with a woman's decision. But both Mr. Wilson and Mr. Seymour say teen-agers seeking abortions should have parental consent.
Mr. Seymour favored oil drilling until the Exxon Valdez accident in Alaska in 1989. After the accident, he said he had learned the "sad lesson" that economic considerations were "outweighed" by environmental concerns.
The Persian Gulf, rather than any of these issues, will be at center stage in Washington when Mr. Seymour takes office, which will happen officially at the moment Mr. Wilson resigns as Senator and takes the oath as Governor on Monday.
Today, Mr. Seymour was asked his position on the rumblings of war in the Middle East, and on the Jan. 15 deadline set by President Bush and endorsed by the United Nations for the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait. Mr. Seymour said his "highest priority" was to "bring the troops home." He added that he "hoped and prayed" for a negotiated settlement in the volatile region but that "sanctions don't appear to be working," and that he stood "four-square behind President Bush."
 
Backing the President
 Furthermore, Mr. Seymour said, and Mr. Wilson concurred, that the President was under no requirement to seek Congressional approval before going to war. "I believe the President has the constitutional right and authority to do what he says he will do," Mr. Seymour said.
Mr. Wilson interjected that his successor would quickly discover that "there is all too much Congressional overreaching" in Washington, and that his colleagues were inclined "to usurp powers not conferred on them by the Constitution."
While Mr. Seymour said he would be "low man on the totem pole" in Washington, his role may actually be more important than that because of the status of Alan Cranston, the state's senior Senator. Mr. Cranston, embarrassed by the savings and loan scandal, and suffering from prostate cancer, has announced his retirement at the end of his current term.
Mr. Wilson said today that if Senator Cranston "lessens his pace" it "may very well reflect an added burden for Senator Seymour." Mr. Wilson noted that he had a similar boost in 1984, when Senator Cranston ran for President. "That brought me business I otherwise would not have had," Mr. Wilson said.
 
Lost Race in June
 While Mr. Wilson was sanguine about his successor's prospects as a Senate candidate, Mr. Seymour lost the last race that he ran -- in June, in the Republican primary here for lieutenant governor. The winner in that contest, who lost the general election to Leo McCarthy, was Marian C. Bergeson, also a state Senator. Senator Bergeson opposed abortion rights, but exit polls indicated that many voters, especially women, assumed that his position was the opposite when they voted in an election that received almost no media attention.
After interviewing a dozen prospects. Mr. Wilson telephoned Mr. Seymour last Thursday at a Sierra Nevada ski resort where he was vacationing with his family, to offer the job.,
"I thought what he wanted was my opinion on an appointment," said Mr. Seymour, an old friend of the Governor-elect.
"It was," Mr. Wilson retorted.
For several days, Mr. Seymour mulled over the offer with his wife and six children. Mr. Seymour said only 8-year-old Barrett, still bruised by his father's loss in the primary, objected.
"You know how bad you want to be a professional baseball player?" Mr. Seymour asked the boy, who tugged at his bow tie throughout today's news conference. "Well, that's how bad I want to be a United States Senator."
And Barrett's response?
"Go for it, Dad."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John F. Seymour, who was chosen to succeed Pete Wilson in the United States Senate. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Construction Spending Down 0.6%

BYLINE: By AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Construction spending fell by six-tenths of a percent in November to its lowest level in two years, the Commerce Department said today. The decline wiped out October's rise, the first in building activity in six months.
 Many economists foresee little improvement before the summer as the economy continues to weaken. 
You're looking at a decline in construction activity at least on a par with recessions of the past," said Gilbert Benz, an economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York, "and it could be worse."
 
Slowest Since October '88
 The Commerce Department said spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $422.4 billion, down from $425.1 billion in October. It was the slowest rate since October 1988, when $421.6 billion was spent, and 2.5 percent below the November 1989 level.
 Even the October increase, the first since a gain of four-tenths of a percent last March, was less than first thought. The department revised the 1.3 percent gain reported last month to just three-tenths of 1 percent, based primarily on a 5.3 percent increase in Government spending.
 Government spending posted the only gain in November, up by 3.5 percent, to an annual rate of $115.9 billion. Spending by the Federal Government was led by a 6.6 percent rise in street and highway projects, to $35.5 billion. Spending on schools rose by 3.7 percent, to $22.4 billion.
 "The public sector continues to hold things up," said Daryl Delano, an economist with Cahners Economics, a forecasting firm in Newton, Mass. But, he added, budget restraints and colder weather are likely to stem that source of activity as well.
 Residential and nonresidential spending continued to decline.
 Residential activity plunged by 2.5 percent, to an annual rate of $173.8 billion, after a drop of eight-tenths of 1 percent in October.
 Spending on single-family homes fell by 2.1 percent, to $100.7 billion, after a 1.9 percent decline the previous month. Apartment spending dropped by 4.3 percent, to $17.9 billion, erasing a 1.6 percent gain in October.
 While the housing industry has been weakening for months, many economists expect single-family activity to start improving by the middle of the year. The outlook is not so optimistic for the multifamily sector, however, because of overbuilding and tight lending practices.
 Nonresidential activity slipped by 2.2 percent, to an annual rate of $96.9 billion, on top of a 3.1 percent decline a month earlier. The industrial group showed the only strength, increasing by 2.6 percent, to $20.1 billion.
 The weakness in the building industry cost Americans 62,000 construction jobs last month, according to the Labor Department. Over the last six months, the industry has seen jobs tumble by about 250,000.

HEADLINE: New Approach in Massachusetts

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
William F. Weld was sworn in today as the state's first Republican Governor in 16 years and gave an inaugural address advocating a conservative approach to healing Massachusetts's ailing financial condition.
In painting hands-off government as the answer to the state's problems, Mr. Weld said Massachusetts was saddled with bureaucracies that were 50 years out of date.
"Entrepreneurial government tends to steer rather than row," he said. "It does not embark on long-term programs without gauging long-term costs."
The new Governor pointedly steered clear of assigning blame to his predecessor, Michael S. Dukakis, but he outlined a dark picture of the state's current financial crisis.
"There is widespread talk of Massachusetts as a fiscal Beirut -- its economy adrift, its credit uncertain, its spirits lower than its bond ratings," he said.
Mr. Weld warned that there would be no quick fixes. "While I promise no miracles," he said, "I can undertake to avoid past mistakes. Things will get better."
Mr. Weld has estimated that he could face a budget deficit from $300 million to $750 million in the first six months that he is in office, which are the end of the 1991 fiscal year.

HEADLINE: Outcry Over Jews' Move to Germany

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
The recent migration of thousands of Soviet Jews to Germany has set off an impassioned response among many Jews, especially those who survived the horrors of the Nazi era.
On the one hand are those who say that, even after 50 years, the memory of the atrocities against Jews is too raw to rebuild the once-flourishing German Jewish population. On the other hand are those who say that the emigres, whatever their decision, should have the freedom to settle where they want. 
 The most emotional reaction came in a letter last week from the president of the American Federation of Jewish Holocaust Survivors, who wrote that reports of a steady stream of Soviet Jews arriving in Berlin have caused "the most profound negative, painful and emotional reaction from us." The group, with 70,000 members, is the largest survivor organization in the world.
 
'Unparalleled Crimes'
 "We cannot, in good conscience, encourage Jewish emigration to a country which, within our lifetime, was responsible for unparalleled crimes against our people," said the letter, which was signed by the organization's president, Benjamin Meed, and sent to Edgar Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress.
While the congress has yet to take position on the issue, its affiliates in the United States, Latin America and Israel have endorsed the survivors' statement, saying they acted out of a combination of emotional and political motives. First they cited the bitter memories of World War II and, second, the need to direct Jews to Israel, which in the last year has been the destination of the overwhelming number of Jews leaving the Soviet Union.
On the other side of the debate, however, are organizations who want Soviet Jews to have the freedom to emigrate where they please. Representatives of these groups spoke with caution, saying that they were sensitive to the feelings of the survivors and to Israel's desire to receive the emigres.
 
'Find a Safe Haven'
 David A. Harris, executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee, said, "From our viewpoint, the first and most important issue is the ability of Jews to leave and find a safe haven," he said. "Coupled with that is the recognition of the special importance that this emigration has for Jewish nation-building in Israel."
But, Mr. Harris added, "The American Jewish Committee has always supported the freedom for Soviet Jews to settle in the country of their choosing. While we hope that country would be Israel, it would be highly presumptuous of others to seek to make those choices for them."
While the committee has not lobbied the German Government for an increase in the number of Soviet Jews allowed to enter, Mr. Harris said, "We believe that the Germany of 1991 is not the Germany of 1945."
Martin A. Wenick, executive director of the National Conference on Soviet Jewry, took a similar position, saying: "We prefer that emigrating Soviet Jews choose Israel as their destination. On the other hand, we recognize that people may go to destinations other than Israel. That's their prerogative and it's up to the receiving states to decide whether to accept them or not."
 
Avoidance of Things German
 None of those in the debate outside of Germany were willing to go as far as the leadership of the small German Jewish minority, which has encouraged the emigration, seeing it as an opportunity to reinvigorate a culture and a people ravaged by the Nazis. Despite millions of marks paid to Israel and survivors and statements of regret by Germans over the "final solution," many Jews outside Germany decline to visit the country; some even refrain from buying German-made products.
Before World War II, more than half a million Jews lived in Germany. Nearly all fled or were deported to their deaths between 1933 and 1945. In the decades that followed, the number of affiliated Jews grew gradually to more than 25,000 -- all but a few hundred of them in West Germany.
In the last year, about 5,000 more have arrived from the Soviet Union, with the number building in recent weeks as 50 to 100 have gotten off trains and buses from the Soviet Union each day.
In an interview, Mr. Meed of the survivors' group spoke with compassion for the new arrivals. "I understand what it means to run away from danger and look for a home," said the 70-year-old survivor of the Warsaw ghetto. "But where do you run? To Germany? How can you forget what the Germans did to us?"
 
'Based on Remembrance'
 "It's too soon," he added. "Judaism is based on remembrance. We make sure to remember from generation to generation, so how can we in our own generation forget?"
The arrival of Soviet Jews in Germany has prompted a debate within the country as well. Some Germans, arguing that the nation has a historical and moral responsiblity, want to open their doors to the Soviet Jews; others believe that they should be subject to strict immigration quotas, just like those who want to enter from other economically troubled Eastern European nations.
The letter by Mr. Meed of the Holocaust survivor organization was endorsed this week by the North American and Latin American branches of the World Jewish Congress. The Israeli office has taken a similar stand. Only the German Jewish office has taken a position encouraging the immigration.

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON TALK;
Recession: Blaming Everyone But Bush

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has now grudg ingly conceded that the economy is in recession. So who is responsible for the economic bad times? Herewith the Bush team's top 10 offenders:
10. European farmers. The talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade broke down last month because the European Community refused to scrap the enormous subsidies it provides for farmers. Farmers are so important politically, especially in France and Germany, that the politicians were not willing to risk angering them. Carla A. Hills, the United States Trade Representatives, says the failure to conclude a trade agreement could cost the world $4 trillion, and the United States alone about $1 trillion, in lost income over the next 10 years.
9. Environmentalists. The environmental movement insists on stifling important technological advances and retarding economic development. "Americans did not fight and win the wars of the 20th century to make the world safe for green vegetables," said Richard G. Darman, the budget director, in a speech last spring.
8. Consumers. Americans, says Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, consume too much and do not save enough, and that means too little money is available for investments that would allow the economy to grow. The family savings rate is about 5 percent, roughly a third of what it is in Japan and about half the rate in Canada, Germany and France. Twenty years ago, the American savings rate was more than 9 percent.
7. Government. "The President," says John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, "feels very strongly that the free market system operates best when it does not have its hands tied by Government, is not shackled by a system that erroneously thinks it can improve it by command and control."
6. Newt Gingrich. If Mr. Gingrich, the House Republican whip who is the most outspoken conservative in Congress, had not led the charge against the budget deal the President struck with Congressional leaders in September, the final budget package would probably not have included higher income tax rates and would have been much more to the Administration's liking. Higher tax rates, in the President's view, are a drag on the economy.
5. The Federal Reserve Board. From his first days in office, President Bush has pressed the Fed to lower interest rates to goose the economy. But the central bank, more concerned about inflation, moved cautiously. When the chairman, Alan Greenspan, began cutting rates in October, it was too little and too late in the Administration's opinion. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady says there is "ample room" now for much bigger cuts in the interest rate.
4. Bankers. Even with the action by the Fed last fall to bring down interest rates, the prime rate, the benchmark for many consumer and commercial loans, was not lowered by the major banks until this week. Business executives say they cannot get the loans they need for their companies to prosper. Mr. Bush has had bankers to the White House to jawbone them, but to no avail.
3. Bank regulators. Some members of the Bush Cabinet, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher in particular, say banks are not lending enough because the bank examiners have been too tough. The President has had the regulators to the White House, too, to give them a piece of his mind, but little has changed.
2. Saddam Hussein. Here is how Mr. Bush put it at a news conference last month: "The increase in oil prices resulting directly from Saddam's invasion is hurting our country, and our economy is at best in a serious slowdown. If uncertainty remains in the energy markets, the slowdown will get worse."
And now, the single most important cause of economic bad times, as recorded in countless statements by the President and his top advisers.
1. Democrats. If only the Democrats had agreed to a budget deal in the spring, if only they would allow a cut in the capital gains tax rate, if only they would keep income tax rates low, if only they would make deep cuts in domestic spending programs, if only they did not persist in controlling the Senate and the House of Representatives, if only Jimmy Carter had not been President. . . .

HEADLINE: Effort to Evacuate Foreigners From Somalia Stalls

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Efforts to evaculate the remaining foreigners from the Somali capital, Mogadishu, were stalled today after Western governments failed in their efforts to get a lull in the fighting, now in its fifth day.
The Italian Government sent C-130 transport planes to Nairobi today for use in evacuation of its 400 citizens, 77 Americans and citizens of several European nations. But the Somali Government warned Italy, the former colonial power of the southern half of the country, that such an evacuation would be considered an unriendly act. The International Committee of the Red Cross said it was willing to accept an Italian proposal that the Red Cross operate the Italian flights, thus guaranteeing that they would be a humanitarian exercise. The Red Cross said that the rebel group, the United Somali Congress, had agreed to the proposal but that there was no response from the Government.
 
Fighting at the Airport
 The head of Africa operations for the Red Cross group, Pierre Gassman, said from Geneva that the organization's workers in the capital reported heavy fighting at the military side ofthe Mogadishu airport this morning. Since the military area is adjacent to the civilian airport, it is not clear whether it would be possible to fly in with a rescue operation, Mr. Gassman said. 
 The Government of President Mohammed Siad Barre, in power since a coup in 1969, has been challenged with increasing intensity by an array of guerrilla groups for the past two and a half years.
The United States supported the Somali President after 1977 when the Horn of Africa was considered of strategic importance in the cold war and the Soviet Union deserted Somalia,then its client, in favor of Ethiopia. But since mid-1989, as human rights violations became more flagrant, Washington has cut its economic and military aid to virtually nothing.
Diplomats in Nairobi who were in contact with their embassies in Mogadishu said today that the situation in the capital appeared to be degenerating, as one called it, into a "grisly" affair. A Somali man who walked to the Mogadishu airport from the rebel-held north of the city Wednesday said he counted 50 bodies along the way on the roadside.
A Kenyan diplomat who also flew out Wednesday said he saw indiscriminate shooting by Somali soldiers as he drove to the airport. He got a seat on the Somali Airlines plane to Nairobi by handing over the keys of his car to the airport clerk, he said. A Washington official involved in planning evacuations of the Americans left in Mogadishu said the main goal was to get everyone out. "It is illusory to think we can do anything about the situation" between the Government and the rebels, he said.
 
Clan-Based Group
 The United Somali Congress, the rebel group that started its assault on the city on Sunday, already controls the center of the country, which lies on the eastern edge of the Horn of Africa. Like all the rebel groups, the congress is based on clan membership, that of the Hawiye ethnic group, which is dominant in the area of the capital.
The United Somali Congress, which was founded in the late 1980's and whose military wing is said to be headed by a former senior army officer of the Government, gets much of its strength from the middle-class people in Mogadishu who resent the exclusionary, clan-based rule of President Siad Barre. The President belongs to the Marehan clan and he has favored its members in virtually all appointments.
Another rebel group, the Somali National Movement, is based on the Isaak clan of the northern region, which was a British colony until the country obtained independence in 1960. The National Movement has controlled the northern section, except the city of Hargeisa, since mid-1988.
These two rebel organizations, together with a third, the Somali Patriotic Movement, which controls the south, issued a statement in London pledging to unite to form a transitional government and re-establish democratic institutions.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Falls and Silver Rises On Peace Hopes in Mideast

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of gold futures fell and silver futures rose yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange in a mixed reaction to new hopes for peace in the Middle East.
Gold futures settled $2.30 to $2.60 lower, with the contract for January delivery off $2.60, to $386.50 an ounce, and the active February contract at $388.90. Silver was 10 cents to 10.6 cents higher, with January at $4.214 an ounce. 
 Market analysts said the split reflected the mix of economic repercussions that could result if the United States and Iraq reached a peaceful settlement of their standoff over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
Analysts said peace prospects grew stronger yesterday after President Bush proposed direct talks between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Iraqi Foreign Minister before a Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait.
A peaceful settlement could bring a quick drop in oil prices, defusing a major inflation threat and cutting fuel costs for manufacturers and consumers.
Investors tend to buy gold as a hedge against inflation. Many sold the metal yesterday as the developments suggested that inflation pressures might ease, analysts said.
At the same time, silver, widely used in the photographic and electronics industries, grew more attractive.
"The idea that we could have peace in the Middle East sort of spurred the industrial sector of the precious metals complex," said Randolph Donney, research chief at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. "Maybe the recession will be a lot shorter-lived than some people are predicting."
Prices of platinum, another precious metal with a large industrial component, also rallied. The contract for January delivery rose $2.20, to $411.40, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
James Steel, a metals analyst with Refco Inc., said the divergence of gold from silver and platinum also reflected attempts by some traders to press the metals back toward their historical price relationships. Both silver and platinum have become extremely cheap relative to gold since Iraq invaded Kuwait in early August.
In other commodities, most orange juice futures plunged on the New York Cotton Exchange, extending Wednesday's losses in reaction to the lack of frost damage to the Florida orange crop over the holidays.
Frozen concentrated orange juice settled 3.85 cents lower to 0.80 cent higher, with January at $1.0616 a pound.
Most livestock and meat futures rallied on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Trading in Dollar Is Mixed Despite Signs of Weakness

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar turned in a mixed performance in narrow trading yesterday as traders, focusing on Persian Gulf tensions, held their ground against signs of economic weakness.
Continued worries about the Middle East helped support the dollar's value against a Government report of a jump in claims for state unemployment benefits for the week ended Dec. 22. 
 The report caused some analysts to revise their unemployment estimates upward. The Labor Department was scheduled to release the December employment data today.
"It would appear that the market is trying to probe a downside for the dollar but is a bit reluctant because of uncertainty in the Middle East," said Robert Hatcher, a corporate dealer for Barclays Bank.
Mr. Hatcher, who did not revise his forecast, said he expected the unemployment rate to increase to 6.1 percent from 5.9 percent.
 
Impact of Talks Proposal
 Also undermining the dollar was President Bush's proposal for a meeting in Switzerland next week between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz. Signs of peace in the gulf can prompt selling of the dollar, which is most attractive in times of turmoil.
Trading was light in advance of the Jan. 15 deadline that the United Nations has set for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face possible military action.
"Nobody's going to take any big positions until we know how that comes out," said Earl I. Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
The dollar closed at 133.00 Japanese yen in New York, down from 134.30 on Wednesday. In London, the dollar closed at 133.22 yen, down from 134.35 late Wednesday. The Tokyo markets remained closed yesterday.
In New York, the dollar weakened against the British pound. Sterling closed at $1.9475, up from Wednesday's close of $1.9445. In London, the pound strengthened to $1.9465, from $1.9420 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday rates, included: 1.4925 German marks, up from 1.4872; 1.2645 Swiss francs, up from 1.2613.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Issues Rise on Jobless Data

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
After a big rise in initial unemployment claims was reported, prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday and interest rates fell further.
At 515,000, initial unemployment claims in the week before Christmas were at their highest level in almost eight years. 
 Analysts said the figures would not be reflected in today's report on December employment. The data for that report were collected in the week ended Dec. 12.
Still, the initial claims numbers heightened expectations that the employment report would be weak.
"The weekly claims numbers were almost of depression-like size," said John P. Costas, director of the taxable fixed-income group at the First Boston Corporation. "But after this number, it is hard to see how the employment data could be better for the market."
With large amounts of new issues to be auctioned next week and the Middle East situation far from resolved, other market participants agreed that the employment numbers would have to be especially dismal to push interest rates lower.
On Tuesday the Treasury will sell a total of $6.9 billion worth of bonds for the Resolution Funding Corporation with maturities of 30 years and longer. Those auctions will be followed on Wednesday by a sale of $8.5 billion worth of new seven-year Treasury notes.
 
What People Believe
 "People want to believe that the Middle East will be solved peacefully and they know the economy is weak," said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Goverment Securities. "But with a whole slew of auctions and the Middle East out there I think there is more risk of a selloff than an extension of the rally."
In advance of the employment report, most analysts were forecasting that non-farm payroll employment declined by about 150,000 last month, and that the unemployment rate rose above 6 percent, compared with 5.9 percent in November.
Traders generally shrugged off a report showing that sales at chain stores were spotty in December, as well as remarks by Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, in a speech delivered in Salt Lake City. Mr. Parry predicted that the downturn would be short-lived and that there was a good possibility that activity would begin to pick up by the middle of the year. He added that the prospects for lower inflation in 1991 were good.
The chain-store sales numbers, which reflected decent activity at discount stores but generally poor results at more expensive retailers, showed that "they had a hard time unloading stock and had to do it at lower prices," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets. "Consumers were somewhat miserly this Christmas."
 
Impact on Bonds
 The impact of the initial claims data was most directly seen in Treasury bond prices.
By late in the day, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 107 6/32, up 3/8 point, to yield 8.10 percent, compared with 8.13 percent late Wednesday.
Reaction in the secondary market for Treasury notes was more subdued.
In late trading, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 103 29/32, up 7/32, to yield 7.91 percent. And the 7 1/4 percent two-year notes were unchanged, at a price of 100 11/32, to yield 7.06 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates dipped a bit further.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.42 percent late yesterday, down 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 6.38 percent.
In other developments, the drop in interest rates since the start of the New Year encouraged a number of corporations to price issues in the investment-grade corporate bond market.
Among the issuers was Marion Merrell Dow Inc., which offered $104.6 million of notes for an employee stock ownership plan.
The 9.11 percent notes, which mature Aug. 1, 2005, were priced at $100, or par, 1.18 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, New York State offered $40 million of general obligation bonds at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by BT Securities won the issue, which consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1992 to 2011.
The securities were initially priced to yield 6 percent on bonds due in 1992, 6.40 percent on securities maturing in 1996, 6.90 percent in 2001 and 7.25 percent on bonds that mature in 2011.
The issue is rated A by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, dealers said prices of most issues rose by 1/8 point to 1/4 point in fairly active trading.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/4 point.
Because of the New Year's Day holiday, the Federal Reserve Board will not release its weekly report on the nation's money supply until today.

HEADLINE: Construction Industry Urged to Police Itself

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
Five years after it was ordered to investigate and analyze widespread corruption and Mafia influence in New York City's building trades, a state agency asserted yesterday that all the major components of the industry -- private developers and contractors, labor unions and the city's bureaucracy -- had to share the blame.
But in proposing its own blueprint for change, the agency, the Organized Crime Task Force, said it should be mainly up to these components to clean up the industry, largely through new self-policing steps. 
 In a particularly sharp critique of the city's role, the panel contended that often the only contractors who seek municipal work are those who are incompetent or tied to organized crime.
Deputy Mayor Milton Mollen and the spokesman for the General Contractors' Association, Francis X. McArdle, in separate interviews yesterday, characterized the findings of corruption and mob domination as exaggerated. Both also said that some of the report's major recommendations appeared to be impractical or unneeded. The construction industry is one of the city's most critical economic engines, generating more than $10 billion in private and public expenditures yearly and employing more than 100,000 full- and part-time employees.
In issuing the report, the panel's director, Ronald Goldstock, said that racketeering and corruption added "substantially" to the costs of construction of private residential and commercial buildings and public projects in the city but that there was no precise price tag.
 
Koch Endorsement
 Mr. Goldstock's office was directed to undertake the study by Governor Mario M. Cuomo in 1985 following reports of rampant corruption and other abuses in the industry. Former Mayor Edward I. Koch had strongly endorsed the inquiry and also urged the appointment of a special prosecutor to root out mobsters and corrupt practices.
State and city officials and private businessmen who participated in preparing the report said the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins, faced with severe budget and street-crime problems, appeared to give a lower priority to revamping the construction industry than had Mr. Koch.
Mr. Goldstock, asked yesterday if the impetus for changing the industry had passed, replied: "This is a fragmented industry that has existed for years with a lot of vested interests. I don't expect these recommendations to be enacted immediately, but there will come a time when this blueprint will be seized upon and implemented."
Governor Cuomo, in a statement, called the report even-handed and said he would "urge the city and the state to act upon the recommendations."
In its 233-page report, the panel proposed these changes:
*The establishment by the city of an Office of Construction Corruption Prevention that would be staffed by the Department of Investigation and the Mayor's construction coordinator. Its main functions would be to develop programs for curbing corruption and expediting municipal construction projects.
*A requirement that the principal contractor on city projects of more than $5 million hire an independent company to investigate and audit its work to prevent payoffs to corrupt inspectors, union officials and Mafia figures. The report said the independent company would serve as a private "inspector general" to discourge illegal activities and to insure that contract regulations were met.
*Wider permission for contractors and developers to use independent architects and engineers to inspect projects for compliance with city regulations instead of relying on Buildings Department inspectors. Self-inspections would discourage payoffs to city inspectors, the report claimed. It said that private architects and engineers would be unlikely to accept bribes because they would lose their professional reputations and licenses to work.
*The creation by the state of an Office of Union Member Advocacy that would oversee union elections and hiring practices. The report said that the Federal National Labor Relations Board had been negligent in safeguarding the rights of union members in the construction industry and that many workers were "exploited" by corrupt union officials.
 
'Corporate Racketeering'
 Peter J. Brennan, the president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of New York, the spokesman for more than 50 construction trade unions in the city, did not return telephone calls yesterday to his office in Manhattan.
The report said that over the last 60 years Mafia groups have obtained control or influence over many construction unions and their welfare funds. "Honest reformers find it almost impossible" to remove corrupt union officials, the report said, asserting that only one private organization, the Association for Union Democracy in Brooklyn, aided construction union dissidents.
"Corporate racketeering," the report said, also contributed to higher costs when contractors seek an illicit competitive edge by either bribing union officials to avoid collective bargaining contracts," or by rigging bids.
The report assailed the city's contract-bidding and inspection procedures as "cumbersome" and "dilatory" saying they dicouraged honest contractors from bidding for city work.
Asked if the Dinkins administration considered the report a high priority, Mr. Mollen, who is the Deputy Mayor for Public Safety, said, "We want to see improvements in the construction industry but one might question most of these recommendations as realistic or doable." He added that the admininstation would decide within six months on whether to carry out any of the proposals.

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall Again; Dow Drops 37.13

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
With the economy slumping and the deadline for Iraq to get out of Kuwait keeping investors on edge, the stock market headed sharply lower yesterday for the second consecutive day.
Drug stocks, usually unaffected by hard times, fell sharply after Merrill Lynch said investors were holding too many drug shares. 
 Blue-chip stocks, as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average, slid 37.13 points, or almost 1.5 percent, to 2,573.51. The Dow now stands a little more than 200 points away from its low point in more than a year and a half.
The broader market, as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500 index, fell by almost the same amount, showing that the decline was being felt by many investors.
The smaller stocks, part of the American Stock Exchange market value index, gave way only slightly.
While still sluggish, trading activity rose to 141.5 million shares, from 126.3 million on Wednesday.
Most categories weakened, though some stocks posted gains, like Digital Equipment, which rose 1 3/8, to 56 1/4; and Compaq Computer, which climbed 1 3/8, to 57 5/8. Some of the weaker groups were drugs, chemicals, oil, gold and insurance.
Asked why insurance stocks were down, Sung Won Sohn, chief economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said, "Insurance is viewed as another problem industry, after S.& L.'s and banks, because of bad real estate loans and the poor quality of bonds."
General Re, the big reinsurer, sank 3 1/4, to 87 3/4; A.I.G., another favorite, fell 1 1/4, to 73 3/8, and Lincoln National slid 1 1/4, to 39 3/4. St. Paul fell 2 1/4, to 59 3/4; Chubb 1, to 52 1/2, and CNA 1 1/2, to 67 3/8.
Warner-Lambert, the drug company, fell 3, to 64 1/4, after Charles I. Clough Jr., chief investment strategist for Merrill Lynch, said that following last year's strong performance, investors held too many drug and medical stocks.
Abbott Labs slid 1 5/8, to 41 5/8; American Home Products 1 3/8, to 50 3/4; Bausch & Lomb 1 7/8, to 68 1/4; Bristol Myers 2 1/4, to 64 3/8; Lilly 1 1/4, to 71 1/2; Medtronic 2 3/8, to 81 3/4; Merck 2 7/8, to 86 5/8; Pfizer 2 3/8, to 77 3/4, and Syntex 2 3/8, to 55 7/8.
 
Traders Increasingly Nervous
 Other than a small rebound around 10 A.M., the Dow fell throughout most of the session, with traders turning increasingly nervous as the day progressed. Birinyi Associaties, which monitors program trading, said that five big selling waves sliced nearly 29 points off the Dow.
Today's employment figures are "expected to be pretty bad," Norwest's Dr. Sohn said. "It implies that the recession is deepening and may turn out to be worse than anticipated."
Moreover, he said, claims for unemployment in the week ended Dec. 22 rose 74,000, the highest since 1983, because of widespread layoffs in manufacturing and construction. And chain-store sales, as expected, were "pretty lackluster."
The combination, he said, was helping the bond market but hurting stocks. A poor economy, he explained, means lower interest rates, which helps bonds. Normally, that should also help stocks but because of the recession, he said, the market expects lower corporate profits, and that hurts stocks.
Among the 10 most active Big Board stocks, the Limited women's apparel chain rose 1/2, to 18 7/8. It topped the list, with 4.4 million shares changing hands, after reporting a 19 percent rise in sales for the four weeks ended Dec. 29.
Philip Morris, the second-best Dow stock last year after Procter & Gamble, slid 1 3/8, to 50 3/4, in what seemed like profit taking. Schering-Plough, which was not given any new drug approvals at year-end, fell 1 5/8, to 41 5/8, after losing 1 1/8 the day before.
Among the movers, Freeport-McMoran, the mining company, rose 2 1/2, to 18 3/8, after reporting a rise in gold, silver and copper reserves. Hilton Hotels rose 2 1/8, to 38 1/2, but the company said it knew of no reason. Digital Equipment rose 1 3/8, to 56 1/4, and Compaq Computer 1 3/8, to 57 5/8, in a mixed high-tech group.
U.S. Surgical, which fell 2 3/8 on Wednesday, fell another 4 yesterday, to 65, after trading as high as 68 3/4. The decline appeared to be profit taking.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
4 People Walking In the Darkness Toward Roselle

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

DATELINE: ELIZABETH, N.J.

 BODY:
Deborah Daniels is a homeless working person. When she woke at the Spinning Wheel Motel on Thursday morning, she did not know where she and her three children would sleep Thursday night.
Money had run out. For three years Ms. Daniels has worked as an aide on a school bus for the handicapped. She tends to the children as the bus makes its rounds through prosperous suburbs. She cleans their drool, makes sure they don't slip from wheelchairs, holds up their heads. She is paid $210 a week -- if there's school. She is not paid for school vacations like Christmas and receives no benefits. 
 Ms. Daniels's three children go to school five miles from the motel, in Roselle, their last permanent address. On mornings when there is money, the four ride a city bus to Roselle. "I'm up at 4:30 to iron their clothes," Ms. Daniels says. She shares a bed with her 14-year-old, Yolanda. Rashan, 12, and Willie, 9, share the other bed.
On mornings when money has run out, as it had yesterday, they leave the motel by 5 for the five-mile walk. "I'm fussing up and down the street to keep them walking," says the mother. "They say there's the bus. I say we don't have fare, a little more and we'll be in Roselle."
"We get sick and tired walking to Roselle in the rain and dark," Rashan said.
The great fear of poor mothers like Ms. Daniels is that they won't be able to hold their families together; that their children will be put in foster care. Nancy Goldhill, a legal services lawyer, sees it more as the economy worsens. Occasionally it surfaces -- like the mother arrested for locking her child in her car trunk while she worked -- but mostly people are too proud to tell anyone until things collapse. Ms. Daniels does not have a dollar.
 Like a lot of the homeless, she stayed with family until the pressure of living doubled up became too much. In September, she moved to a motel. She made too little to afford an apartment and too much to qualify for shelters here, which only take families on welfare. It has been suggested that Ms. Daniels go on welfare, but she refuses. On welfare, she would have medical coverage. When Rashan broke his finger last fall, Ms. Daniels paid out of pocket. After the cast was removed, Rashan was supposed to have a pin installed. "I haven't gone back," Ms. Daniels said. "We can't afford it." This is how the poor become misshapen.
She went to the State Division of Family and Youth Services and asked for a housing grant to keep her family together. "They said the way they could help -- I could put my kids in foster homes. I thought, maybe. The kids said, 'Mom you're not giving us up.' Rashan said he knew a boarded-up house; we could fix it up."
Ms. Goldhill believes the state would save money in the long run if it made housing grants to keep families together, instead of waiting until children need foster homes. A spokesman says youth services does not have the money.
Ms. Goldhill spent months searching for a housing program. "You see the incentive to quit work and go on welfare," Ms. Goldhill says. The Federal Government's Section 8 housing subsidy was created for people like them, but Reagan and Bush Administration cuts have nearly killed that program. Ms. Daniels has been on a Section 8 waiting list for two years. The Elizabeth homeless coalition gave money to keep them at the Spinning Wheel for two months, legal service workers held an office collection, a Catholic charity helped out. Yesterday, that money ran out.
Responding to a reporter's call, William Waldman, a deputy state commissioner of Human Services, had staff members help Ms. Daniels. At 4 P.M. yesterday they found funds for two more weeks at the Spinning Wheel. But Mr. Waldman warns that there's a gap that people like Ms. Daniels are falling into and it is growing. He notes that state voters defeated a bond to provide $100 million in affordable housing for the working poor and that Gov. Jim Florio has been hammered since raising taxes to improve schooling for the poor.
Ms. Daniels fears for her children. Willie thinks it's funny to shout that favorite Reagan phrase, "Say no to drugs!" at dealers who hang at the motel. Rashan was coming back from the store with ice for the cooler where they keep their food when his new $30 jacket was stolen. To shield them from motel life, the mother sends them off for a few hours every evening with the Rev. Daisy Lawson, a forklift driver who runs the Faith and Victory Church.
Ms. Daniels tries to keep their spirits up, but it's hard. Yesterday morning as they walked in the dark to Roselle, she told them, "It's good to walk; we'll lose weight." But Willie answered, "You're telling a story. I know we walk because we don't have money." The boy cried the whole way to Roselle.
