LENGTH: 1144 words

HEADLINE: 102d Congress Opens, Troubled On Gulf but Without a Consensus

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
The 102d Congress convened today, unenthusiastic about war in the Persian Gulf but institutionally uncertain about how and when to express those doubts.
The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, said "there's no question that there will be a debate on the question of the use of force in the gulf." But, he added, "The question is the appropriate time for that debate." 
 In the Senate, though, Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, said: "The best time to debate this issue is before this country commits itself to war and not after. Our constitutional obligations are here and now."
 
Asserting Their Rights
 Assembling from around the country in the clearest atmosphere of impending war since the 77th Congress convened 50 years ago today, the 535 lawmakers spoke more clearly of their prerogatives than of their intentions. And they seemed more agreed on the idea that Congress was constitutionally entitled to a voice than on what that voice should say.
The gulf cast a shadow over the festivities, parties and general good humor that go with the opening day of any Congress. A freshman Republican, Representative Rick Santorum of Pittsburgh, was sworn in with his young nieces, Elizabeth Kusturiss and Alyssa Thornburg, on his arms, and said, "I need more information to be convinced that we need to take offensive action at this time."
Mr. Foley and Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic majority leader, returned to Capitol Hill from a White House breakfast with President Bush in agreement that no Congressional debate should be held pending a possible meeting between Secretary of State James A. Baker and Iraq's Foreign Minister next week. But they insisted that a debate would be held sometime, and maintained that Mr. Bush had no legal authority to order an attack on Iraq without Congressional approval first. They noted that he had disagreed, again today, with that view of the Constitution.
 Meanwhile, their colleagues were drafting and discussing various proposals. One, introduced in the House with 38 co-sponsors by Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, sought to require Mr. Bush to give economic sanctions another year's trial before any attack on Iraq. Other plans included assertions of Congressional authority or of support for Mr. Bush.
But not every lawmaker was ready to wait. While the House convened smoothly at noon, quickly taking up a wrangle over an old issue, the budget, the Senate was immediately plunged into a sharp dispute over the timing of any gulf debate.
Mr. Mitchell got an angry response when he proposed that no resolutions be introduced before Jan. 23, unless he and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, set an earlier date. Almost the entire Senate sat and listened as Senator Harkin and Senator Brock Adams, Democrat of Washington, demanded that he promise to hold a debate before Jan. 15, the date after which the United Nations has authorized the use of force against Iraq if it does not withdraw from Kuwait.
Mr. Harkin and Mr. Adams were unimpressed with Mr. Mitchell's assurance that the Senate would get to debate the issue, and that by holding brief, pro forma sessions every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, it would be ready to act on short notice.
Mr. Harkin called for a specific date on a resolution that he, Mr. Harkin, and Senator Quentin Burdick, Democrat of North Dakota, wanted to sponsor. That resolution would put Congress on record -- as Mr. Mitchell, Mr. Foley and many other lawmakers already are as individuals -- in saying that no military attack could be launched without advance Congressional approval.
"Give us the date for debate before Jan. 15," Mr. Adams demanded. He said that a debate any later would probably come after the fact, because Mr. Bush has maintained that he could attack at any time after the United Nations deadline. "Give me the date," the Senator said. "I'll be here."
 
'Not Normal Times,' Harkin Says
 Mr. Mitchell argued, "A Senate debate on this issue would be much more productive and better informed" after the Baker mission. He said his antagonists were "prematurely forcing a decision on this principle." But Mr. Harkin said: "These are not normal times. These are times when Americans are facing war."
The dispute, which remained unresolved when the Senate recessed tonight, provided a lively start for the session. Republicans, who lost one seat in November and entered this Congress on the short end of a 56-to-44 Democratic advantage, sat by and did not join in as the Democrats tangled.
In the House, where in November the Democrats stretched their dominance by eight seats to a 266-to-168 edge over Republicans (with one seat held by a Socialist elected as an independent, Bernard Sanders of Vermont), there was no effort to block the introduction of resolutions. But Mr. Foley said it was unlikely that any would soon emerge from committees, which are not yet fully organized.
Among the early offerings was a measure by Representative Raymond J. McGrath, Republican of Long Island, demanding that Saudi Arabia use its large oil profits to pay the full cost of the American buildup in the gulf.
 
Economics and Ethics
 In addition to the gulf issue, the recession is expected to be another major concern of Congress. But it showed itself on this week's agenda only with a hearing scheduled Friday by the Joint Economic Committee on whether unemployment compensation will prove adequate during the recession.
Other concerns will include ethics investigations in the Senate, continuing problems with savings and loan associations, and developing trouble among banks. Democrats hope to push new measures to advance health care, to try again on the civil rights bill vetoed by Mr. Bush last year, and to work on campaign finance legislation.
On the gulf issue, Representative Robert H. Michel, the House Republican leader, urged fast action, with no amendments, on a resolution backing Mr. Bush. But Senator Sam Nunn, chairman of the Armed Services Committtee, said, "Most people would like the war to be a last resort after all reasonable efforts have failed." Mr. Foley said "sanctions should be given more time to have their effect on Iraq."
 
'Want It Both Ways'
 And Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, said: "A lot of people here want it both ways. If it works, they want to be with the President. If not, they want to be against him."
In sum, the messsage of this Congress's opening day was far less certain than the one Speaker Sam Rayburn offered early in 1941, 11 months before Pearl Harbor, as World War II raged. 
"Great, and I may say terrible, things are happening in this world," he said. "In issues involving the safety and security and defense of America, I expect again to see us act with practical unanimity, regardless of party."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC SCENE;
The Rich Legacy Of an Economist

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
JOSEPH J. SPENGLER, the eminent economist at Duke University who died this week in Durham, N.C., saw modern economic science as stemming from two roots -- one administrative, the other ethical.
As an economic historian, his great contribution was to trace these two sources through ancient times, cultures and religions. And, as population expert and promoter of economic development worldwide, he demonstrated how vital these administrative and ethical roots of economics remain for the understanding and betterment of human existence. 
 His first book, "France Faces Depopulation," published in 1938, was a highly original investigation of the cultural and political forces that were causing the falling birth rate in France before World War II. Many French demographers, economists and politicians of the day thought they could cure depopulation, which was feared as a source of economic and political weakness, by a moderate degree of state intervention. They proposed financial incentives to increase the birth rate.
But Professor Spengler, who was the James B. Duke Professor Emeritus of Economics and a former president of the American Economic Association, said the proposed remedy would be inadequate because it underestimated the social and cultural changes that were weakening the family "as a reproductive system." Whether birth rates could be lifted or lowered by governmental action, he said, would depend in the final analysis on whether cultural patterns were subject to modification by a modest state program.
He concluded that in the absence of a much more profound change in the income and social structure of France measures to spur population growth were bound to fail. Indeed, even so earth-shaking an event as World War II, which broke out soonafter his book was published, did not invalidate his deep analysis and foresightful conclusion.
A small-town boy -- he grew up in Piqua, Ohio, and worked on the local newspaper there before going to college -- Professor Spengler was, and remained, an ardent lover of baseball and freedom -- and a bitter enemy of umpires and of political or bureaucratic interference in his own life or anybody else's.
Yet he was a realist, and recognized the difficulty of resolving the clash between different views of what human beings are really like and what it takes to make them behave properly. The fundamental clash, as he saw it, was between the philosophies of Thomas Hobbes (1588-1679) and John Locke (1632-1704) -- the Hobbesian creed based on a perception of man as dominated by passions and in urgent need of being governed by the state ("Leviathan") versus the Lockean view based on a perception of man as rational, with little need of state control.
The overwhelming majority of Western economists take the Lockean view. Even the economists of the Soviet Union have shifted to that view, rejecting the state-dominated doctrine of Marx, Lenin and Hobbes.
But Professor Spengler, wanting to accept completely the conventional economic wisdom, still recognized that it might be based on too benign and wishful a view of people and the degree of freedom they could be entrusted with. He liked to quote Plato's thought in "The Republic": "The best is for everyone to be ruled by a wise and godlike power, if possible seated in his own heart; if not, let it act upon him from without."
In a nutshell, Plato's formula describes the battle being waged now within the Soviet Union, with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev being urged by the hard-liners in the military, the K.G.B. and the civil bureaucracy to restore order to save the system, and former Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze declining the vice presidency and leaving the Government in an effort to bring the nation to its senses, and put it back on the path to economic reform, based on a market-oriented economy with power devolving to the republics -- and to individuals. It seems to be a war within the heart and mind of President Gorbachev himself.
Professor Spengler, even knowing the risks of turbulent freedom, would have stood with Mr. Shevardnadze and the physicist and humanist Andrei Sakharov before him. He would oppose Mr. Gorbachev as philosopher-king. He lacked Plato's faith in philosopher-kings, knowing that the philosopher-kings of our time have borne such names as Hitler, Stalin and Saddam Hussein.
But he was no ideologue of the market as the ideal allocator of goods or dispenser of justice. Though the market spurs and rewards efficiency and innovation, he held, it often neglects those esthetic, intellectual and moral qualities essential to the good society. And it may despoil the earth's irreplaceable resources.
Nor was Dr. Spengler a flag waver. He warned that the military security of neither the United States nor the Soviet Union "is firmly based, given the widespread poverty, rapid population growth and rising expectations in the underdeveloped countries." Both superpowers, he said, were wasting their capital, their knowledge, their energies and natural gifts for helping mankind. He was always closer to Jeremiah than to Hobbes or Locke.

HEADLINE: Dispute Prompts Rudin to Quit Budget Panel

 BODY:
Lewis Rudin, the developer active in civic affairs, resigned yesterday from the board of the Citizens Budget Commission in a disagreement over the watchdog group's criticism of New York City's tentative labor agreement.
The city and two large municipal workers unions announced on Wednesday a settlement that would provide a wage and benefit increase of 5 percent to 150,000 city workers. The president of the budget commission, Raymond D. Horton, said that it was too generous and that it would lead to more layoffs of city workers.
Mr. Rudin, the president of Rudin Management, a large real-estate company, said yesterday that the criticism was unwarranted. Mr. Rudin said he had resigned both because he disagreed with Mr. Horton and because the president had failed to consult with board members of the nonprofit commission.
"I am tired of naysayers," Mr. Rudin said in an interview. "I think that this city is being hurt by the constant rhetoric that is being spewed out in the media of negativism in this city."
Mr. Rudin, who serves as an informal economics adviser to Mayor David N. Dinkins, said, "It's O.K. to be critical, but on balance once in the while give the guy a pat on the back."
Mr. Horton said he was sorry Mr. Rudin had resigned. Mr. Rudin had been on the 120-member board for many years, Mr. Horton said, but he had not been an active participant for at least 10 years.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
CalFed Is Expecting Loss of $140 Million

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3

 BODY:
CalFed Inc., the parent of the nation's fourth-largest savings and loan institution, said today that it expected to report a loss of $140 million in the fourth quarter because of a weakening commercial real estate market.
In the fourth quarter of 1989, CalFed, which owns the California Federal Bank, earned $23.6 million, or 94 cents a share. 
 The anticipated quarterly loss is largely the result of CalFed's decision to add $200 million to California Federal's reserves for possible losses on loans. The company said the decision reflected the national downturn in commercial real estate.
"Commercial real estate markets have continued to deteriorate from overbuilding, a weaker economy and a scarcity of credit," said Jerry A. St. Dennis, CalFed's chairman and chief executive. "The prudent action is to increase further our reserves in the fourth quarter."
CalFed said that Federal regulators had recently completed an examination of California Federal's books and that it did not expect the Government to require additional reserves. But CalFed's decision to increase its reserves for the quarter suggests that other savings institutions and banks may have to take similar steps, resulting in another quarter of depressed earnings or losses throughout the industry.
On the New York Stock Exchange today, CalFed closed at $3.375, down 50 cents a share, or 12.9 percent, the day's second-worst percentage decline.
CalFed also said that it had injected an additional $77 million into California Federal as new capital. The additional capital enabled the savings and loan to meet stricter Federal guidelines for financial health that took effect on Dec. 31.
The $77 million came from the proceeds of the sale by CalFed last year of one of its insurance subsidiaries for $110 million. CalFed, which is based in Los Angeles, has been selling its insurance businesses to concentrate on the savings business. It expects to sell another insurance subsidiary in the first quarter for an immediate net gain of $65 million plus another $35 million in the next three years.
"One of the goals in our restructuring program has been to redirect capital from other lines of business in order to strengthen our core banking business," Mr. St. Dennis said. "This capital contribution will enable the bank to move more readily to achieve its potential."

HEADLINE: OFFICE IN MOSCOW OPENED BY ISRAELIS

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Israel raised its blue and white flag over a consulate in Moscow today in a major step toward the restoration of full diplomatic relations between the two nations.
The opening of the Israeli Consulate comes nearly 24 years after the Soviet Union abruptly broke ties with Israel over the 1967 Middle East War, and in the middle of the biggest flow of Jewish emigration from this country to Israel. 
 "This is the day which the Lord hath made," Aryeh Levin, the new Israeli Consul General, said in Hebrew at a simple ceremony, quoting from Psalm 118. "We will rejoice and be glad in it."
On the street in front of the consulate, several dozen would-be emigrants watched and smiled as the Israeli flag with the Star of David was raised in a gentle flurry of Moscow snow.
"This, thank God, will be my last Soviet winter," said Irina Krasnopolskaya, as a chorus from the Moscow Synagogue sang "Hatikvah," the Israeli national anthem, and several guests began to sing and dance spontaneously in the snow around the flag pole.
 
200,000 Left in 1990
 Mrs. Krasnopolskaya, an engineer from Odessa, her husband and two children are among 400,000 Soviet Jews that Mr. Levin estimated will emigrate to Israel this year. In 1990, he said, nearly 200,000 Jews from the Soviet Union moved to Israel, with 45,000 arriving there in December alone.
The easing of Jewish emigration, once a bitter point of dispute between Israel and the Soviet Union and between the United States and the Soviet Union, has been one of the most significant results of the warming of relations between Moscow and Jerusalem.
Mr. Levin officially presented his credentials on Dec. 25, the day a Soviet diplomat presented his credentials at the Consul General in Israel.
Mr. Levin said that his country would have preferred re-establishing full diplomatic ties, but that the Soviet Union was still "reticent on this subject."
 
Moscow Sets Conditions
 At various points, Moscow has demanded that as a condition to such a move, Israel must agree to take part in a Middle East peace conference and guarantee that Soviet emigres will not be settled in the occupied Arab territories.
Mr. Levin said Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze indicated in a meeting last month that Moscow no longer insisted that Israel agree to take part in a peace conference, but that it wanted further assurances that Soviet emigres would not be settled in the territories.
Israeli officials have repeatedly assured Moscow that Soviet emigres were not being directed to the territories. Mr. Levin said today that most housing being built for the new arrivals was within the pre-1967 Israeli borders.
"I think their problem is that they made a decision many years ago," Mr. Levin said of the Soviet hesitation. "And it is very difficult for them to undo this decision, so they are undoing it bit by bit."
 
Direct Flights Planned
 Mr. Levin said that El Al, the Israeli airline, would begin direct charter flights between the two countries at the end of the month, but that at the insistence of the Soviet side, the flights for now would be only for business and tourist travel. Emigrants will continue to travel to Israel by going to transit points in Europe and then boarding Israeli-chartered and sponsored planes to Israel.
Since its embassy here was closed in 1967, Israeli interests have been represented in the Soviet Union by the Netherlands. Friday, in fact, will be the first day that Israeli diplomats will issue Israeli entry visas without the help of Dutch diplomats.
The consulate was closed today for most official business, and there was not the usual line of some 1,200 people who have been coming daily to wait for the final Israeli entry visa that will allow them to leave this country for Israel.
Instead, a few dozen people milled around outside, exchanging gossip about emigration and looking at the newly hoisted flag of the country they will soon call home.
 
Street Becomes a Market
 The street outside the consulate has become a veritable market of rumor and information. Entrepreneurs have set up tables from which they hawk their wares, including teach-yourself-Hebrew courses.
"It's 200 rubles here, but it will cost you $95 there," one seller said of a five-cassette course with a text.
Also being sold were lists of apartment prices in various regions of Israel (two rubles for the list, $135,000 for a three-room apartment in Tel Aviv), Hebrew-Russian dictionaries, a guide to personal computers, a book in Russian titled "Love and the Jewish Bride," and Cyrillic maps of Israel.
One man was selling visa applications to Australia and South Africa, available at the embassies free but for a four-hour wait in the cold, and for 35 rubles through him.
The salesman who seemed to be doing the briskest business was selling very large suitcases.
Jews preparing to leave the Soviet Union for Israel said a complex tangle of reasons pushed them to leave. They said they feared the possibility of civil war in a country of rising tensions. The deteriorating economy made them wonder about their future and the future of their children. If life gets any worse here, they said, Jews will become scapegoats.
 
'Not Very Well Treated Here'
 "Certainly Jews have a collective memory of what they went through over these past 70 years," Mr. Levin said. "This is the primary reason for their departure and for their going to Israel. They were not very well treated here, and that's putting it mildly, over the years."
Some people said that Jews had never stopped being scapegoats and victims here and that even their fear of war in the Middle East was not as great as their fear of what would happen to Jews here if society continued its current collapse.
"I'm not a religious person or even a cultural Jew," said Mrs. Krasnopolskaya. "But it's simply horrible to spend your whole life feeling like a second-class citizen. Here, being a Jew has meant only unpleasantness. In Israel, at least it will be a new beginning. It is honestly our only choice, the only choice we can make for our children."
Mrs. Krasnopolskaya said she had even enjoyed the long hours she spent waiting in the cold outside the Israeli Consulate.
"It's the only line in this country that's pleasant to stand in," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Israeli flag being raised yesterday outside consulate in Moscow, marking a major step in the restoration of full diplomatic relations. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
PAN AM IS CURBING SERVICE IN MIDEAST

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it was suspending flights to Tel Aviv and to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, because of surging insurance rates, a result of the crisis in the Middle East.
In addition, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines canceled its flights to Amman, Jordan, and other carriers are evaluating whether to continue serving Middle Eastern destinations. Travel agents said bookings to the area had dropped sharply and suggested that could be an important factor in the airlines' decisions. 
 "It was not economically feasible to continue operations," Pam Hanlon, Pan Am's director of corporate communications, said, because insurance rates to Tel Aviv have increased twentyfold, to $65,000 a flight, and to Riyadh tenfold, to $162,500 a flight. The airline was not responding to any terrorist threat in suspending its flights, nor had there been any Government attempt to influence the carrier as part of the campaign against Iraq, she added.
 
Caution in Case of War
 In Washington, a State Department official who spoke on condition of anonymity agreed that there had been no increase in terrorist threats or activity but suggested that the airlines and the insurance industry were applying the caution that might be expected when operating in a potential war zone. Much of the world's aircraft fleet is insured by underwriters on the Lloyd's market in London.
Another State Department official suggested the carriers were responding because "the date Jan. 15 has been in every newspaper in the world."
Odette Fodor-Gernaert, a spokesman for KLM, said the Dutch airline had canceled its three weekly flights to Amman this week because of the tensions in the area.
The surge in insurance rates and slide in bookings came at a particularly bad time for Pan Am, which was already pressed for cash. The carrier has been in negotiations with other lines to sell assets to build up reserves to get it through the lean winter months.
Pan Am said it had asked the State Department and the Department of Transportation to provide insurance. The Federal Government can provide coverage to a commercial airline if it is in the foreign policy interest of the United States, and it has done so in the past, but details of how any such plans would work in the current crisis were not available last night.
"We are eager to restore the service as soon as we have the insurance coverage that is necessary," Ms. Hanlon said.
Pan Am, which operated daily flights between its Paris hub and Tel Aviv, is the first major carrier to cancel service to Israel. Saddam Hussein, the leader of Iraq, has threatened to attack Israel if the United States and other nations begin an offensive to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Pan Am operated flights twice a week from New York to Frankfurt to Riyadh. These two destinations are Pan Am's only scheduled flights to the Middle East.
Other carriers, including KLM, British Airways, Swissair and Air France have changed their flight schedules so that their planes and crews do not have to spend the night in Israel.
 
Daily Safety Reviews
 British Airways also reduced its flights from six to four a week in what it called a seasonal adjustment done every year during a period when bookings are low. A spokesman said, however, that the carrier was making daily reviews of whether it was safe to keep flying to Israel but at this point had no plans to curb service.
Some travel agents suggested that airlines might want to cancel flights because of a lack of business.
Estelle Lessack, the head of Travel Trends a travel agency in Fort Lee, N.J., said bookings to Israel had fallen substantially this year after the attacks by terrorists and the revolt by Palestinians in Israel.
"I've kept my brochures on Israel current," she said. "There hasn't been one brochure removed in a while."
"People don't want to go there," she added. "They think it's too dangerous."
The Israeli airline, El Al, has sought to attract customers by waiving cancellation penalties in the United States.
 
El Al Service
 Lori S. Samet, an El Al spokeswoman, said the carrier had not cut back service although its insurance had gone up substantially since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
She said El Al would accept all Pan Am tickets except those issued under the frequent flyer program or to groups that get special discounts.
The other main carrier to Israel, Trans World Airlines, which has six flights a week, has also seen its insurance soar but does not plan to cancel service, James Faulkner, the manager of public relations, said.
Other carriers serving the Middle East were assessing whether to keep flying there. Jean-Marc Felix, the director of public relations for Swissair, which has daily flights to Tel Aviv, said that its schedule could change depending on the situation.
 
Lower Rates Sought
 Danny Danzinger, Pan Am's manager in Israel, told Reuters that insurance premiums were negotiated once a week and that Pan Am would try to lower the rates. The suspension of service may have to be extended if the airline cannot get the rates down, he added.
A person who spoke only on condition of anonymity said that talks with the Government over insurance rates had been going on for months and that the agencies had not acted quickly, as they had in the past. But he said the airline expected the Government to assume insuring the flights in a matter of days.
Ruth Yaron, a spokeswoman at the Israeli Embassy in Washington, said that the country regretted Pan Am's decision and that the carrier should reconsider.
"Life in Israel goes on normally," she added. "This is our answer to the threat of Saddam Hussein."
For Pan Am, however, life has been more precarious than normal, and it is seeking a way to raise large amounts of cash to allow it to keep operating until next spring. Negotiations are under way, but the outlook is uncertain.
 Pan Am has an agreement to sell its London routes with landing rights at Heathrow Airport to United Airlines, and a closing of the sale would bring in $290 million, enough to keep the airline flying.

HEADLINE: Sears Says It Will Cut 21,000 Jobs

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Struggling to reverse what has become a very serious decline, Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it would eliminate 21,000 jobs at its stores nationwide.
That represents slightly more than 10 percent of the jobs in Sears stores. The positions being eliminated will range from those for stockroom clerks to accounting personnel and loading-dock crews. but will not include sales personnel. The reductions will involve 3,500 full-time positions and 17,500 part-time slots. 
 At the same time it announced the job cuts, the nation's largest retailer said it would take more than a dozen other steps to cut costs at stores or to make them more attractive or convenient places to shop.
The new measures represent the latest attempt by Sears to regain customers lost to leaner, more innovative discount rivals like Wal-Mart and Target Stores. About two years ago, Sears began the process of competing more intensively by cutting prices and introducing well-known national brand names to its product lines. When that failed to produce results, Sears began to advertise heavily and even resorted early in December to what it called an "after-Christmas sale."
That, too, helped little, and Sears, like other major department stores, released a disappointing sales report for last month, during the peak holiday selling period. Again, shoppers appeared to prefer the discount stores. [Page D4.]
 
Analysts Are Divided
 Sears's announcement of layoffs and other changes is thus part of a continuing effort. But analysts, while supportive, were divided on the outcome.
"Now they have really begun to cut out fat," said George Rosenbaum, the president of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a Chicago-based market research firm. "I applaud the move."
But Edward A. Weller, at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, said he was skeptical, if only because Sears had announced other expense-reduction programs that produced minimal savings. And he argued that despite the view that Sears's biggest problem was bloated overhead, the company had an even bigger problem: its sales, after adjusting for inflation, are declining.
"They still have not been able to inspire the customer to shop more at Sears," Mr. Weller said.
The retailer's announcement today did not make clear how many employees would be laid off since the 21,000 positions to be eliminated refer to jobs rather than employees.
But Sears said that of the 306,000 people who were working in its retail group as of Dec. 31, 206,000 were actually in stores. Thus, the ultimate percentage of store employees who lose their jobs could easily be 10 percent. To the extent that all 21,000 positions to be eliminated will be in non-selling areas the percentage of people in those areas who could lose their jobs could exceed 10 percent.
In any case, morale at Sears stores, which was already suffering, could sink further in coming days. While an unspecified number of employees whose jobs are being eliminated will be offered positions elsewhere in stores, the majority will be given severance pay and let go.
"It is, as you can see, quite comprehensive," said a senior Sears executive who asked to remain anonymous.
 
Test Phase at 10 Stores
 For more than a year, ever since it became apparent that the giant merchant was sinking into a deep slump, Sears has been faulted by retail rivals and Wall Street analysts for not taking the measures necessary to reverse its sagging fortunes. Among the most serious criticisms has been that Sears has been unwilling to bite the bullet on staffing; its overhead has remained twice that of rivals: roughly 30 percent of sales.
When Sears stores introduced national brands to complement its Kenmore, Craftsman and Diehard house brands, the critics generally applauded. But they also saw the effort as a "me-too" measure that put Sears on a more even plane with rivals but did nothing to give it an edge.
The layoff announcement appeared aimed at showing that Sears was finally serious about major job cuts.
The job reductions make up the centerpiece of what Sears is calling its Store-Simplification Program, aimed at making Sears stores more efficient, attractive and convenient. The program, the existence of which has been rumored for some time and which has been in a test phase at 10 Sears "learning-center" stores around the country, will now be rolled out to all 863 Sears stores.
Sears said the job reductions were but one of more than a dozen elements of the program it hoped to have in place nationwide by the end of June. The program also included these steps:
*Cash registers will be programmed to accept payments due on Sears credit cards and to report account information to card holders. This could result not only in savings to Sears since fewer staffers will be needed in the huge charge-card operation, but also increased convenience for shoppers.
*Automatic tellers will be installed in 150 stores so customers can receive cash advances against their Sears Discover credit cards.
*Sears is computerizing its system for printing and distributing promotional signs. Until now, it has printed signs at regional centers and had them trucked to individual stores. This has resulted in some stores' receiving signs late.
*Kiosks will be installed throughout the Sears retail network to allow shoppers to telephone for information from a Sears representative on everything from availability of replacement parts for cars and major appliances to delivery times for out-of-stock items.
*Personnel at store credit-card desks will be trained to handle refunds and returns, reducing the need for two separate staffs.
But the deepest reductions in staffing will take place in back rooms and on loading docks.
For example, even though operations at the headquarters here are modern, many Sears stores still keep books manually. Some stores have up to 35 logs that keep track of things like merchandise shipped and received. The program calls for computerization of these logs.
"We do expect significant savings, and we do expect this to improve profits," the Sears executive said.

HEADLINE: Vanished: A Man, $13 Million And Faith in a State's Banks

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 3

 BODY:
Month after month last year, the money poured out of a small neighborhood bank here in what its president depicted as a legitimate series of $13 million in loans.
The only trouble, investigators have found, is that the 128 people and businesses listed as loan recipients neither applied for nor received any of the money. Instead, the investigators say, it went to the bank president himself, Joseph Mollicone Jr., who has disappeared. 
 Law-enforcement agents say the story of the bank, the Heritage Loan and Investment Company, is the story of how one man, and a mere $13 million, set off Rhode Island's bank crisis, forcing into insolvency the private fund that insured one-third of the state's depositors and leading the Governor, Bruce G. Sundlun, to declare a bank emergency on Tuesday, his first day in office. It is also an unusual glimpse into the inner workings of organized crime here, and the close connections that law-enforcement officials say exist in this state between organized crime, business and politics.
The 47-year-old Mr. Mollicone (pronounced MAHL-la-cone), who drove a black Porsche and lived in the wealthiest part of town, was last seen Nov. 8, when his son dropped him off at Logan Airport in Boston for a flight to Newark, just as state banking officials began to sift through the series of allegedly fraudulent loans. But investigators say there was no ticket in his name, and a worldwide manhunt by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Interpol has turned up no clues to his whereabouts. Investigators say they assume he is still alive but add that they have no proof.
"The enormity of what happened is incredible," said James E. O'Neil, Rhode Island's Attorney General. Mr. O'Neil is supervising a state grand jury investigation into Mr. Mollicone and Heritage that he said today was "the biggest in state history."
"Part and parcel of our investigation is to determine what role organized crime played in the Heritage affair," Mr. O'Neil said. As part of the investigation, state police officers removed cartons of records today from the bank's main office, a small brick and glass building on Atwells Avenue in Providence's tightly knit Italian-American section.
Among those who were listed as recipients of the fraudulent loans, investigators say, were Mr. Mollicone's father-in-law, his godfather, his golfing partners and Vincent A. (Buddy) Cianci Jr., a convicted felon who was re-elected as this city's Mayor shortly afterward.
Investigators say that in addition to issuing the apparently fraudulent loans, Mr. Mollicone forced several depositors in Heritage to give him blank withdrawal slips, which he then used to make withdrawals they had not authorized. Law-enforcement officials say they are still unclear what Mr. Mollicone's main purpose was and what he did with the money they say he took from Heritage.
One official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said investigators were working on several theories: the possibility that Mr. Mollicone was using his bank to launder money for organized crime, that he was shielding the real identity of depositors by putting money in accounts without properly recording the customers' names and that he was personally siphoning off mortgage money repaid to the bank.
Whichever explanation of his actions proves correct, the consequences were dramatic and widespread, coming at a time of recession in Rhode Island and weakness in banking across the country.
 
Run on the Bank
 On Nov. 13, after Gov. Edward D. DiPrete ordered an investigation into reports of irregularities uncovered in audits, including evidence of the bogus $13 million in loans, nervous customers staged a run on Heritage, withdrawing more than $13 million of its $22 million in deposits. That forced the private Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation, which insured 10 banks and 35 credit unions in the state, to deplete most of its $25 million in reserves.
State officials then ordered Heritage temporarily closed, but when it was reopened on Dec. 4, customers began withdrawing the remaining $8.5 million. The insurance fund then had to pump the rest of its reserves into Heritage, effectively forcing it into insolvency last Monday. It now has $2 million to $8 million, officials say.
So while despositors in Heritage got all their money back, customers at some other banks and credit unions have had their accounts frozen by the new Governor, Mr. Sundlun, and may have trouble recovering their money.
Lee Blais, a former director of criminal investigations for the Rhode Island Attorney General's office, said one factor in the troubles was Rhode Island's "old boy" network. In 1985, he said, he helped compile a report on weaknesses in the private bank insurance fund, which he delivered to Governor DiPrete. He said he also briefed the Governor on connections between Heritage and organized crime.
But Mr. Mollicone was a vice chairman of the fund, and investigators said he was so well connected socially and politically that nothing further was done.
 
'Real Problem of Cronyism'
 Mr. O'Neil, the current Attorney General, also raised questions about the operating methods of the fund, known as Risdic. He noted that there had been no audit of Heritage for three years, though an audit is required every 15 months under Risdic's procedures. And last July, when Risdic examiners finally did begin to look at the banks' books, they found a large number of "off-line" loans, or loans not recorded in the bank's computer and filed with proper documentation.
But the insurance fund did not notify the Atttorney General's office or the State Department of Business Regulation of these problems until Nov. 1. "There seems to be a real problem of cronyism," Mr. O'Neil said.
Mr. Mollicone further insulated himself from scrutiny by filling Heritage's board of directors with golfing partners, business associates and his father-in-law. Among the directors was John Muratore, a 68-year-old man who played golf with Mr. Mollicone on Saturdays. One day, Mr. Muratore recalled in an interview, Mr. Mollicone asked him and another golfing partner if they would like to be on the board.
"We said, 'O.K., that sounds good,' " Mr. Muratore said. In the past 10 years he attended only about two board meetings, he went on, adding, "We didn't do anything."
Banking was a family business for Mr. Mollicone. His father, Joseph Mollicone, ran County Loan and Finance Corporation, which he merged into Heritage and incorporated under his son's name in 1975.
The elder Mr. Mollicone was a close friend of Raymond L. S. Patriarca, the longtime head of organized crime in New England, said Mr. Blais, the former state investigator. From 1962 to 1965, when the F.B.I. monitored Mr. Patriarca's office with listening devices, the elder Mr. Mollicone's name was often used, with Mr. Patriarca directing him to make certain transactions.
Capt. Brian Andrews of the State Police said that after Mr. Mollicone's bank was twice broken into and vandalized last year, he told the State Police that he realized he had a problem with organized crime but that he could "take care of it myself" because he was friendly with Luigi Manocchio, one of the leading contenders to become the new head of organized crime in New England.
"That came as no surprise to us, because on many occasions we had observed Manocchio going into Heritage Loan," Captain Andrews said.
Captain Andrews said the vandalism might have been a "message" to Mr. Mollicone from someone in the Patriarca family, but it was unclear what had prompted the incidents.
 
A Leading Figure in Providence
 Mr. Mollicone was also a leading figure in Providence's business and political circles. According to The Providence Journal, he owned or had an interest in at least two dozen properties in the city. One was the old Providence Journal building, which he had rehabilitated in 1983 and persuaded Mayor Cianci to lease for office space for two city agencies at high rents. Mr. Cianci's action touched off charges of bid rigging and conflict of interest from members of the City Council. In the same year Mr. Mollicone bought Mr. Cianci's house on Blackstone Boulevard, in the city's most fashionable neighborhood.
Mr. Cianci did not return a reporter's telephone calls to his office today. He was re-elected in November even though he pleaded no contest in 1984 to charges of attacking a man he thought was having an affair with his estranged wife. He beat the man with a log and an ashtray while Mr. Cianci's police guard stood by.

State police officers removed boxes of records yesterday from the bank's main branch in Providence. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times) (pg. A14)

HEADLINE: Cost of Labor Peace;
With New Wage Pact, Dinkins Risks More Criticism of Fiscal Management

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
In two weeks, Mayor David N. Dinkins is to unveil a financial plan that seems certain to summon painful memories of the bad old days of the 1970's. So what was he doing this week giving municipal workers a raise?
 First, the Mayor gained labor peace, which is better than the alternative. Because of the way the deal is structured, it would not add to the growing gap in the budget that his administration is now preparing. And, said Eric J. Schmertz, the city's Labor Relations Commissioner, Mr. Dinkins believes the increase in wages and benefits, which amounts to 5 percent over 15 months for 150,000 city workers, is fair and necessary. 
 "The Mayor is very concerned about the impact of substantial cost-of-living increases and he wants to do something about it," Mr. Schmertz said in an interview yesterday. "We're trying to keep a decent work force. We're trying to do something about morale. That's important at a time of economic adversity."
But in agreeing to a $233 million labor settlement with District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees and Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, on top of a $236 million settlement with the teachers' union, Mr. Dinkins has clearly risked more criticism when his ability to manage the city's worsening fiscal condition is already under close scrutiny.
 
Worried About Expense
 If times were less perilous, the contracts might have been hailed as among the cheapest in years. Instead, fiscal monitors and other budget experts were worried about the expense, much as they were when the slightly more generous teachers' contract was reached in October.
With the city's economy sputtering, tax revenues sagging and budget gaps reopening only weeks after they were thought to have been closed, the new contracts all but guarantee that some municipal workers will be getting raises while others are losing their jobs and the city is closing firehouses, increasing school class sizes, rebuilding fewer roads and picking up less trash.
"We tried mightily," said Mr. Schmertz, when asked whether the city sought to persuade the unions to defer or even give up raises to keep more of their members on the payroll. But Barry Feinstein, head of the teamsters' union local, said the city was never willing to guarantee jobs would be saved.
Not that Mr. Feinstein believes that all the layoffs that have been threatened will materialize, since he said he disagreed with the administration's increasingly gloomy view of the city's economic prospects.
"We look at the same numbers they look at," he said. "We put a different view on them."
 
Pressure on Leaders
 Given the nature of the city's "me too" bargaining, though, the deal with the teamsters and District Council 37 was probably sealed when the teachers won a 5.8 percent increase in wages and benefits in a one-year contract. That pact boxed the city and the other unions in, giving workers a target and putting their leaders under pressure to attain it.
"We did that, I did that," Mr. Schmertz said of the teachers' contract. "I will defend that contract to my dying day, but as the first contract it created problems."
As in the teachers' pact, much of the cost in the latest agreement would be covered by a rise in the assumption of how much the workers' pension fund would earn, to 9 percent from the current 8.25 percent. This would allow the city to use money that it would have contributed to the fund for raises. It also would allow Mr. Dinkins to assert that the only city money required for the raises was already in the budget, so the increase would not widen the city's spending gap.
At a time when the financial markets in which much of the pension money is invested are shaky, however, the pension fund change, which requires the approval of the State Legislature and the Governor, is making fiscal monitors anxious. And if such money must be spent, some fiscal experts would prefer it be used to maintain services, not raise salaries.
 
No Sense of Crisis
 To Felix G. Rohatyn, the outgoing chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, a state panel that watches over the city's finances, the current labor talks point up differences in the way the city and the municipal unions now face fiscal strife.
A decade and half ago, when the city was nearly bankrupt, leaders of labor, management and the business community formed a coalition. Workers deferred a 6 percent raise they had already won in exchange for a city policy that made layoffs a last resort. The workers eventually got their money when the city re-entered the financial markets and could balance its budget even with the workers' raises, which happened in the early 1980's.
This time, which Mr. Rohatyn believes is even more threatening, it is nevertheless more like business as usual for the city and its unions.
"It really does seem that there is no sense of impending crisis here," he said, "because if there were, these negotiations would not have come to this conclusion."
 
A Different Approach
 But Stanley Hill, the head of District Council 37, remembered the 1970's differently. He said his members were hurt then, when tens of thousands of city employees lost jobs. This time, they took a different approach.
With this week's labor agreement, the city has brought about two-thirds of its work force under contract agreements. It must still bargain with the uniformed city workers, who traditionally receive the best deal. But Mr. Schmertz, the Labor Commissioner, is already talking about more bargaining with the unions to find ways to reduce the number of layoffs. And if the city's economy worsens enough, he said, contracts already settled could be reopened.
But that hardly seems likely to console Mr. Rohatyn.
"You don't have to be a pessimist," he said, "to be extremely worried about where this is all going."

HEADLINE: Discount Stores Lead in December Sales Gains

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
In the face of the slowing economy, many consumers did their Christmas shopping at discount stores last month. While a number of the nation's largest department stores reported poor December sales yesterday, discount store chains like Wal-Mart Target and Venture posted respectable sales gains in light of the poor economy.
Retail analysts said the poor showing by the department stores was a further sign that the economy -- already battered by rising unemployment, declining industrial output and a housing slump -- was in a recession. 
 "The consumer generally traded down this Christmas," said Kenneth A. Macke, chairman and chief executive of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, a Minneapolis-based retailer that operates both department and discount stores, including Target Stores. "The Wal-Marts, the Targets, the K Marts did better than the high-end retailer."
 
Sears Sales Lackluster
 Among department stores, both Sears, Roebuck & Company and the J. C. Penny Company posted lackluster sales figures.
Sears said yesterday that it planned to eliminate 21,000 jobs as part of a continuing program to reduce expenses. It also announced more than a dozen other steps to improve its competitiveness.
Daniel Barry, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company, said that half of the department stores he follows reported flat or declining sales for December when comparing sales at stores open for more than a year.
"The department stores did distinctly worse than the discounters," Mr. Barry said.
Analysts said white-collar workers, who typically shop at department stores, had been hit hard by the current economic slowdown. "This recession started as a yuppie recession," said Monroe Greenstein, an independent retail analyst.
Mr. Macke of Dayton Hudson also said this Christmas season lacked a hot product in women's fashion or consumer electronics to draw shoppers into department stores.
For stores open more than a year in Dayton Hudson's department store division, which includes the company's two Midwest department store chains, Marshall Field's and Dayton's, sales were flat in December. Sales at the company's Target Stores open for more than a year rose 4 percent.
 
Wal-Mart Assessment
 At Wal-Mart, Paul R. Carter, the chief financial officer, said of the company's 6 percent gain in December for stores open more than a year, "In light of the current environment, it was a pretty good performance."
Analysts said Wal-Mart normally posts double-digit same-store sales gains.
Retailing executives and analysts use same-store results, or the results of stores open for more than a year, as the best measure of a company's performance.
Some large retailers, like R. H. Macy & Company and Montgomery Ward & Company, do not report sales figures on a monthly basis.
Venture Stores Inc., which operates 79 discount stores in eight states in the Midwest, reported same-store increases of 4.3 percent in December.
 
Gains for Specialty Retailers
 The specialty retailers the Gap Inc. and the Limited Inc. both continued to outperform the industry.
But at department stores, "the numbers are not good," Mr. Barry, the Kidder, Peabody analyst, said.
In addition to the sales decline at Sears, same-store sales fell at Carter Hawley Stores Inc., a large department store operator with extensive operations in the West, and at Dallas-based J. C. Penny Company.
Mr. Carter of Wal-Mart and Mr. Macke of Dayton Hudson both said that consumers largely bought functional presents, like small appliances and household goods.
Also popular, Mr. Macke said, were footballs, fishing poles and dolls. "What we didn't sell was a lot of expensive electronic games," he said.
Despite Target's relatively strong showing, Mr. Macke said sales were below expectations companywide. "It's been a tough month and business was difficult to get," he said.
Mr. Macke said Dayton Hudson was not optimistic about the first half of the year. "Consumer confidence is as low as I have seen it in more than 20 years," he added.
 
Sales of Big Retailers
 
By The Associated Press
Here are the domestic sales for December and for the fiscal year to date reported yesterday by some of the nation's largest retailers.
The current year's sales are compared with those of the previous year.
Reporting periods vary slightly. Most retailers' fiscal years end in late January.
Sales include those from stores open at least a year, which are also known as same-store or comparable store sales, and overall sales. Retailers release only percentage changes for same-store sales, while they provide dollar figures and percentages for overall sales.
Not all retailers release same-store percentages.
Sears, Roebuck & Co.: For the four weeks ended Dec. 29, same-store sales fell three- tenths of 1 percent and overall sales rose 1.4 percent, to $3.89 billion; for 11 months, same-store sales rose 1.8 percent, and overall sales rose 2 percent, to $31.37 billion.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc.: For the month of December, same-store sales rose 6 percent, and overall sales rose 23 percent, to $4.47 billion; for first 11 months, same-store sales rose 10 percent, and overall sales rose 26 percent, to $30.1 billion.
K Mart Corp.: For the four weeks ended Dec. 26, same-store sales rose 1.2 percent, and overall sales rose 4.6 percent, $4.45 billion; for 11 months, same-store sales rose 1.8 percent, and overall sales rose 10 percent, to $29.65 billion.
J. C. Penney Co.: For four weeks ended Dec. 29, same-store sales fell three-tenths of 1 percent, and overall sales rose 1.5 percent, to $2.29 billion; for 11 months, same- store sales fell three-tenths of 1 percent, and overall sales rose 1 percent, to $14.28 billion.
Dayton Hudson Corp.: For four weeks ended Dec. 29, same-store sales rose 2.4 percent, and overall sales rose 15 percent, to $2.26 billion; for 11 months, same-store sales rose 4.1 percent, and overall sales rose 14 percent, to $13.52 billion.
May Department Stores Co.: For the four weeks ended Dec. 29, same-store sales fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, and overall sales rose 9.5 percent, to $1.66 billion; for 11 months, same-store sales rose 1 percent, and overall sales rose 7.4 percent, to $9.42 billion.
Melville Corp.: For the four weeks ended Dec. 29, overall sales rose 25.6 percent, to $1.3 billion; for fiscal 1990, ended Dec. 29, overall sales rose 14.9 percent, to $8.68 billion. The company does not report same-store sales percentages.
Woolworth Corp.: For the four weeks ended Dec. 29, same-store sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, and overall sales rose 5.5 percent, to $780 million; for 11 months, same-store sales rose 3.4 percent, and overall sales rose 7.1 percent, to $5.11 billion.
Limited Inc.: For the four weeks ended Dec. 29, same-store sales rose 4 percent, and overall sales rose 19 percent, to $824.2 million. The company did not report a same- store sales percentage for 11 months, but overall sales rose 17.8 percent, to $4.84 billion. The 1989 results included Lerner Woman division, which has been sold.
TJX Cos.: For the four weeks ended Dec. 29, overall sales rose 19.4 percent, to $293.4 million; for 11 months, overall sales rose 13.6 percent, to $2.29 billion. The company does not report same-store sales percentages.
Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc.: For the four weeks ended Dec. 29, same-store sales fell 3.7 percent, and overall sales fell 1.7 percent, to $355.7 million; for 11 months, same-store sales fell 1.9 percent, and overall sales fell nine-tenths of 1 percent, to $2.17 billion.
Gap Inc.: For the four weeks ended Dec. 29, same-store sales rose 12 percent, and overall sales rose 24 percent, to $305 million. For 11 months, same-store sales rose 14 percent, and overall sales rose 24 percent, to 1.79 billion.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Lintas Hires Creative Head; Levine, Huntley Loses Chief

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
IN an unexpected move, Lintas New York said yesterday that it had reorganized its creative department and hired Tony DeGregorio, who produced numerous award-winning campaigns at Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, with the work for Subaru automobiles perhaps the best known.
Mr. DeGregorio's jump to Lintas was just one of two blows to Levine, Huntley. 
 In a telephone interview last night, Harold Levine, the agency's co-founder, confirmed speculation that Robert H. Schmidt, the chairman and chief executive, had resigned to become vice president for marketing at the Dreyfus Corporation, one of the agency's clients.
Mr. Levine, chairman of the agency's executive committee, will assume the chairmanship and said he would name a replacement within 60 days.
Levine, Huntley, with billings of more than $200 million, has been one of New York's fastest-growing agencies.
 Mr. DeGregorio, who had been Levine, Huntley's creative director for three years, will become an executive vice president at Lintas, the agency for Diet Coke and other giant accounts, and will oversee its creative department. He will also assume some responsibility for day-to-day operations, assisting Frank DeVito, the president, who has taken on the added task of overseeing the creative output of Lintas's offices in Canada and Latin America.
In addition to Mr. DeGregorio, Lintas hired Catherine St. Jean as director of creative services. She held a similar post at DDB Needham.
Some industry executives speculated that Lintas had hired Mr. DeGregorio in part to give new pizazz to the advertising for Diet Coke. Executives at the Coca-Cola Company have reportedly been pushing Lintas to create a new strategy for Diet Coke's celebrity-laden "Just for the taste of it" campaign, which has essentially not changed in eight years.
But Mr. DeVito said that was not the case. "Tony is one of the best creative minds in the business," Mr. DeVito said. "I hired him to bring fresh thinking to all of our work. He will undoubtedly change things, but his mandate isn't to stir things up."
Mr. DeVito did confirm that Coca-Cola executives had been putting pressure on Lintas to revamp Diet Coke's advertising. "The motto at Coke is 'The world belongs to the discontented,' " he said. "They've been pushing for us to move on to the next step, but we're reluctant to move away from a successful campaign."
For his part, Mr. DeGregorio said he had decided to join Lintas because he needed to challenge himself. "I'd done everything there is to do at Levine, Huntley," he said. "This is an opportunity to work on brands that are No. 1 in their categories."
At Levine, Huntley, Mr. DeGregorio said he had primarily worked with clients like Subaru that were not category leaders and were looking for aggressive advertising to increase market share. "When you're working for No. 3, you have to do a lot of underdog advertising," he said.
Mr. DeVito said he had taken on a larger role at the agency because Canada and, more important, Latin America were becoming substantially more critical for many of Lintas's multinational clients, like Lever Brothers, I.B.M., Johnson & Johnson and Coca-Cola.
"Many of our clients are telling us they want coherent and cohesive marketing messages around the world," Mr. DeVito said. "My involvement will make it easier to get consistent strategies country to country."
Many of the agency's clients are also paying greater attention to Latin America. Industry executives forecast that because of the region's growing political and economic stability, it will be the next area of big growth in advertising.
To help its clients with sticky strategic problems anywhere in the Americas, Lintas has also formed a special creative committee made up of the top creative directors from these regions. "This way if there is a problem in Brazil," Mr. DeVito said, "we can put together a task force to find the smartest idea."

HEADLINE: Sharp Rise In Claims By Jobless

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
The number of Americans applying for unemployment benefits soared 16.8 percent, to 515,000, the week before Christmas, the highest level in nearly eight years, the Labor Department reported today.
Normally, the weekly report on initial jobless-insurance claims receives little attention. But the figures tend to move sharply at economic turning points, and consequently analysts have begun to monitor them closely for clues as to the severity of the recession that even the Bush Administration now acknowledges exists. 
 Jobless claims are among the favorite lesser-known indicators of economists these days. Others in the group include automobile assembly schedules, orders for long-lasting capital goods and factory and service-sector employment.
Today's report, which covered the week ended Dec. 22, intensified fears about the economy because the increase was exceptionally large, and it followed two straight weekly declines. Friday's report on the overall labor market for December is expected to show the jobless rate rising above 6 percent -- perhaps as high as 6.2 -- from November's level of 5.9 percent.
Traders in the credit markets repsonded to today's report, bidding up prices of Treasury securities. At the same time interest rates fell. [Page D5.]
One economic report today brought a break in the economic clouds. Sales of new homes rose 2.8 percent, to an annual rate of 506,000, in November, the Government said. It was the first gain in five months. Analysts said it indicated the slumping housing market might be stabilizing. [Page D6.]
 
Volatile Figures
 Analysts cautioned that the figures on applications for state jobless benefits were volatile, particularly at the end of the year when many companies close plants and idle workers temporarily. Adjustments for this seasonality may not adequately address the volatility.
Another drawback is that someone who loses or quits a job may get another one almost immediately.
Therefore some analysts, including Robert H. Chandross, chief economist for Lloyds Bank North America, prefer to look at the number of people actually collecting benefits.
Today's report showed 2,987,000 workers receiving payments in the week ended Dec. 15, compared with 3,006,000 in the week before. Initial claims precede benefits by one week.
For all its gyrations, initial claims are still seen as a valuable, forward-looking indicator, one with a signal so strong it can scarcely be ignored.
After chugging along at about 350,000 for much of early 1990, initial claims in early fall suddenly "went straight up like a rocket" to more than half a million, said Kevin Logan, chief economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
Economists are also paying close attention these days to the automobile industry, which still has a powerful effect on the economy, although not so big as it once had.
Sales slumped to a 5.1 million annual rate in mid-December, industry figures showed today, continuing a slump that forced producers to cut December output to a rate of 4.8 million. Scheduled output for the first quarter has been slashed over the last several weeks by 14 percent, to a 5.7 million rate, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.
Mr. Logan is among those who believe that it is business investment, not the statistically larger and steadier consumer sector, that will determine the length and severity of recession. He is closely watching the volume of orders received by factories for goods expected to last at least three years. The Commerce Department reported last week that they fell 10.5 percent in November.
 
Sifting Through Clues
 As for the job data, specialists on Friday will pay relatively little attention to the unemployment rate, believing that better economic clues are to be found in how many additional factory jobs were lost, how many aggregate hours were worked by production personnel and whether further gains in health jobs were enough to overcome losses elsewhere.
Jerry L. Jordan, chief economist for First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles, said he would be particularly eager to compare the two surveys the Labor Department uses to count jobs -- one of households, the other of business payrolls.
In general, economists believe the number of jobs reported by the payroll data is the better gauge, but Mr. Jordan has noticed that in previous recessions the household survey appeared to be more accurate.

HEADLINE: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;
A Senator Arrives, Ruffling Feathers

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
On his first day in office, Paul Wellstone made it clear that he will not be a conventional go-along, get-along United States Senator.
Mr. Wellstone, the only candidate to beat an incumbent Senator in the November elections, was ruffling senatorial feathers even before he was sworn in today. 
 After arriving in the capital in the battered green school bus that was a trademark of his no-frills upset campaign, the Minnesota Democrat left it parked outside the Dirksen Senate Office Building, taking up four parking spaces reserved for members and employees.
What left some old Senate hands grumbling the loudest was Mr. Wellstone's decision to buck tradition at the swearing-in ceremony today. The 34 other Senators who were sworn in were each escorted to the well of the chamber by the other Senator from their state.
But instead of asking Minnesota's senior Senator, Dave Durenberger, a Republican, to accompany him, Mr. Wellstone called on Walter F. Mondale, a former Vice President and Democratic Senator from the state.
Mr. Wellstone said that he had nothing against Mr. Durenberger but that Mr. Mondale was a "statesman" whose "support was critical" in his victory over Senator Rudy Boschwitz.
Mr. Wellstone said the fact that Mr. Durenberger was denounced by the Senate last year for improper financial dealings had nothing to do with his decision.
He said Mr. Durenberger took the decision well and even joked about it.
"I called up Dave Durenberger," Mr. Wellstone said before he was sworn in, "and I said to him that I really wanted to have Walter Mondale escort me. He said, 'If you were a Republican, I'd be pretty worried -- I'd feel slighted.' "
Indeed, Mr. Durenberger insisted, "This is Paul Wellstone's day and he can handle his swearing in the way he wants to."
Whatever hard feelings Mr. Durenberger may have felt, he did not display them as he watched his new colleague being sworn in. With an outstretched arm, he welcomed Mr. Wellstone, a former political science professor, to the exclusive political club.
"Congratulations, Mr. Senator," he said with a smile.
 
Budget Fight Revisited
 Remember the budget battle that came to dominate, even overwhelm, the 101st Congress? It was back practically in full force today in the House of Representatives.
Immediately after representatives were sworn in, civility gave way to rancor when Democrats proposed a change in House rules to allow the Congressional Budget Office, not the Republican-controlled Office of Management and Budget, to make binding budget estimates, which are critical in drafting the budget.
Republicans, who would prefer the O.M.B. to have the authority, angrily objected, saying the Democrats were turning back on an agreement that was brokered in budget negotiations.
Buttons proclaiming "A Deal Is A Deal" sprouted on the lapels of some House Republicans.
Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut, shouted over the presiding officer's gavel that the Democratic move was a "demonstration of oppression of the minority."
Even Newt Gingrich, the Georgia Republican and minority whip who was the chief flame thrower in last year's budget battle, got into the act.
"On the very first day we are in session," he declared, "the Democrats are breaking their agreement with the President."
But as is usually the case in the Democrat-controlled House, the Republican oratory, no matter how strong, mattered little.
The rules change was passed by a vote along party lines.
Saying he was "deeply disappointed and disturbed," President Bush vowed to veto any bill that contains the language in the rule that passed today. "Changing the House rules with a purely party line vote is neither fair nor right," Mr. Bush said in a statement, adding that the matter was "fundamental to public confidence in the budget agreement and in the Government itself."
 
Change of Face
 While they call it the "permanent" Congress, because most members are re-elected, there is something of a new face to the Congress that convened today.
As Representative Glenn M. Anderson, a California Democrat, wandered into the House chamber today, a doorkeeper had to stop himself from addressing him with the same greeting he has offered for years.
"Oh my God, I almost said, 'Hello Mr. Chairman,' " the embarrassed doorkeeper said.
Mr. Anderson, a veteran lawmaker, was ousted last month as chairman of the Public Works and Transportation Committee.
There are 44 new faces in the House. And, while Mr. Wellstone is the only Senator who has never held elective office, there are three other new Senators who moved up from the House.
Another figure who will be roaming the halls of Congress -- but was nowhere to be seen today -- is the Rev. Jesse Jackson, one of the District of Columbia's two newly elected "shadow" Senators. Mr. Jackson will not have voting privileges or a seat in the chamber and will use his unpaid post to lobby for statehood for the capital.
While the only ceremony for him was at the Convention Center here Wednesday night, Mr. Jackson insisted today that he did not want a ceremony at the Capitol. He dismissed rumors to the contrary as "completely unfounded."
 
Bills at the Start
 In seeking, rather unsuccesfully, to avoid a public floor debate over the Persian Gulf, Senate leaders did not follow their customary practice of allowing members to introduce new bills and resolutions on opening day.
But in the House, lawmakers rushed to introduce dozens of measures on dozens of topics.
Representative Barbara F. Vucanovich, Republican of Nevada, introduced legislation that would prohibit states from taxing the pensions of retirees who had moved to the state after earning their pensions in another state.
Besides the gulf crisis and budget matters, priorities of the new Congress include developing an energy policy, revamping the campaign finance system, taking steps to fight a recession and repairing the nation's crumbling roads and bridges.
Thomas S. Foley, the House Speaker, ushered in the new session with words that had probably been uttered by each of his predecessors: "I think we're going to have an extremely active and productive Congress."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vice President Dan Quayle holding a tape given to him by Senator Paul Wellstone, left, Democrat of Minnesota. The tape was recorded in December at a Minnesota town meeting, where people voiced concerns about the United States position in the Persian Gulf. Mr. Wellstone was sworn in yesterday. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)
