HEADLINE: Dinkins Aides Say Budget Needs Millions More in Spending Cuts

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Top Dinkins administration officials said yesterday that New York City's fiscal problems had worsened sharply in recent weeks and would require several hundred million dollars of additional budget cuts by June 30.
They said the city's current budget gap had grown to $500 million, double the $250 million gap disclosed only three weeks ago. 
 The disclosure came only a day after the city announced a tentative $233 million settlement that would give a wage and benefit increase of 5 percent to two of the city's large municipal unions.
At the same time yesterday, estimates of the city's budget gap -- the difference between expected revenue and projected spending -- for the next fiscal year, beginning on July 1, grew from $1.6 billion, to between $1.8 billion and $2.1 billion, an increase of as much as $500 million.
 
'It Really Hurts'
 "It is not a mischaracterization to say that this is a fiscal crisis," said Philip R. Michael, the city's Budget Director. "We also feel that we are in a position to deal with it, based on our past experience in handling very sizable problems. But it really hurts."
The new figures for this fiscal year mean that service cuts and layoffs will be deeper than originally planned. Even before the latest announcement, budget officials were preparing severe service reductions, job cuts and layoffs to reduce city spending in the midst of a recession in which tax revenues have dropped far below expectations.
Estimates have ranged up to 20,000 jobs to be cut, many of them through layoffs over the next few years. Yesterday, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez said he would seek worker furloughs that would shut schools for three days in the spring semester to avoid 4,000 layoffs. [Page B1.]
In a dramatic indication of the budget troubles, the city closed three fire companies yesterday, in the face of weeks of community protests, to save $3 million a year. At one firehouse, on Pitt Street in lower Manhattan, two protesters handcuffed themselves to a fire truck.
 
'Not the Place to Make Cuts'
 "The Fire Department is not the place to make cuts," said Claire Kaleem, pushing a baby stroller near the Pitt Street firehouse. "It is not a question of convenience but life and death."
The Fire Department has said it would have to cut 41 fire companies next year -- or one out of nine companies in the city -- to save $41 million next year. Firefighters have warned that these sharp cuts would signficantly add to response time to fires and cause additional deaths and injuries.
The firefighters at the closed companies will be transferred to firehouses throughout the city.
City officials said the firehouse closings were expected to have only a slight effect on response times to fires.
City officials said the contracts negotiated by Mayor David N. Dinkins over the weekend -- providing employees of two unions with 5 percent wage and benefit increases over the next 15 months -- did not worsen the budget deficit because half of the funds for the settlement come from a pension fund change that would reduce city pension contributions.
But some fiscal experts and public officials have questioned the propriety of substantial pay raises at a time when city officials have said they may have to cut thousands of jobs.
This concern was underscored yesterday as firefighters and neighborhood leaders asserted that closing fire companies could cost lives as fire trucks would take longer to get to fires in some neighborhoods. For each company closed, the city is expected to save about $1 million a year.
 
'People Are Disgusted'
 "It defies logic," said Dario Centorcelli, president of the Richmond Hill Block Association in Queens, who lives down the street from Engine Company 294, which was closed as the overnight shift ended at 9 A.M. yesterday. "Here they gave more than $200 million for wage increases when you are talking about $1 million a firehouse. People are disgusted, unbelieving and frightened."
Budget officials attributed the new budget gaps to reduced collections of city income taxes and the mortage recording and other real estate-based taxes, as well as figures showing that the recession had cut private-sector employment in the city beyond levels previously forecast.
"I really can't say that there is a tax that is doing anything to impress us now," Mr. Michael said.
While not characterizing service cuts and layoffs as a positive development, he said the fiscal situation would force the city to make the municipal government smaller and more efficient, steps that would eventually be needed for its long-term fiscal health.
 
'Reinforces Our Commitment'
 "It just reinforces our commitment to downsize government," he said, "and we are going to have very significant service reductions. We feel that is absolutely essential."
Mr. Michael noted that as of now, new gap projections continue to assume more than $329 million in additional state aid in the 1992 fiscal year. If, as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo warned, the state is unable to provide the extra aid sought by the city, the gap could go far beyond the $2.1 billion figure.
The city is due to disclose plans to close the gap in the current budget, as well as to present the outlines of a balanced budget for the next fiscal year, on Jan. 16. On Wednesday, after announcing the labor settlement, Mr. Dinkins plunged into a series of budget meetings that are scheduled to continue every day for the next two weeks.
In December, when the administration acknowledged a $250 million gap, it warned that the city would have to cut an additional 7,000 to 10,000 jobs this fiscal year -- about half of them through layoffs. To save $500 million in the second half of the fiscal year, the city would have to make deep and painful cuts, in effect making $1 billion in service cuts on an annual basis.
Norman Steisel, the First Deputy Mayor, said the administration had asked city commissioners to prepare budget cuts totaling 17.5 percent for the next fiscal year, much of it through cuts in payroll. At the time, he said, he thought much of the cuts would be set aside for contingencies. "We will have to go very far into that list," he said.
Mayor Dinkins's statements during the last few days have grown increasingly gloomy as the likelihood of more layoffs and service cuts increased.
 
'Fiscal Storm Clouds'
 "The fiscal storm clouds above our region and nation will not pass soon," Mr. Dinkins said yesterday as he announced establishment of a business-labor task force to advise him on how to preserve city services and morale in the face of substantial budget cuts.
In a statement, Mr. Dinkins said the panel was modeled on a mayoral management advisory committee set up during the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's to recommend productivity improvements. That panel was composed entirely of business leaders.
The fire companies closed yesterday -- Engine 17 in Manhattan, Engine 294 on Jamaica Avenue in Richmond Hill and one marine company -- have sparked protests by firefighter unions and community groups since they were first announced in November.
On Pitt Street, firefighters posted a "Gone Out of Business" sign on the door. On Jamaica Avenue, residents held a candlight vigil last night outside the firehouse. Community groups have gone to court in an effort to stop the closings of both firehouses.
The Fire Department has estimated that on average, response time to fires would go up by 13 seconds on the Lower East Side and 38 seconds in Queens, figures disputed by firefighter unions. To minimize both the political and practical effect of the cutbacks, the department has decided to cut companies from firehouses that currently house two companies.

(John Sotomayor/The New York Times); As Engine Company 294 in Queens closed, Firefighter Richard Porcelli carried belongings from firehouse at 101-02 Jamaica Avenue. Remaining were members of Ladder Company 143, which shared the station. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times) (pg. B3)

HEADLINE: Auctions

BYLINE: By Rita Reif

 BODY:
Old Master paintings and English silver acquired under Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former President of the Philippines, and his wife, Imelda, for their palaces and guest residences and for the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, are to be auctioned on Thursday and Friday at Christie's in New York. Christie's estimates that the 97 Old Masters and 78 lots of 18th- and 19th-century English silver will bring $9 million to $14 million.
The Marcoses' property comes from two sources. The Philippine Government is selling 74 paintings and a hoard of Georgian silver; the United States Government is selling 24 Old Master works seized in July 1987 in France from Adnan M. Khashoggi, a wealthy Saudi businessman. Acquired from Mrs. Marcos in 1986, the Khashoggi paintings were discovered by the Federal Department of Justice during the investigation that led to the indictment of Mrs. Marcos and Mr. Khashoggi on charges of racketeering and fraud. When their four-month trial ended on July 2, the co-defendants were acquitted on all counts. 
 Mr. Khashoggi's art holdings are being auctioned by the Government to pay the court costs, which have not yet been revealed. After the trial, Mrs. Marcos and Mr. Khashoggi "renounced any interest they had in the paintings," said Charles G. LaBella, assistant United States Attorney in Manhattan. What remains of the proceeds are to go to the Philippines's Presidential Commission on Good Government for its land program or to help victims of earthquakes, typhoons and other disasters.
 
Some New Identifications
 Ian Kennedy, who heads Old Master sales for Christie's in New York, said the auction house's catalogue differs from the original one published by the Metropolitan Museum in Manila. "That wasn't a really serious catalogue," he said. "When we first looked at these pictures, we realized these pictures were not accurately identified."
Even so, Mr. Kennedy said, fewer than half of the attributions were changed, from one artist to another or from a named artist to his school, studio or circle. Seven paintings formerly identified as Canalettos are now described as Circle of Il Canaletto.
"Lot 2 in our catalogue, described as by the Studio of Giovanni Bellini, was called a Bellini in the Manila Museum catalogue," Mr. Kennedy said. "If it was by Bellini, it would be 10 times the estimate of $70,000 to $100,000."
Most of the paintings are of familiar religious themes, among them the sale's most important work, Francisco de Zurbaran's "David With the Head of Goliath," from the 1650's. The presale estimate is $500,000 to $700,000. Three works carry the next highest estimate in the sale, $300,000 to $400,000: Veronese's "Venice Adoring the Christ Child," a 16th-century work; Boucher's "Apotheosis of Aeneas" from 1747, and El Greco's "Coronation of the Virgin," a painted oval from the 16th century.
 
'One Mega-Lot After the Other'
 "This is the best silver sale we have ever had," said Christopher Hartop, a Christie's silver specialist, referring to the auction of silver from the Philippines to be held at 2 P.M. Thursday. "When you flip through the Marcos silver catalogue, you see one mega-lot after the other," he said. Indeed, there are stacks of plates, groups of tureens and candleholders, and pairs of wine coolers in a sale expected to bring $3 million to $4 million. The most valuable offering is a dinner service of more than 100 pieces by Paul Storr, dated 1806-07, that may sell for $600,000 to $1 million.
Eric Shrubsole, a Manhattan dealer, said predictions are difficult despite Christie's enthusiasm. "There are a lot of interesting things in the Marcos sale, but there are no Arabs waiting to buy them," he said.
Mr. Shrubsole said the services and groups of vessels will probably be broken up. "I don't think for a moment that these things are going to stay together," he said. "The more complete a dinner service is today, the more unsalable. The candlesticks by Paul de Lamerie are fabulous;, the plates are nice; the basket is not so wonderful."
Jacques Koopman, a London dealer, said by telephone: "The economy hasn't affected silver so far. Silver seems to be doing better and better. However, these silver works will sell at wholly unremarkable prices. I cannot see any great disasters or any great joys with this sale."
The sale catalogue does not say how the Marcoses used the silver. "The silver was found in two guest houses close to the palace," said Teresa Roxas, a spokeswoman for the Philippine Presidential Commission. She said it was her understanding that it would have been used there.
 
More Old Masters
 Christie's auction of Old Master paintings from other owners follows its morning sale at 2 P.M. next Friday. The 86 works offered are estimated to bring $7.9 million to $11.4 million. An 18th-century view of Venice -- Francesco Guardi's "Piazza San Marco Looking Toward San Geminiano" -- is the most important painting in the sale, a work that is expected to bring $700,000 to $900,000.
Sotheby's in New York is also holding an Old Master sale next week. "It is deliberately smaller -- one-third fewer paintings," said George Wachter, who heads Sotheby's Old Master sales. The most important work in Sotheby's auction, at 10:15 A.M. Thursday, is Lucas Cranach's "Bacchus at the Wine Tub," from 1530, a work expected to bring $1.3 million to $1.6 million. "It's in beautiful condition -- just very dirty," Mr. Wachter said.
Alan E. Salz, director of Didier Aaron, the New York gallery of the Paris-based auction house, said of the Old Master sales: "There is not a major picture or drawing in the group at either house. You are dealing basically with an unremarkable group of things, but they are certainly going to make good money."
Mr. Salz said the economy and the threat of war in the Middle East has produced smaller sales of Old Master paintings than those held by the same houses six months or a year ago.
 
CHRISTIE'S, Park Avenue at 59th Street, Manhattan (212) 546-1010. Viewing hours for Old Master drawings: 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. today and tomorrow; 1 to 5 P.M. Sunday; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday; 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. Tuesday. Viewing hours for Old Master paintings from various owners and the Philippine Government and silver from the Philippine Government: 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. tomorrow; 1 to 5 P.M. Sunday; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday to Wednesday; 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. Thursday.

Old Master paintings: 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. tomorrow; 1 to 5 P.M. Sunday; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday and Tuesday; 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Movie Tickets Off 10%, but Not Gross

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Ten percent fewer Americans went to the movies in 1990 but higher ticket prices pushed the industry's box-office take to a near-record $5 billion.
The total amount spent by moviegoers flocking to such hits as "Home Alone" (20th Century Fox), "Pretty Woman" (Touchstone Pictures), "The Godfather Part III" ( Paramount ) and 1990's top moneymaker, "Ghost" (Paramount), was just shy of the 1989 record of $5.03 billion, the Motion Picture Association of America said in its annual report on Wednesday.
Although admissions were down 10 percent -- from 1.13 billion tickets sold in 1989 to about 1 billion in 1990 -- higher prices offset that decline, the association said.
People in the industry attributed the decline in attendance to several things. There was no runaway hit like 1989's "Batman," which made $252 million. Movie fans continued to rent and buy movies on videocassette, which does not contribute to a movie's box-office report. And some people think the recession may have cut lesiure spending.
"Ghost," a love story, made $206.1 million to become the year's most popular title and the 11th biggest of all time. "Pretty Woman," a contemporary Cinderella tale about a prostitute and a businessman, was second with a gate of $178.4 million, said the Exhibitor Relations Company, which compiles figures on movie spending.
With a sudden holiday surge, "Home Alone," a comedy featuring a child as a domestic terrorist, jumped to third place for the year with revenues of $152.1 million overall. "Home Alone" made $25.1 million over the five-day New Year's Day weekend to claim first place for the seventh straight weekend. The last film to be No. 1 for seven weeks was the original "Ghostbusters" in the summer of 1984.
The National Association of Theater Owners said ticket prices have been climbing over the last several years, increasing from an average $3.91 in 1987 to $4.11 in 1988 to $4.44 in 1989. The average price for 1990 was not available, but several theater owners said prices rose.
In a few markets, including Los Angeles and New York, movie tickets cost $7.50. The year's top-drawing actress was Julia Roberts, whose movies combined for $278.6 million in 1990, from "Pretty Woman," "Flatliners" ($61 million, Columbia Pictures) and the 1989 release "Steel Magnolias" ($39.2 million in 1990, Tri-Star Pictures). The top male draw was Patrick Swayze from "Ghost" with $206 million.

HEADLINE: Halls of History, Fame, Oddity and Wonder

BYLINE: By RICHARD F. SHEPARD

 BODY:
TIRED of standing in line to see Mexican at the Met? Weary of looking high and low at the Museum of Modern Art? Wondering what's hanging on other walls while the Guggenheim reworks its bobsled ramp-run? Never mind, you ain't seen nothing yet, to coin a cliche (for other coins, try the American Numismatic Society in Harlem). The city that rarely owns up to a past as it ages gracelessly is home to more than a hundred museums and the multi-chambered megamuseum is but the tip of the burg.
Whatever is collectible, from the divine to the eccentric, is probably under glass somewhere within the New York City line. There's a Hall of Chinese History in Chinatown. At Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn, there's the Harbor Defense Museum of New York City. The Garibaldi-Meucci Museum of the Order Sons of Italy in America in Rosebank, S.I., has an exhibition honoring the Italian liberator who was guest in this century-old landmark house when it was home to an Italian-American inventor, Antonio Meucci. 
 The Lower East Side Tenement Museum on Orchard Street takes a decidedly different tack from the course of Aunt Len's Doll and Toy Museum in Harlem. New York's museums cast their nets too wide to hold all their catch in these pages. The ones described here are emblematic of the diversity in store for the curious, who will be rewarded thematically, architecturally and informationally in their quest. There's a SoHo museum with two floors of antique fire engines. Another museum, in Brooklyn Heights, gives us Brooklyn family portraits of the sort not to be seen in a gangster film.
A visit to a historic Flushing house will make you an expert on Queens movie palaces of yesteryear.
In a Jewish enclave of Spanish-speaking north Manhattan, you can learn about a 500-year-old forced mass emigration from Spain.
The Lower East Side Ukrainians, although awash in East Village bohemians, make a proud show of their past and present a few floors up on Second Avenue in Manhattan.
But first, as the old recordings in the Museum of Broadcasting would say, a word about the 18 subway cars and the people who love to board them, even though they are not going anywhere except backward in time.
The New York Transit Museum is a one-of-a-kind, an underground museum that is, barring a last-minute reprieve, an endangered species. Its extinction, in the name of economy, has been voted by the powers that be. As of this moment, no actual date has been set for the end of the line and rail buffs can still make tracks to this unusual institution, a few flights down in the old and immaculately kept station of the IND line's quondam Hoyt-Schermerhorn (in local dialect, Hert-Schoimerhorn) shuttle in Brooklyn. On the station's two levels is an assortment of turnstiles (some proclaiming a 5-cent fare), a very graphic large-scale three-dimensional map of the system and 448 of its 458 stations, maps of other-city subway lines, subway car models, a demonstration model of the safety signal system, lanterns that used to indicate the destination of trains, and, of course, the 18 cars now berthed at the platforms. One may walk through and sit in the cars, which date from 1903, with open-sided platforms at each end, to 1963, an IND steel car.
The current show, through next October, is an exhibition of architectural drawings -- including under-river tunnels and over-valley viaducts -- of the early 1900's that were designed for the first section of the IRT line, the forerunner of all others.
Boerum and Schermerhorn Streets, in Downtown Brooklyn. Open Saturdays from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M., Tuesdays through Fridays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Admission: $1.15; under-17's, over-65's, 55 cents. Information: (718) 330-3063.
 
Forbes Galleries
 New Yorkers, it sometimes seems, do not get to the Forbes Magazine Galleries in Manhattan as often as out-of-towners beat a path to the door of this sleeper of a museum. Malcolm Forbes designed this enticingly escapist space in the ground floor of his magazine empire headquarters as a home for his fantastic collection of toy ships and soldiers, with very real famous manuscripts, a dozen Imperial Easter Eggs designed by Faberge, and an art exhibition thrown in for good measure. It is a splendidly ebullient display from the moment one enters the gallery in which the armada of more than 500 toy boats are deployed. Accompanying it is a triumph of museum show music down to the sound of ship whistles and appropriate nautical airs. The sound track and scenery change as one enters the next gallery, which is home to 12,000 toy soldiers, in ranks serried according to flag, historical era and war. In one setting is World War I; in the next, a battle among the ancient Greeks; in another, a German ambulance corps back in 1914 to 1918 tends the wounded. In addition, a small-scale Great Plains is the arena for the winning of the West.
The figures represent the dogfaces of all history, as well as the leaders, from Alexander the Great to George Washington. Great for the children, but there's even more here for the mature.
At 60 Fifth Avenue, at 12th Street, Manhattan. Open, free, Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Information: (212) 206-5549.
 
Yeshiva Museum
 It's a split-level affair, one level on the ground floor, the other on the fourth. This is the Yeshiva University Museum in the building devoted to research and a library in the eclectic sprawl of academic buildings in Washington Heights. In the upstairs gallery, behind the designer wall of a Spanish setting, is "The Sephardic Journey: 1492-1992," a lavish exhibition that runs through Dec. 19, 1992, of a thousand items drawn from collections on several continents that tells the story of the Spanish Jews in their homeland and after their expulsion. In what the museum calls the first show ever to touch all areas of dispersion, there are models of synagogues in Toledo, Spain; Amsterdam; Curacao; Safad, Israel, and Newport, R.I., mementos from a Jewish family of the old Confederacy, the portrayal of a Moroccan wedding, and candelabras, costumes and religious articles from Turkey, which welcomed the largest part of the refugees.
At 2520 Amsterdam Avenue, at 185th Street, in Washington Heights, Manhattan. Open noon to 6 P.M. Sunday, Tuesdays through Thursdays from 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: $3; 4-16's and over-65's, $1.50. Information: (212) 960-5390.
 
Fire Museum
 It may not be a four-star museum, but it's a four-alarm attraction that should bring buffs on the run to the New York City Fire Museum in SoHo. They will find two floors of the most extraordinary memorabilia, including almost a dozen pieces of ornate equipment, dating from a 1790 end-stroke hand pumper to a 1912 gas-driven tractor with a steamer on the back and such other vehicles as a fire chief's sled, an 1882 ladder truck and various hose carriers, many of them ornamented in an extraordinarily vivid style. Within these walls, one of them smothered in departmental insignia from around the world, are dozens of fire trumpets (including the one Tiger Company gave to Boss Tweed), old fire alarm boxes, a truly attractive 800-ounce punchbowl with glasses fashioned in firemen motifs, and a weather vane topped by a miniature horse-drawn pumper. And photographs, printed memorabilia and a fire-prevention video, with real firemen, not now on active duty, at hand to assure a knowledgeable and friendly visit.
At 278 Spring Street, Manhattan. Open, free, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays. Information: (212) 691-1303.
 
Brooklyn History
 Of all the New York boroughs, none are more mired in cliche than Brooklyn. The museum of the Brooklyn Historical Society takes dramatic note of each feature in its current exhibition, and it goes even further, demonstrating that the borough is more than a stereotype for character actors in war movies.
The first eyecatcher is a high-standing representation of the Coney Island roller-coaster, with photos and other memorabilia of Luna Park, Steeplechase and Nathan's, along with carousels and even a fun-house mirror in which you may distort yourself. There is a wall full of the Dodgers: the Brooklyn Dodgers and other borough ball teams. An "archway" of the Brooklyn Bridge is a small-scale tribute to the nation's most famous span. And those portraits: Brooklyn family people as they saw themselves and were pictured in ambrotypes, daguerreotypes, paintings and tintypes. Finally, there is a tribute to the infinite ethnic shadings of Brooklyn, from Europe, Africa, Asia, the Americas and, yes, from New England, where so many early settlers stemmed from.
 At 128 Pierrepont Street, in Brooklyn Heights. Open Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. Admission: $2.50; under-12's, $1 (free on Tuesdays). Information: (718) 624-0890.
 
Ukrainian Museum
 The Ukrainian Museum, on the third and fourth floors of a neat building on Second Avenue, is in its 15th year, having begun in the years before the Ukrainian neighborhood around it surfaced with its current spate of restaurants and shops that are now attracting outsiders.
The museum emphasizes the traditions of the Ukrainian people and usually the exhibitions are eye-openers to crafts that have been submerged in modern mechanical society. The new show there, "New Acquisitions in Ukrainian Folk Art," displays everything from clothes (blouses, shirts, dresses, exquisitely made and highly chromatic) to vases and a 19th-century forester's ax and walking stick.
 At 203 Second Avenue, at 12th Street, Manhattan. Open 1 to 5 P.M. Wednesdays through Sundays. Admission is $1 (50 cents for students and the elderly; free for those under 12). Information: (212) 228-0110.
 
Queens Historical
 Downtown cineasts probably do not pause to consider that many of the golden-oldies were fashioned in Queens, when Astoria was a world center of movie making. Queens not only made movies, it also went to the movies, and there's an exhibition at the Queens Historical Society opening on Jan. 12 that memorializes particularly three of the grandest theaters in the city, the Loews Valencia, the Loews Triboro and RKO Keith's. In addition to photographs, "Movie Palaces of Queens" does its recollections with posters, old newspaper articles, actual pieces of the facade of Keith's and a continual run of silent films. This gallery is in the downstairs of a venerable landmark, Kingsland House, a 200-year-old residence in downtown Flushing, an area rich not only in pre-Revolution history (a landmark weeping beech tree hangs out in front of the building), but also tastily awash in the latest waves of new arrivals, in the form of Chinese and Korean restaurants and shops.
 At 143-35 37th Avenue, Flushing, Queens. Open from 2:30 to 4:30 P.M. Tuesdays, Saturdays, Sundays. Admission: $2; over-65's and students, $1. Information: (718) 939-0647.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Cerone and Yankees Likely To Part Ways for Third Time

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Rick Cerone's career with the Yankees appears to be over -- for the third time.
The Yankees, needing a spot for Scott Sanderson on their 40-man roster, yesterday designated Cerone for assignment. The move means they have 10 days in which to trade or release Cerone or persuade him to accept assignment to the minor leagues. Release is the most likely choice because Cerone said he would not go to the minors. 
 "I'm not in their plans so why should I waste their time and waste my time," Cerone said in a telephone interview.
Cerone, 36 years old, has one year remaining on a two-year, $1.4 million contract. If the Yankees release him, they would have to pay him his $700,000 salary.
The Yankees initially acquired Cerone from Toronto in the Chris Chambliss trade in November 1979. They traded him to Atlanta in December 1984; signed him as a free agent in February 1987; released him in April 1988, and signed him to the two-year contract a year ago after the Boston Red Sox released him.
"We were afraid to take a chance on losing a younger player," said Gene Michael, the Yankees' general manager. "We felt we were well off with our catching and could afford to do something there."
Bob Geren, a right-handed hitter, and Matt Nokes, a left-hander, are expected to be platooned as the Yankees' catchers. Jim Leyritz, who can play just about everywhere, could be the No. 3 catcher.
Michael said he would try to trade Cerone, but it is unlikely that another club would pick up his salary if it could sign him for the $100,000 minimum after his release.
The Yankees could have released Dave LaPoint or Andy Hawkins, two pitchers they have little use for, but each has a higher guaranteed salary for 1991 -- Hawkins $1.4 million, LaPoint $900,000 -- and pitchers are valuable trade commodities.
When Cerone was unemployed before the 1987 season, he called George Steinbrenner seeking an invitation to the Yankees' spring camp. Steinbrenner signed him to a $250,000 contract for that season. A year ago, when the Red Sox had little use for Cerone, Tom Reich, his agent, got the Red Sox to release him and negotiated the two-year deal with the Yankees.
Before going on the disabled list last June 8, Cerone batted .368, with 28 hits in 76 times at bat. After knee surgery June 10, he didn't play much and his average dropped to .302.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: GOLF;
Light Mood as Golf Season Opens

BYLINE: By JAIME DIAZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARLSBAD, Calif., Jan. 3

 BODY:
As it has for the last several years, the golf season opened today with the Tournament of Champions at one of the country's most sumptuous decompression chambers, the La Costa Resort Hotel and Spa.
With the competitive drive not yet in full gear, the tournament seems little more than a convivial gathering of the sport's princes of privilege, the players who by winning a PGA Tour event last year, are assured of exempt status and the other perquisites that come with being among the game's best. 
 A total of 31 winners from the PGA Tour, and 13 from the Senior Tour, are on hand. Conspicuously absent are Nick Faldo of England, the Masters champion and perhaps the best player in the world, and Jose Maria Olazabal, the World Series of Golf winner. Both players make their limited appearances in this country for the three major championships. In the Senior competition, Jack Nicklaus, a two-time winner in 1990, chose to skip La Costa as part of his announced schedule reduction in 1991.
In Thursday's opening round, Lanny Wadkins, a two-time winner of the Tournament of Champions, took a three-shot lead over Tom Kite and Chip Beck with a seven-under-par 65. Among the Seniors, who are playing the from tees that make the course 200 yards shorter than the layout played by the regular tour players, Frank Beard overcame a triple-bogey 6 on the third hole to shoot a 69 to lead Bruce Crampton by one shot.
"Normally in this position, I'd be thinking about winning," the 41-year-old Wadkins said. "But it's so early in the year, I don't have any idea what to expect tomorrow."
 
Recession May Test Tour
 But with no cut and a guarantee of at least $11,000 in prize money, the mood at La Costa is light. The coming golf year, however, is one full of issues that could become foreboding.
The major issue could be the effect of the recession on what has been a sustained period of growth for the tour. Last year, four major sponsors -- RJR Nabisco, Shearson Lehman, U.S.F.& G. and the Bank of Boston -- said they were leaving the tour, and if there are other departures, it could test the tour's contention that potential sponsors have been "standing in line" to hold tournaments.
"Maybe the line is not as long," Tim Finchem, the tour's deputy commissioner, said Wednesday. "I don't think we are going to have a problem taking care of that very small level of attrition that we have had recently."
Finchem added that if the current recession lasts more than two years, "We could see some problems."
 
Faldo and Trevino
 Last year sounded a crescendo of excellence, as Faldo and Lee Trevino had two of the best seasons by male players in many years.
Faldo's main challenge will be to stay hungry despite the more than $10 million he has earned in business opportunities as a result of his victories at the Masters and the British Open. "I'll come into this season fresh, ready to improve," Faldo said.
Trevino, who won more money on the Senior Tour than Greg Norman did in leading the regular tour, said Wednesday he would play a full schedule of 30 senior tournaments, hoping to increase the seven victories of his rookie year.
"There will be a tremendous amount of pressure trying to duplicate that performance," said Trevino, who shot a 71 today, "but I'm going to try to win more."
 
Waiting in the Wings
 If Faldo and Trevino don't reach previous heights, there are several candidates to take their place.
Norman, who shot a 70 today, was consistently good enough to win the money title despite playing in only 17 official events, the fewest ever by a leading money winner. But his year was marred by a missed cut at Augusta, a poor shot on the 70th hole that cost him a chance to win the United States Open, and a crushing third-round 76, while paired with Faldo, that took him out of contention at the British Open.
Also in the wings are Payne Stewart, who continued his improvement in 1990; Mark Calcavecchia, who won more than $800,000 last year despite not winning a tournament, and Curtis Strange, the two-time United States Open champion.
On the international front, the 24-year-old Olazabal looked poised to make a run at being among the world's leading players. He has been a consistently high finisher in golf's major championships, and his 12-shot victory at last year's World Series was perhaps the most impressive week of golf by any player all year.
 
Looking to Ryder Cup
 Olazabal and Europe's other leading players will be primed to defend the Ryder Cup at the brand new Ocean Course at Kiawah Island, S.C., in September against a United States team determined to reverse the perception that America has ceased to be the dominant force in golf.
Dave Stockton, the captain of the United States team, has arranged for his players to play the Ocean Course several times before September in order to get accustomed to playing conditions that approximate links-style golf more than what is typically found in America.
"If we want to win the cup, our players are going to have get some rounds in beforehand," Stockton said.

Persian Gulf
 
Congressional leaders met yesterday with President Bush to discuss the gulf situation. Supporters of the Administration favor a simple endorsement of Mr. Bush's threat of force, while oponents contend the President needs approval from Congress before taking military action. Congress is expected to remain in session through January so lawmakers can quickly be summoned.
 
Banks and Savings & Loans
 
Senate Ethics Committee hearings on the Keating Five resumed Wednesday. Trouble in the banking industry will probably lead to measures to revise the deposit insurance system and to strengthen bank supervision.
 
The Budget
 
Debate is expected to be short this year because of the deficit-reduction plan passed last October. Hearings will begin soon after the President presents the budget to Congress on Feb. 4.
 
Civil Rights
 
Democrats are pushing a bill intended to overcome recent Supremem Court rulings against affirmative action programs and rulings that make it difficult to win job-discrimination suits.
 
Health Care
 
Democrats may push for a family leave bill. Some lawmakers may advocate a program to provide health coverage for all Americans, expanding Medicare and protection for the uninsured.
 
Campaign Financing and Ethics
 
The Senate is expected to follow the lead of the House, which tightened rules on outside income in the last session. The Keating Five case may lead to an overhaul of campaign finance laws.
 
The Economy
 
Anti-recession measures may include expansion of unemployment insurance and job-training programs. Trade legislation to protect domestic industries will also be proposed.

HEADLINE: Another Misguided Labor Pact

 BODY:
New York City's latest labor settlement is another disturbing sign that the Dinkins administration does not fully grasp the severity of the city's fiscal predicament. Agreeing to give two major unions a 5 percent increase over 15 months -- 4.5 percent in wages, the rest in benefits -- means that City Hall has chosen to give higher salaries to union members at the expense of reducing services for all New Yorkers.
That continues the dangerous pattern set with the even more costly teachers' union contract, and reinforces the cynical fear that Mayor Dinkins is more concerned about rewarding his political supporters in the labor movement than he is in leading New York through this damaging recession. 
 Most troubling is the Mayor's accurate but misleading claim that the $233 million pact does not increase the ever-growing budget deficit. The city will nonetheless pay a high price for the new agreement. Money for the settlement could have been spent instead on shrinking city services. And the higher wages will lead to even more layoffs than already anticipated, a trade-off that, to their discredit, union leaders traditionally favor. The settlement also requires a risky change in the workers' pension plan that could force the city to ante up additional pension contributions in coming years.
The new pact gives District Council 37 and the teamsters a wage increase of 3.5 percent in the first year -- 1.5 percent from money already reserved in the city budget and 2 percent from the city contribution to the workers' pension fund. The pact also provides a 1 percent wage increase from city funds in the beginning of the second year.
City Hall says the settlement bought peace at a time when the city needs labor's cooperation. But at what cost? The agreement will, sooner or later, weaken New York's already shaky finances. For instance, almost half the pay raise will come from reducing the city's contribution to the pension fund. By assuming that the fund's investments will earn 9 percent instead of 8.25 percent, New York can contribute less to the fund and devote the saving to salary increases. But if that rosy projection proves wrong over the long term, the city will have to make up the difference.
Dipping into the pension fund now is unwise for another reason: it limits the city's options to find a prudent way to do so later, with union concurrence, and then use those savings to help close the budget gap. That would help all citizens instead of just those in certain municipal unions.
The settlement could well aggravate the city's deficit problems next year. Mr. Dinkins believes that by maintaining good faith with union leaders, he will get them to accept a wage freeze when the new contracts expire; if so, they will actually have agreed to only a 5 percent wage and benefits increase over two years. But labor leaders are already balking and, if anything, Mr. Dinkins has encouraged them to seek still more from the city next year because he has demonstrated a willingness to make concessions rather than a resolve to stand firm.
The Mayor's concessions could haunt him this year as well by setting a bad precedent for the city's continuing talks with scores of other unions seeking substantial raises. "It certainly is an influential guideline, an influential pattern," the city's labor negotiator, Eric Schmertz, said of the new settlement, in case there was any doubt.
The labor agreements threaten to erode New York's ability to meet fundamental needs at a time when everything from education to bridge repair is struggling to absorb cutbacks. Unless Mr. Dinkins acknowledges his mistakes and finds a way of recouping, he could find himself and his city running out of money, opportunity and options.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Strong Rise in Dollar Aided By Data on Unemployment

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced sharply on world currency markets yesterday in buying prompted by a better-than-expected report on United States unemployment for December.
Gold prices rose overseas but fell in United States dealings that were interrupted by a severed telephone line. On New York's Commodity Exchange, which suspended trading for three hours, gold bullion for current delivery fell $1.60 a troy ounce to settle at $384.90. 
 Investors were encouraged by a Labor Department report showing non-farm payrolls declined by 76,000 in December, about half of the drop that was expected. That put the civilian unemployment rate at 6.1 percent, up two-tenths of a percentage point from the previous month.
"We had received such bad economic news over the past 10 days that most people were expecting a significantly worse number," said John McCarthy, chief dealer at Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York.
Traders sold dollars in anticipation of a weak number, "and, frankly, there were just no more dollars to sell," he said. The dollar moved higher on technical buying.
The market shrugged off a Commerce Department report showing orders to United States factories plunged 5.9 percent in November, the steepest decline on record.
The unemployment report seemed to overshadow the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis. The Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, agreed to meet next week in Switzerland with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d for the first high-level talks between the two nations since the crisis erupted on Aug. 2.
"That would normally make the dollar go lower," but the market was focused on the economic data, said Michael Schaufler, a trader at the Bank of Boston's New York office.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 2.08 yen, to a closing 133.32 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 135.10 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 134.85 yen, up from 133.00 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.9340, from $1.9465 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.9350 to buy one pound, less expensive than Thursday's $1.9475.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5050 German marks, up from 1.4925; 1.2740 Swiss francs, up from 1.2645; 5.1070 French francs, up from 5.0720; 1,132.00 Italian lire, up from 1,123.00, and 1.1513 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1529.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $387.75 a troy ounce, from $386.75 bid for an ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $387.50 from $385.75. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.22 to close at a bid $387.99.
Silver prices were mostly lower. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.155 a troy ounce, down from $4.214 on Thursday. In London the metal was quoted at a late bid price of $4.17 a troy ounce, unchanged from Thursday.

HEADLINE: Few Riches in Rags These Days

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The rag trade is looking a bit frayed. Already battered by competition from low-cost imports, hundreds more American clothing makers were driven out of business last year by the weak economy and poor retail sales.
Nationwide, the industry lost 50,000 jobs in the last 12 months, according to the American Apparel Manufacturers Association. As Wall Street took note of the industry's troubles, the stocks of many well-known companies, including the Hartmarx Corporation, Gitano Group Inc., Farah Inc., Russ Togs Inc. and V. F. Corp., fell sharply in 1990. 
 People who closely follow the making and selling of clothes say that 1991 will probably be no better. In fact, apparel executives predict that the problems that clothing stores are having selling their dresses and suits will increasingly hurt the apparel business. As more retailers go out of business, they will leave garment makers with stacks of uncollectible bills. As a result, experts predict that a fresh wave of consolidation will take place in an industry already shrunk because of imports.
"In the next several years, you will see the larger, well-financed apparel makers acquiring their weaker brethren," said Gerald G. Johnson, the chief financial officer of the V. F. Corporation, which makes Lee and Wrangler jeans.
New York City, the center of the nation's garment business, has suffered from the continued erosion of that once-thriving industry. Although apparel remains the single most important manufacturing industry in the city, the number of apparel jobs has declined steadily.
There are about 108,000 apparel-related jobs in New York City, nearly 6,000 fewer than last year, and 45,000 fewer than in 1980. Those figures include piece workers, as well as executives and secretaries, according to the New York State Department of Labor.
This is a critical time for garment makers, who are beginning to take orders for the important fall season. The big department stores, like the J. C. Penney Company, Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. and Sears, Roebuck & Company, are coming off a disappointing Christmas season. Despite the many pre-Christmas sales and merchants' efforts to keep inventories low, executives fear that cash-short retailers will curtail their orders in coming months.
Also, retailers with heavy debt loads make poor credit risks for apparel makers, who traditionally ship merchandise on credit. Many retailers are expected to fail within the next six months.
"This must be the worst period that I can remember for the apparel industry," said Stig Kry, the chairman of the retail and apparel business consulting firm Kurt Salmon Associates Inc. and a 30-year veteran of the industry. "It seems that there is more concern, more bad results and more bankruptcies than any other time I can remember."
 
'Quite a Shock'
 There are bright spots, most notably Liz Claiborne Inc., which has benefited from consumer's renewed interest in brand-name garments. Shoppers perceive Liz Claiborne clothes as offering quality at a good price, analysts said.
"There are pockets of poverty scattered among little islands of prosperity," said Mr. Johnson of V. F., which is based in Wyomissing, Pa. V. F. controls more than a quarter of the domestic jeans market. Profits fell sharply for the first nine months of the year, in part because of a sudden drop in jeans orders in the fall. "We had quite a shock in September," Mr. Johnson said.
Still, V. F., like other big clothing manufacturers, is expected to benefit from the current weakness of the industry by buying struggling companies. V. F. is attempting to buy Healthtex, a well-regarded maker of children's clothes that encountered problems after being involved in a leveraged buyout, then trying to expand too rapidly.
Mr. Kry, the consultant, said, "The big will grow bigger at the expense of everybody else."
The apparel industry is made up of thousands of small companies, often family owned. Mr. Kry said that there were only 65 publicly traded apparel companies, compared with more than 12,000 independent clothing makers.
 
'I Cried for Weeks'
 Much of the pain is in the smaller factories. "It seems like every week you hear of somebody closing their doors," said Shirley Fulmer, executive director of the Southeastern Apparel Manufacturers Association, a trade association based in South Carolina.
For 31 years, Vera Andrews worked for El Kay Industries, a South Carolina maker of children's clothes for stores like Wal-Mart, Sears and K Mart. El Kay filed for bankruptcy last year.
"I cried for weeks," Ms. Andrews said. She has formed her own company to make clothes on contract, and is soliciting orders from customers, hoping that Christmas sales depleted inventories. "Everything hinges on how well the stores did over the holiday season," she said. "We are a direct reflection of how well the retailer does."
In New York, union officials said many apparel makers had slowed down, rather than shut down. "Shops go to short weeks for a long time before they close," said Nick Unger, director of education and political action for the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers' Union. He said that faced with weak orders, shops were either laying off some of their workers or cutting back to shortened work weeks.
 
'Shops Closing Quietly
 But Walter Mankoff, a researcher for the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, said that shops were quietly closing. "As they lose business, they close," he said. "When you close a shop with 20 or 30 workers, nobody gets excited."
No one disputes that New York City will continue to play a major role as a design center, but Mr. Mankoff and others say it is important to keep the sewing jobs in the city as well. "It is still the most important manufacturing industry in the city," he said.
For years, the apparel industry has blamed low-priced imports, which now control 60 percent of the domestic market, for its problems.
But now, Mr. Unger of the Amalgamated Textiles Workers is not alone in putting more blame on the retailing industry, which has been substantially weakened by several financially driven takeovers and leveraged buyouts.
"This is a homemade recession," Mr. Unger said. "This is retail driven, not import driven." Indeed, the recession seems to be proving a truism of the clothing business that says that in bad times, children get new clothes, women get some clothes and men do without.
The slow sales are affecting even some well-regarded apparel makers. Richard Breier is president of Breier of Amsterdam, a maker of leather apparel, founded more than 100 years ago on the Lower East Side by his great-grandfather. Despite a customer list that includes Brooks Brothers, Nordstrom and Paul Stuart, the company was forced to file for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code last year. The company continues to operate and Mr. Breier said it had reorganized and would emerge from bankruptcy in the next month or two.
 
Pressure From Buyouts
 Mr. Breier said the company's problems, which included large losses on a bad shipment of leather, were internal. But, in general, he said, the retailers' problems were causing trouble for apparel makers.
"The leveraged buyouts have put incredible pressure on the retailers and in turn, on the manufacturers," he said. Of the heavy debt load carried by many stores, he said, "it is a burden to be shared."
Also, many stores have simply closed, forcing apparel makers to seek out new retail customers, who "might not buy what the old customer did, which leads to the inventory backing up," he said.
Jerry Buccino, a consultant in Chicago, said the problems at the retailing level would soon extract a further toll on apparel makers.
Mr. Buccino said in the last year that some troubled retailers have been deemed uncreditworthy by factors, the finance companies that are the traditional source of credit in the apparel business. Typically, when a retailer places an order with a manufacturer, the factor steps in and buys the retailer's bill from the manfacturer at a slight discount, and assumes the risk of collection.
If factors will not buy a retailer's receivables, manufacturers have the choice of not shipping the merchandise and losing the business, or shipping the merchandise and assuming the credit risk. "It is a tough decision," Mr. Buccino said.

F., which makes Lee and Wrangler jeans and controls more than a quarter of the domestic jeans market, also operates an outlet store in Reading, Pa., which Mr. Johnson visited recently. HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Jordan Marsh Set To Shut 4 Stores

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Jordan Marsh said it planned to close four underperforming department stores as part of a plan to strengthen the company's overall performance in a weak Northeastern economy. Jordan Marsh is a subsidiary of the Allied Stores Corporation. Allied Stores, a unit of the Campeau Corporation, and a second Campeau subsidiary, Federated Department Stores Inc., are operating under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code.
The stores to be closed are in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., Southbury and Derby, Conn., and Worcester, Mass. They will close on or before March 31. The closings will result in layoffs for 302 full-time employees and 189 part-time workers, Jordan Marsh said.

HEADLINE: JOBLESSNESS IN U.S. INCREASES TO 6.1%, HIGHEST SINCE 1987

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
The nation's labor market deteriorated further in December, the Government reported today, but the figures were markedly less gloomy than many people had expected.
In the first comprehensive reading of the economy's December performance, the Government said the unemployment rate climbed two-tenths of a point, to 6.1 percent, its highest level since mid-1987, and the number of payroll jobs fell for the sixth straight month. 
 While the report showed clearly that the nation is gripped by recession, some analysts said they detected evidence that Bush Administration officials might be right in saying the worst is over. The White House is projecting that the gross national product in the fourth quarter of last year fell 3.4 percent but the decline will shrink to 1.3 percent in the first three months of this year.
 
'Troubling Information'
 Even so, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, called the latest figures "difficult and troubling information," adding that the Administration remained "hopeful that the drop of interest rates and controls on Federal spending will allow this to be a short-lived recession, but no one can say for sure."
Some dubious private analysts, like Gordon Richards of the National Association of Manufacturers, said they found little comfort in the data. Mr. Richards said the slowing rate of job loss might reflect nothing more than anticipatory layoffs by companies that had shed workers earlier than usual in a recession.
But Norman Robertson, chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said, "The report showed we're still in recession, but it offered the first hints that the decline is slowing and that employment may be starting to stabilize."
The number of payroll jobs, for example, fell 76,000 last month, but that followed drops of 259,000 in November and 180,000 in October. It was only about half as large a drop as was generally anticipated, though it was widely spread across retail trade, manufacturing, construction and other areas.
For factory jobs the decline was 33,000, but this was the smallest loss since July and almost reassuring in light of a 204,000 plunge in November.
New York City went against the national trend, with a report today showing a drop of 1.1 points in the unemployment rate, to 6.3 percent. But figures inched up statewide and in New Jersey, where rates reached the highest level since 1986.
In the bond market, interest rates rose sharply as investors and traders figured that what appeared to be a slower rate of contraction might induce the Federal Reserve to defer additional steps in its easing of monetary policy.
Other bright spots cited by various analysts were a second straight 12-minute increase in the length of the average private-sector workweek and a second straight increase in payroll incomes -- average weekly wages multiplied by the number of people earning them.
 
 A Puzzling Statistic
 But the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Janet L. Norwood, said the lengthened workweek was puzzling in light of sizable job losses in recent months. She ventured that the longer hours might be the result of companies keeping production and inventories in check by juggling the size of their work forces and the number of hours people are on the job.
Dr. Norwood said the latest report was predominantly negative, calling its portrayal of current economic conditions dismal.
The unemployment rate is not rising as fast as in other recessions, particularly 1981-82, mainly because of demographic factors. The generation behind the boomers is very small and this suppresses labor force growth.
There is debate among economists about when the recession began. Most analysts place it sometime during the third or fourth quarter, but others note that manufacturing has been in decline for two years and construction for much of 1990. Some say the recession could easily be already half over, even as it is just now acknowledged to be here.
 
 Rise in an Index
 The longer workweek also contributed to the first increase in four months in the Leading Employment Index compiled by the Columbia Business School. This index, intended to predict job conditions, now stands at 205.6, up from 204.4 in November.
In addition, employment as measured by the survey of households rose 188,000 last month. This is an increase small enough to be characterized by the department as little changed, but it came after a 347,000 decline for November.
Service jobs, which had long offset declines in goods-producing jobs, fell by a total of 21,000 despite a 55,000 increase in the booming health-care sector. Retail trade, partly reflecting reduced holiday hiring, lost 50,000 jobs after seasonal adjustment, wholesale trade suffered its fourth straight monthly decline and business services fell for the third straight month.
Construction shed 30,000 more jobs last month, bringing the decline since May to 290,000 and raising the industry's unemployment rate to 14 percent from 13.3.
 
 Auto Industry Jobs
 Jobs in motor vehicles rose 20,000, but this reflected the reopening of plants closed temporarily rather than the hiring of new workers. The number of auto workers is still 55,000 below the level of mid-1990.
The quarterly tabulation of discouraged workers -- those who want a job but have given up looking -- rose 110,000, to 940,000, the highest since the first quarter of 1988. All the increase was accounted for by women, mostly black women.
In December, the number of people working part time but who wanted full-time jobs climbed by 150,000, to 5.6 million, up 560,000 since June.
Such figures prompted the Americans for Democratic Action, a liberal group, to revive complaints about official figures that it and others contend understate unemployment. It calculated the real rate, including the discouraged and the involuntary part-time workers, at 11.2 percent and urged the Administration to improve unemployment benefits and raise Government spending for public works projects.
 
 People Seeking New Jobs
 Unlike recent months, when layoffs rose sharply, the rise in overall unemployment in December was mainly among those re-entering the labor force -- laid-off or other workers seeking new jobs.
There was little variation in the rate of increase in unemployment among population groups last month, with the rate for adult men, adult women and teen-agers all up two-tenths of a point. The rate for blacks was unchanged at 12.2 percent, twice the overall national rate, while Hispanic unemployment rose seven-tenths of a point, to 9.3 percent.
Among the 11 biggest states, four posted declines in their unemployment rate, including Florida, whose rate fell to 5.5 percent, from 6.3. Of the seven states with rising rates, the biggest were four-tenths of a point increases for New Jersey, to 5.9 percent; Massachusetts, to 7.4 percent, and California, to 7.1 percent.
 
 Regional Differences
 Over the last year, according to other Department data, unemployment rose by about one point in the Northeast, South and West. The Midwest's rate was about unchanged for the year and for the fourth straight month in December was the lowest, at 5.6 percent, of any of the four regions.
Nationally the labor force grew by an unusually hefty 451,000 in December after two monthly declines. Since only 188,000 new jobs were generated, this meant that the ranks of the unemployed swelled by 263,000, to a total of 7.6 million.
In all, 119,191,000 Americans held jobs last month, 117,574,000 civilians and 1,617,000 members of the armed forces stationed in the United States. Including the armed forces, the unemployment rate also rose two-tenths of a percentage point, to 6 percent.
Today's report also showed that the index of aggregate weekly hours worked rebounded to 124.2 last month, from 123.4 in November and that the average workweek rose to 34.6 hours from 34.4, with factory hours rising to 40.8, from 40.5. Average hourly earnings rose by six-tenths of 1 percent, to $10.20.

HEADLINE: New York City Jobless Rate Dips

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The unemployment rate in New York City dipped 1.1 percentage points in December while figures inched up statewide and in New Jersey, where rates reached the highest level since 1986, labor figures showed yesterday.
The unemployment rate in New York City was 6.3 percent in December, down from 7.4 percent in November, the Regional Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Samuel Ehrenhalt, said. 
 Unemployment in New York State rose to 5.5 percent, from 5.4 percent, and in New Jersey to 5.9 percent, the highest rate in that state since early 1986, from 5.5 percent, he said.
Mr. Ehrenhalt said the December 1990 rate in New York City was lower than the previousDecember rate, which was 7 percent. There were 214,000 unemployed New York City residents in December, compared with 248,000 in November and 240,000 in December 1989. Extensive layoffs in New York City began after the stock market plunged in late 1987 and Wall Street and its service industries began to slow down. With tax revenues in the city dropping, Mayor David N. Dinkins has said that many city workers are facing layoffs.
In the state, the unemployment rate for all of 1990 was 5.2 percent, just slightly higher than 1989's rate of 5.1 percent.
The data in New York City are based on a sampling from 2,200 households; in New Jersey from 2,300 households, and in New York State from 5,200 households.

HEADLINE: Jobs Being Lost Fastest Among Some Top Paid

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WOBURN, Mass., Jan. 4

 BODY:
Until two years ago Dan Clark, a computer systems analyst, could walk into virtually any of the booming high technology companies along Route 128 here and be offered a job.
"If I didn't take it, they would ask me why," Mr. Clark said today. But now he has been laid off from his job with Eastman Kodak, and he was attending a workshop for unemployed middle-class professionals in the Woburn office of the Massachusetts Department of Employment and Training. 
 Since Massachusetts's economy began to slump in 1988, its unemployment rate has climbed sharply, from 3 percent -- the lowest of any of the major industrial states -- to 7.4 percent, according to figures made public today by the United States Labor Department.
And it is people like Mr. Clark, the well-eduated engineers, scientists, technicians and managers, who make up the most rapidly growing group of people losing their jobs in Massachusetts, state officials say.
 
 Specter of Welfare
 Mr. Clark, who is married with an 11-year-old daughter, said that his biggest concern, apart from paying his bills, is what will happen if he does not find a new job before his unemployment insurance runs out.
So far, he has used up eight weeks out of the 30 weeks for which the unemployed are eligible under the state's unemployment insurance system. After the 30 weeks, there is no extension of benefits, and Mr. Clark or any other unemployed person would have to apply for welfare.
The rapid rise in unemployment in Massachusetts has raised the possibility that the state will use up its unemployment insurance trust fund by April. If that happens, state officials said, it would turn to the Federal Government's reserve fund, as Connecticut has already done.
Jim Manning of the United States Labor Department's unemployment service, said eight states, including Massachussetts, only have enough cash left to pay for benefits through the spring. In addition, 20 states, including New York, have less than a year's reserves.
Mr. Clark, in a button-down shirt with a gold pen in his breast pocket, estimated that he had sent out 100 resumes and had managed to get nine job interviews. But so far he has not had a job offer, and Mr. Clark is beginning to think the unthinkable: he could end up applying for welfare.
"It is frightening," he said. "We are people who want to work and have all the education and the skills."
 
'A Different Response'
 Mary Muir, the director of the Woburn office, 15 miles north of Boston, said: "This is especially hard for professionals. This is the first time it has happened to them.
"Since first grade, these are the people who got the best grades, and they have always been successful. Now all of a sudden everything they do gets a different response, rejection, and they are not used to dealing with it."
Borrowing from the Federal Government's $3 billion reserve fund would cost Massachusetts extra money in interest payments, possibly reducing benefits to the unemployed.
In Massachusetts, the unemployment insurance system is financed by businesses, which pay the tax on the first $7,000 of an employee's wages.
The administration of Governor William F. Weld, who took office Thursday as the state's first Republican Governor in two decades, has said it plans to rethink the unemployment insurance system as one of its first priorities. But so far Mr. Weld has only said that he is opposed to raising the tax businesses pay to finance the system.
 
Jobless After 20 Years
 Carol Kurzman, a 52-year-old former administrative manager of a Boston law firm, has only nine weeks left on her unemployment insurance. Mrs. Kurzman, a graduate of Boston University who has worked for 20 years, has sent out 400 resumes, but so far the only offers she has received are sales jobs that pay on commission and provide no benefits like health insurance.
Continuing her health insurance is vital, she said, because her husband's company may go out of business soon. In fact, she has been using most of her unemployment money just to pay the $580 its costs monthly to continue the medical insurance policy that covers her family.
Dora McEachern, 40, who managed a recruiting firm until she was layed off last fall, still has 22 weeks of unemployment eligibility. But she and her husband are finding it increasingly difficult to keep up their middle-class life. She, too, is paying out most of her unemployment benefits to cover the cost of her health insurance policy. The family needs the policy because her husband lost his job as a land surveyor with the state last spring.
 
Home is Up for Sale
 He has since gotten a new job teaching at a junior college. But he had to take a 50 percent pay cut and gets no medical insurance.
The McEacherns put their ranch-style home in Arlington, a suburb of Boston, up for sale last spring. They initially listed it at $280,000, the price they paid four years ago at the height of Boston's real estate boom. But even though they have since lowered the price to $250,000, they have not had a single offer.
The McEacherns would like to move to Marylard or Virginia, but with no offers on their house and their savings being rapidly depleted, they are stuck.
The only consolation, Mrs. McEachern said, is the support she has received from friends. "It used to be that being unemployed was a disease, and people wouldn't talk to you," she said. "But now, because it has happened to so many people, your friends call you up and take you to lunch or help you rewrite your resume."

HEADLINE: Bank of New England Sees Loss, Pushing It to the Brink of Failure

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Bank of New England Corporation, the most troubled of the nation's large banking companies, moved to the brink of collapse yesterday when it announced that it expected a large fourth-quarter loss, leaving it with no funds to absorb future loan losses.
With the latest losses exceeding its remaining capital, the nation's 33d-largest banking company would be insolvent by accounting rules. Although it still has the approval of regulators to remain in business, the erosion of the company's financial strength over the last year has now reached a point where Federal regulators are being forced to decide the company's fate. 
 A senior banking regulator in Washington said yesterday that a decision about whether to close down the banking company, offer it some financial assistance or wait for further developments could come early next week. The regulator, who insisted on not being identified, said the staffs of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Comptroller of the Currency were busy yesterday analyzing the latest figures and would soon make recommendations to senior officials.
Regardless of what happens to the company and its subsidiary banks, he largest of which are the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company in Hartford and the Bank of New England in Boston, depositors are insured for up to $100,000 as allowed by regulators. Depositors with even more than $100,000 in the holding company's banks might also be protected, depending on how regulators handle the company's problems.
A decision to close down the bank holding company would have to be made by the Comptroller of the Currency, Robert L. Clarke, and a decision to provide financial assistance would be up to the F.D.I.C., whose board members include the Comptroller. The F.D.I.C. has scheduled a board meeting for Tuesday that is expected to include the Bank of New England situation on its agenda.
 The banking company's chairman and chief executive officer, Lawrence K. Fish, met with senior regulators in Washington on Thursday to tell them of the $450 million fourth-quarter loss that the company expects. The loss, like the nearly $1.44 billion of losses in the previous 12 months, was because of losses on its $6.3 billion of commercial real estate loans, more than a third of which are in default or have been foreclosed.
In the last year, the banking company has reduced its size by more than 25 percent, as it tried to raise cash and reduce expenses. It remains the third-largest banking company in New England, after the Bank of Boston and Fleet/Norstar Financial Group in Providence, R.I.
Joseph Blair, executive director of the Massachusetts Industrial Finance Authority, a state agency that provides financing for medium-size companies, said that "Bank of New England is just too deeply involved in the economic life of the region to be put out of business." He added, "Regulators will have to find a way to provide continuity for its depositors and borrowers."
Banking regulators were not compelled to act immediately in response to yesterday's announcement because banking law gives them discretion to allow troubled companies to remain in business while solutions are sought. And despite the negative capital position at the banking company, its subsidiary banks still have some funds remaining, meaning that the estimated value of their assets is greater than the amounts they owe depositors and other creditors.
 
No Insolvency Seen
 "Our banks are solvent, and we do not expect any of them to become insolvent," said James Dorsey, a spokesman for the company.
While Federal regulators consider whether, or how, to assist the company, Bank of New England officials are working on their own plan to increase the amount of capital it holds to absorb future losses. Late last month, a group of Bank of New England bondholders presented a plan for converting their bonds to stock, which would add $605 million to the company's capital and eliminate the need to make any additonal interest payments on the bonds.
Wilbur Ross, a managing partner at Rothschild Inc., who is representing bondholders, said in late December that bondholders were seeking assurance from regulators that the company would not be closed if they agreed to exchange their bonds for new stock.
But even if the deal with bondholders is arranged, the company will remain woefully weak. "The company will still lack the capital needed to be viable," said one large bondholder who asked not to be identified because negotiations were under way with Federal regulators.
The banking company has also taken steps so that it could collect insured deposits from outside its local markets, if its problems become severe enough that more of its large depositors pull their funds out of the subsidiary banks. The company has obtained approval from Federal regulators to use Wall Street to sell certificates of deposit to consumers around the country, but has not yet started the program.
 
Most Costly Option
 Closing the banking company and paying depositors is considered by many analysts to be the least likely course of action for the Federal regulators because it would probably be the most costly option. One former Federal Reserve official, who asked not to be identified, estimated that closing the banking company could cost the F.D.I.C. more than $2.5 billion, which would make it the most costly bank failure in American history. Another option would be for the Government to take over some of the company's bad loans and then try to find another company that would be willing to purchase Bank of New England.
The cost of any Federal solution for the banking company's financial troubles will be a politically sensitive issue because the Federal deposit insurance program has suffered sizable losses in recent years and the Treasury is seeking ways to bolster the insurance fund.
"The price tag for the F.D.I.C. is going to be huge no matter what it does," said Carol Berger, a banking analyst at C. J. Lawrence Morgan Grenfell Inc., a New York securities firm. "With the New England economy still in a free fall, any potential buyers are going to require inducements."
 
Buyers May Be Scarce
 Even with Federal financial sweeteners, buyers for the banking company may be scarce. Losses on real estate loans have hurt other large New England banking companies to such an extent that they do not have the resources to acquire Bank of New England. Large New York banks are also hurting, and the handful of strong banks that could afford the merger have not yet stepped forward.
Michael Iovenko, a banking expert and partner in the law firm of Breed Abbott & Morgan in New York, said "the question of closing Bank of New England raises the issue of the 'too big to fail' doctrine." That doctrine refers to the practice of Federal regulators of arranging mergers of large banking companies, even if Federal assistance is needed, on the ground that a closing would be even more costly and would wreak havoc on the local economy or, in some cases, the financial system.
