HEADLINE: Job Figures Lift Yields on U.S. Issues

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
An unexpectedly small rise in the unemployment rate in December caused prices of all Treasury securities to plunge and yields to soar yesterday.
Although the Government's employment report raised questions among some bond market participants about how they were calculated, dealers said most thought it prudent to either cash in recent profits in Treasury issues or to sell these securities short. 
 The market had expected another sharp drop in December non-farm jobs, perhaps as large as 150,000. But the Government reported before the opening of trading that 76,000 nonfarm jobs were lost last month. This sent the fixed-income market reeling.
 
Fear on Fed Reaction
 Not only does the bond market tend to thrive on negative economic news because it reduces potential inflation and yields on competitive investments, but investors and traders today also feared that the employment data would discourage the Federal Reserve from lowering interest rates further.
"From the opening on, nothing seemed to relieve the gloom, although the market did recover somewhat on news of the various Mideast peace efforts," said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds, referring to the announcement that Iraq's Foreign Minister would meet with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in Switzerland next week. "But the market ended as weak as it opened. It seem that everyone either decided to cash in profits, and many had nice profits to cash, or decided to go short until signs of a turnaround."
Also weighing on the market, Mr. Sullivan said, was the large amount of Treasury and agency offerings scheduled for sale in the next few weeks. At last count, he added, some $50 billion of new debt was being prepared for sale.
Of more immediate concern to the market was the heavy selling of outstanding Treasury securities. Late in the session, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue due August 2020, was offered at 106 2/32, down 1 5/32 on the day. This caused its yield to climb to 8.20 percent from 8.10 percent the day before. But the long bond's yield was still below the 8.29 percent of a week ago.
The Treasury's long notes, the 8.5 percent issue of November 2000, lost 20/32, at 103 9/32, and now yield 8.01 percent. Among shorter maturities in the secondary market, the new 7 5/8 percent notes of 1994 dropped 10/32, to 100 9/32, to yield 7.54 percent, and the new 7.25 percent notes of 1992 lost 6/32, at 100 5/32, for a yield of 7.16 percent.
 
Data Called Spurious
 As for the employment data that touched off the selling, one prominent economist described them as "spurious" because they did not include a sharp increase in those who could find only part-time work.
"What the numbers didn't show was the 150,000 jump in part-time workers last month," said Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist at the DKB Securities Corporation, the domestic arm of the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo, the world's largest bank. If the increase in part-time workers was deduced from the total of full-time workers, "then the December job loss was about the same as the 259,000 non-farm jobs that vanished in November."
Given the short time span that governs operations in the Treasury securities market, especially on a Friday, Mr. Braverman continued, "many prudent market participants decided not to question the jobs data, but cash in profits or sell short, rather than wait for the Fed's next move to ease credit. Many had thought the Fed would ease today or early next week. While the Fed will have to ease, the timing is now in question."
 
Large Drop in Funds Rate
 The Fed did move to ease credit with the temporary addition of $2.5 billion of reserves to the banking system. The move contributed to a large drop in the key funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans. The Federal funds rate opened at 7.25 percent, or a quarter-point above the Fed's current perceived target. The rate was at 7 3/16 percent when the Fed added the reserves at midday and it moved steadily lower to close at 5 percent.
While the 5 percent funds rate was considered an aberration, the fears that the Fed's next move to ease credit would be delayed weighed on the short end of the Treasury debt market, which would be the most immediately affected by such a move.
As a result, the discount rate on 90-day bills climbed 9 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.53 percent; six-month bills advanced 11 basis points, to 6.51 percent, and the one-year bills jumped 11 basis points, to 6.42 percent. The Treasury said it would auction $11.75 billion of new one-year bills next Thursday.
On Tuesday, the Resolution Funding Corporation will auction a total of $6.9 billion of long-term bonds, proceeds of which are intended to help bail out the ailing savings and loan institutions. On Wednesday, the Treasury plans to auction $8.5 billion of new seven-year notes.

HEADLINE: Record Drop in Orders to Factories

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Factory orders for manufactured goods in November took their steepest one-month plunge on record, the Commerce Department said today in yet another report reflecting a weakening industrial sector.
The department said orders for durable and nondurable goods fell 5.9 percent, to $235.4 billion, the worst decline since it began tracking orders in 1958. The past record was a 5.5 percent drop last January. 
 "It's just one more piece of evidence that the economy is in a recession," said Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI/McGraw-Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting company.
"To the extent that orders are a precursor of what's to come, it suggests that we haven't hit the bottom yet," said Joel Prakken, an economist with Laurence A. Meyer & Associates, a St. Louis forecasting firm.
The report, which followed a 2.5 percent increase in October, was consistent with other economic news of the day. The Labor Department said factory payrolls fell by 33,000 in December following a 200,000 decline in November. And in Detroit, the Big Three auto makers announced they were shutting down all or part of 29 assembly plants next week and temporarily laying off more than 62,000.
 
 Steep Fall in Durables
 The drop was concentrated in durables -- expensive products expected to last more than three years.
They fell a record 10.7 percent, to $115.6 billion -- even worse than the 10.5 percent decline reported last week. Durable goods orders had risen 3.6 percent in October.
Nondurable goods slipped eight-tenths of a percent, to $119.7 billion, the first drop since last May. Ms. Latta said the decline "could reflect that energy prices were beginning to give way a little bit."
Rising petroleum prices after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 drove up the value of many factory orders, particularly in the nondurable category. Energy prices have been moderating in recent months.
Mr. Prakken also predicted that increases in Federal excise taxes on items like cigarettes and alcohol that went into effect Jan. 1 would lead to cuts in spending for durable goods because people would continue to buy beer and cigarettes, diverting spending from the big items that can be postponed like cars and appliances.
The department also said orders for nonmilitary capital goods -- a barometer of business investment plans -- plunged 16.8 percent, to $34.7 billion. These orders had gained 8.7 percent in October.
 
 Military Order Plunge
 The often-volatile military category tumbled 23.4 percent, to $5.5 billion, after a 8.3 percent drop a month earlier. Excluding defense, orders fell 5.4 percent.
While the durable goods declines were widespread among the major industries, the largest decrease was in the transportation sector -- down 27.6 percent, to $27.3 billion.
Aircraft and parts led the decline, dropping 38.7 percent and more than offsetting October's 20.4 percent advance. The rest of the decline was in motor vehicles and parts.

HEADLINE: Unions' Pay Raises Won't Worsen Budget Gaps, Dinkins Says

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Defending a 5 percent raise in wages and benefits for city workers in the face of a daily drumbeat of bad news about budget cuts, Mayor David N. Dinkins insisted yesterday that the raise would not worsen growing budget gaps and complained that news reports had distorted its impact.
"The reports often come that we're going to close X number of firehouses, and we just increased wages, as though there were a connection," Mr. Dinkins said. "That is just not so, and it is important that people not be misled in that regard." 
 Mr. Dinkins's comments amounted to aneffort to put his perspective on a confluence of sometimes confusing pronouncements that have not only drawn criticism from fiscal monitors but stretched credibility with a public worried about impending layoffs and drastic cuts in city services.
In a narrow sense, the Mayor merely stated a truism. The settlement Wednesday with 150,000 members of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees and Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters amounted to no more than 1.5 percent from money already earmarked for wages in the city budget. The rest would come from increasing the assumption for the rate of interest the union pension funds could earn, thus allowing the city to reduce its annual contribution to the funds and use the difference for raises.
Budget gaps that have ballooned in the last month to $500 million for the current fiscal year and perhaps more than $2 billion for the next, and that are likely to force thousands of layoffs, are the result of unexpected shortfalls in tax revenue, Mr. Dinkins said in an interview on "Good Day, New York" on WNYW-TV. He added that the city was prepared to cope with the disparity between resources and needs that he agreed constitutes a crisis.
"He's more than technically correct," in insisting that he had held to the budgeted raise of 1.5 percent, said Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board, which monitors the city's finances. "That was his policy decision and he has held to it. There is nothing that happened this week that the Mayor didn't make clear two months ago -- not that there can't be disagreement with that policy decision."
City officials yesterday took the first step toward the layoff of thousands of employees it had previously said would be needed over the coming months. Leland T. Jones, a mayoral spokesman, said the Office of Labor Relations had notified commissioners that there would be about 280 layoffs in five or six agencies. The notices indicated only the number of positions to be eliminated and the job categories of those affected. The commissioners will be responsible for identifying exactly who will be laid off, probably sometime next week, Mr. Jones said.
Since, as a political matter, using the pension money requires the assent of the unions, Mr. Dinkins contended the money would not be available for general budget-balancing purposes, as a number of fiscal monitors have argued it should be.
But some critics of the latest wage settlement countered that money is the most movable commodity in government, and that the city could have refused to settle, or sent the contracts to arbitration, unless the unions agreed to forgo using the pension money for raises. The critics conceded that doing so would be difficult for the city, which allowed the teachers' union to use pension funds as part of its 5.5 percent raise in October, and said that underscored the bad pattern the city set by settling with the teachers first.
 
'A Zero-Sum Game'
 "I think that argument is really trying to push water uphill," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses that has harshly criticized the city's labor policy, speaking of Mr. Dinkins's contention.
"I just think the most useful way, analytically, is to think of it as a zero-sum game," Mr. Horton said. "You just don't give a 5 percent contract to a group of recipients of public expenditures without imposing exactly offsetting costs somewhere else in the system. That may be layoffs, or raising taxes, but you've got to finance it in some fashion."
For his part, Mr. Dinkins appeared to argue that the settlement was part of a considered effort to secure the cooperation of labor in the darker days ahead.
"It is sensationalist, you know, to show a picture of a fire, and then show a shot of a fireman saying 'We're going to close this company,' and then the next shot is of someone commenting about wage increases, as though they were in fact connected," Mr. Dinkins said. "The fact of the matter is the 1.5 percent we had in the budget, we could not use for gap-closing purposes unless we said we'd give the labor unions zero."
"Well," Mr. Dinkins added, "we're going to have to lay off thousands of people in any event, even if we had no wage increase at all. Now where would you get the cooperation and the assistance from labor that is going to be absolutely essential to get through this period if we were to behave in that fashion?"
 
Advisory Panel Named
 Mr. Dinkins may have a harder time settling with uniformed unions, which traditionally receive the largest raises, and whose pension funds cannot generate the same sort of extra money to supplement the city's 1.5 percent raise. But Mr. Horton said that if the city is a tough bargainer, it could actually be in a good position to extract work-rule concessions from the uniformed unions in exchange for any raise above 1.5 percent.
As part of his efforts to streamline government, Mr. Dinkins this week named an advisory panel and business and labor leaders to advise him on management. Donald D. Kummerfeld, president of the Magazine Publishers of America, resigned his seat as one of three citizen members of the Financial Control Board, in order to join the Dinkins panel. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo must fill the vacancy, subject to approval by the State Senate.
Mr. Proctor of the Financial Control Board, called the debate over the raise, "a classic war of words that's going to be evolving."
"Anyone who wants to say firehouses are being closed because of labor settlements, that's disingenuous," he said of the $233 million contract. "The labor settlement is small potatoes compared to the money they need to save. They would be looking at things like firehouse closings in any event."
On the other hand, Mr. Proctor said, by using the budgeted money and the pension funds now, the settlement creates uncertainty about what will happen when the 15-month contract has expired, particularly if the local economy has not improved.
"While it doesn't widen the city's budget gap, it is continuing a process that makes budget management even more difficult," Mr. Proctor said. "It's meeting today's problem without taking into full account how it constrains you in the future."
Yesterday, teachers were said to be "ringing the phone off the hook" at their union's headquarters about news that Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez wants to propose a furlough that would close schools for three days, leaving employees unpaid for those days. The proposal, a way of avoiding 4,000 layoffs, will be spelled out to the United Federation of Teachers and other school unions on Monday.
Susan Amlung, a spokesman for the teachers' union, said its president, Sandra Feldman, had not yet taken a position on whether, in a crunch, she would prefer layoffs or a furlough or a third savings method -- deferral of a week's salary that would be paid upon retirement.
A furlough would cost an average teacher -- one earning $40,000 a year -- roughly $153 a day, she said. Many teachers, she said, complain that the furlough would essentially nullify the 5.5 percent wage increase the union won in October.
Any furlough proposal would have to be approved by the full membership.

HEADLINE: On 2d Try, Bush Is Likely to Pick Agriculture Chief to Head G.O.P.

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
After a search fraught with political embarrassment, Administration officials and party strategists said today that President Bush was expected to choose Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter for the chairmanship of the Republican National Committee.
Mr. Yeutter, who served as United States Trade Representative in the Reagan Administration, is a 60-year-old Nebraskan with a Ph.D. in agricultural economics and a resume more noteworthy for policy making than politics. 
 Some Republicans described Mr. Yeutter (the name rhymes with "brighter") as a safe choice who would be palatable to all factions of the party, an important consideration given the turmoil that has wracked Republicans in recent weeks.
This afternoon, at an impromptu news conference before boarding a helicopter for his Camp David retreat, the President was asked whether he had selected Mr. Yeutter as the Republican chairman. Mr. Bush refused to confirm his decision but said, "He would be very good, wouldn't he?"
Edward J. Rollins, co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said: "I don't think people think of him in traditional R.N.C. terms, but I think he'll do an exceptional job. Anyone who can deal with American farmers certainly understands American politics."
Administration officials were not sure when the selection would be announced. But the Republican National Committee is scheduled to meet in Washington on Jan. 24-26, and Mr. Bush's choice will be presented then for the committee's approval, which is considered pro forma.
Mr. Yeutter was "saying nothing," a spokesman said, and an Administration official emphasized that the details of this selection were still being worked out. There was little immediate speculation on who might replace him as Secretary of Agriculture.
The search for a chairman to replace Lee Atwater, who is suffering from a brain tumor, has been difficult and has fueled the criticism of the White House's political operation, under the control of John H. Sununu, the chief of staff.
The President's first choice, William J. Bennett, was widely seen as a conciliatory gesture toward conservatives, who were outraged over Mr. Bush's reneging on his "no new taxes" pledge.
 
Bennett Changes His Mind
 But Mr. Bennett announced last month that he had changed his mind, saying he was afraid that concerns over potential conflicts of interest would prevent him from earning the outside income he needed.
Since then, Republican circles have buzzed with the names of people who were supposedly under consideration for the job, several of whom reportedly took themselves out of the running, including Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner and Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp.
One Republican consultant, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said: "The whole process has been terribly bungled. The chairmanship of the national committee is a terribly prestigious job. It should not have been floated. You should have decided who you wanted and then have the President pick up the phone and say, 'You're my guy.' "
Instead, the long search for a chairman seemed to underscore the problems in the party and in the White House, and seemed to suggest, to some, that the job was less than desirable. Moreover, some top Republicans noted that the chairmanship of the national committee would be quickly overshadowed once Mr. Bush's re-election committee was geared up.
 
Defining the Chairmanship
 The job of party chairman is, to a large extent, defined by the man or woman who holds it. But over the years it has come to revolve increasingly around fund raising, rallying the party faithful and carrying the party's message in the news media.
The Democrats took another opportunity today to snipe at the Republicans. "Keeping together the Republican Party is a tall order," said Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman.
Republicans have long worried about filling the void left by the illness of Mr. Atwater, a master strategist who was one of the chief architects of Mr. Bush's 1988 Presidential campaign. There were two schools of thought within the party about how to replace him: one held that the job should go to another strategist; the other held that it should go to a high-profile spokesman, like Mr. Bennett.
Mr. Yeutter, said one Republican, "is to some degree neither fish nor fowl." That Republican, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, praised Mr. Yeutter as smart and respected, but said, "I think there's some question mark about the kind of role he carves out."
 
Some Political Experience
 Still, other Republicans in the Administration and outside it argued that Mr. Yeutter was an articulate and effective spokesman and was not devoid of political experience.
"He's never managed a campaign, but he's been in the kitchen cabinet on numerous occasions and he managed a portion of Nixon's campaign in 1972," one Administration official said.
Paul Weyrich, national chairman of the Free Congress Political Action Commmittee, a conservative group, indicated that Mr. Yeutter's selection would be generally acceptable.
"It doesn't cause the President any problems, which, if you're looking at it from their perspective at this point -- after all the problems they've had -- is probably as good as they're going to get," Mr. Weyrich said.
Mr. Yeutter was the United States Trade Representative from July 1985 until the end of the Reagan Administration in January 1989, and seemed preordained for his current post as Secretary of Agriculture.
He was born in Eustis, Neb., on Dec. 10, 1930, and received a bachelor's degree in animal husbandry from the University of Nebraska. He did graduate work in agricultural economics at the University of Wisconsin, and in the 1960's earned a law degree and a doctorate in agricultural economics from the University of Nebraska.
He came to Washington in the Nixon Administration and took a job in the Agriculture Department under Secretary Earl L. Butz. In the Ford Administration Mr. Yeutter shifted to the Trade Representative's office, where he served as deputy to Frederick B. Dent.
After leaving the Government at the end of the Ford Administration, Mr. Yeutter became president of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
He and his wife, Jeanne, have four children. He retains ownership of a Nebraska farm and considers his permanent home to be in Lincoln, Neb., although he now resides in McLean, Va.

HEADLINE: Stocks Drop for 3d Consecutive Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices fell broadly yesterday for the third day in a row as growing concern over the economy outweighed sentiment that war was beginning to look less likely.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which sank close to 25 points by noon, rallied on news of the announcement by Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, that he would go to Switzerland to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on Wednesday. 
 Within minutes the Dow recouped its loss and by 1 P.M. climbed 32 points from its low. It fell for the rest of the session, though, ending at 2,566.09, down 7.42 for the day and 63.12 for the week.
Trading activity, still sluggish, slumped to 140.8 million shares, from 141.5 million on Thursday. In a mixed picture, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell at about the same rate as the Dow, but on the New York Stock Exchange, 790 stocks rose and only 698 fell.
Traders said a cable break in New Jersey interrupting A.T.& T.'s long-distance service for New York had little effect on their ability to do business or get quotations.
 
 Effect of Phone Problem
 The New York and American stock exchanges said service was largely unaffected because other phone lines were available to all of the top investment firms. The National Association of Securities Dealers, which runs the over-the-counter service, said that 450 of its 3,000 terminals were down most of the day but that 150 were restored for part of the day by backup equipment. It described activity as "about the same as the two previous days."
One trader remarked that because commodity dealings were seriously hurt for most of the day, one of the biggest headaches was the inability to get up-to-date prices for crude oil until the final 30 minutes of trading.
They maintained that with the situation in the Persian Gulf changing so rapidly, the price of crude oil is important to the entire situation and that traders are hampered in other markets by not knowing what the price of crude oil is at any given moment.
In a reflection of how seriously investors feel about the deteriorating economy, Peter G. Grennan, head of stock index futures trading for Shearson, Lehman Brothers, said: "There's a growing feeling peace will break out and the market should have responded better than it has. It's telling you that the economy could be losing momentum much faster than expected."
A weak economy, he argued, means weak profits, and "the market's very nervous about fourth-quarter earnings," which start coming out around the middle of January.
"When earnings come out and are less than expected," he said, "there's no mercy; the stocks get sold."
 
 Big Name Stocks
 In anticipation of some disappointments when earnings are announced, institutions have been unloading many of the big-name stocks all week.
Yesterday alone, Schlumberger, the oil-service company, fell 1 7/8, to 53 5/8; Disney, the entertainment giant, fell 3/8, to 100 1/8; Procter & Gamble, the consumer products company, fell 7/8, to 83 3/4, and 3M, another big consumer producer, fell 1/4, to 83 1/4.
Royal Dutch/Shell, the oil company, slid 1, to 76 1/8; Johnson & Johnson, the drug company, fell 1/2, to 68 3/4; Abbott Laboratories, another big drug company, fell 7/8, to 40 3/4; Pfizer fell 3/4, to 77, and American Home Products fell 1 3/8, to 49 3/8.
Although traders attributed some of the drug selloff to caution in advance of earnings reports, contradictory recommendations from analysts also contributed to the decline. Merrill Lynch prompted a selloff Thursday after saying the group had had big gains and investors should now lighten up. Yesterday Cowan & Company joined Merrill Lynch but Dean Witter, concerned about the recession, urged investors to lean heavily on drug stocks, regarded as recession-proof.
Merck fell 1 3/8, to 85 1/4; Bristol-Myers Squibb 3/4, to 63 5/8; Bausch & Lomb 2 5/8, to 65 5/8; American Cyanamid 1 1/8, to 49 7/8; Warner Lambert 1 1/4, to 63, and Forest Labs 1 5/8, to 46 3/4.
Birinyi Associates, which monitors program trading, reported heavy buying and selling just before and after the noon announcement of the Baker meeting in Switzerland but said that the activity raised the Dow only six points.

HEADLINE: Forbes Will End Publication of Egg Magazine in March

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
Egg, the magazine started by Malcolm Forbes just before his death last year, announced yesterday that it would cease publication with its March issue.
"It was a victim of the overall environment, and it was just not possible to see how the growth that we had to have was going to happen," said Timothy C. Forbes, president of Egg, a division of Forbes Inc.
The oversized magazine, which covered the downtown scene, was aimed at a young, urban, hip audience in New York and Los Angeles. Its first issue was published in March, just about the time that magazine advertising and newsstand sales began their precipitous decline. Among those cutting back were national advertisers like liquor and tobacco and local advertisers like restaurants and clubs, all of which were the backbone of Egg's advertising.
 
 Decline in Pages
 The March 1990 issue, for instance, had 150 pages; the March 1991 issue will have 82 pages, Mr. Forbes said. Last month Fame magazine closed for the same reasons. 
 Speculation in magazine circles that Egg would not survive centered not only on the harsh economic climate but also on the belief that the downtown nightlife scene, a phenomenon of the 1980's, was past. "I think Egg was a poorly positioned concept," said Martin Walker, president of Periodicals Studies Service, a magazine consultant. "It was a downtown magazine for uptown people."
But Suzan Nanfeldt, senior vice president at Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss, an advertising agency, said that the magazine had a good editorial mission and a strong sense of what it wanted to be. "It was trying to be an insider's guide to the downtown cultural life of New York," she said. "I would never say that downtown has died. I would say that it is probably changing directions, which it does every month anyway."
 
'Never Found Its Way'
 Claude Fromm, executive vice president of the TBWA advertising agency, said that advertisers now tended to place ads month by month instead of making longer-term commitments, making it especially difficult for new magazines to get off the ground. "Egg unfortunately never found its way," he added. "It never became hot."
Mr. Forbes declined to say how much had been invested in Egg. Forbes, a privately held company, does not release financial information.
Egg's circulation was 80,000, Mr. Forbes said, with the bulk in New York and Los Angeles. About 35,000 copies were sold on newsstands, 20,000 went to subscribers, and the remainder was unpaid circulation.
The magazine was the idea of Malcolm Forbes, but his son said yesterday that Mr. Forbes's death had not lessened the commitment to go ahead with the magazine. "I wouldn't say we suffered for lack of enthusiasm," he said. "The death of the magazine wasn't a function of cost, losses or desire. It was the function of a harsh economic environment."

HEADLINE: BELIEFS

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
Three weeks ago, Bishop Edmond L. Browning met at the White House with President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. The Bishop, who heads the Episcopal Church in the United States, was conveying to the President, an Episcopalian, the views of 18 Protestant and Eastern Orthodox leaders newly returned from talks with religious and government officials in the Middle East.
"War is not the answer," said a statement issued by the leaders on their return. "No cause will be served, no crisis resolved, no justice secured." 
 Mr. Bush replied by referring Bishop Browning to reports of Iraqi atrocities in Kuwait and asking him whether failing to respond firmly to such actions would be morally responsible.
And on the day after Christmas, Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of New York, invited three guests to his home for a luncheon discussion of the Persian Gulf crisis. They were not experts in desert combat or Arab politics, however. One was a Catholic moral theologian, another a writer for a political journal, the third a Jewish political philosopher. All had written extensively about the ethics of warfare.
Discussions like these are occurring around Washington. As Jan. 15 nears -- the date after which the United Nations has authorized the use of force against Iraq if it does not withdraw from Kuwait -- the moral debate about American policy in the Persian Gulf grows as intense as the military and political debate.
Not all religious leaders are critical of the American policy in the gulf. On Thursday, for example, officials of the American Jewish Committee accused the 18 church leaders of issuing a "one-sided statement" that "plays directly into the hands of Saddam Hussein." Earlier, a distinguished group of Czechoslovak Protestants, veterans of human rights struggles against Communist governments, complained that American Protestant representatives were underestimating "the criminal nature of the regime of Saddam Hussein" after earlier underestimating the criminal nature of Marxist regimes.
But one can find substantial areas of agreement among statements on the gulf that have been issued by religious bodies since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Almost all them condemn the invasion, endorse economic sanctions against Iraq, welcome Washington's organization of a multinational resistance, perceive hazards in maintaining a prolonged military presence in Saudi Arabia, urge the resolution of other conflicts in the Middle East and call for long-range efforts like reducing the West's dependence on gulf oil and promoting economic aid and political equality for Arab populations.
Religious groups have also been united in urging negotiations between Washington and Baghdad. They are not pushing for a swift resort to arms. They are skeptical of talk of "surgical strikes." They expect that an outbreak of fighting would claim victims in the tens of thousands, perhaps the hundreds of thousands. Almost all recognize the vast uncertainties that cloud any calculations of the outcome, not only on the battlefield but throughout the Middle East, once combat begins.
Yet such agreements do not preclude sharp differences. Groups like the National Council of Churches say the impasse could be resolved if Washington held out the prospect of negotiations on a wide range of issues embroiling the Middle East, from the Israeli-Palestinian conflict to the control of oil revenue.
Jewish groups, besides generally backing America's intervention, have bristled at anything suggesting a parallel between between Iraq's seizure of Kuwait and Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza.
And although both the National Conference of Catholic Bishops and the Protestant and Orthodox groups represented by the National Council of Churches have issued warnings about American policy in the gulf, a mid-December editorial in the Protestant weekly Christian Century saw a contrast in their approaches.
The editorial commended the bishops for laying out a coherent framework for evaluating whether military action would be just. But the editorial complained that the National Council of Churches had offered a set of policy prescriptions that could have been learned "from any number of editorialists," without reference to underlying moral principles.
The criticism, noteworthy because The Christian Century shares the liberal, ecumenical outlook of the National Council, pointed to a basic problem: If the National Council of Churches has offered no general principles about the moral use of military force, the reason is that many of the church bodies it represents do not want to face squarely the question of whether war is ever permissible.
This avoidance takes a variety of forms. In November, leaders of the National Council of Churches declared that their membership had "a wide diversity of approaches" to "the question of the admissibility of war as a means of resolving disputes." But two weeks later, a group of essentially the same church leaders sent Mr. Bush a letter flatly declaring that "war as a means of settling international disputes is in conflict with the teachings of our faith."
When several leaders of non-pacifist churches were asked how they could have endorsed such a premise, they either seemed unaware of what they had signed or treated it as rhetorical license.
To some extent, this sweeping antiwar language of the National Council's leaders results from pressure to find a rhetorical common ground embracing its 32 denominations.
By contrast, the Catholic bishops acknowledge that in their teaching, war can be moral, if only under "certain restrictive conditions." In this teaching, war is waged as a last resort, for a just cause, by a legitimate authority, using means not aimed directly at civilians and with the prospect of achieving greater good than harm. In the current circumstance, the bishops say, the launching of a major offensive now would be hard to reconcile with this doctrine.
Groups like the Synagogue Council and the Union of American Hebrew Congregations point out that Jewish tradition endorses the right of armed self-defense, including pre-emptive military action. These groups have urged restraint, but have generally been more willing than the National Council and the bishops to follow the President's lead.
But it may not be fair to compare the stances of the various faiths without considering that they may arise from different notions of the function served by public statements by religious groups.
The Catholic and Jewish traditions instinctively treat such statements as part of an accumulating body of insights meant to guide the intellect over time. The Protestant tradition, which is enlisting a growing number of Catholic antiwar groups, appears to treat such statements more like sermons aimed at moving the will to action in the immediate future.
Does the nation primarily need basic intellectual tools for analyzing a complex moral problem, not only in the next 10 days but as it evolves over months to come? Or is the country so trapped in a momentum toward war that it needs above all a rhetoric of moral urgency to just say no? The attractiveness of one approach rather than another may depend not only on the strength of the arguments but equally on how Americans size up their circumstances.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Europe Offers Plan to Encourage Iraq's Withdrawal From Kuwait

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUXEMBOURG, Jan. 4

 BODY:
In a move to encourage Iraq to pull its troops out of Kuwait, the 12-nation European Community promised Baghdad today that it would work to resolve all problems of the Middle East if the gulf crisis could be settled peacefully.
At an emergency meeting here, foreign ministers of the community nations said "Iraq should receive the assurance not to be subject to a military intervention" once it had carried out United Nations Security Council resolutions demanding its withdrawal from Kuwait. 
 Welcoming the announcement today that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, would meet in Geneva on Wednesday, the community further invited Mr. Aziz to visit Luxembourg on Thursday for talks with three European foreign ministers.
 
No Comment on European Plan
 The European Community meeting was interrupted by the news that Iraq had accepted the American offer of talks, a move that President Bush, speaking in Washington, described as a "useful step." But Mr. Bush insisted that the meeting would be used solely to inform the Iraqis that they have to get out of Kuwait or face war. Questioned on the European plan, the President said he had not had a chance to study it and would not comment until he did, but he declined to rule out the terms of the plan. [Page 4.]
Jacques Poos, the Foreign Minister of Luxembourg, which holds the rotating presidency of the community, said he hoped to meet with Mr. Baker before meeting with Mr. Aziz so the two could coordinate their meetings with the Iraqi.
"We feel it is important that Iraq get the same message twice," he said.
He and other foreign ministers said the central issue was still the need for Iraq to withdraw, or commit itself to withdrawing, from Kuwait by the United Nations deadline of Jan. 15. They also stressed repeatedly that they remained in full agreement with the United States on the crisis.
But while insisting in their statement that there could be no linkage between settlement of the crisis and other problems, it was apparent today that several governments, France and Germany among them, were eager to find some face-saving formula to encourage Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait.
France and Germany called the meeting today in the hope of keeping alive diplomatic efforts to settle the crisis after Washington and Baghdad appeared unable to agree on a date for direct talks. They also favored separate community talks with Baghdad if the United States-Iraqi talks fell through.
But Britain and the Netherlands feared that an independent community initiative could be misread by Baghdad as evidence of a weakening in the broad anti-Iraqi coalition and seemed determined to block any meeting with Mr. Aziz unless he held talks with Mr. Baker first.
European officials said that a potentially embarrassing rift in the community was avoided halfway through the closed-door session today when word came that Mr. Aziz had agreed to travel to Geneva next week for talks with Mr. Baker.
"There was an audible sigh of relief," an official said.
Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said he was satisfied with the outcome of the meeting because it reaffirmed the community's unity.
"We are anxious for peace, anxious to go on searching for a peaceful solution," he said. "But this can only come through a reversal of the aggression."
He said that if Mr. Aziz accepted the invitation to talks with the community he would be given a double message.
"If Iraq does not comply with U.N. resolutions, it will be forced out of Kuwait," he said. "If it fully and unconditionally withdraws, it will not be attacked."
Asked whether Iraq was still required to leave by Jan. 15, Mr. Hurd said that "obviously an element of practical common sense is involved, with the decision of member states depending on the situation prevailing at the time."
Significantly, in a meeting with reporters, Mr. Hurd seemed to echo Washington's more cautious line by not emphasizing the community's offer to help establish "security, stability and development" in the Middle East if Iraq leaves Kuwait.
But other foreign ministers emphasized that intention, including Mr. Poos, who said he was ready to discuss the "after-crisis scenario" with Mr. Aziz. "The community demonstrated that it is not scared of a dialogue with the person responsible for the crisis," he said.
If the Iraqi Foreign Minister comes to Luxembourg on Thursday, he will meet with Mr. Poos, as the current President of the Council of Ministers, as well as Italy's Foreign Minister, Gianni de Michelis, who last held the post, and the Netherlands' Foreign Minister, Hans van den Broek, who takes over the position on July 1.
At the start of today's session, Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France proposed a seven-point plan that served as the basis for today's final statement, including the pledge that Iraq would not be attacked if it withdrew, the community's commitment to tackle other Middle East issues and an invitation to Mr. Aziz.
The plan, immediately endorsed by Germany and Italy, also welcomed President Bush's new effort Thursday to organize a meeting between Mr. Baker and Mr. Aziz and stressed that there was "neither contradiction nor interference" between the American and European initiatives.
In a news conference in Paris today, President Francois Mitterrand nonetheless seemed to distance himself from the Bush Administration's recent warnings of an imminent war by suggesting a new meeting of the United Nations Security Council before any military offensive was started against Iraq. He said he would hold talks with Mr. Baker in Paris on Tuesday before the Secretary of State traveled to Geneva for his meeting with Mr. Aziz.
Mr. Mitterrand also reiterated his call for international conferences to deal with critical Middle East problems and said France would not go beyond the objectives defined by the United Nations.
"I do not favor preventive war," he said when asked about the need to destroy Iraq's war capacity. "France does not consider itself the world's policeman."
Germany's Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who in recent days has strongly urged new diplomatic efforts to settle the crisis, told his community colleagues that "war is not inevitable" and warned of the dire consequences a war would have for the economies of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 The nation's labor market deteriorated further in December, the Government reported, but the figures were markedly less gloomy than many had expected. The unemployment rate climbed 0.2 point, to 6.1 per cent, its highest level since 1987. [Page 1.]
 In Massachusetts, well-educated engineers, scientists, technicians and managers make up the most rapidly growing group of people losing jobs. [39.]
U.S. vehicle sales closed the year on a downbeat amid expectations that the slump would probably continue well into 1991. [29.]
The winning mutual funds in 1990 either put their money in health stocks or sent it abroad, to be invested in foreign bonds. [29.]
Private money managers performed even worse than the broad market indexes last year. [30.]
In the latest attempt to re-regulate cable TV, two members of Congress said they would introduce legislation to give state and local governments wide latitude to control prices. [39.]
Factory orders for manufactured goods in November took their steepest one-month plunge on record, Commerce said. [39.]

HEADLINE: News Summary

 BODY:
International 2-5
Iraq accepted President Bush's offer for a high-level meeting in Geneva on Wednesday. Iraq's Foreign Minister said he would press for "justice and fairness" in the Palestinian cause at the meeting. Page 1
President Bush said Iraq's decision to accept his offer was a "useful step," but he insisted that the meeting would be solely to inform Baghdad that it has to get out of Kuwait or face war. 4

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Fell 5.1% in 1990

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 4

 BODY:
United States vehicle sales closed the year on a downbeat amid widespread expectations that the automotive industry's slump will probably continue well into 1991. Total sales in 1990 were the lowest since 1983.
Retail sales of American-made cars and trucks fell 1.4 percent in the Dec. 21-30 period, capping a year in which sales were off 5.1 percent from 1989. The overall drop in the final 10 days was caused by a 15.5 percent decline in light-truck sales; car sales for the period were up 8.1 percent, for a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 8.3 million, compared with 7.5 million last year.
 
 Monthly Sales Also Down
 Car and truck sales were off 2.1 percent for all of December, to 962,767, from 983,330 last year. Car sales were up 1.8 percent, to 657,164, but light-truck sales dropped 9.5 percent, to 305,603. The monthly figures include all retail sales, of both American-made and imported vehicles. 
 Sales of light trucks have been particularly weak in recent months. Light trucks are less fuel-efficient than cars, and many commercial buyers have scaled back truck purchases because of the weak economy.
For the year, sales of imported and domestic vehicles reached 13,790,280 -- 9,338,911 cars and 4,451,369 trucks -- compared with a 1989 total of 14,489,530 -- 9,831,122 cars and 4,658,408 trucks.
Beyond the decline of the last year, the question on the minds of many auto executives and analysts was how much longer the slump would continue. With consumer confidence low, personal debt high and fear of war pervasive, many think only a resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis will bring a rebound for the industry.
 
 January 'Debacle' Expected
 "January will be a debacle," predicted Ronald Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco. "I think within a couple of months of the situation in the Middle East's being resolved, we will begin to report year-over-year increases."
Robert L. Rewey, vice president for sales for the Ford Motor Company's North American operations, said: "Industry sales in 1990 were disappointing, with a weak economy and concerns about international uncertainties pulling auto sales down, especially in the final months of the year. Based on present economic forecasts, we expect industry sales weakness to continue in early 1991, with improvement as the year progresses."
Ford's car and truck sales in 1990 were 3.63 million, a drop of 7.8 percent from 1989.
But analysts said there was substantial pent-up demand for vehicles based on the age of the existing fleet. David Healy, automotive analyst for Barclays de Zoete Wedd Inc., noted that sales had begun to pick up in the summer after a nine-month slump.
The General Motors Corporation, the industry leader, posted a gain of eight-tenths of a percent in vehicle sales in late December. G.M.'s United States sales dropped 3.3 percent in 1990, to 4.97 million cars and trucks. But G.M. was able to increase its market share slightly from 1989, the only Big Three auto maker to do so.
George C. Eads, the company's vice president of product planning and economics, said G.M. "is well equipped to meet increasingly aggressive challengers in the U.S. automotive marketplace."
The Chrysler Corporation's car and truck sales fell 4.1 percent in late December, compared with a year earlier. Car sales were up 17.1 percent, but truck sales were down 18.2 percent, reflecting the recent trends.
 
 Honda Nudges Chrysler
 For the year, Chrysler's vehicle sales dropped 15.5 percent, to 1.69 million from 2 million in 1989. Chrysler barely nosed out the Honda Motor Company as the nation's No. 3 car maker, with 860,834 sales to Honda's 854,879. Chrysler's top-selling vehicle was its mini-van, sold under the Chrysler, Dodge and Plymouth nameplates.
The proportion of cars sold that were built in the United States increased in 1990, but more of those vehicles were built by foreign companies at "transplant" factories in the United States. Domestic cars accounted for 73.6 percent of cars sold, compared with 71.9 percent in 1989. But cars built at transplant factories accounted for 11.4 percent of sales, compared with 7.9 percent in 1989.
The Big Three's share of the total American vehicle market declined to 69.9 percent in 1990, from 71.1 percent in 1989. The share of Japanese auto makers, including those with American operations, increased to 23.5 percent from 21.6 percent. Other imports declined to 6.6 percent of the market from 7.3 percent last year.
While most car companies posted sales declines for the year, the top two Japanese auto makers -- the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Honda Motor Company -- were able to increase American sales as they relied more on vehicles built in the United States, which cost them less to build than those imported from Japan, primarily because of the yen's strength relative to the dollar. But the Nissan Motor Company posted a substantial decline for the year.
"Despite the apparent downward turn of the economy last year, sales of Toyota vehicles have never been better," said Pat Moran, president of Toyota's distribution company for the Southeastern United States. Mr. Moran said he expected "sustained growth" in 1991.
Particularly hard hit in 1990 were several European auto makers, including Volvo, Saab and BMW. Sales of Audis dropped to 21,106 for the year from 21,283 in 1989, and "quite frankly we don't see 1991 being any better," said Richard L. Mugg, the American executive in charge of Audi. Mr. Mugg said Audi's December results reflected some sales that were "unquestionably pulled ahead from January to beat the impending luxury tax" on vehicles costing more than $30,000.
 
PLANT CLOSINGS CONTINUE

DETROIT, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Big Three auto makers will continue reduced car and truck production next week by shutting down all or part of 29 assembly plants and putting more than 62,000 auto workers on temporary layoff.
The shutdowns stretch out closings that began at some plants the week before Christmas.
The Ford Motor Company plans the most extensive shutdowns and layoffs next week, with all but five assembly plants closed because of low orders, the company said today. Ford will lay off about 20,360 North American workers next week.
The General Motors Corporation will close 13 plants, resulting in 33,280 layoffs, and the Chrysler Corporation will shut three assembly plants, laying off about 8,400 workers.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Senate Prepares for a Gulf Debate Soon After Baker Meets With Aziz

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
The Senate today put itself in position to debate legislation concerning war in the Persian Gulf as early as Thursday, the day after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is scheduled to meet with Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Foreign Minister.
But Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, indicated that it was more likely that the issue would come up on Monday Jan. 14, the day before the United Nations deadline for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait expires and the authorization for military force takes effect. 
 Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, urged a serious debate. He said that while he disagreed with Democrats who challenged the President, he sympathized with their frustration over Congressional inaction.
"For months we have been standing on the sidelines, making all kinds of speeches but not casting a single vote," he said. "Congress has been AWOL."
 
A Lack of Consensus
 But Mr. Dole said he hoped that when the Senate debated, it would unite behind President Bush and the threat of force.
"What a message that would be to Saddam Hussein," he said, arguing that unity in Congress might finally persuade Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait if Mr. Baker's efforts and all else had failed.
He conceded that he did not know how Congress would vote, and whether a majority would back Mr. Bush. But however it acted, he said, Congress had a duty to vote.
There does not appear to be a consensus in either House. Congress, and especially its Democratic leaders, seem committed to voting on how the nation should proceed in the gulf, though it is clear that many individual members are reluctant to take a stand.
 
Time Left, But Not Much
 Absent any direct, insistent appeal from Mr. Bush, there seems to be little Congressional inclination to urge or even acknowledge a course toward war and much sentiment in favor of keeping economic sanctions in place longer. But many on Capitol Hill say they do not expect him to make such a request in earnest for fear that defeat, or a even narrow victory, would undermine his efforts.
Congressional leaders seem to feel that they have time left, that Mr. Bush will not seek to pre-empt their debate by attacking on Jan. 16. But they appear to feel they do not have much time.
Leaders in the House, which was not in session today, did not offer comparable scheduling plans. But the House is expected to be in full session beginning Jan. 14, and for the rest of that week, so that it, too, could debate the situation in the gulf.
The House Foreign Affairs Committee is expected to meet informally next week to discuss the gulf crisis and possible resolutions concerning it. The committee also scheduled a closed-door meeting for Wednesday with ambassadors from the countries allied against Iraq.
 
Daily Cost of a War
 In the only gulf-related event on the House side of the Capitol today, its Budget Committee heard the head of he General Accounting Office say it would cost the United States nearly $1 billion a day once fighting started. The official, Charles A. Bowsher, said that even without war, the gulf operation would cost about $30 billion in the fiscal year that began on Oct. 1.
Today's Senate session began with a series of Democratic speeches contending that the Constitution required President Bush to obtain Congressional approval before any attack on Iraq and urging more time for economic sanctions to work.
"Congress alone has the power to declare war," said Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa.
"Sanctions are running Iraq's economy into the ground," said Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee.
 
Request for a Resolution
 Republicans counterattcked. Senator Steven D. Symms of Idaho complained about "handwringers," and said Mr. Bush had displayed "great restraint."
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York said "the issue is not the Constitution." Instead, he said, "the issue is bottom-line American interest." He said the Senate should vote today to support Mr. Bush.
In contrast to Thursday's sharp half-hour exchange before nearly all members of the Senate, today's speeches were given in a generally deserted Senate chamber and punctuated by repeated quorum calls awaiting the arrival of the next speechmaker.
One Republican, Senator Slade Gorton of Washington, sided with the Democrats on the constitutional issue and with his fellow Republican senators on policy. He said "the President should formally request the Congress to pass a resolution" giving him the authority to use force.

HEADLINE: Tangled Phones and Flights As Cable and Tempers Snap

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
An Illinois woman had breakfast for lunch en route to New York yesterday because a telephone cable broke in New Jersey.
Lorraine Linstead's flight was on time and on the runway at O'Hare Airport in Chicago yesterday morning when it abruptly returned to the terminal. The broken cable had scrambled air traffic control in the Northeast, and by the time Mrs. Linstead's flight took off, it was 11:30 A.M. in Chicago. 
 But the meal aboard the American Airlines jetliner was still what was promised on the ticket. "Here was lunch time now and they served us breakfast, these omlettes that were not very good and a fruit salad that wasn't fit for a bird," said Mrs. Linstead, a resident of Rockford, Ill.
Mrs. Linstead wasn't the only American struggling to cope with delays and petty inconveniences caused by the severing of an American Telephone and Telegraph Company cable in Newark yesterday.
There were the business travelers and vacationers, exasperated because the local banks' automatic teller machines would not accept their out-of-town cards. Travel agents, already suffering as the economy slipped into a recession, were unable to reach reservation numbers.
Stuart Cooper, who owns Fair View Travel in Baldwin, L.I., said his long-distance service was provided by Allnet, a small long-distance carrier based in Michigan, and was working. But one of his two toll-free 800 numbers was on an A.T.&T. line, and by early afternoon it had not rung once.
Air traffic controllers were, if anything, more inconvenienced than the airline passengers. The National Air Traffic Controllers Association said its immediate problem was getting through to members working at two Federal Aviation Administration centers on Long Island that handle most of the flights in the Northeast. "Our representative managed to get through for a few minutes before he lost contact and he said it was just absolutely bedlam there," said Tony Dresden, a spokesman for the union. "I think one of the greatest fears of the air traffic control system is the man with a backhoe who severs a line" he said.
The actual repair of the severed cable caused little disruption on Raymond Boulevard in Newark.
The manhole where the break occurred is 20 feet deep; water from the Passaic River sluices in whenever the tide rises. By the time crews realized they had broken the cable, the manhole was half full.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
BAGHDAD ACCEPTS U.S. OFFER TO MEET BAKER IN GENEVA

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Iraq accepted the Bush Administration's offer tonight for a high-level meeting on Wednesday in Geneva, at which Iraq's Foreign Minister said he would press for "justice and fairness" for the Palestinian cause.
In a statement read over state-run television and released by the official Iraqi press agency, Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz was quoted as saying he had accepted the offer to meet Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d despite the "arrogant statements" and "bad intentions" that accompanied the invitation. [Text of the Iraqi press agency report, page 5.] 
 After the Iraqi statement was issued, President Bush revealed in a news conference in Washington that he had ruled out the idea of sending Mr. Baker to Baghdad for direct talks with President Saddam Hussein. Mr. Bush had originally proposed that the two meet before Jan. 15, the deadline set by the United Nations Security Council for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face eviction by force.
 
No Mention of Irrevocability
 The statement tonight by Mr. Aziz, one of the highest-ranking leaders of Iraq, made no reference to Kuwait or to Iraq's often- repeated assertion that it has irrevocably incorporated the emirate as its 19th province.
Iraq's decision to accept the meeting between Mr. Aziz and Mr. Baker on Wednesday clears the way for the highest-level diplomatic exchange between Iraq and the United States since the Persian Gulf crisis began on Aug. 2 with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
"I was prepared to go to Washington and to receive Minister Baker in Baghdad if the American Administration acted in a courteous manner and respected the internationally recognized rules with regard to fixing dates for heads of states' meetings with other nations' envoys," Mr. Aziz was quoted as saying.
 
U.S. Envoy Receives Word
 Shortly before the broadcast, a senior Iraqi Foreign Ministry official told the top United States diplomat in Baghdad, Deputy Chief of Mission Joseph C. Wilson 4th, that Mr. Aziz had accepted the proposal that Mr. Wilson had relayed on Thursday to Mr. Aziz's Under Secretary, Nizar Hamdoon.
Speaking to reporters outside the American Embassy tonight, Mr. Wilson said, "We really want to go the extra mile to make sure everybody in this conflict understands what we are talking about, which is basically compliance with the United Nations resolutions."
Mr. Wilson indicated that the prospect of talks was a welcome development, notwithstanding Mr. Aziz's polemics.
"I think as long as we are talking, as Winston Churchill said, 'Jaw, jaw, jaw, talk, talk, talk is better than war, war, war,' " he said. "So we'll see."
Mr. Aziz's statement was read after a meeting today of senior members of Iraq's Revolutionary Command Council, which Mr. Hussein heads. Mr. Aziz said that at the talks, "Iraq will also stress adherence to its rights and its readiness to strongly defend them."
 
The Palestinian Question
 "I will also seek to know whether the other side is ready to work for realization of peace and security in the whole region on the basis of fairness and justice," he said. "In the forefront of the causes which need fairness and justice is the Palestinian question and the right of the Palestinian people in establishing its free state on the land of Palestine with Jerusalem as its capital."
In a final comment directed at European Community foreign ministers meeting in Luxembourg, Mr. Aziz said, "Iraq welcomes anyone who wishes to visit Iraq to hold a serious dialogue to realize peace in the whole region."
Bush Administration officials have been adamant that they intend to conclude their diplomacy with Iraq without concessions, negotiations on other regional issues or face-saving gestures.
Yet several European leaders have been seeking a formula under which Iraq's unconditional withdrawal would be followed by a stronger commitment to move the Arab-Israeli peace process forward on the Palestinian question.
 
Original Offer Unreported
 The Administration's offer Thursday for the talks in Geneva went unreported in Iraq's official press today, but the acceptance was featured prominently in broadcasts tonight.
"This is very good news," said Samir al-Jamil, 33 years old, an unemployed accountant who last month was called back to military service after he served nine years in the war against Iran. "It could mean peace."
Iraq's Foreign Ministry summoned the ambassadors of Britain, Japan and Malaysia today and told them that the Government would not be able to guarantee the security of foreign missions in the event of war, according to diplomats.
 
Dispersing Ministries
 The Foreign Ministry's chief of protocol, Fuad al-Rawi, told the envoys that the Iraqi leadership had decided to disperse important ministries to the countryside and that the Foreign Ministry would relocate to Ramadi, 60 miles west of Baghdad.
Mr. Rawi told the diplomats that the Foreign Ministry was awaiting an order to move its functions to Ramadi and that ministry officials already had tested communications there to insure that it would be able to keep in contact with all Iraq's embassies abroad.
 
Envoys Fear Detention
 According to diplomats, Mr. Rawi said they should ask their governments whether they would be willing to move to Ramadi or take some other steps to insure the protection of diplomats if war breaks out.
The diplomats expressed strong concern that such an arrangement might lead to their detention, but Mr. Rawi strongly denied any such intent, according to diplomats. The Iraqi repeated that the move was not compulsory and that foreign missions could remain in Baghdad, but he said the Government could not guarantee their safety there.
Mr. Rawi said the Iraqi Government was preparing for peace and war simultaneously, the diplomats said. He said that there was no guarantee at this juncture of peaceful solution to the crisis and that therefore "we have to prepare for the worst."
The Iraqi official also advised the envoys to evacuate all women and children from their embassies and said the ministry found it understandable and natural that a number of embassies were reducing their diplomatic staffs.

HEADLINE: Israel's 2 Main Museums Cut Back

BYLINE: By RICK BLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan. 4

 BODY:
With most tourists staying away from Israel because of the Persian Gulf crisis, the country's two major museums have had to lay off employees and cut back operations.
"There are almost no tourists coming to Israel," said Nissim Tal, the deputy director of the Diaspora Museum in Tel Aviv. On Thursday, Pan American World Airways announced it was suspending flights to Israel, and travel agents said bookings to Israel and other Middle Eastern points had dropped sharply as a result of the crisis. 
 Mr. Tal said the number of tourists visiting the museum was only a fifth of the usual number. As a result, the museum has dismissed 15 percent of its employees, including a few tenured staff members, to help reduce its $4.2 million budget. "We hope the situation will stabilize shortly," Mr. Tal said.
Similarly, the Israel Museum, the country's largest and most prestigious cultural landmark, has laid off 27 of its 190 employees in the last month and will have to let more people go if the crisis continues to keep tourists away.
 
4-Day Weeks, No Overtime
 As part of its austerity plan, the Israel Museum asked its staff to work a four-day week in November and December. In addition, the museum stopped paying for overtime.
The Israel Museum received half of its current $10 million operating budget from foreign donations and $2 million in Government subsidies. Entrance fees and related revenues were to provide the rest.
The museum plans a budget cut of 20 percent to help cover the current $3 million deficit, two-thirds of which is attributed to the decline in visitors.
Not only tourists are staying away from cultural institutions in Jerusalem. Israelis also are not visiting the Israel Museum and other sites as often as they used to.
 
The Issue of Closing
 "We've decided not to close the museum even one day," said Dr. Martin Weyl, the museum's director. "In such a period, art becomes very important. It's a symbol of a civilized, healthy life."
In fact, the Israel Museum has closed because of war only once in its 25-year history: on the first day of the 1967 war, when bombing by Jordanian Air Force damaged some of the archeological galleries.
The recent austerity measures, though, have left the staff wondering about the ability of the museum to borrow works for future exhibitions and even to stay open.
Most cultural institutions in Israel are finding it more difficult to raise money abroad these days, both because of the recession in the United States and because they have to compete with Jewish organizations raising money to help absorb the 200,000 Jews who arrived from the Soviet Union last year. The immigrants continue to arrive at a rate of about 1,000 a day.
"Most of the donated money is now going to immigration," Mr. Tal said. "So we are being hit twice."
 
Contributions Fall
 At the Israel Museum, for example, the number of American patrons who donate $2,500 to $10,000 a year has begun to fall, Dr. Weyl said.
Both the Israel Museum and the Diaspora Museum depend largely on foreign donations and admission fees, while most other Israeli museums are largely government subsidized. The Government, which is also looking for additional money for the immigrants, seems unlikely to increase its spending on museums.
Government officials did promise to give the Israel Museum an additional $1 million to help cover its operating deficit, but no money has been received.
"It's hard to live day to day, wondering if you'll run out of money or not," Dr. Weyl said. "It's a daily struggle to keep the museum going."
At the same time, the new immigrants are raising spirits at the museum, Dr. Weyl said. The Soviet Jews, many of whom do not have much awareness of their Jewish heritage, come to the museum by the busload. They are admitted free.

HEADLINE: The Safety Net for Securities Holders

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
How safe is your money?
This week's failure of the private Rhode Island deposit insurance fund for credit unions and the recent highly publicized difficulties of savings and loan associations and banks have left many people concerned about the safety of their deposits in financial institutions. And for many, this worry has carried over to the money and securities in their asset-management and other accounts at brokerage firms. 
 For depositors in a bank, savings and loan association or credit union, experts say that the best way to have peace of mind is to make sure that your cash is protected by one of the Government agencies that insures accounts: the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or the National Credit Union Share Insurance Fund. That protection, of course, is limited to a maximum of $100,000 per person at each institution, although the amount can be raised by adding such accounts as individual retirement accounts or trust accounts.
But it's not as simple with brokerage accounts. Although there is a Government-backed fund providing limited protection -- the Securities Investor Protection Corporation, widely known as S.I.P.C. and pronounced "SIP-ick" -- it has a different status than the two agencies for depositors. Furthermore, the value of customer portfolios can change drastically before customers obtain control of their assets after a brokerage is liquidated.
"We become involved only when there is a danger to customers," said Theodore H. Focht, the president of the securities protection corporation. "There has to be a determination that a firm has failed or is in danger of failing to meet its obligations to customers."
How does S.I.P.C. work?
Most "broker-dealers" are members of the Washington-based protection corporation, which is financed by assessments from them. When a member brokerage firm is at the failure stage, the fund applies to a Federal court for the appointment of a trustee to liquidate the firm.
Once that has been done, each customer account is covered by S.I.P.C. for up to $500,000, including up to $100,000 for the cash in the account, while the trustee goes through the legal process of transferring the accounts to another broker. In its 20 years of existence, S.I.P.C. has provided $221 million to 260,000 customers of 220 liquidated firms.
But unlike the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the National Credit Union Share Insurance Fund, the securities fund is not an agency of the United States Government. In a subtle distinction, it is considered a Government-backed fund that has a statutory right to borrow from the Treasury. Yet S.I.P.C. is not supported by the "full faith and credit" of the Government, an important consideration during this period of heavy losses by the F.D.I.C.
In addition, the worth of a brokerage account may go up or down while it is tied up in court proceedings. So another difference between the securities fund and what Mr. Focht calls its "sister programs" is that even if your account comes under the coverage limitations, there is still the danger that the value of the portfolio could decline by the time it is again available for trading.
"When you have dollars on deposit at a bank, they don't change in value, except for inflation," he said. "Obviously, we are not protecting the underlying investment of what you bought. You'll get back your dollars and you'll get back your stock."
But what can be a cause of concern to some investors is that accounts of customers at liquidated firms might be tied up for a long time, sometimes many months. If such a situation occurs in a period of declining securities prices, some consumers may be forced to watch their assets erode without being able to take action.
Sophisticated customers who have another account elsewhere can sell-short the same stocks being held in their blocked accounts, thus preventing future losses. Selling short involves borrowing stock, usually from the broker, in the hope that the value will decline so it will be returned at a lower price.
Along with S.I.P.C.'s protection for as much as $500,000, many brokerage firms also provide private insurance for customer accounts. This insurance, typically underwritten by a major insurance company, adds from $500,000 to $9.5 million to the basic coverage. Thus, total insurance, both Government-related and private, can amount to as much as $10 million.
There are, likewise, both private and Government insurance programs for credit unions. Even after the collapse of the Rhode Island fund, nine private, or cooperative, guaranty funds remain, protecting about 1,500 credit unions that are not covered by the National Credit Union Share Insurance Fund. These funds operate in 21 states, including California, Florida and Massachusetts.
The funds are nonprofit organizations owned by their member credit unions and have their own trade association, the National Association of Share Insurance Corporations. Its managers note that depositors in privately insured credit unions occassionally receive higher interest rates than those in Government-insured credit unions and, at least in some cases, higher insurance coverage.
Nevertheless, as many depositors in Rhode Island credit unions have just discovered -- and as many savings and loan depositors in Ohio and Maryland discovered when similar private funds also were exhausted in the mid-1980's -- insurance is only as good as the entity, Government or private, behind it.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Going Easy on Energy

BYLINE: BY Tom Wicker

 BODY:
The likelihood of war and the fact of recession, both heavily tainted with Mideast oil, demonstrate the need for President Bush to lead the country toward energy independence.
Right? Not as the White House sees it. 
 John Sununu & Co. have struck again, defanging a strong energy conservation program proposed at cabinet level, after 18 months of study. When this offensive document reached the Bush White House -- abandon hope, all ye who enter here in search of the vision thing -- it was stripped of any idea that might have offended anybody this side of the Sierra Club.
Gone are higher mileage requirements for gas-guzzling autos. Gone, too, are Federal regulations to impose energy conservation, any suggestion of government intervention in the sacrosanct private sector, all impolitic urgings toward consumer sacrifice. Gone, for sure, are any energy-related tax increases.
Gone but not forgotten, at least not by the "knowledgeable" and possibly outraged officials who told James Risen of The Los Angeles Times the grim story. They said that Mr. Sununu, the White House chief of everything; Richard Darman, the Ayatollah of the Budget Office, and Michael Boskin, Supreme Commander of the Council of Economic Advisers, had gutted what Mr. Risen termed "the most ambitious" of the proposed energy conservation provisions.
Why -- especially when Secretary of State James Baker's most recent threat of "devastation" to Iraq leaves little doubt that the Bush Administration is prepared to go to war, not least to maintain American access to Middle East oil?
Why, more especially, when in the United States the economy has drifted downward into recession, a process accelerated and made worse by the third oil price "shock" in 20 years?
Why, when even before these immediate reasons for seeking greater energy independence, powerful calls existed for strong measures to insure energy conservation?
Though the number of automobiles operating in the world is inevitably increasing, for instance, greater fuel efficiency could save 2.9 million barrels of oil per day by the year 2000. That's about what the U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization estimates will be needed by then to double agricultural production in the developing countries.
That can't be achieved, nor will the trade deficit be much improved, unless the U.S., with its staggering auto population and oil consumption, learns to conserve energy. Instead of mandating or encouraging conservation, however, the Bush energy program apparently will propose incentives for new oil production in the United States and elsewhere, outside the Mideast.
One reason for this myopic approach to energy policy is that Messrs. Sununu, Darman and Boskin have demonstrated before their bureaucratic mastery of the feckless lower levels of this Administration. Another is that the Energy Department's draft is described as more of a laundry list of options than a specified program for which its authors would be prepared to fight to the death. This made the draft easier to dismember.
More important, the top-level decisions diluting the proposals exemplify the Administration's free-market philosophy and nicely fit Mr. Bush's pro-business views, shaped by his experience in the oil industry. Such considerations prevail in this White House, even when a tough energy program is a national necessity and would tend to validate an ill-understood war.
It's hard to remember now, after 10 years of Ronald Reagan and George Bush, that back in the dim mists of the 70's President Carter produced an energy program the size of the Sears, Roebuck catalogue. It featured all sorts of inducements to conservation and incentives to alternative and renewable energy sources, many of which became law -- just in time, for the most part, to be killed off by Mr. Reagan.
Now George Bush, given another opportunity to use Middle East events to lead Americans toward energy independence, as Mr. Carter tried to use the two previous oil shocks, chooses instead to lead the world into a war the overall outcome of which -- including its effect on oil supplies but not the certainty of many American casualties -- no one can predict.
Another unnamed official, illogically terming the White House energy approach "pragmatic," told James Risen that "for the long term, free-market measures work best." The long term? With a war scheduled in two weeks for which little enthusiasm is visible anywhere, with a recession here and now and getting worse, what would be wrong with thinking about the short term? If not now, when?
