HEADLINE: Albany's Budget Timing Is Way Off

BYLINE: By Mel Miller; Mel Miller, a Democrat, is Speaker of the New York State Assembly.

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
In 1987, the New York State budget was adopted 10 days late. One month later, we enjoyed a $900 million surplus. The 1988 budget was late again, but a month later the state faced a $900 million shortfall that grew to a $1.9 billion deficit. In 1989, the budget was 18 days late. By fall, another deficit was developing that ultimately reached $2 billion.
Last year, the budget was a record 48 days tardy. Had emergency action not been taken last month, we would have been short $1 billion by the end of the 1990-91 fiscal year that ends this March 31. I join those who detect a pattern here. 
 It isn't because state officials can't add. What happens is this: We pass a budget based on an estimate of tax receipts for the current and coming fiscal years. The fiscal year ends and later we get the actual revenue from April 15 income tax collections.
There are times when the obvious is the answer. We should change the state fiscal year to begin later than it does now. By moving it back, budget makers would have more accurate knowledge about the actual and projected fiscal condition of the state.
New York has one the shortest budget review periods of any state. Under our April 1 fiscal year, forecasting economic activity to project expected revenues is like trying to hit a moving target.
Economic conditions haven't improved our marksmanship. Since the 1987 stock market crash, the Northeast has been mired in recession. Last month, the Legislature had to make painful decisions: We cut $1 billion on top of the $1 billion we slashed from the Governor Cuomo's original proposal. The weakening economy and the short time budget makers have to forecast its performance makes another fiscal surprise this year more likely than not.
The reasons for changing the fiscal year are compelling; the benefits are many. Right now, the Governor must forecast revenues before critical tax receipt information is available. This leads to revenue arguments or waiting until the middle of March for more exact data. Recent budgets have been blindsided by mid-March forecasts. That guarantees tardiness in passing a budget.
A July 1 fiscal year would give budget builders time and better knowledge. Simply knowing what personal income taxes total after the April 15 filing deadline will be a major plus.
Changing the fiscal year has been studied thoroughly; in fact, it has been adjusted twice in this century. Whether we now shift the end of this fiscal year from March 31 to June 30, or stretch out the next fiscal year to June 30, 1992, the result can be the same: a budget adopted on time with sufficient revenues to pay expenses.

LENGTH: 555 words

HEADLINE: The Labor Pacts: Go Back to the Table

 BODY:
If these were normal times, New York City's first three labor settlements would be acceptable. But the times are not normal. The city is struggling through an economic and fiscal emergency unlike anything it has experienced in over a decade. In the last year 50,000 jobs disappeared. Property values have declined by a third in some neighborhoods. The city's own budget deficit continues to grow and because the economy is so weak, the needs of New Yorkers, especially the poor, are growing too.
Yet the Dinkins administration has negotiated labor settlements that will guarantee poorer services and thousands of layoffs. There is little choice. Other than imposing dramatic tax increases, cutting services and jobs is the only way to pay for the increases. In effect, Mayor David Dinkins chose to benefit labor at the expense of all other New Yorkers, a misguided decision that demands only one response: a reversal. 
 To his credit, Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez is now trying to prevent widespread teacher layoffs by chipping away at the expensive 5.5 percent increase the city negotiated with the teachers' union. The contract, combined with cuts in state and city funding, could require 4,000 layoffs, disrupting classrooms. Instead Mr. Fernandez proposes that all school employees take a three-day unpaid furlough, for a saving of about $50 million and at a cost to each teacher of about $460. In effect that would reduce the 5.5 percent increase to roughly 4.3. Shortening the school year is not the ideal solution, but a furlough would be less disruptive than layoffs, and would save the jobs of younger teachers, many of them minority members. The unions would be doing the city and their own rank and file a favor to accept the Chancellor's proposal.
Now it is City Hall's responsibility to admit error and pull back from its latest settlements, which give District Council 37 and the teamsters 5 percent wage and benefit increases over 15 months. The reason is not purely fiscal. The city will pay for the settlements with money already in the budget, and funds from a risky reduction in the city's contribution to the workers' pension fund. Technically, the agreements do not have an impact on the budget. But they will have an impact on life in New York.
The city's current budget deficit doubled in the last three weeks to $500 million and could go as high as $2.1 billion in the next fiscal year. Budget officials only just announced those gloomy facts, but they come as no surprise. It's clear that Mr. Dinkins and his negotiators knew about the growing deficit and approved the settlements anyway.
That is indeed troubling. The new raises mean about $15 or $20 a week to the average worker, but will mean cuts in services and dismissals to the rest of the city. That defies common sense.
Mr. Dinkins could follow Mr. Fernandez's lead and seek a similar way out of the agreements with District Council 37 and the teamsters. Another option would be to defer the agreements until the city is in better shape, or go back to the bargaining table. At least a move in that direction would send a prudent signal to those municipal unions still negotiating with the city, and show that the Mayor and his advisers realize that now is not the time to conduct business as usual with city employees.

HEADLINE: There's No Substitute for Parents

BYLINE: By Lisbeth B. Schorr; Lisbeth B. Schorr's book "Within Our Reach" analyzes successful programs for disadvantaged children. She is a lecturer in social medicine at Harvard University.

 BODY:

CHILDHOOD'S FUTURE
By Richard Louv.
420 pp. Boston:
A Marc Jaffe Book/Houghton Mifflin. $21.95. 
 Childhood isn't what it used to be. In the introduction to "Childhood's Future" Richard Louv quotes the child psychiatrist James Comer's memories of growing up in a working-class neighborhood of East Chicago, Ind., where "between home and school, at least five close friends of my parents reported everything I did that was unacceptable." Yesterday's extended families and involved neighbors have been replaced by today's television, impersonal malls and hostile streets. These are the settings of Mr. Louv's passionate call for rebuilding community and family life.
The author, a columnist for The San Diego Union, spent three years traversing the country to interview more than 3,000 parents, children, volunteers, teachers and other professionals. He found heartening community efforts, including Dr. Comer's successful collaboration with New Haven schools and parents to help schools there provide the "warmth and adult contact that many kids don't get at home," the continuing relationships that Dr. Comer considers the basic element most missing in education today.
But in the main, Mr. Louv's conversations reflect parents' isolation from their children and from one another, and a pervasive anxiety about an unraveling of childhood and family life that no one ever intended. His interview subjects grieve over the disappearance of family rituals, even of dinners together, and recount how children come from school to empty houses, how they care for themselves and spend ever more of their time on their own, having achieved what Mr. Louv sees as "a freedom closer to abandonment."
We meet a youngster who believes her parents preferred life at work to life at home with their nine children, who were left to "do whatever we want." The child cooked her own food and learned to "handle everything myself." She says: "I never really knew my parents too well, or my grandparents or any of my relatives. . . . It's kind of like a separate world of mine." Mr. Louv concludes that "the isolation from adults that many children feel is acute, painful, and ultimately numbing."
He finds that the institutions that might compensate for what overwhelmed parents are unable to do are themselves undermined by stingy public policies. A librarian tells of rules and cutbacks that prevent her from waiting outside the closed library with the children whom no one has picked up by closing time. Teachers complain that funding reductions make it harder to educate children who are hungry and neglected and come to school in midwinter without coats or socks. Good day care workers are almost impossible to find and retain at wage rates below those of janitors and trash collectors.
Mr. Louv maintains that the fragmentation of American families is not "simply a question of personal morality or individual fidelity" but is powerfully linked to changes in the economy. He argues that the United States is the only advanced Western nation where family life is a regarded as a private matter, where workplaces operate oblivious to family pressures and where a lingering frontier mentality creates ambivalence about support from corporations or government -- even help that would enable a parent to stay home with a newborn.
Convinced that this is not the way things have to be, Mr. Louv offers a vision of families more connected to one another and to their environment, in cities and towns with schools and libraries and community centers that all provide child care, family supports and a sense of belonging to old and young alike. He believes we can create conditions making it easier to combine work and family life, and providing more time and support for parenting. He sees corporations encouraging part-time employment and offering parental leave and time off so that both men and women could monitor and participate in their children's day care and schools.
Mr. Louv's interviews show a widespread eagerness to make our institutions more responsive to children and families, and an emerging consensus among people of widely divergent ideologies that the family is central, and that if children are to grow into self-sufficient adults, the family needs to be buttressed by social institutions, public and private.
But wishing won't make it so. While acknowledging that the personal must ultimately become political, Mr. Louv fails to deal with the tough questions of how the urgently needed changes might be made to happen. I would have hoped for more help from this talented journalist as to how to bring about the policies, programs and investments needed to turn his appealing vision into reality. Nevertheless, his book is useful because it reminds us that childhood's present does not have to be childhood's future, and because it describes accurately the widespread yearning for a world in which being a parent and being a child regain a cherished place in the lives of both families and communities.

HEADLINE: Among Shattered Young Souls

BYLINE: By Samuel G. Freedman; Samuel G. Freedman is the author of "Small Victories: The Real World of a Teacher, Her Students, and Their High School," which was a finalist for the 1990 National Book Award.

 BODY:

UNDER RUNNING LAUGHTER
Notes From a Renegade Classroom.
By Quincy Howe Jr.
156 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $19.95. 
 When the Khmer Rouge tried to create a generation of young people in Cambodia devoid of conscience, morality and other such vestiges of bourgeois imperialism, they dubbed those new beings the "Year Zero Children." The phrase stayed in my mind while I read "Under Running Laughter," for Quincy Howe Jr. delivers a portrait of youthful souls here at home shattered as completely as any in the Cambodian holocaust.
These "Year Zero Children" form the population of the Leake & Watts Children's Home, a publicly funded residence and special-education school in Yonkers. There are only 90 of them, ranging in age from 10 to 20, but their small number seem to embody almost every form of assault on human dignity, going back through several generations. The demise of the industrial economy in the area plunged their grandparents into poverty. That poverty helped to push their parents into crime and drugs. And those parents visited emotional and physical abuse on the future residents of Leake & Watts. Most have been sent to the facility, either by social service agencies or by criminal courts, because they had been deemed too troubled to be placed in foster homes.
Such a scenario, bleak as it is, does not begin to capture the tragedies that Mr. Howe, as a teacher in Leake & Watts's high school, must face and somehow address. Mr. Howe, who taught Latin and Greek at the college level, now has pupils who pose for casual photographs holding numbered cards beneath their chins in the manner of criminals submitting for police mug shots. Many of those same children suck their thumbs during the movies Mr. Howe periodically shows. Life has taught them to accept murderous violence as a given and to distrust and even destroy the connections with caring adults they so desperately require.
Within the classroom, three-quarters of the high school pupils work at sixth grade level or below. Few can concentrate on a given project for more than 10 or 15 minutes. Their behavior swings wildly between impenetrable withdrawal and manic rage. Mr. Howe's writing assignments routinely elicit accounts such as this one:
"I was small and really didn't know how to fight. So one day people that I knew made up a crew name the Forty Thieves. I was given the name Crime. I used to snatch chains, steal pocketbooks, grocery money, and stick people. These things were the move.
"So one day last year I moved to Bed Stuy (do or die) and I met this kid name Pistol Pop. We would go around sticking up crack spots until one day on the 24th of December my home boy was killed. He was tortured. . . . They knocked out all his teeth. . . . He was raped [with a baseball bat] and then . . . they shot him. . . .
"Now I swear to the dead Father Allah, if I find who did it, I am going to put two bullets in his head. But anyway I cooled down. Now I'm just chillin."
Against such immense social failure, Mr. Howe strives to build and sustain in his classroom "a reasonably good simulation of life itself" -- "reading the newspaper, making photographs, learning about Martin Luther King, Jr., operating the sewing machine, and watching movies." His goal is "to teach them how to esteem themselves and others, how to accept adults as a benign influence in their lives, and how to prepare for a future whose shape is now ominous and confusing for them." The rare success, in Mr. Howe's telling, is the student not only capable of graduating from high school but also, more important, capable of finding a niche in either the armed forces or the semiskilled labor force. The rest, the majority, cannot conceive of any existence other than working for a drug lord or inhabiting a crowded prison cell.
To Mr. Howe's credit, he resists the popular tendency to blame the victims. Nor does he romanticize himself and his colleagues for their efforts. He deconstructs a system of public-agency regulations that forces social workers to spend half their time filling out forms and ultimately drives many talented and caring ones out of the profession. He also argues forcefully and eloquently for a special-education system that would acknowledge the obvious -- that remaking mutilated lives will require the investment of both time and money -- rather than expecting miracles from the usual two-year placement at Leake & Watts.
Yet Mr. Howe is perhaps too reserved. He never explains with sufficient depth or feeling how a university classicist could or would find his way to Leake & Watts, and only in the last two pages does he acknowledge his "almost addictive fascination with the children" and the redemptive moments that have led him to remain there for four years -- even as several of his colleagues have been hospitalized for exhaustion. When it comes to depicting his students, Mr. Howe's reserve becomes an unfortunate kind of detachment; he relies too often on such clinical jargon as "oppositional behavior" and "conduct-disorder" rather than describing real children in detail. Forgoing conventional narrative in favor of a more policy-minded approach, Mr. Howe never allows a reader to know the boys and girls as he has known them, as individuals who grow and falter and struggle. They function more as anecdotal case histories than as the flesh and blood humans whose plight clearly has moved Mr. Howe in ways even he cannot quite express.

HEADLINE: Growing Old Fast in Guatemala

 BODY:
THE MOST POIGNANT evidence of Central America's lost decade of poverty and brutal oppression can be found not only in the economic statistics but in the streets of Guatemala.
Growing numbers of abandoned or orphaned children beg, scavenge and steal to stay alive. In the slums of Guatemala City, a spot on a dirty concrete floor in a primitive shelter costs 12 to 18 cents a night. It is a luxury.
For the great majority of Guatemalans, there are no jobs, no dependable income. Some families abandon their offspring because they cannot feed them. According to an estimate by New York-based Covenant House, which runs a shelter in Guatemala City, the population of homeless children in the capital is 10,000 -- double what it was a few years ago. Some children are forced into prostitution, which is concentrated in a park next to police headquarters. Others depend on the city dump for their food and clothing.
 Many Guatemalan street children dull their pain and their appetites by sniffing glue (center top and bottom right). Inhaled in a bag a spoonful at a time, a 50-cent container can last a group a whole day. Over time, the fumes destroy brain cells and in some cases cause death. But glue temporarily stills the shivers at night and soothes hunger pains during the day. It also gives some children the courage to steal from stores and cars (bottom center).
Crime is rising, and the authorities have responded harshly. Human rights groups have accused the police of killing about 40 children. Photographs of some of the bodies show evidence of torture: ears and tongues cut off and eyes burned out. Many other children have simply disappeared. Sometimes the police pour glue on the heads of the children, who have to shave their hair to get it out. Sometimes the glue runs into their eyes (above), often causing permanent injury.
In late November, two Covenant House volunteers happened upon policemen kicking a 15-year-old boy in the stomach. The officers took off their badges to avoid identification and stopped beating the teen-ager when they saw the photographer (far left, bottom).
The authorities say they are looking into the charges of abuse and have encouraged the police to take the homeless children to the Covenant House shelter (top left).
But Bruce Harris, executive regional director of the shelter, doubts that the police will change. "There is no justice in Guatemala," he says. "These kids are abandoned by their families, by the state and by society."

GRAPHIC: Photos of children in Guatemala. (Photographs by Miguel Luis Fairbanks)

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS VIEW;
Merengue's Dance-Till-You-Drop Beat

BYLINE: By DAISANN McLANE; Daisann McLane writes about Caribbean music for The Village Voice, Details and other publications

 BODY:
The power -- and air-conditioning -- goes out for at least four hours every day in sunbaked Santo Domingo, filling one's head with visions of the beach. But the beach is a 20-minute drive away, and in the Dominican Republic, the wait for a full tank of gas can take hours. Even a shower is impossible; without electricity, there's no water pressure. On these sweaty, miserable afternoons, it seems there's only one thing that hasn't quit in this capital city: merengue. It jumps from battery-powered blasters downtown on Calle El Conde, palpitates from the speakers of customized vans along the Malecon boulevard. The national rhythm of the Dominican Republic never stops.
Santo Domingo at first seems an unlikely home for the most vibrant and commercially successful musical scene in the Caribbean. Economic and political chaos and a deteriorating infrastructure turn the most basic business activities -- recording an album, mounting a concert, distributing records -- into tests of ingenuity and faith. It is not uncommon for the power to fail in the middle of a recording session, ruining a day's work. Yet even top Dominican performers -- like the singer-songwriter Juan Luis Guerra, who could easily afford to work elsewhere -- stay home. Like Kingston, Jamaica, Nashville or Memphis in their heydays, Santo Domingo has it all: the best songwriters, musicians, producers and arrangers. A sound. 
 Santo Domingo's merengue -- that hyperdrive, horn-propelled rhythm with a percussive heart murmur -- competes with reggae and rap for dominance on the streets of Manhattan. Dominicans are one of the fastest-growing immigrant groups in New York City, with estimates as high as 500,000 people. "The money from Dominicans in New York is the pulmon, the lungs, of the economy back home," says Jose Tejeda, a New York-based merengue concert promoter. It is the record-buying fever of these homesick emigres that provides the cash that pumps the hit factories of Santo Domingo.
There's no official merengue Top 10 list, but a stroll along Broadway in the largely Dominican Washington Heights section of Manhattan will tell you instantly which bands rule: La Coco Band and Jossie Esteban y La Patrulla 15. These groups -- both hard-working, big (11 or more members) dance bands -- are the mainstay of New York's thriving Dominican nightlife (Santo Domingo may be a recording center but there's little live music). Jumpy and relentless, the bands fuse Saturday-night dance-till-you-drop energy with intricate, multilayered horn arrangements and naughty, double-entendre lyrics.
Musicians would probably prefer La Patrulla 15, whose latest albums are "En Accion" and "Hot" (Top Ten Hits 1947 and 1965 respectively; LP and cassette). Modern merengue is an arranger's playground, and Patrulla's Ringo Martinez is a whiz at whipping trumpets, trombones and alto and tenor saxophones into swirling horn confections that raise sugar levels and pulse rates. But for rock-the-house intensity, dancers at Washington Heights clubs like Fuego Fuego and Studio 84 favor La Coco Band. In a genre where you can be neither too fast nor too sexually suggestive, the Cocos set new standards on their latest album, "Pochi y su Coco Band" (Kubaney KD 20028; all three formats); on stage they sing about girlfriends while waving three-foot bones.
 Power merengue bands like these have popularized Dominican music far beyond its original audience, spreading into other Latin communities (merengue has hit the charts everywhere from Puerto Rico to Colombia) and even, occasionally, into American discos. The big-band party sound still dominates in merengue, but the recent crop of releases from Santo Domingo indicates there are musical trends emerging.
Merengue tipico, a rough-hewn acoustic music from the rural Cibao region that is the precursor of modern high-tech merengue, sells briskly in Manhattan and Santo Domingo. A tipico ensemble bears some resemblance to a Cajun zydeco outfit; it is fronted by a singer-accordion player, with the main percussion instrument a cheese-grater-like cylinder called a guira. But the wild, atonal solo duels of squeeze box and saxophone on Fefita La Grande's "Cintura Mia" (Juan and Nelson Records; LP and cassette) have as much to do with Don Cherry as with Clifton Chenier; tipico is an avant-garde improvisational fest in Caribbean disguise.
The latest news in Dominican music, though, is bachata, a Dominican country-folk music similar in rhythm to the Cuban son and in emotion to the Mexican ranchera (or for that matter, to Hank Williams). This old-fashioned song form has been revived by young, hip Dominican songwriters like Juan Luis Guerra. On his long-awaited new album, "Bachata Rosa" (Karen K136; all three formats), Mr. Guerra uses the bachata as underpinning for his smart, imagistic love songs in much the same way that Paul Simon recycled the English ballad for his early folk-rock hits.
The modern bachatas of the gifted and prolific songwriter Luis (Terror) Diaz are not as pop conscious or airy as Mr. Guerra's, but they have a rich, earthy romanticism and dazzling melodies -- one "ay yi yi" from Mr. Diaz is worth a thousand layers of horns. Mr. Diaz's own work is hard to find -- he's studio shy, and his only record is years out of print. But his friend Sonia Silvestre, a warm, powerful alto singer, recently released an entire album of Diaz songs, "Yo Quiero Andar" (OI Records; LP only), and several Diaz compositions are featured on a fine new debut album, "Iris y Franklyn" (Karen KCD 130; all three formats), by the Dominican duo of the title.
Mr. Diaz also writes most of the material for Sergio Vargas, the boyish singer who, along with Mr. Guerra, is the Dominican Republic's most popular performer. Mr. Vargas's last two albums, both entitled "Sergio Vargas" (CBS Discos; all three formats), are available in Latin-record stores and world-beat bins at large chains, as are most major merengue releases.
Mr. Vargas lacks Mr. Guerra's poetic dimension and writing talent, but he compensates with a deliciously teasing tenor and natural stage presence; handsome and magnetic, Mr. Vargas is merengue's first pop star. Last November, in a concert at Lehman College in the Bronx, he held a mostly Dominican audience rapt (and made young girls scream) with a two-hour multimedia collage of songs, skits and dances that chronicled his rise from sugar-cane cutter to musical hero.
Mr. Vargas's attempts to take Dominican music beyond the dance club are exciting Dominicans everywhere. Back in Santo Domingo, this ambitious show sold out for two weeks, at a time when the power crisis was at its worst, labor strikes rampant and gasoline nearly impossible to find.
"You can turn out the lights, stop the water, take away the cars and buses," Mr. Vargas explains. "But nothing can keep a Dominican away from his music."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jossie Esteban, far left, with his band La Patrulla 15--a mainstay of New York's thriving Dominican nightlife (Top Ten Hits )

LENGTH: 1111 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Giving New Meaning to the Phrase Team Player

BYLINE: By CORY DEAN

 BODY:
The lights dim, the ABC Sports theme fills the air and the referee bounds into the arena in a black-and-white-striped jersey, a whistle hanging from her neck. The judges prepare their score cards, the two four-member teams take their places, the referee flips a coin, and the match is on.
But the athletes are actors, the arena is a tiny stage in the basement club of a Manhattan restaurant, and the game is Speaking in One Voice. 
 A team member steps forward to explain the rules: "All four of us, who don't know the story we are about to tell you, will tell it at the same time." Someone in the audience supplies "a dangerous location" -- 42d Street -- and the actors are off, speaking in unison, sometimes in bursts of words, sometimes haltingly: "As I was . . . walking . . . on 42d Street . . . I met a man. . . . He . . . asked me for . . . all . . . my . . . clothes. . . . He . . . put . . . them on . . . and . . . gave me . . . his clothes. . . . I said . . . what are you doing and . . . he said . . . cross . . . dressing!"
The crowd around the darkened club's tiny tables cheers, and the three judges hold up their score cards: on a scale of 0 to 5, the team has scored 5-5-4.
This is theater sports -- improvisation performed as a competitive sport in which actors vie for high marks in skill, story and show ("Was it entertaining?"). It began in western Canada with fans who took to it with the fervor they normally reserve for ice hockey; now it has spread around the world.
The actors who appeared at the West Bank Cafe recently were from TheaterSports/NY, the troupe that brought the improvisational form to the city. After years in the minors -- small downtown Manhattan clubs and midnight shows -- they open Friday night at 8 at the John Houseman Theater on West 42d Street. It may not be the big leagues, but it's close enough.
The group fields a roster of about 30 team members who range in age from early 20's to 40's and has a repertoire of more than 100 improvisational games they make up or borrow from other teams. Though the format varies depending on whether the match is between two teams or a four-team round robin, the basics remain the same. The referee functions as emcee and when a skit goes bad, any of the three judges recruited for the evening can honk a horn, ending it.
The goal is not only an evening's entertainment. Players use theater sports to hone their acting skills and, more important, to confront something that sports accepts but show business usually does not: failure.
Although theater sports first found success in Canada, it "came out of professional wrestling back in the 50's in England," said Keith Johnstone, who got the idea while working as a play-reader and teacher at the Royal Court Theater in London. The wrestling "was clearly improvised theater," he said. "All the pain was played in front. If you were going to twist someone's neck, you made sure they were facing out front. It was the only form of working-class theater I'd ever seen, the genuine product."
Theater sports never really caught on in England, primarily, Mr. Johnstone believes, because until about 20 years ago all theatrical texts had to be approved in advance by the Lord Chancellor, making improv practically impossible. But in 1971 Mr. Johnstone settled in Alberta, Canada, where he teaches at the University of Calgary, and, after organizing a theater, he tried again.
"It was a wild success as soon as we started," he said in a telephone interview from Alberta. "The Canadians are crazy about sport. They reacted like it was ice hockey."
From Calgary, theater sports spread to Vancouver and then down the west coast of the United States and across the Pacific to Australia and New Zealand, where it has enjoyed wide popularity, especially among audiences in their 20's and 30's.
"Wherever you go," Mr. Johnstone said, "it's the young audiences who won't go to a normal theater who go to this."
According to George Babiak, one of the New Yorkers who competed in a 1989 tourney in Auckland in which his team, from TheaterSports/NY, finished third in a field of nine, "Before theater sports arrived, I don't think many young audiences had much experience with improv."
The Auckland competition was held at the Commonwealth Games; the team also competed at a tournament held at the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary and in matches in Edmonton, Toronto and Brisbane against teams from England, Canada, New Zealand, Australia, Norway, Sweden and Czechoslovakia. TheaterSports/NY will be the host for the next big international tournament, at Pace University in New York in June.
But despite the sport's popularity, Michael Durkin, who manages the company's finances, says members do not make enough money to live on. He likens performances to "an Off Broadway show with a cast of 30. That's just economically not possible at this moment."
Many of the games are staples of improv and, like actors in other improv companies, team members use their workouts to polish skills for more traditional stage work.
For example, the game Sit, Stand and Kneel requires three players to monitor one another as one sits, one stands and the third kneels. When a player changes position, the others must move to compensate. "It really makes you watch the other players," said Hugh Sinclair, a team member.
But the element of competition adds something missing from conventional improv. In the first place, Mr. Johnstone said, "audiences respond amazingly to it."
"The audience reacts a lot more," agreed Laura Livingston, an actress who is also the company's artistic director. When a skit goes well, she said, "it's like you just scored the winning basket in a close game."
More important, the element of sport helps actors overcome the fear of failure that all of them face but many cannot acknowledge.
"There's something special about failure in sport," Mr. Johnstone said. "If you're in show business, you paper over it and smile. In sport, every note of failure is part of it. Otherwise you'd make the net lower or push the goals closer together."
 A low score can come as a relief to actors and audience. "Sometimes improv doesn't go too well," Mr. Babiak said. "Theater sports admits that."
Mr. Babiak invented one of the team's most popular games, Research and Development, in which the audience is asked to suggest the name of a game and then the actors devise the rules and play it.
In a 5-5-5 win against failure, one audience-inspired game, Nerdbusters, requires a member of the audience to recount an embarrassing moment from life; the players re-enact it, but transform it from disaster to triumph.

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS VIEW;
Sorting Out The Caruso Alternatives

BYLINE: By DAVID HAMILTON; David Hamilton, a music critic, produces recordings of historic material for the Metropolitan Opera.

 BODY:
Old recordings may never die, but they do go out of print. Even election to the Grammy Hall of Fame doesn't assure currency: recent honorees still absent from the catalogue include Bidu Sayao's classic recording of Villa-Lobos's "Bachiana Brasileira No. 5," Lehman Engel's "Porgy and Bess" and Dimitri Mitropoulos's "Wozzeck." And while the CD medium is reviving a remarkable range of material, the end products often suggest that sound recordings are not yet treated in accordance with their role in music and society.
A telling illustration is the legacy of Enrico Caruso, which never achieved an integral edition on LP. Few performers deserve such recognition more than Caruso, a singer not only splendidly endowed but also admirably conscientious, whose records made him the universal model for later generations of tenors, while his reputation played a major role in establishing the phonograph socially and economically. Although he remained an Italian citizen, his career centered in the United States, where he became a genuine folk hero to his immigrant compatriots and to everyone else as well. 
 Thus it doesn't seem utopian to expect his recordings to be carefully translated into the newest technology and packaged in a manner befitting their place in history. Other cultural legacies have long been handed down and restored with scrupulous care. For more than a century, international consortiums of scholars, supported by governments and foundations, have prepared authoritative printed editions of the music of the great masters. These days, classics of American literature receive comparable treatment, in collected editions emanating from university presses, underwritten by the National Endowment for the Humanities.
Despite controversy over details, the desirability of doing such projects thoroughly and professionally is taken for granted. Though the resulting weighty tomes are destined principally for libraries, they also spawn popular editions for general readers, performers and listeners (in the foregoing literary example, the handsomely printed volumes of the Library of America). Regrettably, none of the three Caruso editions produced on CD in the last year matched comparable projects in other fields in vision, scholarship and technical quality.
The first, Bayer's "Caruso/Complete/ Compact" package, failed to live up to its billing, and appears to have been motivated only by opportunism. Two installments of "The Caruso Edition" followed, from England's Pearl label, using tapes prepared by the American engineer Ward Marston (Pearl EVC I and II; three disks each; two more volumes to come). BMG Classics last spring announced "The Complete Caruso" (RCA Gold Seal 60495-2-RG; 12 disks), and managed to get it into the stores in time for Christmas.
 Which to go with? Indeed, except for sound archives and compulsives, who needs all of Caruso's recordings anyway? Myself, I may never play again many of the salon, sacred and popular songs he recorded in increasing proportion over the years -- though some are treasurable for their verve ("Luna d'estate,"), vocal polish ("Vaghissima sembianza") and sheer splendor (Adam's "Cantique de Noel"). From Franchetti's "Germania" in 1902 to Caruso's last new role, in Halevy's "Juive" in 1920, the operatic records are sui generis; no opera lover should be without at least a sampling. If nobody else's selection will satisfy you, it may be simpler to have it all. (A good starting point for beginners is EMI's single CD of early Caruso, CDH7 61046-2.)
These three sets sound strikingly different, and the layman may wonder why. Well, for one thing, recordings aren't like books or printed music. While a new printing of "Huckleberry Finn" in a modern typeface may lack the aura of the first edition, it still transmits the voice of Mark Twain: if Twain's letters, words and punctuation are correctly transcribed, his meaning is preserved. But sound is not made of such discrete elements; it is a wave, a continuum, analog rather than digital in nature, until recently actually preserved in analog form: undulations of record grooves, patterns of magnetic particles on tape.
Transferring that wave from one storage medium to another is a process full of variables and options -- and in a profound sense unverifiable. Printed editions can be proofread to insure equivalence to the original, but the "original" of a sound recording -- the actual performance -- is unavailable for comparison; it long ago vanished into thin air. Few now survive who heard Caruso in the flesh, and seven decades of listening to the records have doubtless colored their recollections.
 So standards of judgment are ultimately subjective. Nobody objects to minimizing the nonmusical noises that afflicted older recordings -- but beyond a certain point this may entail altering or suppressing some musical content as well. How much "enhancement" of the musical sound by adding resonance, altering frequency balance, and the like, is justified? To what extent do the engineers modify the sound to match models inside their own ears? (And to what extent do listeners make similar comparisons?)
There are no simple answers, but the three Caruso projects demonstrate how the working methodology behind a project makes a difference. Each started from a different kind of source. In the fall 1990 issue of the Journal of the Association for Recorded Sound Collections, Gary A. Galo convincingly demonstrates that the Bayer is merely a clumsy digital massage job on the egregiously flawed 1973 Murray Hill LP reissue; as the computer folks say, "Garbage in, garbage out." For Pearl's project (now half complete), Mr. Marston has used the quietest, least worn copies available in numerous private American collections.
Caruso recorded principally for Victor, to which BMG is corporate heir. Then isn't its package, billed as "including the original Victor Talking Machine Co. Master Recordings," made directly from the original materials? Not so, though BMG doesn't go out of its way to clarify the point. In fact, all but 51 of the 238 tracks here were prepared from tapes made with Thomas G. Stockham's Soundstream digital restoration process and issued on RCA LP's between 1978 and 1985. And since we were never told what Mr. Stockham started with, the suspicion remains that these CD's may incorporate the products of still earlier technology -- and in any case don't represent what today's engineering might do with the original masters.
Soundstream sought to compensate for the old recording horns' erratic frequency response, yet won little acceptance, partly because it added an intrusive roaring noise in the lower-middle range. Spot-checking indicates that the Soundstream Carusos have been modified for the CD edition, reducing the roaring -- and also the stronger bass line of the LP edition, which was a plus. (Considering the fanfare that introduced these transfers on LP, how ironic that Soundstream receives just one tiny mention in the new package.)
 The rest of RCA's tracks (pre-1906 recordings, plus a few others overlooked in the Soundstream series) were freshly taped by William R. Moran, using materials in the RCA archives. These sound more like the Pearl transfers; the methodology was basically similar, using traditional analog equipment. Comparison is vivid when RCA juxtaposes two takes of Tosti's song "L'alba separa" recorded the same day, one restored by Mr. Moran, one by Mr. Stockham. The latter is louder, the orchestra fuller, the voice apparently more forward -- but there's still that confounded roaring, and rather a lot of nonmusical noise. (Surprisingly, RCA has no decisive advantage over Pearl in the condition of its originals; for example, in RCA's set several of the 1905 recordings sport substantial ticks absent in the competition.)
Another problem: before 1925, recording speeds were not standardized, so original Carusos don't all play at 78.26 rpm. Fortunately, unlike Bayer (and many earlier reissues), Pearl and RCA are careful about pitch, though not always in agreement. Pearl's Mr. Marston convincingly argues that Caruso transposed down a few more selections than commonly accepted, while RCA follows the consensus. (This matters on CD, since variable speed is much rarer on CD players than on LP turntables.)
There are other considerations. RCA's booklet indexes the recordings six ways to Sunday, and includes excerpts from Michael Scott's recent Caruso book, placing Caruso and his singing in its historical context with contemporary reviews and comments. Pearl provides gracious, less informative notes by John Steane (who has missed the latest research: Caruso was the 3d of 7 children, not the 18th of 21), and its documentation, well intentioned, is poorly edited and proofread.
Neither RCA nor Pearl gives the words Caruso sang, not even for unfamiliar songs few listeners will have access to. Nor does either observe an ethical obligation: unissued recordings, not approved by the artist, often have ample historical interest, especially in the context of a complete edition, but should be clearly marked as such. A not minor consideration: the RCA set is mid-priced, Pearl's high-priced.
All told, none of these is what we need and Caruso deserves. By mixing two types of restoration, the RCA package puts its user at a disadvantage in comparing the younger and older Caruso; it looks as if corners were cut to get this set out quickly. Pearl is moving more slowly and carefully on the sonic side. Yet a single edition, using that kind of care plus all available sources (from both private collections and RCA's archives), considering newer digital restoration techniques, and preparing full documentation and editorial apparatus, would have been to everyone's advantage. Full justice remains to be done to Caruso.

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
Choreography in the Pursuit of Happiness

BYLINE: By Jack Anderson

 BODY:
Brian Jucha turned on a radio during "Life's Hell!!! Savettka Sings the Blues." What he heard was the speech of 1962 during which President John F. Kennedy announced the Cuban missile crisis. That news made the young man Mr. Jucha portrayed look uneasy. He had yet another reason to seem unsettled. Although Mr. Jucha ended his solo wearing a man's T-shirt and jeans, he began it in a long gown and a woman's silver-blond wig. As he danced, he recited a monologue about a man's fascination with women's clothes and his determination to go his own way.
To remind his audience of the world's complexities, Mr. Jucha blended personal and political crises in this solo, which was part of "Fresh Tracks," a series of works by young choreographers offered last month at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. The solo was one of several dances recently performed in New York City about people puzzled by conflicts in their minds and in the world around them. None of the pieces offered ready-made solutions to social problems. Nevertheless, all raised important issues and proved sadly relevant at a time when society has such trouble dealing with concerns like homelessness, drug addiction and economic uncertainty in our own country or political instability and the threat of war abroad. 
 Two particularly impressive depictions of people in quandaries were Susan Marshall's "Contenders," which Ms. Marshall's company danced last month at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and Ann Carlson's "Flag," which was part of Codanceco's autumn program at the Bessie Schonberg.
Uncertainty was the point of "Contenders." At the outset, however, there appeared to be no ambiguities in this dance. Tom Kamm's set resembled a stadium. Lynne Steincamp's costume designs were inspired by gym suits. The recorded score by Pauline Oliveros combined the noise of roaring crowds with the perky but banal tunes often played at skating rinks.
The physically demanding choreography turned the dancers into runners in a race. They gathered at a starting line, struggled forward, fell back and gained enough second wind to plunge ahead again. Ah, yes, it was easy to say, Ms. Marshall is metaphorically envisioning life as a race.
But soon something else became clear. No one -- neither the audience nor the dancers themselves -- could ever be certain just what the rules of the game were. What made "Contenders" disquieting was the way the rules kept changing without notice and for no discernible reason. Every time the dancers had to reassemble at the starting line, they gathered in different places. Just as they never quite knew the proper way to start their contendings, so the point of their strivings was equally ambiguous. No finish line was ever in sight.
Because there were moments when it was impossible to tell whether the dancers were cooperating or competing when they clustered together, "Contenders" could be interpreted as a depiction of a troubled society. But, like Mr. Jucha, Ms. Marshall combined social comment with psychological insight. Sequences of lifts made one wonder if the people involved wished to help or hinder one another. And when dancers paired off, their duets became erotic contests rather than displays of affection.
High-minded gym teachers often tell students, "It doesn't matter if you win or lose, it's how you play the game." But the dancers in "Contenders" were obviously playing to win. What made their behavior especially dismaying was not the violence of their struggles, but the fact that no one could determine the point of their efforts. It was impossible to tell if they were winning or losing, or even if they were playing well or badly.
"Contenders" ended with its runners jogging in slow motion into eternity. By choreographically creating a long-distance race with no apparent goal, Ms. Marshall suggested that society may be exhausting its energies for no ethical purpose.
In her work "Flag," Ms. Carlson also set men and women dashing about, even panting as they ran. At other times, they prowled, plodded, staggered and stumbled. These were worried, uncertain individuals, and it was easy to see that they were not fretting over trivialities. All their pacings and hurtlings took place on a floor cloth adorned with stars and stripes to resemble an enormous American flag.
 Ms. Carlson had more than sensationalism in mind here. Although the members of her cast were trampling on the flag, they were not desecrating it. This was not an example of flag-burning without fire. The flag in the dance became a symbol of a disunited United States, and the turbulent choreographic events that occurred on it evoked national unrest.
When dancers collapsed, one could not be sure if they were simply exhausted or physically or emotionally wounded. Sometimes, when they fell, they tried to give one another artificial respiration. And when they bent to kiss the flag, one knew that Ms. Carlson was regarding the nation's problems with compassion as well as horror. Therefore, it was totally appropriate that her dance concluded with a taped recitation of the passage from the Declaration of Independence in praise of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.
Mr. Jucha and Ms. Marshall would surely join Ms. Carlson in echoing those noble sentiments. Even though they can offer no sure-fire formulas for the pursuit of national happiness, these choreographers' troubled dances prod the conscience.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Taking a Home on the Road With an RV Rental

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
TRAVEL by recreational vehicle, despite the increased cost of gasoline, has become an important way of vacationing. But you don't have to buy one. In addition to the estimated 8.5 million RV's registered to private owners in the United States, there is a sizable pool of RV's -- campers, trailers and motor homes -- for rent in the United States and Canada, as well as in Europe, New Zealand and Australia. Germans and Britons are big customers for rental RV's in the United States.
The snowbird season is the next-to-biggest time of the year for recreational vehicle travelers. Retired people living in the northern tier of the United States and in Canada unplug their coffee pots, put them in their camper trailers or motor homes and start driving to warmer weather. 
 The head of an assistance service that copes with medical emergencies of people on the road says he virtually tracks the weather by the area codes of calls for help. He said he gets a vision of motor homes down on their haunches like rabbits ready to streak for Orlando or Arizona at the drop of a snowflake. By now, he says, snowbirds are resting in the sun on the east and west coasts of Florida, Southern California, South Texas and around Phoenix and Tucson.
In the main, snowbirds own their vehicles because they want to use them year round. Younger families with tighter budgets and people thinking about buying an RV will probably want to consider rental. Rentals are continuing to rise, as they have since 1980, sometimes by as much as 50 percent in a year.
Although rentals are not cheap and the vehicles use a lot of fuel, daily costs for a trip may be lower than renting a car and staying in hotels. The saving, clearly, comes from doing a lot of your own work: cooking, bed-making, driving, cleaning, using the coin laundry.
Prices vary by area, length of rental, size of vehicle, length of trip and distance traveled. Demand also affects price. Here are some rates from the 1990 edition of "Who's Who In RV Rentals," published by the Recreational Vehicle Rental Association. In Orlando, Cruise America offers 19- to 24-foot motor homes for three to five for $385 to $980 a week. Also in Orlando, Go Vacations offers 18- to 27-foot motor homes to sleep four to six for $161 to $826 a week. In Atlanta, Holiday RV Superstores quotes a 22- to 26-foot motor home for four to six at $548 a week.
In busy seasons most outlets have minimum rental periods, as few as two days and as many as seven. Rentals do not include bed linens, pillows and blankets, pots, pans and plates, which are available for an extra cost, either by the person, perhaps $30 each for the whole rental, or for $50 to $100 for everything. Most rentals allow 100 free miles a day, with a per-mile charge after than, and a basic collision damage waiver.
Rental involves a security deposit, possibly $500 for the vehicle, a cleaning deposit of $50 and sometimes an added deposit of $50 for sanitizing.
Maintaining an RV
Bob Strawn, the executive vice president of the Recreational Vehicle Rental Association in Fairfax, Va., is blunt in sorting out the duties in an RV rental. Mr. Strawn, who for 19 years was an RV dealer in Denver, said that the dealer must say to the renter: "Now you are going to spend the next two or three hours listening to me about how this works. If you do, you will have a wonderful trip and come back again. If you do not, you may have an unpleasant and expensive experience."
Then the dealer should start by showing the customer how to put in oil, how to read the gauges and how to start the generator. Customers, he said, should be sure they understand the vital parts of a big machine that includes plumbing, water supply, propane gas, two electrical systems and a sewage pumping system, just to name a few.
All of this rules out arriving at the airport at 4 P.M. and taking off that night, as one might with an auto rental. Mr. Strawn said that sometimes Europeans acted confident about understanding the instructions and wanted to hurry away but discovered later, "usually at 3 A.M.," that their knowledge was flawed.
Mr. Strawn's organization includes 912 of the 3,800 RV dealers in the United States, but he says it is a purely voluntary group and membership is no guarantee to a consumer. The small type on the individual contract will specify what the insurance covers and stipulate what the traveler should do in the event of problems. He said most rental vans were less than three years old and would be sold at 50,000 miles. Failure to add oil or to understand how many hot showers are possible in a day, he said, tends to be the cause of difficulty rather than bad maintenance.
A dealer rents an RV 14 to 16 weeks a year, he said, with some very energetic dealers getting 22 to 26 weeks. He said that winterized vans, "mobile ski chalets," had longer seasons, and that sometimes dealers and hospitals enabled families to rent and live in a motor home near a relative who was getting treatment.
The Recreational Vehicle Rental Association publishes a good brochure, "Rental Ventures, How to Arrange to Tour North America by Rental Motor Home." It comes with the directory of 100-odd dealers that rent in 37 states and four Canadian provinces, and costs $5. The new edition of the directory will be published in February.
R.V.R.A., 3251 Old Lee Highway, Suite 500, Fairfax, Va. 22030.
A 1988 University of Michigan survey of 2,085 households is the source for the figure of 8.5 million recreational vehicles registered in the United States. The survey also found that one out of 10 vehicle-owning families had at least one recreational vehicle, and that 2 out of 10 were interested in renting an RV for a coming vacation. In Canada, estimates by Transport Canada and the RV association there put privately owned RV's at 500,000 to 750,000.
In the United States, according to the Michigan survey, 44 percent of the owners are 55 years of age or older; 39 percent are 35 to 54 years old. The remainder are owned by people 18 to 34.
The price of an RV varies widely: a camping trailer that unfolds into a tent may cost $2,000; a travel trailer may be $12,600. The industry association says that a luxury motor home costs an average of $59,000, with smaller models beginning at $26,000. A standard motor home of 20 to 22 feet, sometimes also called a mini-motor home, sleeps up to five people, as does an intermediate model of 23 to 24 feet. A large model, 24 to 26 feet, sleeps six and a deluxe model of 29 to 31 feet sleeps up to seven.
The big motor homes used to give only 4 to 5 miles to the gallon, but David J. Humphreys, president of the Recreational Vehicle Industry Association, a manufacturer group,said in an interview that improvements in weight and aerodynamics had brought this up to 10 to 12 miles to the gallon. Mr. Humphreys said that he expected 1990 sales, affected by waning consumer confidence in the economy, to be 7 percent below the 1989 sales figure of 395,700 units.
Motor Homes Abroad
A new agency in the United States has linked up with a British company and is offering RV rentals in England, usually for those who travel in caravans. The company, Britannia RV Rentals, lists rates of $760 a week in January for vehicle with two double beds to $1,890 for a week in August for a vehicle with three double beds. It also has the smaller van conversions. The price includes pickup from Heathrow Airport in London, the 15 percent value added tax and a basic collision damage waiver. Mandatory European Touring Insurance for trips outside England, $109 for two weeks, is also not included. The British company is U.K. Motorhomes Ltd.
Britannia RV Rentals, Box 1333, Jonesboro, Ga., 30237; (800) 872-1140.
There is also a clearinghouse for families with RV's who want to swap with European families who have RV's. Like programs for home exchanges, this has become much more informal because the operator discovered he was losing money on the plan; he now only circulates the information and leaves the arrangements to the parties. Bill Topping, who organized International Camper Exchange, will send an application form to anyone who sends a stamped self-addressed business envelope. When the form is returned, along with two or three envelopes each bearing 45 cents in postage, he copies it and distributes it to contacts in the countries that interest the applicant.
International Camper Exchange, Box 947, North Bend, Wash. 98045.

HEADLINE: Talking: Repair Loans;
Handyman Special Financing

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
PEOPLE of low or moderate income are often in a double bind when they try to buy a house. The sort of property within their grasp is frequently riddled with drawbacks such as bad plumbing or wiring or a dilapidated, leaky roof -- a handyman special that needs an immediate strong infusion of cash.
 Yet having used up all available savings for the down payment and closing, cash is the last thing they have to spare. Nor is an equity loan likely to help even if the repairs can be put off a year or two. Most homes today, especially in the Northeast, are not increasing in value fast enough to make an equity loan feasible. Besides, many lenders are phasing out equity loan programs as the market and economy weaken. Equity financing is often more costly, too. 
 Several programs are gearing up to deal with this situation. Their aim is to provide purchase financing and fix-up money in one loan package.
 Under such a program a rundown house selling say, for $80,000, is appraised during the purchase process at $100,000, its estimated value after the proposed renovations. The buyer is then provided with 90 or even 95 percent of the $100,000 as a mortgage amount. Part is used to buy the house and the rest is kept in escrow, to be released gradually by the lender to pay for materials and labor as the renovations move forward.
 This gives the buyer readily available cash while letting the lender hold onto the money until he is certain the work is being done. "But it's for basics," said Jane King, a vice president at Statewide Funding Corporation of Clifton Park, N.Y. "It's not for hot tubs."
 This type of loan should be available in three ways during 1991. Proabably the best opportunity will come from a new mortgage called the Community Home Improvement Loan being sponsored by the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae), the quasi-public corporation that buys mortgages issued by primary lenders and thereby sets the tone for their lending practices.
 The second, a similar but little-used Federal Housing Administration program called 203 (k), has been around a while but was strangling in red tape. Officials at the agency insist it will become far easier to use.
 The third alternative is a similar concept offered independently by a handful of lenders who have regularly provided all-in-one loans in the past. They will continue to offer the opportunity on a case-by-case basis, but the borrower will need to ask for the privilege as a special concession.
 About a dozen lenders nationwide are participating in the Fannie Mae progam, which is starting this month . Marty Levine, senior vice president at Fannie Mae in Washington, said that every effort is being made to begin with at least one lender. In New York, for example, it is being offered initially through the Chase Community Development Corporation of Brooklyn (718-624-4700), a subsidiary of Chase Manhattan Bank.
 Since others are expected to join in almost immediately, Fannie Mae has also set up a national hot line that interested borrowers can use to find out which lender to contact in their area (call 202-752-6527).
 This program is limited to households with incomes no more than 15 percent above the median income for the area. Nationwide this works out to around $42,000 to $62,000. But unlike many special low-cost mortgages offered through state-sponsored programs, it is not limited to first-time buyers. It is not available to investors.
People who already own a house can use the program to refinance a current mortgage to a level that might not otherwise be available. Origination costs and interest rates should be about the same as for a conventional loan. Renovation plans must be approved in advance by the lender.
 The down payment is 5 percent of the improved value. Mortgage size is limited to $191,250 and the amount set aside for renovations cannot exceed 30 percent of the total value of the property after the repairs.
WORKING with the 203 (k) program has traditionally been a nightmare of delays and documentation, butofficials in Washington insist that it was revamped in September 1989 to make it more user-friendly and that the local officials who process the applications are now better trained to speed matters along. Figures show that 619 borrowers benefited from such loans in 1990, up from 543 in 1989.
 There are no income limits for 203 (k) applicants and investors are welcome. However, the purchase price is limited -- around $125,000 for a one-family house to $197,950 for a four-family in high-cost areas like the Northeast or West Coast, and slightly less elsewhere. The down payment, based on the improved value, is 5 percent for owner-occupiers and 15 percent for investors.
 Borrowers must have their plans and specifications preapproved by local F.H.A. officials, which can create a delay of two months or more. An independent inspector must also approve the improvements each step of the way. Origination fees and interest charges may also be slightly higher than for conventional mortgages to cover the added processing costs. Renovation work must reach a minimum of $5,000, but there is no limit proportionate to purchase price.
 Mark Herbert, a financial adviser planning to buy a rundown three-bedroomm split-level in New Carrolton, Md., last June for $119,999, for example, figured he could incorporate financing for up to $6,000 for improvements by using 203 (k). He gave F.H.A. officials a detailed estimate. The loan approval took six weeks.
"Later they released the renovation money directly to me when I showed them I was doing most of the work myself," he said. He got his loan through Statewide Funding (1-800-726-5626) a national lender.
 Anyone needing all-in-one financing should also explore the independently run programs offered by local lenders.
At Mechanics and Farmers Savings Bank of Bridgeport, Conn., for example, a 10 percent down payment is required. There are no income or purchase price limits, but the program is for owner-occupiers only and plans and specifications must be approved in advance. Origination fees are the same as for coventional financing but there is a $100 charge for each field inspection of the renovation work; about three are normally required before completion.

HEADLINE: A Dragging Pace for New-Condo Sales

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
NEW YORK CITY developers, hurt by tight mortgage-lending requirements and shrinking demand from foreign buyers, are struggling to sell hundreds of new condominiums in a market already reeling from a long real estate slump.
The apartments, in more than 60 Manhattan buildings, include some of nation's most expensive residential real estate. They are the last to be absorbed from a development wave -- prompted by tax abatements and the city's heady economic boom -- that began in earnest during the mid-1980's. 
 By 1987, the developers had broken ground for one of Manhattan's biggest bursts of expensive, privately financed residential construction in decades, and they have completed more than 30,000 new condominiums over the last four years.
Experts say demand for the apartments was surprisingly strong in 1988 and 1989, despite the city's deepening economic downturn. Research by Yale Robbins, a New York City real estate analyst, found that 90 percent of the new condominiums have been sold.
That has left about 3,000 apartments unsold, with prices in the least expensive buildings starting at about $350 a square foot and developers in some cases asking more than $1,000 -- or over $1 million for a small two-bedroom.
Real estate transfers recorded by the city suggest that sales in the new buildings have been painfully slow since last July.
At best, the developers say sales are steady, but less than robust. At worst, their unsold apartments have been languishing on the market for more than a year. Some people who have signed contracts are looking for a way out of their deals.
For residential developers in New York City, the 1990's are so far proving to be the decade of the hard sell.
"We just missed the market," said Olga Feliciano, sales manager for the Leighton House, a new 163-unit condominium at 88th Street and First Avenue, which opened its sales office in March. Only 35 of the apartments have been sold, so the building's developer, General Atlantic Realty, has rented out 110 of the condominiums..
General Atlantic is far from the only developer to offer new condominiums as rentals, and some real estate executives say the tactic is likely to become more widespread if sales do not increase soon.
"The rental option is a way of turning total disasters into the walking wounded on their way to recovery," said Andrew Graham, vice president of Gilbert Charles Beylen, a Manhattan brokerage and management company. He added that many of the developers, having paid huge sums to acquire their development sites during the height of the city's real estate boom, now have little leverage to lower prices on the apartments they sell.
"For many of them, the situation is barely palatable," he added. "They can't lower prices much or they get wiped out. But they tell their bankers they will rent their apartments out, get sufficient cash flow, and maybe realize 120 percent of their investment sometime later."
Perhaps hardest hit by the slump is Donald Trump, whose Trump Palace condominium, with 163 apartments at 69th Street and Third Avenue, is nearing completion. Mr. Trump began selling the apartments in mid-1989, promoting them heavily to investors in Toyko, Hong Kong and other Asian financial centers, and asking over $1,000 a square foot for some of the apartments in the building.
Initial results were promising. He obtained sales contracts for 78 apartments, most by the end of 1989. But now, with Mr. Trump's financial problems making news around the world, no more sales contracts have been signed, the 78 buyers have asked New York State Attorney General Robert Abrams to negate their contracts and Mr. Abrams's staff has blocked any further sales in Trump Palace until the developer demonstrates that he can meet his financial obligations to the building.
Elsewhere in Manhattan, even where sales are progressing more smoothly, developers say they are handicapped in ways that few had anticipated.
"The local banks are impossible to deal with," said Abbot Stillman, the developer of 3 Lincoln Center, a condominium built over the Juilliard School at Lincoln Center. Like other developers and sales agents, he said mortgage lending policies have been tightened to a point where some banks refuse to finance any sales in buildings in which less than 25 percent -- or even 51 percent -- of the apartments have already been sold.
Other lenders, which have traditionally financed 80 percent of an apartment's purchase price, are limiting themselves to 50 percent or 70 percent.
"It's as though the banks are on strike," Mr. Stillman said.
SIX blocks north of Mr. Stillman's project, the Zeckendorf Company, one of New York City's most prolific residential developers, has begun moving buyers into the Alexandria, a 201-unit condominium at 72d Street and Broadway.
"We have been knocking off two or three sales contracts a week," said William Lie Zeckendorf, who is in charge of the project. Nonetheless, he added, the foreign investors who had been spurring the feverish demand for Manhattan condominiums in the late 1980's are now far less plentiful.
"Interest among foreign buyers is clearly not what it was," he said.
Mr. Robbins, in his analysis of the new Manhattan condominiums, reviewed sales in 61 buildings that were completed since mid-1988, or were due to be completed over the next three months, and where apartments remain unsold.
The buildings in the study contain 6,379 condominiums, about half of them sold.
Mr. Robbins counted official transfers of property since July, as recorded by New York City, thus including only transactions in which sales had closed. The study found that the market was almost moribund during the second half of 1990, with no sales in 34 of the buildings.
Even where sales had occurred, it found apartments moving at a paltry rate. In some of the buildings, only one apartment had been sold, in several others, less than five.
"The rate of sales clearly dropped way down this year," Mr. Robbins said. But he added that his research did not reflect the number of condominiums that, like those at the Leighton House, had been rented out temporarily. Such rentals "are likely to be a significant factor now in light of weak demand from buyers," he said.
Although no one denies that the market weakened in 1990, developers say sales, as measured by the number of contracts signed instead of closings, are far stronger than Mr. Robbins's study suggests. Sales contracts usually require a buyer to pay a nonrefundable down payment of at least 10 percent of the purchase price.
In new construction, there is often a lag between the signing of sales contracts and closings because condominium developers are required by New York State to wait until they have contracts for at least 15 percent of their apartments before there can be any closings. They sometimes stagger other closings to allow an orderly flow of legal work and the movement of buyers into their buildings.
"We are generally pleased with sales," said Mr. Zeckendorf. Sales at the Alexandria began in May and the closings on the first condominiums in the building took place in December. He said 60 percent of the apartments in the building are under contract with buyers. Apartments in the Alexandria are priced at an average of $450 a square foot, $450,000 for a 1,000-square-foot, two-bedroom unit.
THE Zeckendorf Company, in a partnership with Larry Silverstein, another New York developer, is also completing work on a more expensive condominium, Park Avenue Court, with 222 apartments at 86th Street and Lexington Avenue. Sales in the building, where apartment prices average $580 a square foot, began in September 1989 and so far there have been no closings.
Nonetheless, Mr. Zeckendorf said, contracts have been signed on 110 of the apartments, or almost 50 percent of the building. Despite more rigid lending requirements by some banks, he said, sales are now getting a boost from a decline in interest rates, which have fallen from over 10.5 percent in early 1990 to under 9.75 percent for New York City condominium buyers.
"We are getting good traffic in both buildings and sales are remarkably steady," he said, adding that "we are giving no thought whatsoever" to renting out apartments temporarily instead of selling them.
Such thoughts have occurred to Mr. Stillman, the builder of 3 Lincoln Center, where condominiums are priced at a lofty average of $685 a square foot. Since sales began in December 1989, he said, contracts have been signed for 85 of the building's 347 units. None have closed, although he said he expects several closings between this month and March.
"We are not going into a rental program in a big way," he said, but added that some apartments in the building may be rented unless the volume of sales increases soon. "Early in the life of a building it is better for everyone to have the apartments occupied," he said.
For many developers, a critical element in the economic equation is the huge prices they paid for land in the 1980's. Even at the heady prices they are asking for condominiums, some have little room to negotiate without losing money.
Although the developers refuse to divulge their land prices, real estate experts said the prices for the most desirable Manhattan sites rose during the 1980's from under $50 to over $100 per developable square foot. A developable square foot refers to the amount of floor area in a new building that will be allowed by the city, given the amount of land it is built on, zoning rules and limitations on height, bulk and setbacks.
Added to the cost of land are the costs of labor and material for construction, which experts say often amount to $100 to $120 a square foot. Architects, lawyers, advertising bills and other marketing costs, plus the interest costs incurred during construction, may add an additional $40 or $50 a square foot.
And since not all of a finished building can be sold -- hallways, lobbies, storage areas and elevators often take up at least 20 percent of a condominium's interior -- the final arithmetic means that the developers are unlikely to lower their prices, at least not much.
"Where a developer paid land prices that were premised on getting $400 or $500 a square foot for his condominiums, his options are now limited," said Mr. Graham. "Cutting prices by 20 percent might wipe him out."
AS a result, with buyers trying to negotiate rock-bottom prices, some developers say they are receiving offers they must quickly dismiss.
"People are looking for drastic price reductions, and those offers are being rejected without hesitation," said Jay Neveloff, a spokesman for Mr. Trump, who said the Trump Palace condominium has been attracting more than 20 "bargain hunters" a week despite the Attorney General's order postponing any closings in the building.
But he added that Mr. Trump has no plans to rent out apartments in the building, even as a temporary solution.
"Donald Trump and his marketing people firmly believe these condominiums are marketable," he said.
Others, however, said they have found sufficient demand for high-priced rental apartments to postpone further efforts to sell.
At the Leighton House, General Atlantic realty said it had rented its apartments at monthly rates ranging from $1,175 for small studios to $7,000 for a large four-bedroom. It has also also offered renters the option to buy at a price negotiated before they sign their leases, and will apply all of their first year's rent to their down payments.
"For the moment, there is a tremendous hesitancy to buy," said Mr. Arens of General Atlantic. "But we expect that hesitancy to disappear in a year or two, and we are finding people very eager to rent."
