HEADLINE: Reaction Is Split on a New Hudson Rail Crossing

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THE new railroad link across the Hudson River proposed by the Metro-North Commuter Railroad would significantly expand its transportation network, and perhaps alter the way Westchester residents live and work and perceive suburban life.
The railroad's $2 billion vision of its future calls for a new bridge or tunnel to connect rail lines east and west of the Hudson, either between Hastings-on-Hudson and Palisades, N.J., between Tarrytown and Nyack or between Beacon and Newburgh. The $1.25 million feasibility and cost-benefit study was completed last month by the Manhattan-based engineering consulting firm of Parsons Brinckerhoff Quade & Douglas. 
 The new crossing could provide Orange and Rockland commuters with direct access to Grand Central Terminal, create the first east-west suburban rail connection between New Jersey, Westchester and Connecticut, and possibly link Stewart Airport in Newburgh with the New York City area.
The Board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the commuter railroad's governing board, is expected to vote next month and to approve a $5 million appropriation to continue a four-year study of the proposal, including a further refinement of alternatives, an analysis of costs and an assessment of the environmental effects.
Government and business leaders have hailed the proposal as a needed vision for an increasingly congested transportation system and as a boost for the local economy. But others question whether an extension of commuter rail service is the right mass-transportation solution for the New York City area and if it is, whether money can be found to finance a $2 billion proposition in an era of shrinking resources.
"Anything that gets cars off the road we would seriously look at," said Westchester's Commissioner of Transportation, Eric Langeloh. But he added, "There is a rather monumental price tag, and no one is even close to knowing what the real costs would be."
 
'Thinking Regionally'
 He said he expected the municipal planning organizations that include Westchester representatives to support continued study of the M.T.A. plan. But until the concept becomes more specific, he said, the county would continue to take a "wait and see" attitude.
Jeffrey Zupan is a senior fellow specializing in transportation for the Regional Plan Association, an independent group monitoring development in the region. "The good news is that Metro-North is thinking regionally and broadly," Mr. Zupan said. "The real issue is whether this plan, or any of several others now being considered by different transportation groups, have staying power. Will this project give you the best for your $2 billion?"
Other transportation plans being considered for the region, Mr. Zupan said, include an extension of New York City subway service to New Jersey and the upgrading of New Jersey Transit rail service to carry more passengers on the western side of the Hudson. At the county level, state officials are considering the addition of one or more high-speed or "high-occupancy vehicle" lanes to Interstate 287 to relieve congestion.
Metro North's proposal, its supporters said, would decrease automobile congestion and pollution while adding as many as 10 million rail riders, provide needed economic help to White Plains and Stamford and bring jobs and affordable housing closer together.
 The Tarrytown connection is believed to be the one most favored by the Metro-North Committee of the Metropolitan Transportation Committee, which is evaluating the ongoing conceptual plan. It would permit the railroad to use existing rights of way along I-287 to extend the railroad east and give it three alternatives for interconnecting: with either the Hudson, Harlem or the New Haven Lines.
 
Reaching Stewart Airport
 If the proposed east-west railroad extended to the Harlem Line, for example, White Plains commuters could reach Stewart Airport in an hour. If the line reached to the New Haven Line, Connecticut commuters would have direct access to New Jersey as well as to Stewart Airport.
The proposal would enable commuters from Orange County, the fastest growing county in the state, to reach jobs in Manhattan, Westchester and Connecticut more quickly and reduce highway congestion. Only a fifth of Orange County's commuters use trains to reach their Manhattan jobs. Those who do take trains usually drive over the Tappan Zee Bridge to reach the Hudson Line because Metro-North's rail lines in Orange and Rockland terminate in Hoboken, where Manhattan-bound passengers must tranfer to PATH trains.
Commuting from the Orange-Rockland County region will increase by 55 percent over the next 20 years, the Metro-North study shows, as more families seek out the affordable housing available there. Despite the current economic downturn, Metro-North officials say, it is important for the region to begin considering a realistic mass-transportation option for the next century, one in which single-occupant automobile travel will be increasingly unacceptable.
 
What the Critics Say
 Critics of the plan say that any gains would be only temporary, that expanding the rail system is a prelude to more residential and commerical development, which most suburban dwellers do not want, and that it would lead to more roads and other improvements, changing the face of the county forever.
At least one regional environmental group is already preparing to fight the M.T.A. plan. "We have regrouped and will fight to the death any new Hudson River crossing, rail or roadway, at the Palisades, in the Tappan Zee area or in the Hudson Highlands," George Case, a member of the board of the Citizens Committee for the Hudson Valley, said in an appearance before the board of the M.T.A. last month.
The 25-year-old organization successfully defeated a plan by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller to build a Hudson River expressway down the east side of the Hudson through Westchester.
Village officials in Hastings-on-Hudson and in Tarrytown have voted unanimously to oppose the development of a rail bridge or tunnel in their communities, an experience Tarrytown residents say is all too familiar. The building of the Tappan Zee Bridge there 35 years ago split the village in two, and residents say that on days when traffic to the bridge backs up, as it does frequently, it can take over an hour to drive from one end of town to the other.
 
'Can You Imagine?'
 "If there were a railroad station in Tarrytown, and you knew you could go there and go north, south, east or west, can you imagine what an attraction that would be?" asked Jerome W. Blood, Tarrytown's deputy mayor and the leader of an effort to have the east bank of the river around his village declared a scenic district by the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
Four communities, including Irvington, Greenburgh, North Tarrytown and Mount Pleasant have joined Tarrytown in the effort to protect what they consider the special scenic, historic, environmental and recreational features of the area. Should the conservation department agree, the designation -- the third granted in the state -- would guarantee that strict environmental studies would be performed before allowing construction of bridges or tunnels.
A similar scenic designation was recently won by a group of communities facing Tarrytown on the other side of the river, and Mr. Blood said, "We want to mirror what they have done on the other side, before everything is destroyed."
Another bridge, Mr. Blood said, could easily become a combined rail and vehicular structure, one that would encourage more economic development in mid-Westchester. "People move to the suburbs because they want to live in small towns," he said. "There is a limit to the amount of development people want."

HEADLINE: CRAFTS;
Must-See Ceramics

BYLINE: By BETTY FREUDENHEIM

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
THE Newark Museum, like other museums around the world, possesses hundreds of treasures that are rarely seen by the public. Of course, one may suspect that fine paintings, sculpture and craft items are hidden away in the vast storage vaults. But the creme de la creme is right out in the open, under the spotlights.
Visitors just hurry by with barely a sideward glance, in a frantic dash to see blockbuster, highly publicized shows before they close. Some day, they no doubt have promised themselves, they will take a few minutes to stop and examine the museum's own collections. 
 On the ground floor of the museum, a superb group of items from the 80's in the Contemporary Ceramics Gallery fits nicely into this must-see category. And, to fill the bill, it is displayed on the route to the entrance of the museum's renowned Victorian-era Ballantine House.
 To find these ceramics, turn right at the grandiose "Grecian Urn," created by the Trenton Potteries in 1904. The urn, almost five feet tall, with its swirls and curlicues of gold against a royal blue and porcelain white background, is one of four made for the New Jersey pavilion at the Louisiana Purchase Exposition in St. Louis.
Undoubtedly great technological expertise was required for the creation of the urn, but who worries about such mundane concerns when confronted by this extravaganza? Its surfeit of neo-Rococo ornamentation is the antithesis of the urn's delicately rendered portraits of shepherdesses and goddesses lolling about in pastoral scenes. Louis XIV would have coveted this vessel.
 The gallery featuring ceramics of the 80's is also replete with contrasts. The collection was selected by Ulysses G. Dietz, whose 10 years as curator of decorative arts at the Newark Museum encompasses the decade. His is a refined taste that has never been enticed by the razzmatazz that typifies so much of the craft work of this era.
 "Everything from ceramic history came together in the 80's," he said. "The work ranges from beautifully crafted, functional ceramics, with a Japanese Zen-like quality, to wildly eccentric, nontraditional pieces."
He made his selections from the work of artists who are in their 30's to others in their 80's -- and one who is still very active in her 90's.
 As an introduction to the collection, Mr. Dietz featured a plate from the 70's by Albert Green, whom he called the "dean of New Jersey potters." Mr. Green's subtle color harmonies and the Japanese brushwork of his glazes set a high standard for the 80's and future decades.
 Nearby, Toshiko Takaezu's immense bulb-shaped pot closes at the top with a pin-sized hole, so that viewers can only guess what secrets are hidden inside. Her work has both power and poetry, no matter what the scale. Its muted glazes are applied in the intentionally accidental manner that her forebears in Japan worked so hard to achieve.
 In "Spirit Corn Vessel," Nancy Adams re-created ears of corn in clay with such precise realism that hybrid-grain farmers would recoil at the irregular rows and missing kernels. Yet we sense that the six corn ears, which support the handle of the bowl, are treated with reverence. The title reminds us that corn is one of three deities, along with beans and squash, that are worshiped by many Indian tribes at planting and harvest times. The fragility of the drooping leaves negates any functional application of this pot.
 Mr. Dietz selected Michael Duvall's "Mission Box" for its resemblance to the post-modernist architecture of Michael Graves, who designed the renovation of the Newark Museum. The box profile is rigidly geometric, and the surfaces are glazed in pastel hues of green, blue, yellow and rose. While the contours suggest an old mission church, with a flattened dome and unadorned cross, there is no door and the base is footed.
By definition, the piece is indeed a vessel because the crucifix can be removed, like the stopper of a perfume bottle. (A triangular alternative stopper was provided for non-Christians.)
"These nonfunctional pieces fit into a tradition of ornamental vessals that dates back to 18th-century Sevres," Mr. Dietz said.
 Ralph Bacerra's "Platter" infuses the optical illusions of W. C. Escher with luxuriant colors and assorted checkerboard patterns. Occasionally, the eye of one bird is shared by another one, flying in the opposite direction. Wings interlock. Here is an orderly tumult that can mesmerize the viewer.
 An iridescent "Chalice" has three handles on each side that give it an awesome ritualistic aspect. The creator, 97-year-old Beatrice Wood, made her first pot in 1933 when she could not find a teapot to match her six antique luster plates.
Garth Clark, a Manhattan gallery owner, said Ms. Wood continued to produce as much work as any other artist he shows. No blue jeans in her studio; Ms. Wood likes to wear a sari and two armloads of jangling bracelets when she sits down to throw on the potter's wheel.
 The "Endurance Bowl" by Anne Kraus evokes a dour mood. This ceramist first studied painting and took up ceramics only as recreation. Painted scenes on her pots relate legends of painful encounters or brooding scenes of loneliness. Three on the border of this bowl are labeled "Critics," "Impass" and "Failure." The last depicts rocks falling on the hero's head.
 To set off the decade of the 90's, Mr. Dietz acquired a Phillip Maberry "Presentation Cup" for the collection. Its gold handles seem to flutter outward, like ribbons catching the breezes. With its painted portraits, which decorate the central portion, viewers are reminded of the Trenton urn at the start of the ceramics collection. "They are both bombastic artistic statements," Mr. Dietz said.
 And what is his prediction for American ceramics of the 90's? If economic constraints continue, there will be "more affordable, high-quality but utilitarian work," he said. "We don't collect casseroles, but there is a level of functional work that is technically and esthetically beautiful -- even if it is not in museums."
The Newark Museum, at 49 Washington Street, is open Wednesday through Sunday from noon to 5 P.M. Admission is free.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A pottery "Spirit Corn Vessel," left, by Nancy Adams; A glazed earthenware bowl, left, by Anne Kraus, and a pottery "Mission Box" by Michael Duvall. (Photographs from the Newark Museum)

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY Q & A: JOHN C. KELLY;
Weighing Effect of the New Tax Laws

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

DATELINE: ROSELAND

 BODY:
JOHN C. KELLY has developed an intimate understanding of a subject that most people would just as soon ignore: income taxes.
 Upon graduation from Seton Hall University in 1963, Mr. Kelly went to work for Arthur Andersen & Company, one of the nation's largest accounting firms. In 1974, after having served for two years as a lieutenant in the United States Army and earning a master's degree in business administration and finance from Seton Hall, Mr. Kelly was made a partner in the prestigious firm. 
 Four years ago, he was appointed managing partner of the firm's New Jersey offices in Roseland and Princeton, and last year he was elected president of the New Jersey Society of Certified Public Accountants, an organization with more than 12,000 members.
Mr. Kelly, who was born in Newark, lives with his wife, Mary, in Convent Station. They have two daughters.
 Q. In general terms, what impact will the new tax laws have on New Jersey residents?
A. It's fair to say that lower-income New Jersey taxpayers will not be impacted significantly. In fact, in some cases, lower-income taxpayers will pay less in income taxes than they did last year.
Q. How are you defining lower-income taxpayers?
A. A person earning $25,000 a year, for example. That person's combined state and Federal taxes will probably go down by $100 in 1991.
Q. And taxpayers at the other end of the spectrum?
A. Let's take a wage earner who has $200,000 in taxable income. That individual will be paying $3,600 more in taxes, plus an additional $1,050 in increased Social Security taxes. The changes in both the state and Federal tax laws were really geared toward extracting higher taxes from higher- wage earners.
Q. And what about the vast majority of taxpayers who fall somewhere in between?
A. In general, a person who's earning $70,000 or less, owning or renting his home or apartment, will probably be paying less in state taxes after taking into consideration the homestead rebate and more in Federal taxes.
Again, an example might best illustrate the situation. A married couple with two children, filing jointly and earning $50,000, will pay about $200 less in combined Federal and state taxes. The same couple, however, with $75,000 in income for 1990 will probably pay $500 more in combined taxes before the homestead rebate.
Q. What about the tax forms themselves? Are there any major changes?
A. Yes. The most significant change is that the New Jersey tax form may have to be used by individuals who may never have had to use it before. In the past, if you owned a home, you would get your application for the homestead property tax rebate mailed to you in October or November.
Well, that form is gone and has now been replaced by a combined form included on the New Jersey tax return. So homeowners who want to claim their homestead rebate will have to fill out the form even if they wouldn't otherwise have to file a state tax return.
Q. What about tenants?
A. Tenants will also have to complete the homestead rebate form because the $65 tenant credit that they were entitled to in past years now comes under the homestead rebate program.
Q. How does that work?
A. Essentially, the law assumes that a certain percentage of your rent goes to paying property taxes. So the person who rents his home or apartment is entitled to a homestead rebate. That could amount to as much as $500 depending upon the person's rent and income level.
But remember, the $65 tenant credit has been eliminated, so on April 15 the average taxpayer is probably going to pay additional tax or get back less of a refund. That will be made up, however, in October when the person receives the homestead rebate.
Q. So will homeowners be paying more on April 15 as well?
A. Most likely. In 1989 a homeowner could effectively take a deduction for property taxes paid. That has been eliminated and replaced by the new homestead rebate. In many cases, those earning less than $70,000 a year and paying property taxes could get a significant increase in their homestead rebate, some as high as $500.
Q. Can you deduct your homestead rebate from any New Jersey taxes you owe?
A. No. It's important for taxpayers to know that if they have a tax liability on April 15, they cannot offset the homestead rebate against it. Those who are entitled to homestead rebates will receive them by mail by about Oct. 31.
Q. What about the form itself? The old homestead rebate form only required the property owner's signature.
A. The form itself is not complicated, but it contains no preprinted information. The old form, which would arrive with information about the property already on it, only had to be signed. The new one must be completed.
And while the instructions for the old form took up about half a page, the new instructions are about four pages long. The reason is because taxpayers will actually be calculating the rebate themselves. The new form is going to take a little more time, there's no question about it.
Q. Does that mean that it will cost more to have your tax return prepared if you don't do it yourself?
A. It could, yes. The tax preparer is going to have to spend more time completing the form.
Q. Are there any other changes in the state tax forms that might be of interest to taxpayers?
A. Yes. For the first time there are pie charts included in the booklet that describe the source of state revenues and what those revenues are being used for. And in addition, the Division of Taxation has included two forms that a large number of taxpayers have requested in the past. One is used to report excess unemployment and disability contributions, and the other is to be used to file for an extension of time to file the return.
Q. How might a person pay excess unemployment and disability contributions?
A. If you have more than one employer during the course of a year, it is possible to pay more than is required. If you have, you can fill out the form and get a refund.
Q. And does filing the automatic extension mean that you can postpone paying your state tax?
A. No. The form only extends the time to file the official return. Any taxes that are due must be filed with the request for extension; otherwise the extension will be denied.
Q. What about New Jersey residents working in New York? Will the new tax laws affect them in any way?
A. In the majority of cases, New Jersey residents working in New York will not pay any additional New Jersey tax in 1991. The reason is because the typically higher New York tax rates will result in a larger credit against New Jersey taxes on the 1991 return.
Q. And what about Federal taxes? Are there any major changes in store?
A. The biggest changes for 1991 are obviously the rates; the rates are going up. For lower-income taxpayers there shouldn't be much of a difference, but high-income earners will see an increase in rates.
For example, the tax rate on all income above $82,150 on a joint return will be 31 percent in 1991. Under prior law, income above the $82,150 would have been taxed at 33 percent up to about $220,000, but then at 28 percent thereafter. And there are some other nuances that increase the tax rate even further.
Q. Such as?
A. Well, the new law reduces allowable itemized deductions when adjusted gross income exceeds $100,000. It's based on a fairly straightforward formula, but some deductions are not included and others can be reduced by no more than 80 percent. In effect, it results in an increase in the marginal tax rate by about one percentage point on the income above $100,000.
Q. Any other major changes?
 A. The other major change is in the Social Security tax. A person earning more than $53,000 will be subject to increased Social Security taxes on income up to $125,000. And since the Social Security tax is a matching tax, both the employer and the employee could pay up to an additional $1,050 each in 1991.
Q. Any final words of advice for taxpayers?
A. Yes. Read the instructions, pay close attention to the homestead rebate form, and don't wait until the last minute to file.

HEADLINE: Rethinking Newspapers

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Times are tough for the newspaper industry. Advertising is in a slump some analysts are calling the worst in 20 years. Profits are down substantially at many papers. Vacancies are being left unfilled and budgets are being squeezed if not slashed. Almost everywhere -- especially in the Northeast, where papers have been hit hardest -- the mood is black.
Perhaps because the business has been so lucrative for so long, the painful decline in advertising caught many in the industry unprepared, prompting a wave of anxiety about the future. 
 But the current misery seems also to have snapped the industry out of its torpor and has propelled the most energetic effort in decades to face problems that pose a long-term threat to newspapers, such as declining readership and new demands from advertisers. James K. Batten, chairman of Knight-Ridder Inc., said that in this respect, the current recession is "a blessing in disguise."
Across the nation, newspapers are broadening their services to advertisers by devising new marketing strategies. For example, newspapers owned by Harte-Hanks Communications Inc., based in San Antonio, Tex., now offer advertisers access to extensive data bases on their communities, created by the company's local papers.
Some major newspaper companies are also creating delivery systems to compete with the United States Postal Service. The Times Mirror Company, Gannett Company Inc. and Capital Cities/ABC Inc., for example, have all signed agreements with Alternate Postal Delivery Inc., giving many of their newspapers the right to be part of a new national postal network.
 
New Designs to Help the Reader
 And many papers have begun experimenting with changes in both design and content. The Los Angeles Times has revamped its design to help speed readers through the paper, and has added such features as a letters-to-the-editor section for arts and entertainment to let readers talk back to the critics. The Boston Globe is publishing a music section on Fridays. Several papers are creating geographically zoned sections that focus on local news and attract local advertising.
Poor economic conditions have delayed execution of some ideas. But the currents of change are powerful nevertheless and will not be forestalled for long.
Even now the economic pain is relative. Advertising has remained sufficiently ample and cost-cutting has been sharp enough that most papers are simply experiencing lower profits, not outright losses. John Morton, an industry analyst, says operating profit margins for papers owned by publicly traded communications companies peaked in 1985 at 20.2 percent, and have fallen steadily since. Profit margins were 17 percent in 1989 and about 15 percent for the first nine months of 1990, a level most businesses would envy in good times. Northeastern newspapers generally had lower margins, however; The New York Times newspapers showed an operating profit margin of 10.7 percent for the first nine months of last year, compared with 15.4 percent in 1989.
Largely because of advertising rate increases and the fact that some regions have not experienced the huge advertising slide seen in the Northeast, the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, a sales and marketing organization, predicts that total expenditures on newspaper advertising for 1990 will be five-tenths of 1 percent above 1989 levels and will grow 2 percent in 1991. The average annual increase for the last 20 years is more than 9 percent.
While a 2 percent increase does not make up for a variety of rising costs, any growth in advertising suggests, to industry analysts, an inherent strength. Money-losing newspapers, like The Daily News in New York City, are essentially an aberration; most papers long ago won the labor efficiencies The News is seeking from its striking unions, and most dailies do not face competition from other papers.
Owning a community's only newspaper has generally proved so profitable that many proprietors had come to regard themselves as economically unassailable. It is that confidence, or overconfidence, that is giving way.
No one knows how much of the former advertising will return once the economy rebounds, or how much may have been permanently lost to such rivals as direct-mail companies and cable TV. Moreover, some major industry clients, like large department stores, are so battered that they may never return to former strength.
"Newspapers' cheeks are rosy -- but they are hemorrhaging internally and their former success is not a guarantee of long-term survival," said Albert E. Gollin, co-director of research at the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. And of the present condition, Walter E. Mattson, chairman of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau and president of The New York Times Company, said, "Nothing focuses one's attention like pain."
Rethinking the newspaper business is occurring on two tracks. The first attacks the basic product -- from content to the way advertising is sold. The second is moving to create an entirely new range of information and marketing services.
 
Fewer Readers
 The future of the daily paper itself clearly depends on its ability to cope with one fundamental -- and, thus far, unsolvable -- problem: People increasingly do not read newspapers.
At the end of World War II, most American households subscribed to a morning and an afternoon paper. Newspaper market penetration was 135 percent, meaning more papers were sold every day than there were households. Circulation climbed until the early 60's, then leveled off at about 62 million, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. But population kept growing, bringing a steady decline in penetration.
In the mid-70's, as baby boomers were about to turn 30, executives were gleefully anticipating a surge in readership. But it never came.
Television largely replaced the afternoon paper as post-work entertainment, and young women, who had comprised a huge portion of newspaper readership, went to work.
In 1989, the Bureau of the Census counted 93 million households in the United States, and total morning and evening newspaper circulation was 62.6 million; penetration had thus fallen to 67 percent -- less than half of the figure at the end of World War II.
Another point is that those who say they are newspaper readers increasingly do not read a paper every day. The National Opinion Research Center reports that the percentage of adults who do dropped to 50 in 1989, from 73 percent in 1967. At the same time, the percentage that read "once or more weekly" increased to 38 from 18 percent.
But while readership penetration was declining, profits were soaring. Labor costs fell with advanced technology; advertising linage rose, especially during the booming 80's, and ad rates rose faster than inflation.
With profits increasing steadily, the nettlesome problem of declining penetration could be neglected. Indeed, there are still newspaper executives who regard the furor over circulation as beside the point.
 
Reaching the Affluent
 "I think the penetration issue is a red herring," said W. Dean Singleton, chief executive officer of Media News Group Inc., a chain that includes The Houston Post and The Denver Post. Mr. Singleton argues that newspapers must have "effective penetration" of the middle-class and affluent audience with buying power. He said his newspapers -- and, he suspects, most others -- still reach most of this audience, while the people lost by newspapers include those "who don't read, period, and also don't buy."
However, many other newspaper executives say the readership problem is real and to ignore it is to court disaster.
Some believe that, unless ways can be found to attract young readers and recapture older ones, the traditional mass-market newspapers will evolve into niche publications, aimed at the rich and well educated or at sports fans or segments of the business world, for example. The other side of this equation is the concern that, in their pursuit of readers, newspapers could enter the world of outright pandering, and, like much of television, become slaves to ratings. The historic role of newspapers as the Fourth Estate, or as a kind of village billboard of vital information, would disappear, with profound consequences.
Such problems defy easy solutions.
Research by the Newspaper Advertising Bureau and many newspapers suggests that the enemies of newspaper readership are a shortage of time and ever more media options. Inconsistent newspaper delivery and even guilt at the sight of unread papers piling up have also been cited as factors. Some executives concede that they have not been effective at promotion.
But many publishers believe the unpleasant fact is that newspapers simply have not been important or interesting enough to their readers, and they are trying to correct that.
"We believe in breaking the boredom barrier with every issue," proclaims The Daily Sparks (Nev.) Tribune, a 6,000-circulation daily.
Many publishers say that, as recently as two years ago, many editors were reluctant to join the chase for readers by making content changes that seemed to trivialize the news. A speaker at an American Society of Newspaper Editors convention in 1988 evoked disapproval when he said he had solicited postcards from readers detailing their travel experiences, and then used precious space to publish them.
Publishers say that their top editors now see a crucial need to improve their product, though agreement will probably never come on what precisely will constitute improvement and what trivialization.
Content is not all that is getting close attention; circulation, delivery, promotion and advertising are being examined as well.
Many analysts expect that, when the economy springs back, advertising will too. But new competition has arisen in the meantime in the form of real-estate magazines, for example, and computer networks and help-wanted data banks.
 
Discounts on Ads
 So the papers are focusing on ways to expand the old advertising base. On days that are light, like Monday and Saturday, for example, they are offering discounts.
And they are creating sections with special themes to attract related ads. No one is suggesting that newspapers should break the line they have strived for between advertising and news: that they sacrifice honesty and objectivity and begin printing a certain story in return for a certain ad.
But, without crossing that ethical barrier, a somewhat closer relationship between content and advertising has developed and is now generally regarded as beneficial -- to newspaper, advertiser and reader. Lumping related stories together in a package that attracts advertisers of products related to those stories can be useful to everyone without breaking sacred lines. Still, such cooperation has prompted concern that a timid newspaper might not print a critical article on a defective product, say, for fear of offending an advertiser.
Large retailers, discount stores and grocery store chains are targets of the ad salespeople as well.
These advertisers often make their decisions from some central regional location, and thus one company can strip away business from hundreds of papers because of a policy to use direct mail, for instance, or television. In the past, advertisers seeking a broad audience have often been less attracted to newspapers because they had to place each ad individually and pay each paper separately. One of the major pushes now is to connect dailies into market networks in which national advertising can be bought with a single check.
And a variety of other marketing and sales and circulation techniques are being tried. Indeed, the bad times have forced newspapers to sharpen their business acumen in almost every respect. Newspapers have not always demonstrated great vision in this area when it has come to protecting their financial future. Now they feel they have no choice.
 
PRODUCT REDESIGN FOR THE BABY BOOMER
In an experiment closely watched by the newspaper industry, Knight-Ridder Inc. is publishing a newspaper dramatically redesigned to lure the busy baby boomer.
In the new Boca Raton (Fla.) News, no article jumps to another page. None. Ever. Long articles are broken into two or more smaller ones. The type is larger than the traditional, and, though the old News splashed garish colors on its front page, the reinvented paper uses softer pastels.
Louis Heldman, supervising editor, said research indicated color and design helped readership, but only as a complement to meaty content. "When we presented people in focus groups with fairly shallow packages, no matter how attractive they were, they were rejected," he said.
Knight-Ridder's chairman, James K. Batten, said he hopes the new paper will make readers "feel plugged-in and smart, touch their emotions, recognize their time poverty and help them with their lives."
One goal is to guide the reader, but some innovations seem almost didactic, if imaginatively so. For instance, Page 3 is devoted to world news and each of the 13 or so articles of varying length has a number next to its headline. In the center of the page is a map of the world and the geographical subject of each article is located by a number -- creating a bit of a geography lesson.
A pull-out tabloid magazine called Essentials appears with a theme for each day. Monday's deals with business, Tuesday's health and fitness, Wednesday's parenting.
Knight-Ridder began the so-called 25/43 project -- for the ages of the baby boomers it is designed to reach -- as a laboratory to try ideas that may later be used at the company's other newspapers, which include The Charlotte Observer, The Miami Herald and The Philadelphia Inquirer.
Since October, when the new format was introduced, circulation has risen by 3,200, from 21,000.
 
WEEKLY READERS
 Rethinking the newspaper business has begun with a look at cherished -- and now largely invalid -- assumptions.
For instance, the daily newspaper is not a daily at all, at least in a business sense; it is more of a weekly published on Sunday, because the Sunday paper carries the lion's share of the week's advertising.
Sunday, when circulation is always much higher, has become the one day when people have the time to read, and the Sunday paper has evolved into a feature-loaded, magazine-style publication packed with advertising and pre printed circulars.
In 1989, 847 of the nation's 1,626 dailies published Sunday papers, but Sunday's total circulation -- 62 million -- was the same as that for the rest of the week when all the papers were publishing. Now all but the smallest newspapers have a Sunday issue; while the total number of dailies has dropped since 1946, the number of Sunday papers has nearly doubled.
Actually, today's paper is more of a thricely. Two other days have also become especially important: Wednesday, the grocery paper, carries most of the food advertising, and Friday, the weekend paper, has become an entertainment guide.
But in some communities the other four days can get pretty thin.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Why a U.S. Recession Still Matters

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Desynchronization is fast becoming one of the economic buzzwords of the 1990's. It is shorthand for the divergence of economic growth patterns around the world. Rather than everyone following the leader -- which had been the United States -- economies have become more independent. Right now, the United States and Britain are in recessions while Germany and Japan are growing.
Desynchronization is another of the proofs that the United States is not the center of the global universe anymore. But it does not mean that when the world's largest economy goes into decline it does not hurt elsewhere. 
 Some economists in Europe are already worried that a deeper or longer-than-expected American decline will slow European growth even more than anticipated as sales of European exports suffer.
But an even more dramatic impact is likely in the so-called emerging economies: the developing countries from Latin America to the Far East that depend on the American market and consumer for much of their economic growth. Those economies -- as well as their stock markets -- will be facing some bad times.
Nine major emerging economies -- Mexico, Brazil, Chile, South Korea, Taiwan, Indonesia, India, Thailand and Malaysia -- depend on the United States to buy an average of 27 percent of their exports, according to International Monetary Fund data for 1989. The American market share ranged from 11.8 percent of India's exports to 63.3 percent of Mexico's. Almost 37 percent of Taiwan's exports and almost 34 percent of South Korea's went to the United States that year.
"The United States is still the biggest and most open economy," said Richard O'Brien, chief economist at American Express Bank in London. "The old adage -- if the U.S. gets a cold, everyone else gets pneumonia -- is not true. But if the United States has a recession, everyone else is affected."
And that means trouble for the stock markets in these nine countries, as well as other emerging nations, many of which have been spectacular performers in recent years. The market in the Philippines rose 58.65 percent in dollar terms in 1989; Malaysia 58.84 percent; Taiwan 103 percent; Thailand 123.61 percent, and Turkey 366.85 percent.
The strong growth potential of such young economies made it easy for their stock markets to outdo the mature markets in the United States and Europe. In fact, in 1990, Mexico was the top performer in dollar terms for the third year in a row in the Financial Times World index of 24 markets.
But overall, 1990 was not a good year for emerging markets, with many falling even further than those in the United States and Europe. The markets were devastated by the sharp rise in oil prices that followed the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August. And concern about the slowing United States economy also contributed to the sharp decline. The continuing bleak outlook for America can only add to the downward pressure, especially given the risk of investing in these very volatile markets.
Making matters even worse last year was the fact that shares in many of the popular closed-end country funds performed even more poorly than the stock markets they represented. The funds are the vehicles through which many American and European institutions and individual investors get a stake in the developing world.
According to Lipper Emerging Market Funds Service, the 16 closed-end funds listed on the New York Stock Exchange that invest in emerging markets showed an average decline of 12.6 percent in net asset value in 1990. But the price of shares in those funds fell an average of 27.7 percent. The reason for the disparity is that closed-end country funds are ruled by two masters: the prices of the underlying foreign securities and the demand for the stock in the fund itself. This is why these funds can trade at a discount or a premium to the underlying value of their stocks.
William G. McBride, international editor of the Lipper funds service, said that the key factor in the deeper declines in the share price of the funds was the boom in the number of funds. About 70 have been started around the world in the last two years alone, raising the total to about 230. This sharp increase diluted demand, he said.
"You saw a fad come crashing down," Mr. McBride said. At the beginning of last year, many investors who rushed to buy the funds got out when they saw fund prices dropping even as the underlying markets rose. In addition, many Japanese investors who had pushed up the value of the funds sold out as the Tokyo stock market declined and money was needed back home, he said.
All this means that the emerging markets are beginning the new year hobbled by the recession in the United States. And the funds that invest in these markets face a decline in demand.
That, in turn, means some funds could offer good value because of steep discounts. But take care, says Mr. O'Brien of American Express. Such investments have to be long term, he said, because the drag on the emerging markets could well continue for two years.

HEADLINE: Diversifying to Counter A Slump on the Slopes

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN M. BERRY

 BODY:
When the Resort at Squaw Creek opened near Lake Tahoe in California two weeks ago, its ski slopes were packed tighter than a cable car at Aspen, Colorado's legendary ski resort famed for its crowds and opulence.
Squaw Creek's owners hope their venture can approach Aspen's success, so it was not surprising that the resort, which cost $135 million and includes a 405-room hotel and a 36,000 square-foot conference center, looks as much like a luxury spa in Hawaii or Hilton Head, S.C., as it does a ski area. 
 From California to Maine, the nation's ski resorts are struggling to hang on to their share of the consumer's leisure dollar at a time when competition is increasing and the industry must cope with high operating costs, fewer skiers, scarce capital, several years of disappointing weather and budding environmental concerns. As the competition increases, more and more ski areas are for sale and the anxious owners are looking to Japanese investors to bail them out.
"The ski industry is in a market-share game now," said Jerry Jones, the head of Jerry Jones & Associates, a marketing firm in Aspen. "To grow, you have to take market share away."
The ski industry, with annual revenues of $7 billion, wants to recapture the gilded age of the 1960's and 70's when annual revenue growth reached 15 percent and the number of new skiers taking to the slopes seemed to have no bounds. But baby boomers are older now and there aren't enough young people coming along to take up the slack. Moreover, the economic squeeze in the last few years has left many resorts undercapitalized and cut into profit margins.
During the holiday season that ended last week, attendance at ski areas was down 10 to 40 percent from the same period a year ago, according to a check of regional ski associations. Annual revenue growth is now only about 4 percent.
Such dismal figures have forced ski operators to look beyond winter snow and people on skis.
"If you build the Waldorf Astoria just 10 feet from a ski lift, you can't survive on a purely winter business," said Bob Gillen, a spokesman for Crested Butte Mountain Resort in Colorado. "That's the crisis that ski resorts face."
The ski operators' fondest dream is to take market share away from other leisure industries and not just from their fellow ski operators. To do this, many areas are imitating other industries, building theme resorts equipped with health spas, tennis and golf facilities and hiking trails.
With their large, luxurious conference center, the developers of the Resort at Squaw Creek have targeted an upscale business clientele. The owners, an investor group led by the Perini Land and Development Company in San Francisco, are marketing the resort to executives at the country's 1,000 largest companies. Next summer, long after the snow is gone, Squaw Creek's owners hope the center will be vibrant with people mixing business with recreation.
"The salvation of the ski industry is to find a niche to move into, whether it's catering to older skiers, kids, executives, whatever," said Charles Goeldner, a business professor at the University of Colorado at Boulder.
Ski areas built on a theme are not new. One of the first theme resorts was Vail, Colo., which began as a European-style alpine ski center catering to the affluent athlete and now has become both a summer and winter mecca for others as well.
Competition is stiff among Colorado's 27 ski areas, so smaller areas have developed themes in an attempt to set themselves apart from the crowd and to build summer business.
Keystone Resort pitches itself to families and has designed special programs for senior citizens. Telluride's theme is its setting, a high-mountain town filled with restored Victorian-era buildings. Steamboat Ski and Resort Corporation, which was acquired by the Japanese Kamori Kanko Company last September for an undisclosed amount, has a frontier theme.
Ski areas are also pooling their resources with local towns. The town of Mt. Crested Butte recently passed a lodging tax to collect money for summer advertising. Keystone, Copper Mountain and Breckenridge have a system of shared lift tickets and packages that helps them compete against Vail and Aspen.
But even as ambitious development plans are being launched in many areas, signs of a downturn are growing.
Family-owned and privately held ski operators have been hit the hardest. In the last decade, the number of ski areas in the United States has shrunk to 560 from 880, according to the United States Ski Association.
Consolidation among a few top companies, the influx of Japanese investment, warm weather and the high cost of snow-making equipment has made it difficult for the marginally profitable and usually undercapitalized companies to survive.
To some extent, technology can solve the snow problem, as long as there are enough stretches of below-freezing weather. But snow-making equipment is expensive and requires an adequate water supply.
 "For some people, it makes or breaks your business," said Pam Murphy, assistant director of marketing at Mammoth Moutain Ski Area in California, which is purchasing its first snow-making machine, at a cost of between $7 million to $10 million, for the 1991-92 season. "If we didn't have snow making most areas wouldn't be open," said Betsy Perry, communications director for the Northeast Ski Areas Council.
 The Northeast has been hit particularly hard by warm weather and the economic downturn. In New England, only two of 70 areas posted gains this season. In Vermont, only three or four of 17 ski areas in the state are turning a profit, according to the Vermont Ski Areas Association. Even when the balance sheet is positive, the news is less than cheering. For example, Killington-based S-K-I Ltd., one of the few publicly held ski companies and historically one of the most profitable, had to content itself last year with revenues of $84.5 million, up from $82 million a year earlier.
Mr. Jones of Jones & Associates in Aspen estimates that as many as 25 percent of the nation's ski areas are for sale right now. Fortunately for many operators, Japanese investors have begun to appear, checkbooks in hand. Heavenly Valley and SkiUSA, two California operations, were bought last year by groups of Japanese investors.
 Adding to ski operators' woes are growing environmental concerns.
Mammoth Mountain is uncertain about the water supply next year for its new snow-making equipment. Ms. Murphy said that ski operators have not yet thought through how snow making will contribute to water shortages, especially in drought-ridden states like California.
Some ski operators are running up against groups that want to restrict growth. Executives at Killington Inc., a subsidiary of S-K-I, say that they spent $2 million last year fighting efforts to restrict their development.
In part the industry's problems stem from the fact that there are 25 percent fewer people in the 15-24 age group this year than there were in 1970, according to the Census Bureau. Executives hope the current baby boom will produce a new generation of teen-agers shortly after the turn of the century who will take to the slopes with gusto.
 
EQUIPMENT'S SIMILAR SLIDE
 The ski equipment industry's bitter winter comes after a year of poor sales.
While some retailers are unloading goods at wholesale prices to stay out of the red, others are closing their doors for good.
"Retailers are going to get killed this year, especially in the Northeast," said I. William Berry, publisher of two ski industry newsletters, one for retailers. "For some, there's no place to go but out."
The slump is at least in part a reflection of poor sales by retailers nationwide. Mr. Berry said that sporting goods stores, and ski shops in particular, could expect a decrease in sales of 15 to 30 percent this year.
Though sales of ski products in the United States remained level at $1.5 billion last year, fewer skis are being sold.
About 650,000 pairs of skis were sold last year, down from a peak of 1.1 million in 1986. Sales of clothing and accessories have risen slightly.
After record low sales last year because of poor weather conditions, some retailers cut back on inventory by as much as 15 percent.
"We're surviving better than last year, so in a sense it's an improvement," said Bruce McElroy, general manager of Olympic Sports, a chain of retail stores in Seattle with about $25 million in annual sales.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY/December 30-January 4

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The Trouble With Private Bank Insurance
 
Questionable loans, nervous depositors, pliant public officials, a depleted insurance fund -- the collapse of Heritage Loan and Investment Company in Providence, R.I., at first glance seems familiar. The likely involvement of organized crime provides a dash of local color. But instead of sticking around to blame his troubles on regulators, Joseph Mollicone Jr., the bank's president, vanished. He had made $13 million in what investigators describe as fraudulent loans to himself. An investigation caused a run on deposits, draining the private fund that insures 45 banks and credit unions. The state's Governor, Bruce G. Sundlun, declared a bank emergency on Tuesday, shutting the affected institutions. Many will reopen with Federal insurance, but depositors at the weakest might lose their money. Will the story end in Rhode Island? Probably not, said Bert Ely, a financial institutions consultant. With private insurance programs for banks and credit unions elsewhere, he said, "One serious hit that isn't quickly and convincingly dealt with can bring the whole plan down." Some other states are likely to require privately insured institutions to switch to Federal coverage, resulting in depositor losses or state bailouts for those too shaky to qualify.
 
Putting a Good Spin on Bad News
 
Higher unemployment is good news of sorts when it is still lower than economists had expected. The rate rose two-tenths of 1 percent in December to the highest level since mid-1987. Non-agricultural payrolls fell by 76,000, but the decline was less than a third the drop in November. William C. Dudley of Goldman, Sachs said that even these figures overstate the economy's weakness, since hours worked in December rose six-tenths of 1 percent. "The report makes you more comfortable that the production cutbacks happened quickly enough in October and November so that further big cutbacks may not prove necessary," he said. A record 5.9 percent plunge in November factory orders was worse than economists expected, but no great surprise after news of low orders for durable goods.
 
Dinkins, the Optimist
 
First Donald J. Trump came up with his forecast for Atlantic City casinos. Then Robert Campeau and his New York deal-makers issued their outlook for retailing. Last week the Dinkins administration raised its 1991 earnings estimate for the York City's pension fund to 9 percent, more optimistic than about 9 in 10 of the nation's other cities. New York City's hopefulness certainly doesn't spring from its 1990 record, when forecasted earnings of 8.25 percent actually came in at just eight-tenths of 1 percent. More likely, the city's optimism comes from its need to reduce pension contributions and come up with millions, quickly, to finance 5 percent raises for workers under contracts reached last week. At this rate, Yankee management, come April, is bound to predict a pennant.
 
A Skeptical Eye at Christie's
 
For conservative valuation and fiscal prudence in New York, look instead to Christie's. The auction house prepared for the sale this week of the Ferdinand E. and Isabella Marcos collection of Old Master paintings by scrutinizing several pieces. Seven of the Marcos Canalettos were busted down to the Circle of Canaletto. What was a Giovanni Bellini in Manila, valued at perhaps $1 million, is School of Bellini in New York, worth a tenth as much. Several million dollars worth of English silver is for sale, too; no doubts, apparently, about whether copper lurks underneath.
 
In Brief
 
For the first time since 1979, American semiconductor makers gained in 1990 against the Japanese. Their share of the worldwide market rose to 36.5 percent from 34.9 percent.
 
The Federal Trade Commission is investigating whether the makers of infant formula colluded to raise prices.
 
The prospect of Middle East peace talks pushed oil prices down to $24.90 a barrel, the lowest since the day after Iraq invaded Kuwait.
 
There Goes the Prime
 
The nation's major banks lowered their loan rates last week for the customers they still consider unquestionably credit worthy. The prime rate, a benchmark for many other loans, fell half a percentage point, to 9 1/2 percent, the first decline in a year.
 
COMPANIES

 
Hello? Hello? New York?
 
Wish fulfillment? New York was cut off from the rest of the nation on Friday when an American Telephone and Telegraph Company line was severed in New Jersey. Airline flights were delayed and diverted, and the New York Mercantile Exchange closed. Last January, computer troubles shut down A.T.& T.'s long-distance system nationally for about nine hours.
 
Sears Slashes the Work Force
 
Sears, Roebuck & Company is hoping that fewer people in the stockrooms, loading docks and back offices will lower costs and bring more shoppers into its stores. The nation's largest retailer announced on Thursday that it would cut 21,000 jobs. Some analysts shrugged. "The announcement shouldn't be over-read," said Samuel G. Liss, director of research at Salomon Brothers. Most of those laid off will be part-timers, he said, and in a slack economy, the savings are unlikely to be evident for several quarters. Sears's overhead has been twice that of its competitors; some stores still keep track of merchandise shipments with handwritten logs. Sears had slower sales in December than several discount chains. Comparing sales in the same stores with the year before, Sears suffered a three-tenths of 1 percent decline.
 
The Best Products Company went private in 1988. On Friday, it became the latest retailer to seek bankruptcy protection.
 
Giving Back LBO Loot
 
Wall Street's wheeler-dealers might want to see about malpractice insurance. Bankers, lawyers, maybe even shareholders who profited from leveraged buyouts that later failed could be forced to surrender their gains. Barry L. Zaretsky, an examiner appointed by the Federal Bankruptcy Court, said that Revco D.S. could sue to recover fees paid in a 1986 buyout. Professor Zaretsky, of Brooklyn Law School, concluded that Revco's advisers and investors pulled out so much capital that they rendered the company insolvent. Revco filed for bankruptcy protection in 1988.
 
Mideast Flights Grounded
 
Nobody wants to insure flights to the Middle East anymore. So Pan American World Airways announced on Thursday the suspension of flights to Tel Aviv and Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Insurance had risen to $65,000 for the Israeli flight, $162,500 to Saudi Arabia. KLM Royal Dutch Airlines canceled its three weekly flights to Amman, Jordan.
 
Matsushita's Yosemite Crisis
 
Now that the Japanese own the concessions at Yosemite National Park, Washington has become eager to protect the wilds. Last week, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. threatened to cancel the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company's newly acquired contract to run the park's hotels, shops and restaurants. Profits from the park should not flow abroad, he said. He demanded that Matsushita donate its subsidiary, the Yosemite and Curry Company, to the United States, or sell it to a foundation at a low price. Matsushita picked up the concessions in its $6.6 billion purchase of MCA Inc. Environmentalists have accused Curry of abusing its franchise, packing convention facilities and a virtual shopping mall into the park and luring enough tourists to choke the area with traffic and smog. MCA has called Mr. Lujan's threats "Japan-bashing," but agreed to put its Yosemite earnings in escrow for the time being.
 
A Bank on the Brink
 
The Bank of New England Corporation said it expected to post a fourth-quarter loss of $450 million, more than wiping out its net worth and bringing it to near-collapse. The Boston-based institution is trying to raise capital to avert a Government takeover, which would lead to major losses for the Federal deposit insurance fund. The nation's 33d-largest banking company, the Bank of New England has suffered severe losses on real estate loans.
 
 
 
INRTERNATIONAL


Walesa on the Free-Market Path
 
Poland's march toward free markets appears likely to continue under Solidarity leader and now President Lech Walesa. During his campaign, Mr. Walesa had the habit of promising faster progress and less pain at the same time. But he is filling his Government with ministers committed to economic reform. His Prime Minister, Jan Krzysztof Bielecki, is an economist so devoted to capitalism that he founded a trucking business while the Communists still held sway. Leszek Balcerowicz, the architect of the nation's economic programs and Finance Minister to Tadeusz Mazowiecki, whom Mr. Walesa defeated, appears likely to keep his job. Keith Crane, an economist at Planecon Inc., cautions that Mr. Walesa might bend to pressure to ease the impact of free markets. But Mr. Crane doubts the Government will reverse direction, saying, "In no way will it undo what has been done before."
 
Mexico's Market Miracle
 
The Mexican stock market completed its third straight year as the world's strongest. Mexico led the 24 markets in the Financial Times World index last year by advancing 79.6 percent in dollar terms. . "Money is coming back to Mexico, and new money from the U.S. and Japan is going in," said Robert A. Pastor, director of the Latin American program at the Carter Center. Dr. Pastor said coming trade talks with the United States are likely to accelerate the investment flow. A possible danger: As demand for the peso helps improve its performance against the dollar, Mexico's exports could suffer. On an early December visit to Mexico, Dr. Pastor said, "I was surprised by how much more expensive things had become."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Why Stocks Make Sense Now

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Should you sink money into stocks this year? No way, most mutual fund investors would probably say. And with good reason: Many were badly burned in 1990, when the average stock fund lost more than 7 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks mutual funds.
But sidestepping stocks would be a big mistake, experts say. Although most believe the market hasn't hit bottom -- many expect the Dow Jones industrial average to fall to about 2,100 by mid-year and some expect an even steeper drop -- the consensus among analysts is that there will be a recovery this year. And the biggest profits always are made in the early part of a bull market, when many investors are not invested in stocks. 
 For that reason, four investment advisers, asked by The New York Times to craft model portfolios for 1991, all included a good sampling of stock funds. In fact, some funds are favorites of more than one adviser: Brandywine Fund, Harbor International and the Gabelli Asset Fund.
Here's what the four advisers have to say.
 Kenneth E. Gregory, principal in the San Francisco-based money management firm Litman/Gregory, said he would put 60 percent of his holdings in intermediate-term bonds to avoid the risk in the stock market early this year and to reap capital gains from falling interest rates. Because of the recessionary environment, he would concentrate on high-quality bond funds. Two favorites: Vanguard Bond Market Fund and the PIMIT Total Return Trust. Top-bracket investors should consider tax-free bond funds, he said, and he likes the Vanguard Municipal Bond Fund Intermediate Term Portfolio.
The remaining 40 percent of the portfolio is evenly split between American and foreign stock funds. On the American side, he likes small-company stocks, which, battered for years, are now are as cheap as they've been since the mid-1970's. He would put half that money into growth funds, many of which have a small-company component. For aggressive investors, he recommends the Brandywine Fund; for conservatives, SteinRoe Special or Counsellors Capital Appreciation. The balance is split between a pure small-company fund, the Nicholas Limited Edition, and the Gabelli Asset Fund. On the foreign side, he likes Harbor International and the T. Rowe Price International Discovery Fund.
 He expects the stock market to near its bottom in the first quarter;that's when he would shift the allocation, putting 80 percent into stocks and leaving the balance in bonds.
Another investment adviser, Tom Bailard, chairman of Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser, in San Mateo, Calif., would keep 10 percent in cash, "partly for safety and partly to shift over into equities." He would put it in the Vanguard Prime Money Market Fund.
Mr. Bailard would put 45 percent into 15- to 20-year Treasury bonds, and likes the Vanguard Fixed Income Securities Fund Investment Grade Bond Portfolio. And 15 percent would go into international bonds.
Another 15 percent should go into American stocks; Mr. Bailard prefers the Vanguard Index Fund, and would move more money there late in the first quarter. The remaining 15 percent is split by the Vanguard World International Growth Fund (10 percent) and the Fidelity Real Estate Investment Portfolio (5 percent), because REIT's, he says, have been "beaten through the pavement because of negative investor sentiment, but still yield 10 percent."
Kurt Brower, partner in Brower & Janachowski, San Francisco-based investment advisers, would put one-half of a conservative investor's portfolio into the Harbor Bond Fund. The balance is split between the Vanguard Equity-Income Fund, the Janus Fund and Gabelli Asset Fund.
He chose a different portfolio for investors willing to take more risk: half would go into the Brandywine Fund; the rest would be split between Harbor International, which he likes because it has very little invested in Germany and Japan, and the Robertson and Steven Emerging Growth Fund, a small-company fund that invests heavily in bio-technology and medical technology companies.
Marc O'Brien, a Cambridge, Mass.-based adviser, has a dimmer view of the 1991 markets than his colleagues. He warns investors to "readjust their expectations" and recommends a very conservative approach. He expects "recession, major bankruptcies and generally difficult economic times." For him, the theme is quality. He also focuses on income, invests in small-company stocks and keeps a sharp eye on fund expenses.
He said he would tiptoe into the market. He would begin the year with all his cash invested in the Scudder Short-Term Bond Fund, using that as "a temporary parking place." Then, every two months, he would shift one-sixth of the money into long-term funds. By year-end, investors following that formula would have equal amounts in Scudder's Short-Term and International Bond Funds; Wellesley Income, a high-quality bond portfolio; Ivy International; SBSF Growth Fund, a conservative growth-and-income fund, and Babson Enterprise, a small-company fund. Over all, the portfolio would be roughly split between stocks and bonds, and international and domestic investments.
 
WHEN BIG IS BEAUTIFUL
Conventional wisdom holds that after a growth fund gets too big, its managers cannot be quick enough on their feet to keep up the fund's performance. The huge asset base must be invested in too many different issues, the reasoning goes, and handling that much cash deftly is simply too hard.
That's not so, as the accompanying chart shows. Furthermore, the average five-year gain for the 25 largest growth funds is 11.9 percent, nearly two full percentage points more than the average for all growth funds, while the 25 smallest funds returned an average of 4.6 percent.
D. Tyler Jenks, director of research for Kanon Bloch Carre & Company, a Boston-based mutual fund consulting firm, concludes: "The average investor is actually pretty smart." In other words, the biggest funds are getting bigger because investors like the results.

HEADLINE: All About/Silver;
With the Price Right, the White Metal Heads for a Rebound

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
When the price of silver reached a momentary peak of $48.70 an ounce during the Hunt brothers' buying spree a decade ago, and averaged out in 1980 at a stratospheric $20-plus, manufacturers abandoned the precious metal in droves.
But since then, silver has fallen to about $4.20 an ounce, its lowest point since the late 1970's, and the metal is once more attractive, particularly in photography and electronics. Industry analysts estimate that global silver use by manufacturers climbed 2.3 percent last year to 480 million ounces, the most since 1976. They also estimate that 123 million ounces were used in the United States, the most in a decade. 
 Jewelers are hopping on the bandwagon as consumers find silver more affordable, certainly more affordable than gold. Even makers of silverware, an industry that nearly vanished, are saying that business is up.
Manufacturers are using silver more economically this time around. Makers of photographic film use more silver overall, but a bit less for each frame. Electronic equipment makers employ more silver as a conductor, while its use in computers has soared.
Producers, meanwhile, are still suffering. Many major silver-mining companies are losing money and curtailing production. Others, who mined silver as a sideline, are abandoning it altogether. Analysts anticipate further price declines before tightening supplies force a price uptick in 1992.
The largest American silver producer, Asarco Inc., mined 7.4 million ounces in 1989, followed by Nerco Inc., with 6.1 million ounces. Several foreign silver companies are larger, Industrias Penoles of Mexico holding the title of industry giant, with 23.7 million ounces in 1989. Next is MIM Holdings of Australia, with 13.9 million ounces.

 
 
At the Mines
Costs Are Down, But So Are Profits
 In most businesses, a company that cuts operating costs in than half would be profitable indeed. But Thomas Albanese, chief operating officer of the gold and silver mining subsidiary of Nerco Inc., has little to show for reducing his silver production costs from $8 an ounce in 1983 to $4 an ounce early last year. "The recent prices have been putting the silver mining industry into a fix," he said.
The decline in operating costs has been largely due to a mining technique known as heap leaching. Companies scoop ore from open-pit mines and then leach out the silver by applying potassium cyanide, hydrochloric acid and sulfuric acid. This technique requires less labor and eliminates the need for costly underground mines.
But when silver sells for $4.20 an ounce, many mining companies turn to other metals. Two-thirds of the United States silver producers also unearth gold, copper or zinc. Mr. Albanese has been turning to gold. "That attention to other metals has helped our operations to be profitable," he said. "There really isn't much choice."
For producers with no alternatives, low prices have meant steep losses. Production costs for most silver miners fall between $4.75 and $5 an ounce -- yielding narrow profits at the average 1989 price of $5.50 an ounce and losses last year. "Globally, silver companies have lost hundreds of millions of dollars," said Jeffrey M. Christian, managing director of the CPM Group, a New York-based precious-metals consulting company.

 
 
Film and Flatware
Photography Is The Growth Focus
 In the United States, silver is most likely to be found not in bank vaults or table settings or jewelers' cases, but in rolls of film. Photography accounts for more than half of United States consumption, up from a third in the late 1970's. The amount of silver in each frame of film plunged 17 percent between 1978 and 1980.
Since then, it has risen, although not quite to the same levels as before the Hunts' heaviest buying. Americans take about 5 percent more pictures each year and doctors take more X-rays, accounting for about a third of all photographic silver use.
Silver demand in the dining room has seriously lagged that in the examining room. "Silver on the table is better than money in the bank," says Miss Manners, but few young families trying to make a downpayment on a house agree. Consumption of silver tableware in the United States fell from a peak of 44 million ounces in 1973 to an estimated 4 million ounces in 1990 -- down from 22 percent of total silver demand to 2.4 percent. Analysts note that young couples gave up throwing formal dinner parties illuminated by silver's glint. "Americans moved to a more informal lifestyle and silverware was seen as something from one's parents' generation," said Mr. Christian. "And when the price rose in the 1980's, that was another nail in the coffin." Of the leading American silvermakers -- once known as the Seven Sisters -- two have halted silverware production and the others have cut back sharply.
But some producers say that Americans are again beginning to buy silverware worthy of the name. "We're enjoying a resurgence," said Anthony D. LaChapelle, vice president of sales and marketing with the Reed & Barton Corporation, of Taunton, Mass., one of the country's oldest silverware makers. Mr. LaChapelle said that the company's sales, in ounces, were up nearly 10 percent in 1990.
One obvious source of stimulation: a four-piece place setting, which cost an average $400 in the early 1980's, goes for just $140 to $185 today. Then there is the revival of formal entertaining as the postwar generation ages. "There has been a return to traditionalism," Mr. LaChapelle said. "The Baby Boomers are now well educated and they are spending money on the home. And companies that make finer quality goods for the home have benefited."

 
 
New Applications
From Windshields To Computer Chips
 Although overall silver demand has diminished during the last 20 years, the metal has found new uses as its cost has declined. It is a very effective conductor of heat and electricity.
In 1986, the Ford Motor Company introduced an optional windshield for its Taurus that had a molecular layer of silver laminated between the layers of glass. Heating the silver layer cleared the windshield of frost and ice within two minutes. Now many American models and some of the Japanese offer the silver-lined windshields as standard equipment.
Silver films are increasingly common in microelectronics. There, they are replacing $90-an-ounce palladium, which once had an exclusive role in connecting silicon chips on circuit boards for computer and other equipment. And silver plating is showing up in more electrical uses, like contacts in switches. In these applications, it is copper that is displaced. "Manufacturers are finding the cost is no longer prohibitive and that silver is a better conductor," said Mr. Christian of the CPM Group.
John Lutley, executive director of the Silver Institute in Washington, says that the white metal might become the primary conducting material if superconductors, which carry electricity with little resistance, become viable. For superconductors, "any commercial use is probably a decade away," he said. "But silver is one of the few materials that can be used successfully with that technology."
 
 
COINS FOR REMEMBRANCE
 For decades, a silver dime, quarter, half-dollar or dollar was really silver. But by 1964, the metal's price had risen to the point that the silver was worth more than a coin's face value. The United States mint turned to copper and nickel as the principal metals instead.
Several European nations still use silver for their standard, circulating coinage. But other nations have begun minting silver coins intended primarily as investments. So far, the largest such issues have come from the United States, which accounts for about a quarter of the world's silver demand for this purpose. Canada is the second-largest issuer, West Germany third.
Silver investors buy the coinage primarily as a hedge against inflation. And demand for it has grown in the United States from 1.8 million ounces in 1982, when prices came down with a thump, to 6.8 million ounces in 1989.
The United States Eagle and the Canadian Maple Leaf have come to account for about three-quarters of demand from small investors, according to the Silver Institute, a trade group in Washington.. In some states, investors who buy official coinage are exempted from paying taxes on their purchases.
Commemorative silver coins have also become increasingly popular, feeding the fortunes of private operators, like th Franklin Mint, as well as Washington's coffers. The United States itself has issued coins for the 1976 Bicentennial, the 1984 Olympic Games and the 100th anniversary of the Statue of Liberty. Next will come issues for the centennial of Mount Rushmore, the 40th anniversary of the Korean War and the 1992 Olympics.
The prices of the official coinage varies with the cost of silver, the size of an issue and, of course, investor demand. The Eagle, one ounce, now costs slightly less than $10. Appreciation is the general rule, but those who stocked up when the Hunt brothers were investing are almost certainly stuck with a loss.
