HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
Are Computer Safety Laws Taking the Right Tack?

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
The San Francisco Board of Supervisors last month passed an ordinance that will require larger businesses in the city to pay more attention to the health and safety consequences of using computers in the workplace. The legislation, which Mayor Art Agnos signed after some last-minute compromises, is being heralded by labor unions as a model for other cities and counties.
The health issues of computer use in the office, including radiation from video display terminals, job stress and repetitive motion disorders, are likely to receive widespread attention in the coming decade. Tens of millions of computer workers will enter the job force, joining tens of millions of current computer users who will be getting older. 
 "In the 90's, with the aging of the Baby Boom generation, there will be a lot more people entering their 40's, and that's when you start seeing increases in wear-and-tear injuries," said Rani Lueder, president of Humanics Inc., an ergonomics consulting company in Encino, Calif. "There is also a cumulative effect from a number of years of exposure to automation." Ms. Lueder and other critics say that although the measures adopted in San Francisco may help reduce the physical ailments of computer users, they do little to address what may be a greater cause of computer-related injuries: the increasingly stressful workplace.
The San Francisco legislation is similar to a law passed in Suffolk County, N.Y., in 1988 that was struck down by a state court on the ground that only the state had the authority to make such law. Because the San Francisco law was negotiated with the business community, however, perhaps no legal challenge will be mounted.
Neither the San Francisco nor Suffolk County laws directly addressed the issue of video display terminal radiation, which is being investigated as a possible factor in increased cases of some types of cancer and pregnancy problems. Rather, the San Francisco law focuses on repetitive motion injuries, eye strain, headaches, general malaise and other neuromuscular ailments that are believed to be caused by extended computer use.
The San Francisco law requires the use of adjustable chairs and tables, lighting, angle-adjustable screens and keyboards, work time at tasks away from the computer, training of workers and supervisors and the use of printer covers to reduce office noise.
 In general, the law affects any business with 15 or more daily employees, and those employees who spend more than half their working hours at a computer terminal.
Business owners and business associations opposed the San Francisco bill, as they had the Suffolk bill, because of the perceived high cost of buying new tables, chairs, light fixtures and other equipment. Supporters of the measure say businesses pay even more for the lost work time, higher medical bills and lost productivity that the current environment brings.
Under the compromises reached by business leaders and Mayor Agnos late last year, companies have 30 months to refit existing work stations to comply with the law, but no company is required to spend more than $250 per work station. All new work stations installed after this year must comply with the law, regardless of cost.
Repetitive motion injuries of the sort associated with computer use are among the fastest-growing categories of workplace injuries, the Bureau of Labor Statistics says. They accounted for 18 percent of all workplace injuries in 1981, the year the International Business Machines Corporation introduced the first I.B.M. PC. The percentage rose to 52 percent in 1989, by which time there were some 40 million personal computers in use. The bureau reported 28 percent more repetitive motion injuries in 1989, the latest year for which figures were available, than in the year before.
Although repetitive stress injuries are also associated with many assembly-line jobs where people perform one task over and over, some office workplace researchers feel that hand and wrist problems caused by use of computer terminals may be a much larger problem.
The most frequently cited ailments among computer users are carpal tunnel syndrome and wrist tendonitis; the most common victims are secretaries, telephone operators, data entry clerks, airline reservation workers and journalists.
The affliction is caused when wrist and hand tendons are stressed repeatedly without sufficient time to recover. Over time it can become debilitating, causing pain so great that some workers resort to surgery or leave their jobs.
 Some ergonomics researchers fault the approach taken in San Francisco, saying that simply buying adjustable furniture may do little to help people who suffer from those ailments.
"Like other VDT laws it is inadvertently designed to sell products and services rather than protect VDT users," said Bert Dumpe of Ergotec, a nonprofit office ergonomics association in Arlington, Va.
Ms. Lueder of Humanics added: "I don't know of a single study that has found that ergonomic furniture or adjustable VDT workstands will prevent carpal tunnel syndrome or improve it in any way."
Increasing workplace stress, she said, rather than ill-fitting furniture, is the probable cause of most cases of carpal tunnel syndrome. "Computer use is becoming a lot more stressful than it used to be," she said. "The technology is pushing people more than ever before. At a phone company I visited recently, for example, they keep adding new software systems that make people spend more time on the job and intensify the work."
The stress is exacerbated, she said, by the current recession, which has caused many computer workers to fear for their jobs.
Another problem is that most workers do not take advantage of the adjustable furniture when it is provided. "In a study at Ontario Hydro in Canada, they found that only 5 percent of the adjustable furniture had ever been adjusted, and that only 12 percent of the workers even knew it was adjustable," Ms. Lueder said.
The San Francisco ordinance calls for workplace education to inform computer users about health issues of computers. All employees are to be given training on proper use of computers, adjustable furniture and lighting, foot and wrist rests, and other work station equipment.
In the end, though, the best defenses against computer-related ailments are low tech or no tech. Frequent short rest breaks are better than infrequent long ones for people doing computer work. Other advice from experts: get plenty of rest and exercise, do not smoke, lose weight, sit up straight and learn to manage stress. And workers who hammer away at the keyboard are more likely to injure themselves than those who type lightly and smoothly.

HEADLINE: Managing;
Doing Business in Hard Times

BYLINE: By DEBORAH L. JACOBS; Deborah L. Jacobs is a Brooklyn-based business writer.

 BODY:
Lawrence Caplan knew it was time to diversify when he noticed a decline in orders for poached salmon and a new appreciation for turkey sandwiches.
 Mr. Caplan, whose New York business, Berkeley Caterers, once catered $30-a-head lunches at law firms, advertising agencies and investment banks, shifted gears in 1989. He began by renting party equipment to companies that preferred to do the work themselves. Last summer, he added a sideline: a discount supply company that offers everything from beverages to Band-Aids. 
 "When income declines, you look for other ways to generate income," he said. Adding sidelines has enabled Berkeley to compensate for a 20 percent drop in its food business since the 1987 stock market tumble, he said.
 As large corporations trim their budgets for everything from legal fees to office temporaries, service companies that once helped with the workload or provided the extras find profits sagging. To survive, many are cutting overhead and offering discounts. But the ones most likely to thrive, economists and management consultants say, are the strategists: those able to shift emphasis in services they already offer, or introduce new sidelines to replace segments of the business that have gone flat. The ability to take advantage of changing opportunities can spell the difference between bankruptcy and success.
Perhaps the best test cases of business flexibility are in the Northeast, where the service industry -- long driven by Wall Street -- has been battered since the 1987 market crash. After adding an average of 16,400 jobs a year to the New York economy between 1982 and 1987, business and professional services have nearly stalled, and are now adding only 2,600 new jobs a year, according to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. Virtually every service is affected.
 Many law firms, hit hard by declining work in real estate and mergers and acquisitions, are moving into burgeoning fields like bankruptcy and environmental law. Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler built an instant bankruptcy department in July by acquiring a small firm of bankruptcy specialists, Levin & Weintraub, Crames & Edelman. "Each week we get another major company either on the verge of bankruptcy or going into Chapter 11," said Peter Fishbein, chairman of Kaye, Scholer's executive committee. "The biggest challenge is to reprogram our lawyers and reallocate our resources."
When Richard Ross, president of the New York firm TempsAmerica, saw his business threatened by the growing popularity of in-house temporary services, he began offering a seminar on how to start an in-house temporary pool. "This is the time when you have to come up with other services to stay competitive," he said.
 The MAC Group, a management consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., has compensated for less work for financial institutions by increasing revenues from overseas, said Scott Parker, a managing director. KPMG Peat Marwick, the big diversified accounting firm, faced with a drop in mergers and acquisitions, is emphasizing services in cost containment, capital raising and credit, said Steven Roberts, a partner.
 Unfazed by the dwindling job market for young attorneys, Kerry Lutz founded Lutz Legal Services to help lawyers collect delinquent accounts. "As the recession kicks in and more and more judgments get entered and fewer of them get paid, there's more and more need for the service we provide," he said.
Bill Herz, a New York magician specializing in corporate events, is expecting his best year ever in 1991. "I'm a cheap alternative" to laser shows and ski resort weekends, said Mr. Herz, who charges $1,000 or more for a performance. He says one of his most popular tricks these days is turning a one dollar bill into a $100 bill.
To keep the money coming in, many service businesses -- including advertising and accounting agencies and public relations firms -- are slashing rates and offering volume discounts to loyal clients. Service firms must "figure out new methods to provide the same service at less cost," said Philip Kotler, professor of marketing at Northwestern University's Kellogg Graduate School of Management.
 
GETTING AWAY FROM THE FRILLS
Wendeen H. Eolis, who heads the New York-based legal search firm, W. H. Eolis International Inc., has been in business for 22 years and has weathered other recessions. She can deal with a drop in revenues but not in profits, she said, so she has been trying to cut overhead.
Ms. Eolis now audits her books to focus on a different business expense each month. She said she has cut her annual advertising budget by more than $100,000 and saved 35 percent on stationery by switching suppliers. Instead of expensive "power lunches" she substitutes breakfast meetings or invites clients to her office. Streamlined cocktail parties have replaced dinners she once hosted. "We're running lean and mean and being mindful about getting away from the 80's frills," she said. "It's like being anointed with a renewed humility."
These are some other steps she recommends to cut overhead:
* Negotiate discounts with caterers by offering to entertain at their least busy times.
* Request winter discounts for office landscaping.
* Use several different long-distance telephone carriers, taking advantage of each one's favorable rates for calling cards and special calling plans.
* Self-insure office equipment and appliances, rather than buy service contracts.

HEADLINE: Hard Edges Aside, Manhattan Still Lures the Ambitious

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
After months of persuasion, Sylvia Laniado, a recruiter for an advertising agency, convinced Bonnie Brainin, a talented copywriter from Connecticut, to set aside her fears about crime in Manhattan and take the train into the city for a job interview.
In the short walk to Ms. Laniado's office from Grand Central Terminal, Ms. Brainin's wallet was stolen from her purse. "She spent the first half hour of the interview on the phone with the police and the credit card companies reporting the theft," recalled Ms. Laniado. "Needless to say, it was not exactly the best way to start the interview." 
 While such stories abound, recruiters and corporate human resources executives are divided as to whether the perception that the quality of life in New York City has steadily deteriorated has made it harder to lure talented workers to the city.
And when job candidates balk, it is far more often because of the high cost of housing in the area, rather than the high rate of crime, according to experts. The New York City area is the third most expensive in the country, after San Francisco and Los Angeles, according to Runzheimer International, a management consulting firm in Rochester, Wis.
For many job seekers, however, the unique attractions of the New York City job market continue to outweigh the well-publicized problems. However one may feel about $1,000-a-month studio apartments or the possibility of being mugged or knifed on a subway platform, for those who aspire to work at a certain level in fields like finance, communications, advertising and the arts, a job in New York at some point seems all but mandatory.
"If you want to be in the big leagues, frequently you don't have that much of a choice," said Martin H. Bauman, an executive recruiter. "There are certain industries that if you are not in New York, you probably have not arrived."
"For people who want to do finance, Mecca is Mecca," said Mark Bieler, executive vice president of human resources for Bankers Trust.
Many recruiters say that it has always been difficult to attract outsiders into the city and that it is not getting harder.
"We don't see any difference in our ability to attract people into New York," said Mr. Bieler of Bankers Trust, adding, "I can't recall the last time that New York was a significant impediment to a hire.".
Some experts say that the faltering economy and the large number of unemployed executives have made New York -- or any location -- less of an issue. "It is just getting so hard to get a job, the desirability of the venue is less important," said Theodore Erikson, a recruiter with Canny Bowen Inc. "There is a hierarchy of needs. When you are unemployed and you've been unemployed for a while, you'd move to Alaska."
But others detect a growing resistance to relocating to New York. "Is it getting more difficult to attract people to New York? "Yes, it is," said Karen N. Gerard, a vice president with the management consulting firm, Moran, Stahl & Boyer.
Ms. Gerard, a deputy mayor during the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, said the city has gone through cycles when it was hard to bring people in. She said the back-to-the-land movement that began in the 1960's soured a generation of young people on the idea of life in Manhattan. "This isn't the first time there has been a disillusionment with the Big Apple," she said.
But Ms. Gerard calls the growing distaste for New York "pretty serious" compared with earlier down cycles.
Martin H. Bauman, an executive recruiter, said, "It has been getting harder every year" to attract people to the city.
Carol A. Filippi, a relocation specialist for Time Inc. Magazines, a division of Time Warner, said, "It certainly is getting harder, because of the high cost of the whole New York area." Ms. Filippi said that high housing costs and long commutes, not crime, were the most frequent objections to New York.
The slump in the Northeast has made housing slightly more affordable in the metropolitan area, but house prices are still among the highest in the country. Rents for some types of apartments have dropped recently, too, but not as fast or as much as other housing prices. While there is no hard data on resistance to moving into New York, Ms. Gerard and others said corporations are encountering the most problems in filling middle-level management jobs.
"Companies are not getting their first choice," said Ms. Gerard. "I've heard people in this region say, 'Our problem is we can't bring people in and we can't get the quality of people we want,' " she said. More and more middle-level jobs are going to the No. 2 or No. 3 choice or being filled locally, she said.
Mr. Bauman said he detects a definite resistance to moving to New York for jobs below the $200,000 level. Senior executives are paid enough that they can avoid many of the city's most corrosive elements.
Senior-level appointments are still readily filled because corporations are willing to pay whatever it takes to hire the person they feel is best suited for the job, employment experts say.
Larry Materi, a veteran banker, recently switched jobs, leaving his employer of 10 years rather than accept a transfer to New York. Mr. Materi worked in Cleveland for a Canadian bank that decided to close its office there and move it to New York. After extensive discussions with his wife, Mr. Materi, joined a different bank in Chicago.
"We felt it would have been difficult on our family life," he said of a move to New York. Mr. Materi has two children and was concerned about the long hours he would be away from the house commuting. He now commutes from a suburb of Chicago, but "At least I get home and have dinner with my kids and read them a story before they go to bed."
Ms. Gerard said companies could do more counseling and education to help overcome reluctance about moving to New York. A division of American Express is putting together an orientation program for the 60 to 80 top-ranked business students the company recruits each year.
Margaret Gagliardi, a senior vice president at the American Express Travel Related Services Company said, "We are going to make an effort to try to get at some of the options that people have when they consider working in New York." While the program is still being planned, it will probably include sessions on buying versus renting, the suburbs versus the city and perhaps even a talk on how to make friends.
"The M.B.A. market is an incredibly competitive market," said Ms. Gagliardi. "You hate to lose capable individuals because of misconceptions that they might have about New York."
Neither Ms. Gagliardi nor Ms. Laniado who works in advertising, have detected an increase in resistance to moving to New York. However, Ms. Laniado said New Yorkers are now far more willing than they were in the past to entertain and accept offers from the hinterlands.
New York salaries are significantly higher than those in other parts of the country. For transfers, many companies grant cost-of-living increases. Some companies offer interest-free loans for housing, help with day care and private school costs. Companies will pay for "anything that's legal" to attract top executives," said Mr. Bauman.
Others note that employees are becoming less willing to relocate to any city. "People are getting much more selective in making a move," said Linda K. Stroh, of Loyola University in Chicago, who was a co-author of a recent study on relocation. The changing demographics of the labor forces -- more women in the work force, single-parent families and dual-career couples, for example -- are having an impact on workers' willingness to relocate. The study found that employees in 1989 were far more negative about the benefits of moving than were employees questioned in 1978.
Despite such feelings, Mr. Bauman said he has found that many outsiders' misgivings about New York quickly dissipate. "It's hard to get people into New York," he said. "It's even harder to get them out."

HEADLINE: A Gift Certificate to Pampering

BYLINE: By GEORGIA DULLEA

 BODY:
As women in white coats peered at his pores, Kenneth Levine, a 34-year-old clothing company executive, lay under a sheet in a small, dim, clinic-like room last Thursday. Cotton pads covered his eyes and his feet, in black tasseled loafers, stuck out of the sheet. His chin was being painted with a mask of mud and sufhur that felt, he said, initially like good old shaving cream.
Mr. Levine, whose skin-care regimen was a splash of after-shave lotion, was having his first facial. "My wife gave me a gift certificate for the holidays and I gave her a tennis racquet," he said, waving freshly manicured hands in electrically heated mitts, "but this is much more relaxing." 
 "Sometimes they fall asleep," said Astrid Bedrossian, director of technical services at Georgette Klinger salons. "Sometimes they snore," a facialist, Gabrielle Eniou, said.
Leaving the Men's Clinic, on the Spa Level of the Klinger salon at 978 Madison Avenue at 76th Street, Mrs. Bedrossian drifted along the white corridors, looking in on other recipients of holiday gift certificates. Thanks to loved ones, they were having scalp treatments, exercise lessons, nutritional counseling, all sorts of services meant to make them look and feel better.
In an ideal world, they might all be at Main Chance or Golden Door. They might be taking the waters at Baden Baden. But at this Klinger salon, a so-called urban spa on the scenic Upper East Side, the philosophy is, Mrs. Bedrossian said, "If you can't get away for four days, five hours will do."
Miss Klinger herself was away on vacation in Arizona. But Anne Thompson, the company's vice president for sales, said that the 74-year-old dean of skin care would be back soon to celebrate her 50th anniversary in business. Meanwhile, how about a low-calorie, low-cholesterol lunch like the one served during the $260 Day of Beauty or, in the case of male clients, the $205 Day of Caring.
Trays of green salad, mineral water and herbal tea appeared. Mrs. Thompson sank back on a white leather banquette and talked about business during tough
times. Sales figures at Klinger salons in New York and five other cities around the country were up about 10 percent for the last quarter of 1990, she said, compared with the same period for 1989.
"We had an enormous gift certificate business this year," Mrs. Thompson said, peeking from a wide-brimmed black hat. "Despite the recession people still want an updated makeup or hair style, to feel a bit pampered or to relax after the stress of the holidays."
Catching a bracing whiff of peppermint oil, Mrs. Bedrossian came upon the mummy-like figure of Conni Weissman. Only Mrs. Weissman's tanned face, diamond studs gleaming at the ears, was visible. She had just returned from a month in St. Martin where, she said, she had employed liberal quantities of the salon's No. 15 sun block and achieved a healthy tan. Mrs. Bedrossian looked pleased.
Enveloped in towels saturated with essential oils, Mrs. Weissman was having a body treatment to rid the skin of toxins. It was part of a Day of Beauty, a Christmas present from her husband. "It's a great gift,although right now I'm having a very strange sensation, almost like suffocating," Mrs. Weissman said. "I'm sure it's just temporary."
Mrs. Bedrossian nodded and moved on to Hilary Schaffner, whose 12-year-old face was aglow from the special Facial for Teen-agers, given on the Clinic Level. "I consider this a wonderful luxury," said Hilary, a seventh grader at Brearley School. She was holding a small bag of Klinger cleansing products and beaming at her mother, Cynthia Schaffner.
As they prepared to leave, a facialist appeared, asking if Hilary wanted just a smidgeon of blue eye shadow. Eye shadow was part of the package. Hilary glanced at Mrs. Schaffner who said perhaps in a year or so.
Eye shadow was in order for 25-year-old Gigi McHugh. A private school teacher and freelance sportswriter, she was having a makeup lesson on the Salon Level. "My mom gave me the facial and the makeup," she said, staring into the mirror and fluffing her hair, "and one of my ex-student's parents gave me the haircut."
Miss McHugh's gift certificate also entitled her to lunch. To save time, though, she decided to dine on raw carrots while, a makeup artist, Richard Downs taught her to twirl a mascara wand like an expert.
"This is the best gift," she said, carrot stick in one hand, mascara in the other. "There's no point in getting stuff for Christmas if you don't feel good. If you look good, you feel good."

HEADLINE: Social Events

BYLINE: BY THOMAS W. ENNIS

 BODY:

Art Auction for Women
Jan. 7 -- The Women's Center for Education and Career Improvement is to benefit from an auction of works mainly by contemporary American artists at the Brooke Alexander Gallery, 59 Wooster Street (Broome Street). Among the artists are Romare Bearden, Camille Billops, Elizabeth Catlett, Jacob Lawrence and Judy Rifka. The works will be on view from noon to 5 P.M.; a wine reception follows at 6 and the auction at 7. The Women's Center, established 20 years ago in New York, provides counseling, training and guidance services to unemployed women and women at risk of losing their jobs. Tickets $25; (212) 964-8934.
 
For Christian Rescuers
Jan. 10 -- Maximilian Schell, the actor, will narrate a program produced by Arthur Whitelaw, the Broadway producer, about the rescue of Jews in World War II by Christians. The program will be part of a dinner and dance at the New York Hilton to benefit the Jewish Foundation for Christian Rescuers, maintained by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith. Jack and Lewis Rudin of the New York real-estate family will receive the foundation's Recognition of Goodness award. Reception at 6:30 P.M. Black tie. Tickets $500; (212) 490-2525, extension 115.
 
Humanitarian Awards
Jan. 10 -- The 36th annual humanitarian awards dinner and dance of United Cerebral Palsy of New York will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and Rupert Murdoch, the publisher, will be honored at the event, which is also a fund-raiser for the organization. Barbara Walters will be the mistress of ceremonies and Maureen McGovern will sing. A cocktail reception precedes dinner at 6:30 P.M. Black tie. Tickets $500 and $750; (212) 683-6700.

Jan. 13 -- Tony Randall is to receive the Israel Culture Award at a dinner and dance at the Pierre for the sale of Israel Government bonds. Guests at the party, which is sponsored by Sabra Society of the Israel Bond New Leadership Division, will be expected to purchase a minimum of $1,000 in bonds. Wendy Wasserstein, the playwright, is to present the award to Mr. Randall. The party starts at 6:30 P.M. Black tie. Tickets $135; (212) 677-9650, extension 346.
 
For the Ocean Liner Museum
Jan. 14 -- Walter Lord, an author and a specialist on the sinking of the Titanic, will be honored at a fund-raising dinner and dance at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, to benefit the Ocean Liner Museum. The museum, founded in 1981, is still without a home, but it does have a charter. Among its mementos of famous liners is the Normandie's whistle. The party starts at 6 P.M. Festive attire. Tickets $100 and $150; (212) 333-8639.
 
Helping Bank Street College
Jan. 14 -- The Bank Street College of Education, founded in 1916 in New York as the Bureau of Educational Experiments, is holding a fund-raising dinner and dance for its programs at the Waldorf-Astoria. It will present Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Mark with honorary degrees for their role in making the education of children a corporate priority. Mr. Mark is the chairman of Colgate-Palmolive. His wife, known professionally as Dr. Arlene Mark, is a child psychologist. A reception at 6 P.M. precedes dinner at 7. Black tie. Tickets $400; (212) 838-2660.

HEADLINE: Kean at Drew: Economics and Bikes

 BODY:
In "For Kean, Drew Has Become a Laboratory for His Ideas" (Nov. 18), former Gov. Thomas Kean is quoted as saying: "One thing Keynesian and supply-side economists agree upon is that raising taxes in a falling economy is a mistake. I hope that if the economy continues to drop, the current administration will find some way to readjust the taxes."
Mr. Kean is in serious error here. The liberty to run a deficit (financed with debt) belongs only to the Federal Government, which can, in ultimate distress, fund its debt by printing money. States do not have that liberty because their debt is not regarded as being free of default risk.
If the Florio administration were to "readjust the taxes," it would also have to cut expenditures by an equal amount. This confronts the question of how much collective expenditures the electorate wants.
The distinction between Federal and state fiscal freedom is important and is one that anyone with Potomac fever would do well to understand. It is to be hoped that Mr. Kean will not teach economics at Drew.
 
 H. PETER GRAY
 
Belle Meade
Emeritus Professor of Economics and Finance
Rutgers University

HEADLINE: Tungsram's Track Record in Research

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Regarding "Running on Fast-Forward in Budapest," Dec. 16, which described the joint venture between General Electric and Tungsram, a Hungarian firm specializing in electric lighting, it may be of interest that, between the two World Wars, Tungsram created, in addition to its manufacturing facilities, one of the strongest research laboratories in Europe.
The discoveries made and developed in this lab were patented by Tungsram and are the basis of its leading position in the industrial world. One of these discoveries by the distinguished physicist Imre Brody was the krypton incandescent lamp. (His great contributions did not save Mr. Brody and his family from being murdered by Nazis in 1944.)
After the war, Tungsram continued its high-quality basic and applied industrial research. Apparently there are organizations that not even Communism can destroy.
 
PETER D. LAX
New York, N.Y., Dec. 22

HEADLINE: U.S. and Philippines Set For New Talks on Bases

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA

 BODY:
A deal on a new military basing agreement between the United States and the Philippines will probably not be reached before a Jan. 31 deadline imposed by President Corazon C. Aquino, negotiators for both sides say. But they are convinced that a deal will be struck before the old agreement expires on Sept. 16.
The fourth round of negotiations on the future of the six American bases are scheduled to resume on Jan. 8. Previous rounds have been marked by intricate discussions of who, in any new deal, will cut the grass on the bases, run the taxis and deliver the mail; whose currency and driver's licenses will be used; who will profit from the fast-food restaurants, and whose courts will have jurisdiction on sensitive cases. 
 But more basic questions remain unresolved, too: the duration of a new agreement, how much it will cost and whether it will be cast as a treaty, requiring ratification by the United States Senate.
"We're in a bleak period on the bases," a senior Western diplomat said. "But the makings of a settlement and its outlines have been identified. A deal is doable and defensible in both countries. But to satisfy the demands for real drama here, you need to fail to meet your deadline."
 
'Need for Theatrics'
 A senior Asian diplomat who follows the talks closely said similarly: "This is the Philippines, and the need for theatrics and dramatic crisis must be satisfied in order to prove that a deal everyone knows is coming has been in fact a great accomplishment and has humbled the Americans."
The Americans want a 10- to 12-year phased reduction of the their military presence here, after which the two main bases at issue, Subic Bay Naval Station and Clark Air Base, could be available on a pay-per-use basis, as in Singapore.
The Americans have already announced the withdrawal by September of all fighter planes and 1,800 military personnel stationed at Clark.
"We no longer need big chunks of real estate and all the trappings of ownership," the senior Western diplomat said. "We need access to places where we can do what we need to do."
The Americans want to preserve warehousing for predeployment, regular visits, training facilities, ship repair, military resupply and a few other functions, including the maintenance of a counterterrorist unit.
 
Range of Philippine Views
 The Philippine side embraces a range of views from Health Secretary Alfredo Bengzon, who calls in public for the Americans to leave in September, to Foreign Secretary Raul S. Manglapus, who says Manila's position is for a 5- to 7-year treaty to allow for a sensible transition, at the end of which the Americans will leave.
The Filipinos have talked about separate arrangements for Subic, with the other bases coming under complete Filipino control after September. But Manila has since backed away from demanding full operational control over Clark, in large part because the Philippine military says it has neither the trained personnel or the budget to handle the task.
Mr. Bengzon complained during the last round, in mid-November, that the Philippine panel was feeling pressure from Aquino officials responsible for the economy and from the military.
About 70,000 Filipinos are employed at the bases, which house about 16,000 American troops and add about $1 billion a year to the local economy.
Filipino negotiators acknowledge that the country's severe economic problems have helped make a new agreement much more likely. They say an American departure would further distress needed foreign investors, who are already shying away because of political instabilty.
While the Philippine Senate has been critical of the American bases in the past and must ratify a new deal, Manila officials are confident that an agreement that is construed as a final phase-out of the American presence will win the necessary two-thirds vote.
 
Philippine Pride Cited
 American negotiators, for their part, complain that the Philippine side appears to be divided and seems unwilling to negotiate specifics in an orderly way. But these complaints both amuse and annoy the Filipinos, who are very sensitive to perceived slights by their former colonial masters.
"It's contentious, and there's a large measure of pride at stake," a Filipino negotiator said. "The Americans can't conceive that we really want them out. So we argue about who mans the gate and who cuts the grass. It may not be entirely rational on the Filipino side, but it goes to the heart of sovereignty."
"We own it, and we want to cut the grass," the Filipino said. "The Americans say, 'But you're not into maintenance, you won't cut the grass.' And so we actually said, 'O.K., we'll get some goats, and they'll cut the grass every day!' "
"We are not unreasonable allies," the Filipino continued, "and we understand the global role of the U.S. All they need to do is ask permission. Access is O.K."

HEADLINE: CRIME OVERWHELMS PRETORIA'S POLICE

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Before dawn on Christmas Day, a gang of youths raided a Salvation Army home sheltering teen-age girls in the black township of Soweto.
The gang members, who nicknamed themselves the Zebra Force, beat the night watchman unconscious, stabbed a matron who tried to stop them, smashed windows and beds, stole Christmas presents, food and money and abducted eight girls who were gang-raped. 
 The attack evoked the kind of public outrage around Johannesburg that the assault on a woman who was jogging in Central Park in New York City prompted last year -- but with a difference.
Residents of Soweto's Mopholo and Phomolong districts, where the attacks took place, had little confidence in the police, who reportedly took an hour to respond to the shelter's call for help.
So they assembled a posse of men who tracked down 11 gang members and delivered them to the police station. Eleven more gang members are being pursued in connection with the attacks.
 
Upsurge in Common Crime
 Minister of Law and Order Adriaan Vlok warned against vigilantism even as he congratulated the Sowetans for public spiritedness. But last weekend, he promised that 10,000 more police officers would be patrolling streets around the country by next June as part of an aggressive anti-crime campagaign.
Mr. Vlok was responding to a broad surge in crime that the police has been unable to stem. South Africa reported nearly 3,500 deaths in politically motivated violence in 1990.
But even more people were victims of savage mayhem motivated by profit. About 13,000 South Africans were slain in 1990, an increase of 25 percent over 1989, and the police reported similar rises in rape, assault and robbery.
Criminals once content to hijack cars have begun shooting the drivers.
 
Attacks on the Elderly
 In Soweto on Christmas Eve, a Johannesburg businessman who drove two employees home was slain at a traffic light by a gang who wanted his car. Nineteen days earlier, a woman was gunned down in front of her home in Morningside, an affluent Johannesburg suburb, and her vehicle was stolen. A motorist near Durban was fatally shot when he tried to protect his car.
Attacks on the elderly rose more than 30 percent in the first six months of 1990 over the corresponding period in 1989.
In Pretoria, an elderly couple were stabbed and strangled in their home last month and in northern Durban, an 84-year-old man was suffocated by robbers.
Muggings in downtown Johannesburg have reached such "intolerable proportions" that tourism is threatened, Spencer Thomas, executive director of the South African Tourism Board, told the Johannesburg newspaper The Star.
Critics of the Government attribute the jump in crime to a perception, especially in the black townships, that the police are more inclined to protect the state and unjust laws than citizens. They also say unemployment and inferior education have made criminals of black youths who cannot find another way to live.
 
Armed Security Guards
 The police contend that the African National Congress and its allies, by encouraging protests and destabilization, have promoted an anarchic climate in which crime flourishes.
At least 91 policemen were killed in the line of duty in 1990, 65 of them in political unrest, according to Mr. Vlok's office, and 1 of every 10 officers was wounded.
The South African police, half of whose 75,000 members are nonwhites, are viewed as undermanned.
The police are seen patrolling so infrequently that whites, who live with high walls and burglar alarms, routinely hire armed security guards to protect their homes and businesses, giving South Africa four times as many private security guards as police officers.
Whites are also buying firearms. As of a year ago, 1.1 million South Africans had permits for 2.7 million firearms. In other words, one in two white families owned at least one firearm, and gun ownership is expected to soar this year.
Residents of black townships cannot afford such protection. A Soweto resident said the only recourse in a mugging was to report the crime later at the police station.
 
Crime and Apartheid
 Criminals are also more heavily armed. More than 7,700 firearms were stolen from owners last year. And AK-47 assault rifles, smuggled in from Mozambique, are now common in robberies.
The police reported that 385 people were killed or wounded in 1,083 robberies in Johannesburg in 1990.
The rising crime rate could erode white tolerance for the dismantling of apartheid that President F. W. de Klerk has undertaken, because most crimes of violence are committed by blacks. But as the attack on the Salvation Army shelter illustrated, blacks are also the most frequent victims.
As a result, black sympathy has increased for the African National Congress's proposal to form self-defense units in the townships.
Kgabisi Manunkutu, a spokesman for the Soweto Civic Association, said the gang raid on the Salvation Army shelter showed that "the people can't fold their arms and wait for the police to protect them against criminals."

HEADLINE: Editors' Note

 BODY:
An article in The Week in Review last Sunday headed "It Isn't Just a Downturn, It's the Bill for the 1980's" discussed fears that structural weaknesses in the United States economy could contribute to a serious recession. The article ended with a description of what the country had learned about preventing such factors from leading to a depression.
Through an editing oversight, the final paragraph, dealing with the prospect of war, included revisions on which the writer was not consulted;they did not accurately convey his meaning. 
 The writer did not mean to say that if there was a consensus of American economists it would probably be that if war was deemed unavoidable, the nation should go all out to win it. He intended to say that while peace would clearly be bullish for the economy and a long war would inflict a severe economic blow on the United States, no one knew the costs, benefits and further consequences of even a short war.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Text of the Radio Address by the President

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Following is the text of the radio address by President Bush today, as issued by the White House: 
 As the new year begins, new challenges unfold -- challenges to America and the future of our world. Simply put: 1990 saw Iraq invade and occupy Kuwait. 1991 will see Iraq withdraw, preferably by choice; by force, if need be. It is my most sincere hope 1991 is a year of peace. I've seen the hideous face of war and counted the costs of conflict in friends lost. I remember this all too well, and have no greater concern than the well-being of our men and women stationed in the Persian Gulf. True, their morale is sky-high. True, if they are called upon to fight the aggressors, they will do their job courageously, professionally and, in the end, decisively. There will be no more Vietnams.
But we should go the extra mile before asking our servicemen and women to stand in harm's way. We should, and we have. The United Nations, with the full support of the United States, has already tried to peacefully pressure Iraq out of Kuwait, implementing economic sanctions, and securing the condemnation of the world in the form of no less than 12 resolutions of the U.N. Security Council.
This week, we've taken one more step. I have offered to have Secretary of State James Baker meet with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Switzerland. yesterday, we received word that Iraq has accepted our offer to meet in Geneva.
 
 Baker's Message
 This will not be secret diplomacy at work. Secretary Baker will restate, in person, a message for Saddam Hussein: Withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally and immediately, or face the terrible consequences.
Eleven days from today, Saddam Hussein will either have met the United Nations deadline for a full and unconditional withdrawal, or he will have once again defied the civilized world. This is a deadline for Saddam Hussein to comply with the United Nations resolution, not a deadline for our own Armed Forces. Still, time is running out. It's running out because each day that passes brings real costs.
Saddam already poses a strategic threat to the capital cities of Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Israel and Syria, as well as our own men and women in the gulf region. In fact, Saddam has used chemical weapons of mass destruction against innocent villagers, his own people. Each day that passes brings Saddam Hussein further on the path to developing biological and nuclear weapons and the missiles to deliver them. If Saddam corners the world energy market, he can then finance further aggression, terror and blackmail. Each day that passes increases Saddam's worldwide threat to democracy.
 
 Economic Effects
 The struggling newborn democracies of Eastern Europe and Latin America already face a staggering challenge in making the transition to a free market. But the added weight of higher oil prices is a crushing burden they cannot afford. And our own economy is suffering, suffering the effects of higher oil prices and lower growth stemming from Saddam's aggression.
Each day that passes, Saddam's forces also fortify and dig in deeper into Kuwait. We risk paying a higher price in the most precious currency of all -- human life -- if we give Saddam more time to prepare for war. And each day that passes is another day of fear, suffering and terror for the people of Kuwait, many who risked their lives to shelter and hide Americans from Iraqi soldiers. As the Emir of Kuwait said to our Vice President just last week, those who advocate waiting longer for sanctions to work do not have to live under such brutal occupation.
As I have discussed with members of Congress, just two days ago and in our many other consultations, economic sanctions are taking a toll, but they are still not forcing Saddam out of Kuwait. Nor do we know when or even if they will be successful. As a result, America and her partners in this unprecedented coalition are sharing the burden of this important mission; and we are ready to use force to defend a new order emerging among the nations of the world, a world of sovereign nations living in peace.
 
 Forces at the Front
 We have seen too often in this century how quickly any threat to one becomes a threat to all. At this critical moment in history, at a time the cold war is fading into the past, we cannot fail. At stake is not simply some distant country called Kuwait. At stake is the kind of world we will inhabit.
Last Thanksgiving, I broke bread with some of our men and women on the front lines. They understand why we are in Saudi Arabia, and what we may have to do. I witnessed courage unfazed by the closeness of danger and determination undiminished by the harsh desert sun. These men and women are America's finest. We owe each of them our gratitude and full support. That is why we must all stand together, not as Republicans or Democrats, conservatives or liberals, but as Americans.

HEADLINE: Strapped, Big Cities Take Painful Steps

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5

 BODY:
With chronic deficits, ruined credit and little sympathy from state officials, Philadelphia is in the worst fiscal shape of any big American city. But many other cities are in trouble, too, and around the nation the steps mayors are taking to keep their budgets afloat are burdening residents and in some cases making government more efficient, officials in 40 of the nation's largest cities said in interviews.
The steps are often painful, and elected officials acknowledge that how they manage them will probably affect their political futures. 
 Many cities have had to raise taxes and fees, but other measures that have been adopted are as different as the cities themselves. Philadelphia put off buying pants for graduates of its police academy. Virginia Beach stopped buying library books. New York and Baltimore are closing firehouses. San Francisco stopped a therapy program for mental patients.
"Across the land, it's just harder times than usual," said Mayor Maynard Jackson of Atlanta, who has not yet announced how he will manage a $9 million revenue shortage this year.
 
'A Death Spiral'
 As the nation slides toward recession, tax revenue at all levels of government are dropping below projections, leaving growing gaps between what cites are collecting and spending. Many cities have been pushed to the limit. "Cities have raised property taxes, lowered services and only the poor can't move to the suburbs," said Frank H. Shafroth, director of government relations for the National League of Cities in Washington. "Cities are caught in a death spiral."
But not everyone holds that view. Daniel J. Mitchell, a policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation, a research organization in Washington, said the worsening financial condition of the cities offers opportunities to improve management, like having private contractors perform services like garbage collection.
"Many cities still have bloated work forces and they still haven't privatized enough services even though it has been demonstrated in city after city that the private sector does some jobs much more cheaply than the cities," Mr. Mitchell said.
Chicago recently began hiring private contractors for services like trash recycling, vehicle towing and building maintenance to help eliminate an anticipated $75 million shortage in its $3.2 billion budget for this fiscal year. "It used to cost us $25 to tow a car, but now that we privatized towing, they pay us $25 to tow every car," said Avis LaVelle, press secretary to Mayor Richard M. Daley. "We're making a couple million a year on towing, instead of spending a couple million a year."
The towing company pays the city and collects its own fines from drivers.
 
Trying to Affect the Fewest
 But in most cities, officials say streamlining government is not enough. A top goal, they say, is to raise taxes and cut programs in ways that affect the fewest people.
San Francisco, for example, faced a $27 million budget gap this year, including a $15 million reduction in state aid for health and welfare programs. The city raised business taxes by $8 million and trimmed services that officials said would matter least to residents.
Mental health programs took the deepest cuts. The city eliminated or reduced programs, including one for juvenile offenders and one that provided individual therapy for mentally ill people, many of whom were homeless. "It means we will be sustaining people and making sure they don't get sicker as opposed to helping them get well," said Carol Wilkins, the city's Deputy Mayor for finance.
One of the fastest ways to save is to cut a payroll. New York will eliminate up to 20,000 jobs next year, half through attrition and half through layoffs, said Philip R. Michael, the city's budget director. On Friday, just after the city granted 150,000 city workers a 5 percent pay increase, Mr. Michael issued new estimates on the budget gap. An estimated $250 million shortage had doubled this year, he said, and it could run as high as $2.1 billion next year.
Mr. Michael said the raise was covered by savings in city payments to pension plans and did not contribute to the city's growing shortage. He acknowledged for the first time that the city is in a fiscal crisis.
 
Detroit Focuses on Hiring
 Detroit is trying to work off a $32 million budget gap, primarily with a hiring freeze and other administrative savings. Washington, which faces a budget gap of about $100 million, has stopped filling vacancies, eliminated 500 contract employees and halted promotions, bonuses and most overtime pay.
Baltimore has balanced its budget primarily by eliminating 1,400 positions, or almost 12 percent of its work force, in the last two years, said Edward J. Gallagher, the city's budget director. He said the city reduced trash collection, recreation programs and library services, and closed four fire units. "We're continuing to down-size government," he said.
Nashville, with a $1.2 million shortage on a $702 million budget, is eliminating 80 of its 2,050 jobs in police and fire departments, and is closing 40 of its 208 hospital beds.
Miami, short $16 million on a $198 million budget, eliminated 207 jobs, but has found other areas to cut; the city sold $1 million worth of city cars and ended a program that gave $1.3 million to arts programs.
 
'We Did Everything'
 Walter C. Kraemer, budget director of Virginia Beach, Va, said, "We did everything from buying fewer library books to reducing road maintenance" in the current fiscal year. After rapid growth in the 1980's the city is adjusting to a $15.4 million budget gap.
Taxes are an unpopular option, but most cities have raised fees and fines, and 40 percent raised property taxes, the National League of Cities reported. San Antonio, for instance, increased property taxes by 8 percent this fiscal year and Long Beach, Calif., increased utility taxes by 2 percent.
Philadelphia, which has a $229 million deficit, eliminated 1,700 positions from its work force in the last fiscal year, and reduced spending this fiscal year by $65 million by cutting back on services like street cleaning and programs for the homeless.
A plan to save the city from bankruptcy remains elusive, since city officials are relying on more state and Federal assistance that may not be forthcoming. "The state's billion dollar deficit this year makes it even more difficult for the city to expect help from the state," said Robert C. Jubelirer, a Republican from western Pennsylvania who is president pro tempore of the Republican-led State Senate.
State officials have also insisted that as a precondition to any new state aid to the city, a state control board be established to oversee the city's finances.

HEADLINE: After Release From Foster Care, Many Turn to Lives on the Streets

BYLINE: By J. C. BARDEN

 BODY:
A large and disproportionate number of the nation's homeless are young people who have come out of foster care programs without the money, skills or family support to make it on their own.
Some left foster care for the streets because of an inability to adjust to their foster families or to group homes. Others managed life as blue-collar or service workers until they lost their jobs in the economic slowdown. 
 Still others simply never learned the basics of existence, like finding and keeping a job and a place to live.
Experts in the field do not fault the concept of foster care, in which a child ideally in the temporary custody of the state lives with a foster family or in a group home while social workers try to sort out the problems in the child's family. This type of intervention, experts say, has saved many young troubled people from fruitless lives.
 
A System Overwhelmed
 But they say foster care systems around the country are being overwhelmed because of the growing number of children in them and the lack of government money to finance them. The experts also say that many states may be hurting youths in foster care by releasing them from the system at the age of 18, before they are emotionally or professionally able to manage alone.
For whatever the reason, four studies have confirmed what has long been hinted in informal surveys of homeless populations: People formerly in foster care are vastly over-represented among the homeless. The studies, in different parts of the country, found that the percentage ranged from 38 percent in Minneapolis to about 13 percent in rural Ohio.
"The foster care kids are there, and there is no question about it, by whatever standard of measure you use," Prof. Irving Piliavin of the University of Wisconsin, who led the study in Minneapolis, said in a recent telephone interview.
 
Some Will Lead Chaotic Lives
 There are now more than 360,000 youths in foster care. About one-third of those are at risk of leading chaotic lives, ranging from homelessness to criminality, a recently published study led by a Columbia University professor estimated. Still another survey, this one under way in San Francisco, has indicated that about half of those who leave foster care for the streets turn to trading sex for meals or a place to sleep.
A 17-year-old in San Francisco who did, Valerie M., was in seven group homes or family homes before running away from the last one several months ago. Valerie, who was placed in foster care at the age of 13 after repeated sexual assaults by her stepfather, said she had reached the point where she did not want anyone to tell her what to do.
"So many placements try to act like parents," she said in a recent telephone inteview, "and I refuse to to let anyone else tell me how to run my life."
Valerie, who is now living in an abandoned housing project with her boyfriend, said she spends most days at the Larkin Street Youth Center, a private organization that provides food, medical care and counseling for young people in need.
Experts say the adjustment to foster care is particularly difficult for young people who were physically or sexually abused by their parents. "These kids are a lot harder to handle because of the psychological damage they've suffered," said Diane Flannery, executive director of the Larkin Street Youth Center. "They don't trust adults, so for the foster care relationship to get going is almost impossible."
 
Not Enough Aid
 Ms. Flannery, like other experts interviewed, was not critical of the concept of foster care. They said foster care could be lifesaving for young people subjected to abuse and neglect in families devastated by drugs, alcohol and poverty.
But these experts said the foster care systems of almost every state were overwhelmed because of insufficient money from the Federal, state and local governments. They cited Family Court judges who have too little time to make decisions that will determine a child's future; children placed in foster care by social workers because of a lack of programs to aid troubled families, and young people placed in incompatible group and family homes by undertrained workers who do not have time to monitor them properly.
The experts were also critical of foster care systems that stop paying for foster care when young people turn 18 and force them into the working world before many are ready to make their own way. New York is one of the handful of states that retains an obligation to youths in foster care to the age of 21.
"The vast majority of 18-year-olds are not ready to live on their own in the best of circumstances," said Rich Gordon, executive director of Youth and Family Assistance, a private group in Redwood City, Calif., that helps youths in need. "And the youngsters in foster care have never had the kind of childhood we think of as normal. They have not completed the task of being children, and yet the system demands they become independent at 18."
The New York State foster care system raised its age limit to 21 in the mid-1980's after advocates for the homeless won a lawsuit on behalf of a group of young people who had been discharged from the foster care system on their 18th birthdays and subsequently became homeless. Many states that say their obligations to foster care youths end at 18 do make exceptions, like allowing the youths to complete high school or a vocational course if it can be done before they turn 19.
Now, advocacy groups are pushing all states to raise their foster care age limits to 21. Congress last year raised the age limit to 21 on the Federal Foster Care Independent Living Program, a program that helps these youths learn to manage life on their own. And the American Civil Liberties Union has begun pressing for expanded independent living plans in lawsuits aimed at forcing states to spend more money to improve their systems.
But the independent living programs, which are run by the states, vary in intensity, from little more than two-day seminars to two-year plans that include setting up the young people in their own quarters.
"These crash courses in how to battle a budget and get a job are not going to make a big difference if you're not equipped to interact with people who are going to be your employer," said Della Hughes, director of the National Network of Runaway and Youth Services, an information and lobbying group for about 500 youth shelters around the country.
 
Lack of Necessary Skills
 The lack of skills that are necessary in a more technical marketplace and the absence of family members to lean on in hard times were mentioned repeatedly by the experts as major factors in the homelessness of former foster care youths.
An example is Warren Gage, 31, who has been living in homeless shelters in St. Louis for a year after the painting jobs that had sustained him for 15 years dried up and he was evicted from his apartment for not paying the rent.
Mr. Gage said he was placed in foster care when he was 14 because his mother physically abused him. He ran away a year later when the court ordered him returned to his own home. "I wasn't going back to any more whippings with an extension cord," said Mr. Gage, who had managed through work and friends to have someplace to live. Now his work is reduced to the jobs he sometimes gets on a daily basis, with his home now one of the five shelters run by the New Life Evangelistic Center in St. Louis.
When it is not possible to keep a troubled family together, foster care can be the best choice. The study led by the Columbia University professor, David Fanshel of the School of Social Work, found that 60 percent of 585 children who had been in foster care in five Western states were leading stable lives seven years after leaving. Another 20 percent were sent back to the courts because they could not get along in their foster homes, and a high proportion of these youths later became involved in crime. An additional 20 percent returned home, with many having problems in leading independent lives later.
The report concluded that about one-third of those in foster care are in danger of leading unstable lives, which could range from being street people to criminals, Professor Fanshel said. The study, "Foster Children in a Life Course Perspective," was published in November by Columbia University Press.
 
An Estimate on Homelessness
 While that study did not try to estimate the number of former foster children who had become homeless, another did. Richard P. Barth, an associate professor in the School of Social Welfare at the University of California at Berkeley, studied 55 people who had left foster care in the San Francisco Bay area in recent years, Of them, 29 percent reported that they had no home or were moving from week to week, while 39 percent said they sometimes or often had problems with housing. The study was reported in the October ssue of Child and Adolescent Social Work Journal.
In a study still in progress, researchers at the College of Social Work at Ohio State University found that 13.4 percent of 921 homeless adults interviewed in 21 randomly selected rural Ohio counties had lived outside their homes during adolescence. This figure included a small number who had been in juvenile detention centers, said Prof. Beverly G. Toomey, one of those involved in the study.
A study in Chicago found that 14.5 percent of the homeless people had been in foster care at some point. The study, led by Michael R. Sosin, a professor at the University of Chicago's School of Social Service Administration, questioned 535 of the people who obtained their main meal of the day free at 31 sites. Professor Sosin said this method is much more accurate than interviewing people in shelters.
In the Minneapolis study, conducted by Professor Piliavin and the University of Wisconsin's Institute for Research on Poverty, 337 people were interviewed at nine meal sites.
Harder and Kibbe Research, a private firm, is conducting the San Francisco study that found about a half of the youths who had been in foster care were among those using sex to survive. Researchers began following 50 young people who fit this description two years ago in a three-year study intended to assess the effectiveness of state programs to help these youths.
Using "survival sex" seemed to most of the young people as the easiest way to go, said Paul Harder of Harder and Kibbe Research, because two-thirds of them had been sexually abused at home.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Islamic Bloc Gains in Jordan, Provoking Unease

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 4

 BODY:
A shake-up of Jordan's Cabinet this week has increased concern in this capital about the growing strength of Islamic fundamentalists and touched off an intense debate about how best to contain them.
Many officials and prominent Jordanians are disturbed by Prime Minister Mudar Badran's decision to bring 5 members of the Muslim Brotherhood into his 23-member Cabinet. Mr. Badran announced on Tuesday that the fundamentalists would head the ministries of social development, health, education, religious affairs and justice. 
 Mr. Badran said the Government had little choice but to make concessions to the Brotherhood, whose members have dominated Parliament for a year, ever since the country's first parliamentary elections in 22 years. Their inclusion was required, he and others said, to avoid parliamentary paralysis or debilitating divisions over how to respond to the growing financial and political pressures on Jordan caused by King Hussein's refusal to join the American-led coalition against Iraq.
Bringing the Brotherhood into the Government, they maintained, would require its members to share responsibility for Jordan's problems, help split the movement and tame its most hard-line elements.
 
Officials Reported Alarmed
 But some senior officials are said to have warned that such "appeasement" risks further enhancing the substantial influence of the Islamic bloc and its ability to advance what many charge is its unstated goal of overturning the monarchy in favor of an Islamic government. They said that opposition to the Brotherhood's inclusion in the Cabinet was a major factor in the departure of Marwan al-Kasim, the Foreign Minister, as part of the Cabinet shuffle. Mr. Kasim, a 29-year government veteran, had angered fundamentalist leaders by openly challenging several of their proposals.
Mr. Kasim was also accused, particularly by leftist secular members of the Parliament, of pursuing a "Jordan first" policy that meant less than staunch support for Iraq, despite statements by King Hussein that Washington and its Arab allies have interpreted as openly sympathetic to Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi President. Mr. Kasim was said to be increasingly concerned about Jordan's isolation.
Mr. Kasim was replaced by Taher al-Masri, a Jordanian of Palestinian origin who, until his latest appointment, was chairman of the foreign affairs committee of the lower house of Parliament. Mr. Masri, who was Foreign Minister from 1984 to 1988, has shown stronger public support for Iraq and has advocated better ties with the P.L.O. along with "political, if not mechanical linkage" of the Persian Gulf crisis and the Palestinian problem.
 
'Both the King's Men'
 Arab and Western diplomats, however, said they did not believe that Jordan's foreign policy would change dramatically. "They are both the King's men," said a diplomat of Mr. Masri and Mr. Kasim.
Mr. Masri agreed. "This country's foreign policy will not change," he said. "There will continue to be harmony between the feelings of the public and the policy of this Government, including toward Iraq."
Several political analysts said Mr. Masri's appointment might reinforce the impression in the West that King Hussein was siding with extremism in deference to the prevailing mood among Jordan's Palestinians, who make up more than half of the population. But some maintained that choosing domestic popularity at the expense of political support from the West and economic support from Saudi Arabia and the other gulf nations could endanger his rule.
Mr. Masri defended the inclusion of the Muslim Brotherhood in the Government. "Their influence, not only in the Parliament, but also on the street, is evident," he said. "We have to admit it. That's democracy."
While Jordan has had free elections, King Hussein still controls Government policy and the composition of the Cabinet. But even though Parliament's authority is still sharply limited, realistically the King cannot ignore it.
Earlier this week, King Hussein approved a national charter endorsing constitutional rule, political pluralism and the legalization of political parties, which had been banned for years. The King said he hoped the moves would help counter the Brotherhood's radicals.
 
'A Calculated Risk'
 Some analysts said that the King had decided to move out ahead of the growing public support for the Muslim fundamentalists here. Several Jordanians noted that King Hussein had grown a beard, which is associated with Islamic devotion. Still others said the Cabinet shuffle would defuse the Brotherhood.
"The Brotherhood is already splitting between those who wanted to be part of this Government and those who didn't," said Kamel Abu Jaber, a political scientist. "Sure this is a calculated risk, but I think under the circumstances it is hard to think of an alternative."

HEADLINE: I.R.S. Sees Evidence of Wide Tax Cheating on Child Care

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
The Internal Revenue Service has striking new evidence that large numbers of Americans have been cheating on their taxes, claiming deductions for children who do not exist and child-care credits for baby sitters who are paid cash under the table.
In 1989 the agency began requiring taxpayers who take the dependent-care credit to give the name, address and Social Security number of the baby sitter or day care center they paid. The new rule was intended to force child-care providers to report and pay taxes on their income and to give employers an incentive to put the baby sitter on the books. The year the rule went into effect, thousands of day-care providers began reporting income, but 2.6 million baby sitters effectively vanished, since the number of taxpayers claiming the credit dropped by 30 percent. 
 "What probably happened in most cases is that people were paying their baby sitters off the books, and their baby sitters would not provide their Social Security number or go on the books, so the family had to choose between finding a new baby sitter or giving up the tax credit," said John Szilagyi, an I.R.S. researcher who is compiling the results of the new law.
Only 6.1 million taxpayers claimed a dependent-care credit in 1989, as against 8.7 million in 1988.
 
$1.2 Billion Revenue Gain
 The dependent-care credit can be claimed by any taxpayer who is paying someone to care for a dependent child or disabled adult so that the taxpayer can work. For those with two or more dependents, the credit can be as much as $1,440 a year, or 30 percent of up to $4,800 in child-care expenses.
Mr. Szilagyi estimated that the I.R.S. collected an additional $1.2 billion from the 2.6 million families who stopped taking the dependent-care credit in 1989.
Although the law requires families to pay Social Security taxes for any household employee who earns more than $50 per calendar quarter, most families do not comply.
Child care has always been an informal, off-the-books industry, made up of baby sitters who come to a child's own home and the far more common day-care arrangements, in which a woman takes care of several children in her own home. One I.R.S. study found that 80 percent of such family day-care providers did not report their income.
 
Going on the Books
 While the new law apparently led more than two million families to give up the tax credit, it also prompted many day-care providers to put their operations on the books for the first time. Mr. Szilagyi said the number of child-care businesses reporting income to the I.R.S. rose to 429,569 in 1989 from 261,372 in 1988, an increase of 64 percent.
"It's a good thing to go on the books if it brings better professional status and better pay," said Barbara Reisman, executive director of the Child Care Action Campaign, a national advocacy group. "It can also mean that day-care providers become eligible for Social Security, unemployment and disability, which can be very important."
Another change in the tax law has yielded even more blatant evidence of widespread cheating. Starting in 1987, the I.R.S. required that taxpayers report the Social Security number of all dependents over the age of 5. That year 7 million American children disappeared from the nation's tax returns, representing a 9 percent drop in the 77 million dependents claimed the previous year and $2.9 billion more in yearly tax revenue.
 
Some Nonexistent Dependents
 The tax agency said about 20 percent of the vanished dependents were children who had been claimed as dependents by both parents after a divorce. Under the law, only one parent may claim the child as a deduction.
Most of the others probably never existed, Mr. Szilagyi said. And some families apparently became quite greedy in creating dependents, each worth a $1,080 deduction in 1986, and $1,900 in 1987.
About 66,000 taxpayers who claimed four or more dependents in 1986 claimed none in 1987, after the Social Security identification rule went into effect. And more than 11,000 families claimed seven or more dependents in 1986, but none in 1987.
Those returns are now under investigation, with more than 1,000 audits in which the 1986 dependents were disallowed, and back taxes and fines collected. Mr. Szilagyi said some cases of apparent fraud have also been referred to the authorities for criminal investigation.
 
'Big Areas of Abuse'
 "In any individual family, you can imagine that one or two children might legitimately have stopped being dependents in 1987, but it's hard to imagine a legitimate situation in which a taxpayer had seven dependents one year and none the next," said Mr. Szilagyi, who drafted the proposal to require Social Security numbers from dependents and baby sitters.
Mr. Szilagyi said his research indicates that there are probably four million to five million more dependents being claimed illegally, either because they are fictitious or do not legally qualify as dependents.
The I.R.S. is now checking the Social Security numbers provided in an effort to winnow out nonexistent numbers or those claimed on another return. As of this year, taxpayers must provide Social Security numbers for all dependents over a year old.
"We knew from our sample audits that the dependent deductions and the child-care credit were big areas of abuse, and relatively easy ones to check," Mr. Szilagyi said. "There are other areas we're looking at, including hobby losses and real estate taxes, where we may have some proposals."
