HEADLINE: Nobel Physicist Raises Alarm on U.S. Science

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Despite the nation's growing budget problems, the next president of the country's largest general science organization plans to recommend that the Federal Government double the amount of money it spends on science.
In a report stunning for its assertiveness in the normally circumspect world of science policy, Dr. Leon Lederman, a Nobel prize winner in physics, raises questions about the future of scientific research in America and warns that the nation is losing its leadership role. 
 He hopes to raise an alarm by holding a news conference in Washington on Monday and sending copies of a report called "Science: End of the Frontier?" to 130,000 scientists and other members of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the organization he will lead starting in February.
After questioning 250 researchers at 50 universities, Dr. Lederman said in the report that their responses "paint a picture of an academic research community beset by flagging morale, diminishing expectations and constricting horizons."
 
'Once Upon a Time'
 Dr. Lederman, a professor at the University of Chicago, added, "From one institution to the next, across demographic categories, across disciplines of research, the nation's scientists are sending a warning: Academic research in the United States is in serious trouble."
The report continued: "Once upon a time, American science sheltered an Einstein, went to the moon, and gave to the world the laser, the electronic computer, nylon, television, the cure for polio. Today, we are in the process, albeit unwittingly, of abandoning this leadership role."
Dr. Lederman recommended doubling the Federal budget for science over the next few years, and following that with annual increases of 8 to 10 percent. The Federal Government spent $7.8 billion in 1989 to support basic and applied research at colleges and universities.
Though its conclusions have been voiced before, the report has already set off a clattering debate in the quiet circles of science policy. Dr. Lederman has broken with etiquette in science politics by saying that science is so important that it cannot be made to take the kind of budget cuts that other fields must suffer.
 
A Distaste for Pleading
 Among science policy professionals in Washington, Dr. Lederman's action was seen as bold because his organization has historically shied away from such public advocacy, and it has created some controversy because many scientists are not willing to engage in "special pleading like any other interest group," as one Congressional policy analyst said.
Dr. Lederman's case argues that Federal financing for science was only 20 percent more in 1990, when adjusted for inflation, than it was in 1968. But in the intervening years, the number of scientists with Ph.D.'s has more than doubled, the cost of instruments and laboratory buildings has gone up several-fold and the cost of paperwork and overhead have sharply risen.
One major factor is "sophistication inflation," he said in the report. "As our understanding of nature increases, the questions we need to answer become more complex," he said. "There is a corresponding increase in the sophistication (and cost) of the equipment needed to do research, both for small 'table top' experiments and large facilities such as telescopes and accelerators."
Dr. Lederman said he felt deeply about the matter and is determined to press the case even if he appears to be a special pleader. "I am well aware of the hesitations of some colleagues, hesitations based on the desire not to appear self-serving, not to bring science down to the level of 'just another interest group,' " he wrote. "However, if in fact U.S. science is at risk, then what course should we take? It is my opinion that the risks of appearing to be self-serving are far outweighed by the risks inherent in not making the case."
 
Choosing His 'Crowd'
 In a telephone interview, he said politicians could say to him: " 'We helped you and you still complain more than ever.' Well, that's true. But the fact is the American science is important to the future of the country. I need to get that across."
There are essentially "two crowds," he said. "One says show restraint; take our share of the budget cuts; make use of limited resources by setting priorities. The other crowd says we have to expand the base. Science is the best investment we can make, and we are now using up all the capital from our golden age, the late 1960's. I am clearly on the side of the second crowd."
Washington experts on science policy generally agree with Dr. Lederman that the United States is under-investing in science.
But there are also critics. As Michael Davey, a science and technology analyst at the Congressional Research Service, asked: "Is the Federal Government in business to make sure every Ph.D. gets funds? Shouldn't we look at the problems in cancer or AIDS or computer science, and ask whether we are spending the right amount before we talk about spending more?"
 
'Tough for the Politicians'
 Many of the science dollars must be allocated in the same Congressional committees that decide what is spent on housing and veterans affairs. "It makes it very tough for the politicians who have to look at housing and hospitals and make decisions about how to distribute the money," said Dr. Frank Press, president of the National Academy of Sciences, which is made up of the most prominent scientists in all fields of research.
Dr. D. Allan Bromley, the nation's top science policy officer in his job as the President's science adviser, said in a statement that Dr. Lederman's report "raises important issues that deserve, and are receiving, serious con sideration." But, he went on, "Federal support rose from $5 billion in 1968 (in 1988 dollars) to $8 billion in 1988."

HEADLINE: Art of a City Hall Labor Deal: 11 Months of Agony

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Compared with the momentous fiscal and political issues at stake for New York City, the final point settled in the labor contracts for many municipal workers last week was tiny and arcane.
After nearly a year of tortuous negotiations, the moment of truth arrived last Sunday night in the basement of Gracie Mansion, the Mayor's official residence. Mayor David N. Dinkins was face to face with two major union leaders, Stanley Hill and Barry Feinstein. 
 The last sticking point they resolved concerned vacation time for new employees that had been given up in a prior contract in exchange for adding the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday as a holiday. Some of the lost time would be restored, the three men agreed -- but not until July 1, 1991.
The value of that seemingly obscure change equaled a mere 0.2 percentage points out of a 5 percent total benefit and wage increase estimated to cost $233 million this fiscal year, ending June 30, and next.
But by agreeing on the restoration and thus settling the contracts, Mr. Dinkins made perhaps his single most important decision in the worsening financial crisis that has gripped his administration since its inception.
 
Deal Done, but Not Fighting
 "Finally someone said, 'We have a deal,' but I don't remember for sure who it was," said Eric J. Schmertz, the city's Labor Relations Commissioner. Mr. Feinstein, of the Teamsters, and Mr. Hill, of District Council 37, leaned across the table to shake the Mayor's hand.
But although the deal was done, the fighting was not over. Neither was the controversy about the contracts, nor the harsh feelings between some critical negotiators.
The most immediate result will be a raise for about 152,000 civil servants, nearly half the city government's work force. The $233 million settlement also set a precedent for the 130 other contracts remaining to be bargained, including those with police, fire and sanitation workers.
In its broader impact, the settlement appears to worsen the city's future budget gaps and increase the prospect of more tax rises, service cuts and layoffs.
 
Anger and Indecision
 An agreement on a higher raise was almost reached as early as May and again later, officials now say. But because of the city's steadily deteriorating finances and moments of anger and indecision during bargaining, those efforts collapsed.
The talks lurched along since February, in ever-changing formats. Sometimes they were formal sessions, with dozens of people arrayed along opposing sides of a 30-foot table in the Presidential Suite on the 21st floor of the Sheraton Centre hotel in midtown Manhattan. Other meetings and caucuses took place at City Hall, the office of the city's labor relations agency on Church Street and the Teamsters' headquarters near Manhattan's meatpacking warehouses on the lower West Side.
Some sessions lasted hours without progress, while some important overtures sprang from quick telephone calls, sidewalk encounters and hallway huddles.
One persistent obstacle was the unions' doubts about the severity of the city's finances. Even today they express skepticism on the need for widespread layoffs or a wage freeze next year. Critics of their settlement say it makes those unpleasant prospects all the more certain.
 
Mayor vs. 2 Close Allies
 The negotiations pitted the freshman Mayor and two of his closest political allies. As early backers of Mr. Dinkins's candidacy, Mr. Hill and Mr. Feinstein had been instrumental in his election.
Critics accused the Mayor of capitulating to the contract demands because of the unions' support. He rejected the charge. So did the unions, who said they found it paradoxical that their chosen Mayor had given them their roughest negotiations and smallest raise in more than a decade.
During most of the talks, the Mayor was not at the table. His team was led by his Labor Relations Commissioner, Mr. Schmertz, with First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel and Budget Director Philip R. Michael.
When the turning point came last weekend, however, Mr. Dinkins was there, wearing a green Super Bowl jacket.
 
Sessions Quicken
 After months of public and private wrangling, the talks had quickened with secluded sessions in Gracie Mansion's sedate museum room, where historic city artifacts are displayed. The Mayor met with the two union chiefs, Mr. Hill and Mr. Feinstein, and a handful of his top aides.
They assembled a puzzle with a few big pieces and a couple of little ones. The all-important raise was the 3.5 percent raise the first year. Then they extended the term by three months and added 1 percent to the raise for those months. They increased the health and welfare fund $100 a worker, equal to an 0.3 percent raise. Last came the vacation clause, which brought the total wage and benefit increase to 5 percent.
Besides the contracts, another vital understanding was reached. The Mayor would announce plans to freeze wages for the fiscal year beginning July 1; the unions would dissent now but postpone the fight til the next negotiations. Both sides agreed on the roles they would play.
Mr. Feinstein, president of the 12,000-member Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, is still steaming, characterizing the city's bargaining as "amateur night at the opera."
"The budget office kept changing their numbers all the time," Mr. Feinstein said in an interview. "They would say this is what our number is today, then the next day they would say that's not the real number -- here, it's something else. Nothing was the same tomorrow as it was yesterday. They made a mistake or miscalculated or forgot. It was always something."
Mr. Feinstein said that after he objected to the Budget Director, Mr. Michael, "they took him out of the loop, so he became a nonplayer."
But Mr. Michael said the budget numbers had changed not from errors but because economic conditions had kept eroding. And he said he had been kept fully apprised of the talks and had missed sessions only when preoccupied with the latest budget revisions.
 
Final Credit to Mayor
 Mr. Feinstein also complained that the administration team had fought among themselves."At one point we had a deal with Steisel," he said, "but the Mayor said no. I couldn't believe the First Deputy Mayor didn't have the authority to make a deal. At another point, Eric Schmertz recommended a settlement, but the Mayor blew that up, too."
Recollections from the other side differ. Mr. Steisel said he had been amenable to one proposal if its financing had withstood scrutiny, "but when we looked at the numbers, it didn't work."
Despite his dismay over some of the Mayor's earlier actions, Mr. Feinstein credited him with ultimately resolving the prolonged dispute in the final hours.
As soon as the city and the unions agreed on the contracts, they promptly disagreed on how to release the news. City officials wanted to do it the next day, Dec. 31. Unions leaders protested that the event would receive little notice.
 
Bad News the Next Day
 So the settlement was not announced until Wednesday -- three days after the official handshakes. In a full-dress news conference at City Hall, the Mayor and union leaders beamed smiles, patted each other on the back and praised the pact.
Critics of Mr. Dinkins's fiscal and labor policies, including Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier, assailed the contracts as irresponsible. They said the raise would worsen the deficit, service cuts and layoffs. The administration's rebuttal was that the raise was covered by reserves in the budget and by new pension savings, which critics called a precarious gimmick.
Now there is grumbling in the union ranks because the raise did not keep pace with inflation and failed to match the 5.5 percent raise and 0.3 percent benefit increase in a 12-month contract the city granted to teachers in October.
Although Mayor Dinkins declined to divulge details of the negotiations, saying "it would not be fruitful," other participants discussed the art and the agony of the city's premier labor deal.
Negotiations were almost settled in May, said a city official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. He was not a principal in the talks but monitored them closely.
As the lead union, the Teamsters were bargaining to renew a contract that expired in June. They thought they had an unofficial agreement for a one-year raise of about 5 percent. The teachers' union was expected to follow with a slightly bigger raise. But settling with the Teamsters was postponed until the summer to allow the city to finish its budget and start the fiscal year July 1.
 
Pledge Dropped With Revenues
 That delay proved crucial because the city's revenues deterioriated, and it could no longer honor the unofficial commitment. The same frustrating cycle was later repeated.
Also during the summer, Mr. Hill's 140,000-member union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, started its talks.
The teachers, meanwhile, threatened to strike if they did not have a new contract for the fall semester. Facing that deadline, the Mayor summoned Mr. Feinstein to Gracie Mansion the last weekend of September for one more attempt. A raise of about 4.5 percent was under consideration. But the Mayor's advisers were split, so he declined it.
Then the teachers' talks moved to the fore. The next day Mr. Dinkins announced their settlement.
The rest of that week spun wildly out of control. The Mayor announced a $1.8 billion crime-prevention program that would hire thousands more police officers. But then his press office suddenly issued a warning that falling revenues could result in at least 15,000 layoffs.
Mr. Hill and Mr. Feinstein, caught unaware by the layoff warning, denounced it as a betrayal.
Several weeks later the two labor leaders joined forces, held a news conference with the Mayor and began a new round of sessions, which also foundered. The unions broke off the formal talks but kept almost daily informal contacts, which eventually led them back to Gracie Mansion.

HEADLINE: Worker Mistakenly Cut Phone Cable

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
New York City's most important telephone link broke on Friday because an A.T.&.T. employee mistakenly snipped it with a large pair of wire-cutters while removing old cables, the company said yesterday.
Michael P. Tarpey, an American Telephone and Telegraph Company spokesman, said the damage was not caused by workers who were pulling out old cables and accidentally snagged and broke an active cable, as the company initially believed. 
 The worker, whom he did not identify, will not be disciplined, Mr. Tarpey said. "He didn't do it on purpose, and he's on a union contract," he said.
In a separate accident yesterday morning, 52,000 residents of northeastern Pennsylvania lost most or all long-distance service when a contractor drilling test holes for a sewer authority severed a fiber-optic cable belonging to Bell of Pennsylvania. Eric W. Rabe, a company spokesman, said such accidents happened several times a year in Pennsylvania and typically were fixed the same day.
 
Questions About Vulnerability
 The breakdown on Friday was the third time in a little more than two years that a large part of the A.T.&T. network failed because of a failure in a small piece of the complex system.
The incident raised two important questions in the minds of some regulators and telecommunications experts: Have technological changes made the nation's telephones more vulnerable? And has deregulation removed incentives for the long-distance giant to re-invest in equipment?
But some experts, and A.T.&T. itself, say those concerns are unfounded. They argue that competing companies effectively serve as a back-up if A.T.&T.'s system fails. And they point out that there is a limit to how much extra capacity can be built into the system economically -- it is easy to plan for slack periods, but the break on Friday morning occurred at a time when phone circuits are heavily loaded.
A.T.&T. crews in hard hats worked all night on Friday and through the day yesterday to replace their emergency repairs of the severed fiber-optic cable with sturdier permanent repairs.
 
Previous Breakdowns
 In the previous breakdowns in the A.T.&T. system, a cable break in November 1988 disrupted millions of East Coast calls for nine hours, and a faulty computer program shut down half the network on the afternoon and evening of Jan. 15, 1990.
The company's heavy dependence on a single cable surprised many experts because of New York's enormous reliance on telephone communications. According to a study released last May, residents and businesses in New York State make more local and long-distance calls each year than are made by the entire populations of France or the United Kingdom, each of which has about three times as many people. New York City alone accounts for a third of the country's international calls.
Some consumer groups have suggested in the past that the deregulation of A.T.&T. may be allowing the nation's largest long-distance network to deteriorate.
The Federal Communications Commission has gradually reduced its regulation of A.T.&T. since the company divested its local telephone companies on Jan. 1, 1984. And in July 1989, the agency abandoned so-called rate-of-return regulation, which had guaranteed the company a high return on all investments during its days as a monopoly and thereby gave it an incentive to spend heavily.
The F.C.C. replaced rate-of-return regulation with price-cap regulations, which allow A.T.&T. to set prices freely within a certain range and keep any profits that may result from cost reductions, including any cuts in investment. A.T.&T.'s smaller rivals, such as the MCI Communications Corporation and US Sprint, are not subject to either set of regulations because they are not former monopolies.
Consumer groups and some communications experts have expressed concern that price-cap regulations are giving A.T.&T. an incentive to save money and increase profits by cutting the quality of service and eliminating costly back-up systems.
 
Incentives to Invest
 "The incentives are to not overbuild, to have as lean and mean a network as possible," said Samuel A. Simon, a consultant and lawyer in Washington who works on telephone issues for consumer groups and phone companies. "Instead of gold-plating, now the issue is whether there's enough."
But A.T.&T. and the Federal Communications Commission contend that the new regulations give the company an incentive to invest more efficiently, and that competition from rivals like MCI and US Sprint forces A.T.&T. to maintain a reliable network or risk losing customers.
A.T.&T.'s annual investment in its network has been steady at $2.5 billion to $3 billion for several years, said Thomas H. Norris, an A.T.&T. vice president for regulatory affairs.
Competition in the long-distance market now provides the back-up capacity that once was the responsibility of A.T.&T., said Carl Oppedahl, a lawyer involved in telephone issues in New York. "You want a redundant network, you've got it: A.T.&T., MCI and Sprint," he said. "An anarchic terrorist could destroy one network, and you'd still have the other two."
Fiber-optic cables are more easily broken and carry more calls than the copper cables and microwave links they replace, so more people are affected by a single accident. Friday's accident occurred shortly before mid-morning, when calling volume typically peaks. A.T.&T.'s four alternative cables into New York City were already mostly full, making it harder for A.T.&T. to redirect calls.
But to install completely redundant equipment just to be ready for any cable failures would be very expensive and increase the cost of calling on the A.T.&T. network, the company says.
However, A.T.&T. is installing more sophisticated electronics in the network, which the company says will provide improved service and increase capacity, so that problems like the breakdown on Friday can be circumvented quickly.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
BUSH LEAVES OPEN TIMING OF ASSAULT ON IRAQ'S FORCES

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
President Bush said today that American military action against Iraq would not necessarily begin immediately after Jan. 15. But he warned President Saddam Hussein in a letter that he would "face destruction" if he did not withdraw his forces from Kuwait by that date, an Administration official said.
In a radio address delivered 10 days before the United Nations deadline, Mr. Bush said "time is running out" and that each additional day the United States waits to act could mean more casualties. 
 "We risk paying a higher price in the most precious currency of all -- human life -- if we give Saddam more time to prepare for war," Mr. Bush said.
 
No 'Secret Diplomacy'
 The President, who met today with the United Nations Secretary General to review the crisis, promised in his speech to explore a peaceful solution. But he said there would be no "secret diplomacy" when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d meets with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq in Geneva on Wednesday.
"Secretary Baker will restate, in person, a message for Saddam Hussein: Withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally and immediately, or face the terrible consequences," Mr. Bush said. [Text of his address, page 4.]
In an apparent effort to step up the pressure, Mr. Bush used blunter language in a letter that Mr. Baker is to hand Mr. Aziz in Geneva. A senior Administration official said the letter warns Mr. Hussein that he must withdraw his troops from Kuwait or "face destruction."
 
'Two Choices' for Hussein
 "The letter says to Saddam, you have two choices: Get out or we will use force, there will be a war," the official said. The purpose of the letter, the official said, is to "hand over something tangible that Saddam Hussein will have to read in case Tariq Aziz doesn't have the nerve to repeat our message word for word."
In Baghdad today, a senior Iraqi official said the Iraqi leadership still believed that a meeting in Baghdad between Mr. Baker and President Hussein should "not be excluded" from the final rounds of diplomacy. But Iraq rejected a meeting with the European Community, which on Friday offered to work to resolve all problems of the Middle East if the gulf crisis could be settled peacefully. [Page 4.]
Mr. Bush seems to be leaving himself some room to maneuver at a time when the United States expects a flurry of diplomatic activity -- perhaps even some new effort by Mr. Hussein.
Administration officials said the United States was approaching the meeting with Mr. Aziz with the expectation that the Iraqi official would come with some kind of surprise. The challenge for Washington, they said, was to find a way to continue to show a desire for a peaceful solution without raising public expectations or pressure to make a deal with Iraq.
Mr. Baker will be in London on Monday to meet with European Community officials. Mr. Bush has said he would reject any direct linkage between the gulf crisis and the plight of the Palestinians, but has not explicitly ruled out an approach like the one suggested by the European Community. The White House has otherwise been silent on the European offer to address Middle East issues generally, and Mr. Bush did not mention it in his speech, which was taped on Friday.
Asked about the proposal today, an Administration official said the White House considered it a "nonstarter" but did not want to get into a public dispute with its European allies about it. The official said the United States viewed the proposal as linking the gulf crisis with other Middle Eastern issues, but that the Europeans did not define it that way.
"It's a matter of semantics that's certainly not worth creating a hornet's nest about," the official said.
 
Meeting With U.N. Chief
 France, which had extracted the commitment from the community to help resolve other Middle East conflicts, also suggested that it would be "desirable" for the United Nations Security Council to meet again near Jan. 15 "before unleashing a war."
Mr. Bush met today at his Camp David retreat in Maryland with the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar. Mr. Bush said on Friday that while he did not see any need for further United Nations action, "I'd be interested to hear if the Secretary General feels to the contrary."
A White House statement issued after the meeting said the two men "discussed the general situation in the gulf, including diplomatic activities aimed at resolving the crisis in a peaceful manner." Mr. Bush had invited the United Nations leader to Camp David to compare notes. White House officials gave no indication that anything more than that had occurred.
In his radio address, Mr. Bush said, "We should go the extra mile before asking our servicemen and women to stand in harm's way," adding, "We should and we have." He called next week's meeting between Mr. Baker and Mr. Aziz "one more step."
 
'Time Is Running Out'
 "Eleven days from today, Saddam Hussein will either have met the United Nations deadline for a full and unconditional withdrawal, or he will have once again defied the civilized world," Mr. Bush said. "This is a deadline for Saddam Hussein to comply with the United Nations resolution, not a deadline for our own armed forces."
The remark seemed to give the President some leeway in case the meeting between Mr. Baker and Mr. Aziz produces some movement toward ending the stalemate in the Middle East. But Mr. Bush said: "Time is running out. It's running out because each day that passes brings real costs."
Mr. Bush, who has drawn criticism for not fully explaining his reasons for contemplating war, said that Iraq "already poses a strategic threat to the capital cities of Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Israel and Syria" with its missiles and warplanes.
 
Burden of Rising Oil Prices
 He noted that Iraq has chemical weapons, and he repeated his assertion that "each day that passes brings Saddam Hussein further on the path to developing biological and nuclear weapons and the missiles to deliver them."
"If Saddam corners the world energy market, he can then finance further aggression," Mr. Bush said. "Each day that passes increases Saddam's worldwide threat to democracy."
The President also raised an economic argument: higher oil prices are "a crushing burden" that the new democracies in Eastern Europe and Latin America cannot afford. "Our own economy is suffering," he said, "suffering the effects of higher oil prices and lower growth stemming from Saddam's aggression."
He said the economic sanctions imposed on Iraq by the United Nations "are taking a toll, but they are still not forcing Saddam out of Kuwait."
"Nor do we know when or even if they will be successful," he said.

HEADLINE: PRO HOCKEY;
Rangers Prevail in Overtime as Nicholls Scores

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 5

 BODY:
The red light went on and then in an instant the riot of a celebration was under way, the Rangers pouring over the bench in exhaustion and shock, a 3-2 overtime victory over the Blues officially recorded in the National Hockey League books even if it had not yet fully registered in their consciousness.
The Rangers, wiped out by a grueling series of games and a draining 62 minutes of close checking and cheap shots, nonetheless manufactured the drama to defeat the Blues when Bernie Nicholls tucked a loose puck under Vincent Riendeau and inside the far post with 1 minute 48 seconds remaining in overtime. 
 Nicholls, slicing in front of the crease as Normand Rochefort let a blast go from the left point, scooped the bouncing puck into the net for his 17th goal of the season and thus sent his teammates bouncing off the bench.
The celebration ended, the Rangers streamed for the exits and the start of the trip back to New York, possessors of a perfect 2-0 record on a road trip that concluded with their third game in four nights, their sixth in nine days. It also lengthened their lead in the Patrick Division to 7 points over the Flyers and ran their mark for the season to 24-13-7.
 
Big Night for Hull
 The climactic goal also negated and abruptly ended Brett Hull's latest night of terror. The right wing for the Blues with dynamite in his wrists and an almost unfathomable 41 goals in 41 games scored 2 against the Rangers tonight.
But the Rangers, having absorbed the impact of Hull's relentless offensive onslaught, were not defeated by it, and Hull was on the bench when the game sudenly ended, his sublime skills rendered useless by Nicholls's impromptu magic.
Hull, who tends to lurk inconspicuously before he pounces, pumped his second goal of the game behind Mike Richter 11:50 into the second period to give the Blues their second advantage of the game. In his trademark style of making no great moves but no mistake with the puck once presented with an opening, Hull trailed the play into the offensive zone and slid to the slot when Jeff Brown cranked up an uncontested slap shot from the right face-off circle.
Richter kicked out Brown's shot, but then could only close his eyes and dive once the puck trickled straight to the stick of Hull at 10 paces. The squat right wing promptly nailed his 41st goal of the season to the back of Richter's net.
Darren Turcotte, as John Ogrodnick had done earlier in the period, equalized affairs by depositing a power-play rebound goal with a wicked economy at 17:16 of the period to send the game into the third squared at 2-2.
Hull, on one knee, had given the Blues the game's first goal at 8:15 of the first. The Rangers, undermanned and undecided about how to combat the St. Louis power play, were ultimately outmaneuvered in a fatal sequence that left Hull alone at the lower rim of the left circle. Richter had no look at Hull's quick redirection of Adam Oates's soft pass across the slot.
 
SMITH PLEASED WITH PROSPECTS
 Neil Smith, the general manager of the Rangers, returned from a scouting trip at the junior world championships enthusiastic about the performances of Steven Rice of Canada and Doug Weight of the United States, two forwards who are among the organization's top prospects. "Weight does a lot of things well," Smith said of the American center, who plays for Lake Superior State and who accumulated 18 points in seven games for the United States team. "He's a good skater, a strong defensive player, his size is O.K. and he can handle the puck." Of Rice, the captain of the Canadian team, which won the gold medal, Smith said, "He could have been the strongest player in the tournament." Rice, who played in nearly a dozen games for the Rangers at the start of the season before being returned to his junior team, is expected to return to the club before the start of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
A Hemmed-in Congress, Cranky From Gavel to Gavel

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN the 102d Congress convened last week, the usual heady talk of prospects for vital new initiatives was drowned out by grousing over what will never be accomplished thanks to the threat of war in the Persian Gulf and the budget constraints at home.
Perhaps it was the possibility of combat or that a surprising number of lawmakers had close brushes with defeat in November, but many said the climate was unusually tense and uncomfortable. 
 Representative Jerry Lewis, a California Republican, for one, saw signs that this session might be the least civil in his 12 years in Congress. Moments after House members took the oath of office on Thursday, he said, the back-slapping gave way to impatient gavel-pounding and flaring tempers over a successful move by Democrats to push through a measure that would alter provisions of last year's budget agreement.
"It's already a tense environment," said Mr. Lewis, chairman of the House Republican Conference. "The whole institution came close to falling apart this last session. Now it may get even worse."
Indeed, anxiety among members seems far greater than when the session opened a year ago. The jubilant talk then that the end of the Cold War would yielda "peace dividend" for domestic programs long forgotten. Now the speculation is over how many billions of dollars Operation Desert Shield will cost.
As he roamed the Capitol corridors shortly after the session opened, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, a Texas Democrat and chairman of the Finance Committee, could think of few new proposals with a chance of being enacted. "You're going to have much more in the way of extraordinary constraints, considering the budget agreement," he said. "And you've got a wild card in the cost of Desert Shield."
But not all lawmakers saw it that way. Thomas S. Foley, the House Speaker, insisted that there will be "some room for expansion of domestic" programs, though he acknowledged there would be tough decisions about shifting spending priorities.
And Representative Constance A. Morella, a Maryland Republican, predicted that "the fact that there's such anxiety and concern about the gulf is going to goad Congress into pushing itself into other issues." Collectively, she said, the new Congress was unusually serious, with "people who want to concentrate their energy on accomplishing something."
 
Examining New Options
 Members say the initiatives with the best prospects will be those prompted by either the gulf conflict or recession. Normally, lawmakers would endeavor to pep up the faltering economy by cutting taxes and encouraging the creation of new jobs, options that seem unrealistic in the current fiscal climate.
But Congressional leaders say they are examining other options, such as expanding unemployment insurance, and many said they would back a major proposal to rebuild the nation's crumbling public facilities. Everyone on Capitol Hill, it seems, is talking "infrastructure." It is an issue whose time has come, Mr. Foley said, recession or no. "The infrastructure bill is something that is important to do in any event," the Speaker said."I believe we're tragically behind in catching up to the deterioration of highways, airports, various kinds of public facilities."
Tensions with Iraq, meanwhile, have rekindled interest in some moribund energy issues, such as the formulation of a national policy to promote the development and conservation of domestic energy sources.
Issues with no crisis cachet are likely to float to the top of the legislative agenda only if they lack dollar signs. One such proposal is to grant three months of unpaid leave to workers with new babies or sick family members, a measure that President Bush vetoed last year.
House Democrats have have already begun one effort to push legislation that Mr. Bush vetoed, by introducing, as the first bill of the new year, legislation that would make it easier for minorities and women to prove employment discrimination.
Such measures may stand a better chance of enactment this year because Democrats picked up one seat in the Senate and nine in the House, which may make it more difficult for Mr. Bush to continue his record of never having a veto overridden. The new Congress may also have a stronger left wing than its predecessor, with new liberals including Senator Paul Wellstone, a Minnesota Democrat who was an anti-war demonstrator, and Neil Abercrombie, who won back a seat for the Democrats in Hawaii and took part in radical causes in the 1960's.
In a preview of what leading Democrats are pushing, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, chairman of the Labor and Human Resources Committee, has scheduled hearings beginning this week on such issues as needs of the workforce in times of recession and proposals for universal health insurance. And, once again, lawmakers are also pledging to overhaul the campaign finance system.
Although Congress is taking up issues earlier than usual because the members have assembled to address the Persian Gulf crisis, it is often the President who sets the legislative agenda, and his State of the Union address is not scheduled until Jan. 29.
But some experts argue that a humdrum legislative session is unavoidable. Stephen Hess, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said that what with the gulf crisis, the deficit and redistricting, the new Congress will be nowhere as productive as the 101st, which was vilified because of the budget stalemate but still passed notable measures like the child care and clean air bills.
"The combination of simply not having any money," Mr. Hess said, "and the unique political constellation that comes with redistricting, means that it is not going to be a memorable Congress."
In fact, with expected partisan sniping over the economy and issues such as civil rights, he added, "I think it's going to be one of those especially unpleasant Congresses before we're finished."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 3; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 1183 words

HEADLINE: The Region;
Layoffs and Cutbacks And 5 Percent Raises

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
NEW YORKERS got a small, bitter taste of the future last week. The city closed three fire companies, the first of 41 that may eventually be shut. It shifted traffic agents to replace more than 150 it has already lost. It began the process of laying off 280 workers in a purge that might trim more than 7,000 employees from the municipal payroll in the coming weeks. And it prepared a financial plan that seemed likely to make the city even less livable in dozens of different ways for years.
None of the austerity, though, stopped two large municipal unions from securing for their members raises and benefits that would amount to a 5 percent increase over 15 months, or the administration of David N. Dinkins from arguing that it was a fair settlement, and the best deal it could get. 
 The situation reminded some of the confusing week in October when, on successive days, the city announced that teachers would get a 5.8 percent raise in wages and benefits, put forth a plan to raise taxes to hire more police officers, imposed a job freeze and finally warned that 15,000 layoffs might be needed.
Now as then, fiscal experts wondered whether the administration, or Mr. Dinkins himself, had fully grasped the weakness of the city's economy and the constraints that placed on the municipal government, despite ever more gloomy news from the administration's own budget office.
"I think that's certainly true, that we're in a crisis," Mr. Dinkins said when asked late last week about budget gaps now estimated to have widened to $500 million for the current year and perhaps $2 billion for the next one.
But to Felix G. Rohatyn, departing chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which has watched over the city's finances since it nearly went bankrupt in 1975, the latest labor settlement seemed to suggest business as usual, or an uncomfortably close approximation of it.
"It really does seem that there is no sense of impending crisis here," he said, "because if there were, these negotiations would not have come to this conclusion."
The criticism from Mr. Rohatyn, who played a central role in resolving the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's, was no surprise. Once a Dinkins adviser, he had likened the administration's actions in October to parts of a Calder mobile that hang in the air with "their own motion and their own life."
Even the administration was acknowledging that it had boxed itself in by settling first with the teachers, who are underpaid compared with their suburban counterparts and so had the strongest argument for a raise. Given New York's me-too brand of bargaining, the 5.8 percent increase they won became the target for the other unions.
 Because the contracts depend in large part on money the city would otherwise contribute to worker pension funds, the administration could claim that they would not add to the budget gaps. The contracts' structure -- 3.5 percent in the first year and the rest thereafter -- make them cheaper than they appear. And officials hinted that they might get some of the money back, when the January budget plan is announced and unions interested in keeping more members on the payroll might be willing to make concessions. (Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez has already suggested that the schools might be closed for three days in the spring and workers furloughed without pay to avoid laying off thousands of employees.)
Settling the contracts now also enables the city to draw up a budget plan with fewer uncertainties and establishes a climate of labor peace that may be valuable in even tougher times later on.
Those who defend the Mayor's fiscal vigilance note that one of his first press releases announced that a police class would be delayed because of budget problems. He has already cut the city's capital expenditure budget, which relies on borrowed money and thus has served a symbol of the city's restored creditworthiness. And after he worked hard to reassure Wall Street, the latest batch of city bonds sold out, though at slightly higher interest rates than the city had hoped.
Even so, the new contracts, combined with the ever-worsening budget problems, suggested to Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, an independent research organization sponsored by businesses, that the Mayor might be receiving "divided counsel."
"I think there's been an enduring split within his administration over whether to sit back to see if things will get better," Mr. Horton said, "or plunge ahead on the assumption that they are not going to get better and take decisive action."
Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board, another monitor of city finances, said he was disappointed with what he saw as the administration's lack of long-term planning. When he has discussed contingencies with the administration, he said, "The answer was always, 'We'll cross that bridge when we come to it.' "
Mr. Dinkins's inauguration on a frosty morning a year ago was the culmination of years spent negotiating the treacherous currents of city politics. His campaign, which stressed innovative approaches to social ills, raised expectations. His being the city's first black mayor no doubt increased them. Which can only make the progressively worsening fiscal news he has received since taking office, the result of a faltering city economy, mounting job losses and slumping consumer spending, that much harder to bear.
The man who brings him the dismal numbers, Philip R. Michael, the city budget director, said Mr. Dinkins "absolutely takes it all in and appreciates what is going on, but he very steadfastly rejects the idea that he should have a knee-jerk reaction to it."
Mr. Michael has been going over the financial plan with the Mayor line by line and agency by agency. While Mr. Dinkins's deliberateness can sometimes be frustrating, it can also lead to deep reflection on the consequences of cuts. For instance, Mr. Michael recalled, when they got to the Human Resources Administration, caretaker for the city's impoverished and abused, Mr. Dinkins posed a question pointing up how numbers on a budget sheet could affect lives: "Whose babies are these we're talking about?"
In appearances before corporations and business organizations, the Mayor has stressed the importance of a balanced budget to the point where he has sounded to some like his predecessor, Edward I. Koch. But Mr. Horton said that in some respects Mr. Dinkins brought to mind Abraham D. Beame, who also assumed office after a long public career and as the city's economy was tumbling. Back then, Mr. Horton said, there was "a profound feeling that this just couldn't be happening."
It is true that even as the Beame government was facing its bleakest hour the city was about to begin a spectacular economic resurgence that would result in hundreds of thousands of new jobs and annual budget surpluses of hundreds of millions of dollars. So maybe the fortunes of New York City, and Mr. Dinkins, will soon change.
But it is also true that Mr. Beame was a one-term mayor.

HEADLINE: The World;
Somalia, Abandoned To Its Own Civil War With Others' Weapons

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: NAIROBI , Kenya

 BODY:
IT has taken longer than many people thought, but the unraveling of Somalia, a small country that wraps like a boomerang around the eastern border of Ethiopia, is under way. Western nations started to weary of propping up one of Africa's most corrupt and brutal regimes two years ago. They regard last week's warfare in the capital, Mogadishu, as the final bloody coda: a struggle fought with rocket-propelled grenades, assault rifles and machine guns mounted on four-wheel-drive Toyotas stolen from aid agencies.
The current battle is more than the obvious one: an effort to oust President Mohammed Siad Barre, the octogenarian autocrat who has ruled the country for 21 years. It is a blood feud, fought between the President's Marehan clan, who constitute the bulk of the armed forces, and the more numerous middle-class Hawiye, who inhabit the center of the country around Mogadishu and make up the rebel United Somali Congress. 
 The authority of President Siad Barre, until recently a handsomely supported military ally of the United States, crumbled two years ago. That was when the Somali National Movement, formed by a third clan, the Isaaks from the north, returned to Somalia from Ethiopia as part of a peace treaty between the two countries.
The treaty ended 11 years of hostilities over control of the Ogaden, a desert area in eastern Ethiopia, and appeared to be one of the few promising developments in the ethnically fractious Horn of Africa. But to the surprise of President Siad Barre, the Isaak rebels returned home armed by Ethiopia, and won control of the northern section of Somalia. In that battle, a State Department report said, 5,000 unarmed Isaak civilians were purposely killed by the army, a brutality that began to stir second thoughts in Washington about its Somali client.
The United Somali Congress, a newer insurgency group, was formed about two years ago and is under the military leadership of Hawiye who defected from the Somali army, diplomats here say. These rebels seem to be armed mostly with weapons captured or bought from soldiers reportedly eager to sell their arms for money to buy food. In all, five clan-based rebel groups of various strengths are arrayed against the President.
For more than two decades, Somalia was little more than an expensive sideshow in the theater of the cold war. The Horn of Africa, with its proximity to the Middle East, was a region that both superpowers competed in. When he grabbed power nine years after independence in 1960 from Britain and Italy, President Siad Barre embraced socialism and was rewarded with weapons by the Soviets. But after neighboring Ethiopia, a traditional American ally, turned Marxist, the two superpowers switched sides. Moscow provided Ethiopia with military equipment for its war against Somalia and the United States won access to Somalia's port of Berbera on the Gulf of Aden. Between 1986 and 1988, Somalia received $100 million in military and economic aid from Washington.
The strategic value of Somalia has now diminished, but the legacy of all the weapons accounts for much of the ferocity of the current fighting, those who have fled the capital say. A typical Somali soldier, an evacuee said last week, wears an American-supplied uniform and brandishes a Soviet-made AK-47 rifle. But the soldiers at checkpoints in Mogadishu last week usually lounged, bare chested, in the shade of a tree, wore sandals and chewed chat, a leaf popular in the Horn of Africa for its marijuana-like qualities, according to aid workers who fled last week. The police, they added, were armed with modern Italian machine guns, and many civilians were armed with weapons purchased from "under the mangoes" at open street markets.
Washington pursued its support of President Siad Barre much longer than some people, including the American military attache at the in Mogadishu from 1987 to 1989, thought wise. The attache, Col. Alfred Girardi, wrote congressional offices after his retirement in mid-1989 that the Somali army was "poorly motivated due to a lack of pay and basic comforts, poorly led by inept officers and unfortunately tempted to salvage what they can by hook or crook."
Washington became disenchanted when President Siad Barre, in an effort to reassert his presence, unleashed the presidential guard, the Red Beret. The guards slaughtered hundreds during street demonstrations in July 1989, according to Western diplomats. In the last year, Washington has virtually cut off its aid. Even the Italians, the most stalwart of the regime's friends, dramatically cut back. The last straw for the Italians seemed to be the killing of an Italian professor: He wandered from his hotel one evening and was found hanged the next morning in the headquarters of the Red Beret.
The Libyans stepped into the breach last year, Western diplomats say. Two small passenger jets from Libya were seen at the Mogadishu airport after the latest round of fighting started, prompting speculation that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader who enjoys meddling in the region, was attempting to bring the President more arms.
With the fierce fighting and the lack of foreign aid, the economy of the nation of 6 million, most of them camel-herding nomads, has fallen apart, as have attempts at peace talks. Most Westerners say the only uncertain element is how long it will take to dislodge the President. Colonel Girardi, who thought President Siad Barre a lost cause, cautioned the Congress: "A future regime will lack the charismatic and singular ability of Siad Barre to juggle the many opposing factions and therefore with no true leader in sight, more turmoil and instability will result." That warning may now be coming true.

HEADLINE: Hussein's Handy Home Survival Guide

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq

 BODY:
SADDAM HUSSEIN doesn't talk much about the goals of Baath Party socialism these days. The party principles that ostensibly provide the ideological glue for the regime are largely forgotten, at least for the moment -- overtaken by a fierce pragmatism based on survival.
The invasion of Kuwait has accelerated a process of corrosion of party ideals that began several years before -- a process that reflects how much rule in Iraq under Saddam Hussein has become a matter not of ideology but of the exercise of personal power. 
 The Arab Baath Socialist Party was founded in Damascus in the 1940's by two French-educated Arabs. It saw its task as the creation of a new Arab man: disciplined, uncorrupted and committed to a romantic blend of Arab nationalism and mild socialism. But the ideology -- an artificial, secular hybrid whose principles were always vaguely stated -- never resonated among the people of Iraq in the same way, say, that religion did among the people of Iran.
Instead, the party structure in Iraq came under the domination of one man -- Saddam Hussein -- who has invoked the ideology when it suits his purposes and has strayed from it when other principles seem to be needed if he is to survive in power. The Baath Party also took root in Syria, but the party's two branches have split, with Saddam Hussein and the Syrian leader, Hafez al-Assad, each asserting that only he is the correct personality to lead the movement.
As an economic plan, Baath socialism didn't work, despite some early achievements; in Iraq, when the eight-year war with Iran ended in 1988, the promised earthly paradise of jobs, access to consumer goods, a lifting of wartime restrictions and expansion of the country's infrastructure didn't come. Now, with the invasion of Kuwait, the Iraqi people have been handed food rationing, bread lines, unemployment, more military service, a worthless currency and the threat of an all-out war with the United States.
Certainly, as a political organizing principle, the party structure still works here. The party carries out the food rationing system, buses in women and children for "spontaneous" demonstrations, mobilizes the masses for civil defense exercises and penetrates all segments of Iraqi life. But people can't eat ideology, and in a country where the price of eggs has risen 500 percent since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and rationing tickets buy less and less flour, sugar, tea and rice -- when they are available at all -- the lofty rhetoric had to be adjusted. Survival of the fittest now seems more important than collective sacrifice.
Under Mr. Hussein, Iraq has always succeeded in ruthlessly suppressing even the slightest hint of unrest. But the regime does not rule by terror alone. It survives because it has been supple enough to respond to the basic physical needs of the people. The philosophy of governing is best expressed in two key words: "tarhib" -- terror -- and "targhib" -- enticement.
For the moment, to insure that private grumbling does not burst into public protest, the regime has introduced a new level of flexibility that is often in conflict with the discipline that is supposed to be at the core of the new Baath Arab man. The regime closed the traditional tea houses of Baghdad after the invasion, but the grumbling got so loud that they were opened again -- with enough tea and sugar.
 
Rising Corruption
 "Saddam Hussein is very pragmatic, very realistic and in the present circumstances, his priority is that people enjoy a minimum standard of living," said an ambassador from a developing country. "When you're pragmatic, you're not bound by rigid lines. You make your compromises along the way. So the regime has shut its eyes to all sorts of things."
Perhaps most dramatic is corruption. A decade ago, it would have been unthinkable for an average Iraqi to offer to change local dinars for hard currency, because the prison sentence would have been too long. In the face of war, however, the practice is not only tolerated but encouraged. Even the armed forces, whose loyalty to the regime is guaranteed by layers of party apparatchiks and security officers in the ranks, has been affected. Army reservists tell of paying off their commanders either to delay reporting for duty or to get assignments closer to Baghdad where they may be able to work part-time. Others have simply not shown up for reserve duty.
 
A Plea for Smuggling
 The corruption of the army is most obvious in Kuwait. The elite Presidential Guards benefited more from the massive looting of the country than the regular army, and many soldiers have complained to foreigners about the inequity of the spoils. And an Amnesty International report last month documents cases of soldiers who released detained Kuwaitis in exchange for payoffs, particularly television sets and videocassette recorders. A 17-year-old Kuwaiti was offered his freedom in exchange for an Indian or Filipino woman, the report said.
In addition, Western diplomats say that after the invasion, officials claiming ties to the Ministry of Trade visited a number of foreign businesses doing work here and told them that any restrictions would be waived if the businesses would help smuggle in goods.
 Some Iraqi officials quietly acknowledge that relaxing the rules carries potential political risks. In Iraq's repressive atmosphere, the introduction of flexibility in everyday life can only be temporary if the regime hopes to maintain the stability that has been the hallmark of its 22-year history. If the regime survives intact after the current crisis, it will have to find a way to rebuild loyalty to the state and purge corrupting influences. The only way to do that, say a number of foreign diplomats with years of experience here, will be to crack down again. "The total control will have to return, and it will," said one European diplomat. "The regime has nothing else to use to bind the people."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Your Tired, Your Poor, Your Masses Yearning To Be With Relatives

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
THE term "push-pull" is a simple bit of shorthand used to explain why millions of people have undertaken the vast journeys of immigrants. Poverty pushes them. Economic opportunity pulls them.
Leaving aside political refugees, who are considered the exception to the rule, this fundamentally economic model of immigration served as the guiding principle for major revisions of American immigration laws completed late last year. As Congress debated how immigration could help meet the nation's labor needs, a variety of experts and scholars were developing more complex views of immigration that incorporate historical, cultural and social factors in trying to explain why people emigrate. 
 Those using the new approach, which does not yet have a name as neat as push-pull, say economic factors alone do not explain why New York and Los Angeles have attracted thousands of Koreans as grocers, and not similar numbers of would-be merchants from Thailand or Indonesia.
Nor does push-pull alone explain why nurses from the Philippines have become a major presence in American hospitals and why people from other poor densely populated countries have not.
Some scholars, like Alejandro Portes, a sociologist at Johns Hopkins University, argue that the American military presence in Korea and the Philippines along with the events that brought it about may be as important in stimulating immigration as purely economic motivations.
Similarly, Mr. Portes and others say economic considerations do not explain why certain areas of Mexico send more immigrants to the United States than other regions that are either poorer or closer to the border or both. Long-established migration patterns create powerful links between certain communities in Mexico and the United States, according to recent studies. Understanding such dynamics and predicting immigration flows are becoming increasingly important in formulating policy.
Immigration has been on the rise for at least a decade and Congress last year mandated that the numbers continue to rise. As a result, immigration now plays a greater role in shaping the labor force than at any time since the Depression.
Washington has attempted to shape immigration's economic impact through two laws that together produced the first major revision of immigration policy since 1965. The first law, enacted in 1986, sought to curtail the flow of illegal aliens by prohibiting their employment and thus cutting off the supply of jobs that pull them here.
Then, last year, Congress turned its attention to legal immigration. In late October it enacted a law that will increase the number of immigrant visas to 700,000 a year from the current level of 500,000. As in the past, the families of citizens will get preferential treatment for most of the visas, but the new emphasis on economic considerations dictated that most of the additional 200,000 visas go to people selected for their job skills or their ability to make major financial investments. The assumption is that there are plenty of such immigrants pushing to get into the United States and that the doors just have to be opened to them.
 
Kinship With Lands Afar
 Non-economic considerations, however, may diminish the laws' effectiveness.
"Immigration from the Philippines is a textbook example of why it is wrong to base policy on the idea that people are just calculating where they can make the most money and then traveling there," said Mr. Portes. "People immigrate to where they find connections and a measure of familiarity."
The extent to which the United States permeates modern Philippine history and culture means that "potential immigrants are partially Americanized even before they leave," he said. The same, he argued, holds true for South Korea and Taiwan, and similar historical connections explain why many people from former British and Dutch possessions in the Caribbean have chosen to migrate to London and Amsterdam even though Miami is much closer.
Even some staunch advocates of a strictly economic approach to immigration now agree that those additional factors need to be taken into account.
George J. Borjas, an economist at the University of California, San Diego, said, "Someone in the Philippines is not going to become an immigrant unless they think they'll improve their economic condition, but having a lot of information about the United States is an economic consideration that makes immigration more likely by reducing costs and risks."
Aside from the connections between two countries, the case of Korean grocers illustrates how connections at a more personal level can affect immigration flows. Successful immigrants have paved the way for new arrivals by helping them with information, employment and financial assistance. This is merely a modern version of a kind of networking that historians believe is as old as immigration itself.
Among Mexican immigrants, especially those who come illegally, similar patterns exercise a powerful influence. Analyzing extensive studies that have been conducted in the Mexican states of Michoacan and Jalisco, Wayne A. Cornelius, director of the Center for U.S.-Mexican Studies at the University of California, San Diego, has described a "culture of out-migration."
"In these communities that have been the traditional sources of migrants for decades, the kids grow up with a whole world view that is shaped by the prospect, if not the inevitability, of migration to the United States," he said. "It is an expectation so widespread that it is impervious to the machinations of the governments on either side of the border."

HEADLINE: America's Duty to New York;
Fighting for Fairness: I

SERIES: To Restore New York City: First, Reclaim the Streets -- First of two editorials

 BODY:
New York City is staggering because of tax dollars lost to the recession, which no one can control, but also because of massive Federal unfairness, which Congress can control. America calls on New York and its other largest cities to serve as the nation's poorhouse, but so far the rest of the country refuses to pay its fair share.
Medicaid, foster care and other expenditures for the poor cost New York City $3 billion a year. That's almost a fifth of all the money the city spends on its own programs, and far more than the amount needed to close the present critical budget gap. And that $3 billion doesn't include the cost of police and schools, driven upward by the needs of the city's poor. 
 Cities, most of all the largest cities, contain a disproportionate number of the nation's poor and afflicted. New York did not create its schizophrenic homeless, crack addicts or AIDS carriers. Indeed, the city's humane response has served as a magnet for these victims. And New York, like Los Angeles and Miami, provides socializing institutions for waves of Asian, Latin and other immigrants.
New Yorkers are no less responsible for these needy fellow residents than neighboring suburbanites or Midwest farmers. But why should they be required to carry substantially more of the burden?
Last Sunday we urged that, in this period of darkening fiscal storms, New York's first priority be to reclaim the streets. Today and tomorrow, we urge that, to make that possible, Congress's first priority be to spread the burden.
Cities like New York, Los Angeles and Chicago are centers of culture and excitement -- and violence and despair. Some of the decay arises from political fumbling. But self-inflicted wounds cannot explain the spreading pattern of urban distress.
John Yinger of Syracuse University and Helen Ladd of Duke University document how economic and social factors beyond the control of major cities make it ever harder for them to provide reasonable public service, especially for children and the poor.
The civil rights revolution revived the old tides that swept the white middle class to the suburbs. Recent years have seen a black middle-class tide in the same directions. Cities, meanwhile, feel a vicious dynamic. As the urban cores decline, people who can depart do so, leaving behind a more concentrated distillation of poverty.
In cities studied by Richard Nathan, the public policy expert at the State University of New York, Albany, the percentage of poor blacks trapped in extremely poor neighborhoods increased from 25 percent to nearly 40 during the 1970's.
The Reagan Administration compounded the problem by cutting back Federal grants for housing, education and public works. Over the past decade, Washington has whittled its share of state and local budgets from 25 percent to 17.
There is little logic and no fairness in asking city taxpayers to pay for the poor on the same basis that they pay for schools and garbage collection. Social welfare is different. The poor are not their poor but America's poor, and being poor, they are drawn to big cities.
Forced to assume the consequent costs, cities and states are prompted to drive benefits lower, hoping the poor will settle elsewhere. No wonder states have passively allowed inflation to eat into the value of their welfare benefits. Welfare is a national problem that demands a Federal solution. Only a Federal program can guarantee that everyone will pay a fair share.
The point is not that Iowa farmers or Marin County lawyers should be asked to bail out New York. It is that New York and other big cities are strapped and, even with the best will in the world, cannot long continue to pay everyone else's bill.
Tomorrow: How to federalize welfare.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Why

BYLINE: By Richard Nixon; Richard Nixon, the former President, is author most recently of "In the Arena."

DATELINE: WOODCLIFF LAKE, N.J.

 BODY:
It is time for some straight talk about why 400,000 young Americans spent Christmas in the deserts of Saudi Arabia and why in less than two weeks the U.S. may be once again at war.
We must first be clear about what the conflict is not about. 
 If we must resort to military force to drive Saddam Hussein from Kuwait, it will not be a war about democracy. While our goal is to restore Kuwait's legitimate Government, it is hypocritical to suggest that we hope to bring democracy to Kuwait. Except for Israel, there are no democracies in the Mideast, and there will be none in the foreseeable future. The Emir of Kuwait is among the world's more benevolent dictators, but once he is back in his palace in Kuwait City, he will still be a dictator.
Nor is intervention justified because Saddam Hussein is a cruel leader. President Bush has been criticized for equating him with Hitler. Whether he is that bad is irrelevant. He is bad enough. His soldiers are murdering, torturing and raping defenseless Kuwaitis and pillaging their country. He violated international law by using chemical weapons against Iran and the Kurds.
But if our policy were to punish cruel leaders, we would not be allied with Syria's President Hafez al-Assad. He ordered the massacre of 20,000 innocent people in the city of Hama in his own country, has supported international terrorism and presided over an army that has committed brutal atrocities in Lebanon. Both Syria and Iraq threaten our interests, but today Iraq poses a profoundly greater threat.
Those who fault President Bush for enlisting President Assad's support should remember Winston Churchill's classic rejoinder to those who criticized him for supporting Stalin after Hitler invaded the Soviet Union during World War II: "If Hitler invaded Hell, I think I would find a kind word to say about the Devil in the House of Commons."
We are in the Persian Gulf for two major reasons.
First, Saddam Hussein has unlimited ambitions to dominate one of the most important strategic areas in the world. When Senator Bob Dole said we were in the gulf for oil and Secretary of State James Baker said we were there for jobs, they were criticized for justifying our actions on purely selfish grounds. We should not apologize for defending our vital economic interests.
Had we not intervened, an international outlaw would today control more than 40 percent of the world's oil. While, by stringent energy conservation, the U.S. might be able to get along without oil from the Gulf, Western Europe and Japan could not. What happens to the economies of other great industrial nations directly affects the economy of the U.S. We cannot allow Mr. Hussein to blackmail us and our allies into accepting his aggressive goals by giving him a choke hold on our oil lifeline.
Because he has oil, he has the means to acquire the weapons he needs for aggression against his neighbors, eventually including nuclear weapons. If he succeeds in Kuwait, he will attack others, and he will use whatever weapons he has to achieve his goals. If we do not stop him now, we will have to stop him later, when the cost in young American lives will be infinitely greater.
There is an even more important long-term reason for rolling back Iraq's aggression. We cannot be sure, as many believe and hope, that we are entering into a new, post-cold-war era where armed aggression will no longer be an instrument of national policy. But we can be sure that if Saddam Hussein profits from aggression, other potential aggressors in the world will be tempted to wage war against their neighbors.
If we succeed in getting Mr. Hussein out of Kuwait in accordance with the U.N. resolution and in eliminating his capacity to wage war in the future -- which must be our goal if he refuses to get out peacefully and forces us to act militarily -- we will have the credibility to deter aggression elsewhere without sending American forces. The world will take seriously U.S. warnings against aggression.
Some critics argue that we should continue sanctions for as long as 18 months before resorting to force. They contend that even if sanctions do not work, Mr. Hussein will be so weakened that we will suffer fewer casualties if war does come.
They are wrong on three counts. First, while the Iraqi people suffer the effects of the sanctions, President Hussein will direct his resources so that the Iraqi military will not. Second, while the sanctions will weaken Iraq, they will weaken us even more, because of the political difficulty of holding our alliance together abroad and maintaining support for our troop commitment at home. Finally, the most the critics can claim is that it is possible that sanctions might work. It is certain that military force will work. The stakes are too high to risk failure.
Other critics believe diplomacy will eventually convince Saddam Hussein that he should get out of Kuwait. But neither diplomacy nor sanctions has a chance unless he knows that if he does not get out of Kuwait peacefully, the American people and our allies will be united in support of driving him out military.
Should Secretary Baker's meeting with the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, fail to produce an ageement that complies unconditionally with the U.N. resolution, we must remember that when dealing with an insatiable aggressor a bad peace is worse than war because it will inevitably lead to a bigger war.
If we must go to war, it will not be just a war about oil. It will not be a war about a tyrant's cruelty. It will not be a war about democracy. It will be a war about peace -- not just peace in our time, but peace for our children and grandchildren in the years ahead.
If Saddam Hussein gains in any way from his aggression, despite our unprecedented commitment of economic, diplomatic and military power, other aggressors will be encouraged to wage war against their neighbors and peace will be in jeopardy everywhere in the world. That is why our commitment in the gulf is a highly moral enterprise.
