HEADLINE: Education Lobby Getting Crowded

BYLINE: By Karen De Witt

 BODY:
NEXT MONTH the higher education lobby in Washington, D.C., will swing into action when Congress takes up the reauthorization of the Higher Education Act of 1986. Once, the most effective charge would have been led by the 27 education groups housed in the National Center for Higher Education -- more frequently referred to by its address, One Dupont Circle -- groups such as the American Council on Education, the National Council of University Research Administrators and the Council on Postsecondary Accreditation.
But in the last 10 to 15 years, the postsecondary education lobby has exploded in number and location. Today, education aides on Capitol Hill and officials in the Department of Education say that One Dupont Circle is no longer the center of higher education power. 
 "There has been such a significant proliferation of groups representing higher education that it very often gets confusing as to who actually speaks for college campuses," said Richard T. Jerue, staff director ofthe House Subcommittee on Postsecondary Education. "But the most effective associations today represent very targeted, very specific interests."
 
 
Effective Groups
 Discussions with education experts elicited the names of a few groups particularly effective in producing Federal regulations favorable to their constituencies or an increase in Federal financing for their programs. Among these are the National Association of Student Financial Aid Administrators, the Consumer Bankers Association, the National Council of Educational Opportunity Associations, the National Association of Trade and Technical Schools, the National Associations of Independent Colleges and Universities and the Association of Independent Colleges and Schools. Only the last is at One Dupont.
Michael McPherson, an economics professor at Williams College and former Brookings Institution education policy analyst, noted that three of these groups were not education groups at all, but bankers and for-profit school organizations. The banks, Professor McPherson said, have been particularly successful in getting rules for student loan guarantees written in their favor.
"The way the rules are written for the payments that come to the banks," he said, "the banks are thoroughly insured against inflation risks. And whenever there are any proposals floated that would reduce the benefits banks would get, the banks warn that if their returns are cut, they will pull out of the program."
Many consider the National Association of Student Financial Aid Administrators, which represents 3,200 campuses nationwide and 9,000 financial aid officers, to be the lead lobby because of the technical expertise of its president, Dallas Martin.
"He has a better grasp of the issues than Dupont Circle and understands the politics on the issues," said one Capitol Hill aide. "He is willing to take risks and say things that are not always status quo-oriented."
The power of the bankers and financial aid officers goes to theheart of a change in education that occurred more than 20 years ago, when Congress was working out the best way to assist American higher education. One faction thought Federal aid should be delivered directly to postsecondary institutions; the other, that aid should go to students. The groups at One Dupont lobbied for institutional aid: they lost.
 
 
'90% Student Aid'
 So today, a Congressional education committee aide explained, "Ninety percent of what we do up here on the Hill is student aid." He added: "In the last Congress, if you judge effectiveness by the budget increases, then student-aid groups did very well."
The organizations at One Dupont Circle are called presidential associations, because they almost exclusively represent college and university presidents. But spokesmen from the new groups contend that presidents don't deal with day-to-day issues such as student aid or student and research grants, which is why athletic academic standards, medical research using animals and other controversies caught the presidential groups off guard.
The traditional education lobbies have been further weakened by the growing diversity of their constituencies and the groups' hesitancy to play rough-and-tumble in the political arena. "They don't have political-action committees or make contributions or deliver a vote," said a staff member of the House Labor and Human Resources Committee. "All that works against them."
Robert Atwell is president of the American Council on Education, which has been particularly effective over the years in maintaining appropriations levels for the 1,800 institutions of higher education it represents. He has enjoyed considerably less success in persuading members to form a political-action committee.
Dr. Atwell said the presidential associations felt that such involvement meant "buyinginto an unhealthy dimension of American politics," and that they wanted to present themselves, the presidential associations, as something "other than just another interest group."
But the most dramatic example of the rise of a new education lobby that considers itself an interest group is the National Association of Trade and Technical Schools -- a rise tied to growth of student aid, narrow, targeted lobbying and an organizational makeover.
It represents 1,300 private, for-profit, accredited postsecondary institutions that train students in careers ranging from avionics maintenance to X-ray technician. Less than a decade ago, the organization's lobbying strategy was to stay low and keep quiet -- and with reason. Its members' reputations were less than exemplary, their public image frequently that of fly-by-night operations that promised training to low-income people but never delivered, and often the focus of investigations by the Federal Trade Commission.
 
 
A Strategy Shift
 That strategy shifted when the organization hired Stephen J. Blair as president in 1985. Mr. Blair had been director of policy and program development in the Federal Education Department's Office of Student Financial Assistance, responsible for policy and program development of the annual Federal student-aid programs.
One of his first actions was to collect data on who Natts' members were and how many students they served. He hired a public relations firm to help members reduce student default rates. When Congress began investigating default rates in postsecondary education, Natts had evidence that it was aware of the problem and doing something to correct it.
Mr. Blair also created a seven-member, full-time lobbying staff, assembled one of the few political-action committees in higher education.
"All of a sudden they were able to go out in the field and organize constituent groups," said John B. Lee, who runs a consulting firm in higher education.
But sensitivity to the marketplace isn't the only measure of an education lobby's influence.
The National Council of Educational Opportunity Associations persuaded Congress to increase its Federal financing by 38 percent, from $242 million in fiscal 1991 to $333 million in fiscal 1992.
The nine-year-old organization is a public-advocacy policy group representing intervention programs such as Upward Bound, Talent Search and Student Support Services, which help low-income and minority youngsters. "It was a very important victory," Dr. Mitchem said. "We argued that our programs were helping about a million students, only a fraction of the population that was eligible. We pointed out the changing demographics of the country and the productivity crisis and said, 'Hey, you can get more bang for your buck by increasing money for these programs, which help keep kids in school or help them go to school.' Talent Search and Upward Bound help with dropout. Eighty-two percent of people in Federal and state prisons are dropouts. It costs $16,000 to $20,000 a year to keep them there. Keeping a student in one of our programs costs about $2,000 a year. We had very effective witnesses on our side."
When Federal higher education programs come under the scrutiny of reauthorization next month, questions will come up such as whether student aid should be tied to educational outcome, what the structure of the system of student-aid delivery should be, whether private lenders work best in the program or whether there are other ways to deliver money to students, and what the appropriate balance is between grants and loans. At that point, no matter what their approach, whether loftily ethereal or eminently pragmatic, all the academics will be haunting the halls of Congress with something to say.

HEADLINE: R.O.T.C. Doesn't Want You

BYLINE: By Keith Bradsher

 BODY:
THE Reserve Officers Training Corps, one of the best-financed Federal education programs in the 1980's and a rare source of scholarships for middle-class students ineligible for aid programs based on need, is shrinking in the 1990's.
The R.O.T.C. is a 74-year-old program to train military officers at colleges and universities other than the nation's three main military academies. Now it is cutting back recruitment, closing units and releasing some students from their military obligations. 
 Better relations with the Soviet Union have allowed the United States to trim its armed forces, including the number of officers. The American military deployment in the Persian Gulf has delayed but not stopped this process.
 
 
Fewer Opportunities
 Politicians and economists have been looking to reductions in military spending as a way to limit growth in the Federal budget deficit. But for thousands of Americans, a smaller R.O.T.C. means more limited educational opportunities.
Paul A. Merwin, a junior at Manhattan College from Hunter, N.Y., said an Army R.O.T.C. scholarship enabled him to study civil engineering. His father died when he was very young, his sister is in college and his mother has been working two jobs to support them. Without the scholarship, Mr. Merwin said, he would have had to attend a two-year college. "There are no two-year civil engineering colleges that I know of," he added.
For Ingrid R. Stabb, a senior from San Diego majoring in Russian studies at Columbia University, an Army R.O.T.C. scholarship meant attending an Ivy League school, not a state university in California. Ms. Stabb said family income made her ineligible for other financial aid. "My mother was in the hospital. The future looked uncertain. I really needed the scholarship," she said.
Yet in the last four years,combined enrollment in Army, Navy and Air Force R.O.T.C. fell 10 percent, to 86,000, while the number of scholarships was reduced by 21 percent, to 21,700, making the scholarships more competitive than ever. There were, for example, 11,421 applications last winter for 1,232 Navy R.O.T.C. scholarships starting in the current academic year, said Lieut. Comdr. Ray P. Kempisty, a Navy spokesman. No figures are available from any of the services on applications since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August.
The most dramatically shrinking R.O.T.C. program is that of the Army, which is closing 50 of its 416 college and university units and asking students at campuses no longer served to commute to campuses where programs remain.
In an even more drastic measure, all nonscholarship seniors in the Army R.O.T.C. were offered exemptions from military service last year. The Army ended up releasing 1,136 cadets and commissioning the remaining 8,217 as officers.
 
 
Air Force Cuts
 For the current academic year, the Army is commissioning only 6,000 officers. No decision has been made yet about offering releases from military service to this year's seniors, said Capt. Mary Ann Kilcullen, an Army spokeswoman.
The Air Force is reducing to 2,200 the number of R.O.T.C. cadets it commissions during the current academic year,from 2,335 during the last year and 2,823 the year before. An offer last spring to release seniors from military service attracted 104 cadets; a similar offer last autumn drew 141 more, said Terry S. Boksan, a civilian Air Force spokeswoman.
Scholarship cadets released from service must repay all benefits received over a 10-year period at an annual interest rate of 9 percent.
 
 
Navy Following Suit
 The Navy is reducing the number of incoming midshipmen for its R.O.T.C., which also trains officers for the Marine Corps. But it is not closing units or offering releases from military service.
"We do commission all of our graduates, and we intend to keep it that way," Commander Kempisty said.
Many R.O.T.C. students are finding that those commissions, and their school financing, come at an unexpected price.
Allan D. Barall, a senior majoring in business at New York University on an Army R.O.T.C. scholarship, said he was recently jeered when he walked in uniform past a demonstration in Greenwich Village against sending American troops to the Persian Gulf.
Faculties on several dozen campuses, including Harvard's have passed nonbinding resolutions asking that administrators expel campus R.O.T.C. units if they do not alter policies that exclude homosexuals. And the long-run value of military service to private-sector careers is being widely debated.
Stories abound of R.O.T.C. officers receiving dull postings that teach them little. But laudatory accounts are also easy to find. Randall . Tobias, one of two vice chairmen of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said he met his wife and learned to speak with confidence in public after he was assigned to teach at the Army's artillery school in Fort Sill, Okla. "Those are experiences that are difficult to duplicate in terms of leadership development," he said.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Defeating Iraq Would Create Worse Problems;
Winners and Losers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Roger Fisher, professor of law at Harvard University and director of the Harvard Negotiation Project, has said that unless we answer two questions about Iraq's presence in Kuwait, we will be unable to resolve the conflict. The first is "What happens to Iraq if it remains in Kuwait?" The second is "What happens to Iraq if it withdraws?"
We are certainly addressing the first question. Economic sanctions have taken a tremendous toll on Iraq and its people, and President Bush's tough rhetoric and military presence are definite responses to the first question.
However, as Professor Fisher also points out, until we begin to address the second question, Saddam Hussein has no incentive to leave Kuwait, no matter how intolerable we make the circumstances. And until he sees that the fire won't be hotter than the frying pan, he will not leave.
The sanctions have not extricated President Hussein from Kuwait and restored the Kuwaiti Government because of our failure to address the second question. One problem with asking it is our very normal reaction against allowing Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait without being punished, even if all of our demands are met.
This view, however, assumes that there can be a winner and a loser (we win, they lose), which is clearly the option we would prefer. Yet, of the three scenarios, win-lose, win-win or lose-lose, the win-lose scenario is not practical or possible.
Resorting to military force, even assuming victory, would result in the loss of thousands of lives, create a schism in this country deeper than Vietnam, deepen an economic recession and perhaps lead to a depression, result in the loss of the oil fields we are there to protect, unite the Arab nations of the world against the United States, lead to terrorism within our borders, promote an attack on Israel and perhaps initiate the use of nuclear weapons. Thus, even in winning, we would lose.
When left with the remaining options, win-win or lose-lose, win-win becomes our best course. It is now time for us to discover creatively the win-win scenario.
With the President's deadline of Jan. 15, we had better get on with it quickly.
 
JAMES F. CARSON JR.
Macon, Ga., Dec. 26, 1990

HEADLINE: School Finance: It's a Jungle

BYLINE: By William Celis 3d

 BODY:
In the world of school finance, these are unsettling times. From Texas to Mississippi to Illinois to Nebraska, states are struggling mightily to repair or reconfigure finance plans that are being challenged by parents and school districts or have already been struck down by courts as unconstitutional.
The embattled states, without exception, have long used finance formulas that lean heavily on local property taxes, a method that courts have increasingly rejected as unacceptable because they allow property-rich districts to spend more on students than property-poor districts do. The result, state and Federal courts have said, has been an inferior education for the children in less-affluent school systems. 
 The states' efforts to overhaul these property-based plans have given birth to a variety of approaches, most of which attempt to address inequities in financing. Other plans are designed to raise money to support education improvement statewide. Some ambitious efforts try to do both.
But state lawmakers have found the going exceedingly tough in the face of voter opposition to higher taxes, recently seen in Nebraska, Oklahoma and New Jersey; a sputtering economy, and the lack of models from which to learn.Texas, for example, home to some of the nation's richest and poorest school systems, is under court order to narrow the disparity in spending among them. Last summer, the State Legislature approved, and a reluctant governor signed, a $528 million package financed by a state sales tax increase.
But a state judge rejected the plan because, he said, it didn't go far enough in closing the school spending gap in a state where the richest district spends nearly $20,000 a year per pupil as against about $2,000 in the poorest district.
 
 
Tax Increase Likely
 In rejecting the proposal, State District Judge Scott McCown forced the newly elected Governor, Ann Richards, and the State Legislature back to the drawing board to produce a plan that likely will require tax increases in a state where the economy still is recovering from the oil industry's collapse in the mid-1980's.
Other states have approved school-equalization formulas, but not without a battle. Under a Nebraska plan, approved by state legislators last April, the state sales tax jumped to 5 cents from 4 cents and the state income tax was increased by 17.5 percent, generating $178.8 million on top of existing state education spending in the firstyear and $238.8 million more in the second. The plan bars property-rich school systems from raising spending in any year more than 4 percent, while allowing poorer districts to increase spending 6.5 percent.
State education officials called the plan a "shift-in-taxes" approach, because under the new system, districts will receive 45 percent of their aid from the state, up from 25 percent under the old system. Some Nebraskans, however, called it unfocused and tried to repeal it through a voter-led initiative on the ballot last November. The initiative failed.
Mississippi, by contrast, tried raising money generally for education spending without addressing spending differences among school systems. The state's three-year plan, which officials last year estimated would cost $250 million, addresses virtually every aspect of education programming, from early childhood to adult literacy. But the package approved last spring is stalled because of disagreement over how to best support improvements. Some lawmakers favor higher taxes; others do not. Later this month, the legislature will try to settle the issue.
Some states have attempted the near impossible by addressing both school-wealth inequities and overall educational improvements -- a one-two approach best seen in Kentucky.
In that state, which was under court order to revamp its entire school system, the Governor and the legislature worked together to boost a variety of taxes, including the sales tax, to 6 percent from 5 percent. The total package is expected to raise $1.3 billion to help support the first two years of a mammouth five-year plan to improve schools.
 
 
Poor Districts Benefit
 Under Kentucky's plan, poor districts receive larger state aid and an additional allotment of state money if they raise their taxes to stipulated levels. According to state education officials, if all districts take advantage of this offer, spending differences between rich school districts and poor ones will narrow to 45 percent.
Critics believe that is still too large, while proponents of the new formula say it eliminates disparities that were sometimes triple that. "At least Kentucky tried to do it all," said John Augenblick, a Denver lawyer and school finance expert who worked on the Kentucky reconfiguration. "It bit the bullet, which most states don't even try to do."
Some education policymakers and local educators believe states blanch at voter opposition to higher taxes -- opposition that, they say, reflects an attitude among taxpayers that because they worked hard and bought homes in good neighborhoods with good public schools, parents in poor systems should do the same. "I'm sure there are feelings of resentment in some communities," said Charles L. Slater, superintendent of the Alamo Heights Independent School District, in San Antonio, which serves some of that city's more affluent students. Over all, though, Mr. Slater said, "Our feeling is that we are one part of San Antonio, and if we're going to have good services and successful people in our community we must have good education for everyone."

HEADLINE: SPECIAL REPORT;
A Learned Response

BYLINE: By Janet Elder

 BODY:
Think again if you think the ability to reason comes easily, if at all. Think again if you believe that scientists are about to solve the mystery of human thought and its underlying biochemistry. Still, Americans are increasingly recognizing the importance of reasoning skills and are trying to develop, hone and teach them to adults and children alike. The endeavor is commanding national attention and demanding individual thought.
 THINKING IS NOT like breathing, educators agree; it doesn't come naturally. Thoughts do, but the ability to organize, explain and defend those thoughts is more like learning to ride a bicycle. It's shaky going at first; training wheels and a steady, patient tutor are usually needed. But once mastered, the learner will always be able to get somewhere on his or her own steam. 
 That is why in kindergarten classrooms and college lecture halls, educators are starting to teach students to think. "Of course it's better if children start to learn this when they are young," said Carol Camper, director of critical thinking at Marymount College in Manhattan. "But learning to think is a permanent thing, so it's really never too late."
But what does it mean to think? Educators more often explain what thinking isn't than what it is. "It is not a collection of little skills," said Lauren Resnick, a psychology professor and director of the Learning Research and Development Center at the University of Pittsburgh. "Its very nature resists precise forms of definition. It is an emergent process you can't predict."
Educators agree that critical thinking, creative thinking and reasoning are members of the family of "higher-order thinking." But definitions of higher-order thinking are vague. "What we mean is thinking through complicated issues in a fairly serious way," said Daniel P. Keating, professor of education at the Ontario Institute for Studies in Education, in Toronto. "Developmentally, that means different things at different ages."
 
 
From Stacking Blocks to Classifying Data
 For the 5-year-old, it may mean experimenting with different heights to find out how high you can pile blocks before they tumble down. For the college student it may mean figuring out what type of information is needed to compare major economic systems. Dr. Resnick, in her book "Education and Learning to Think," written for the National Research Council, part of the National Academy of Sciences, offers some of what educators seem to agree are characteristics of higher-order thinking: "It is complex, nonalgorithmic, yields multiple solutions and involves nuanced judgment."
The new classroom emphasis on learning to think results partly from the failure of the back-to-basics movement to educate children to think beyond the facts taught by rote. "We as a society are finally realizing that people are graduating from high school without learning how to synthesize large amounts of information," said Shari Castle, coordinator for research and development at the Center for Innovation, part of the National Education Association, the nation's largest teachers' organization. Dr. Castle added: "For educators that means moving away from rote learning"
But giving up the predictability of rote learning is difficult, for teachers and students alike. Teachers have to give up some classroom control and let students come up with their own ideas, said Robert J. Sternberg, professor of education at Yale University, adding, "Theyalso have to change their perspective. They have to see that giving kids the facts isn't enough."
For students, thinking means giving up the inertia of passive learning. "This society spoon-feeds them everything and doesn't encourage them to process deeply," Dr. Sternberg said. "After a certain age, it's hard to rock them out of their chairs." And when it comes to teaching them to think, he said: "Some of them long for the old days of being told what to do."
 
Where Thinking Reigns, Problems Vanish
 In classrooms where thinking is the heart of each day's mental workout, where right answers are no longer as important as right questions, problem students tend to disappear, educators say. "There is no such thing as a child who is intellectually lazy; they are just uninspired," said Perry Halkitis, a sixth-grade teacher at Hunter Elementary School, a public school for gifted children in New York City. "If you ask the right questions, kids dive right in. The function of the school is to help pull the information out of kids."
One such dispirited student was Peter Wilson, 11 years old, according to his mother, Yvette Wilson, an employee of the Social Security Administration from Berkeley, Calif., who said, "Nothing mattered to him emotionally, intellectually -- nothing." Then Peter took an algebra class designed to teach fourth-graders to think and trust their own ability to think. "Ms. Molnar's class lit a fire under him," Mrs. Wilson said. "He was like a puzzle -- his mind was in a million pieces. She helped him put it together into a beautiful picture."
There is another side to thinking. Educators are finding that children who learn how to think do better not only in school but in life. In Peter's case, thinking through the confusion of higher mathematics has helped him think through other tasks and activities. "When I fight with him now," Mrs. Wilson said, "he won't slam around and say, 'I want to do something.' He'll say, 'I want to do this because . . .' "
In Jane Molnar's class at Malcolm X School in Berkeley, children "discover" mathematics. Ms. Molnar asks the questions, but the class finds the answers through discussion and by reasoning with her and with one another. "The whole emphasis is on getting them to think, not to parrot the right answers," Ms. Molnar said. "At first it makes them anxious to just let a paradox emerge. But as the weeks go by they begin to trust their own instincts and ability to think."
Ms. Molnar's method was developed by William Johntz at the nonprofit Project Seed in Berkeley, whose intent was to bolster minority students' self-esteem.
Stimulating children to think abstractly, as Ms. Molnar and others do, goes against much of the groundwork laid by the psychologist Jean Piaget for early-childhood and elementary education. "Piaget said children are not able to think abstractly and we should leave them in a concrete mode with plenty of social interaction until they are ready," said Matthew Lipman, founder and director of the Institute for the Advancement of Philosophy for Children at Montclair State College in New Jersey. "That thinking has resulted in two generations of cognitively deprived children."
Dr. Lipman has used philosophy as the basis for a set of books designed to be used from kindergarten through high school as the catalyst for classroom discussion and exploration of philosophical ideas. Like Ms. Molnar, Dr. Lipman uses an abstract subject to teach children to learn by thinking, not memorizing. In the process, he says, teachers have told him that students are benefiting from enhanced self-esteem. "Being listened to by their peers is an intoxicating experience for children," Dr. Lipman said.
The other benefits of learning how to think are less easily envisioned. As Dr. Sternberg said: "One thing no one is thinking much about is that if we are successful at teaching children how to think, are we as a society prepared to deal with the consequences?"

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: 515 Park Avenue;
An Old Holdout Is Imperiled

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
WHEN it is viewed in a lineup with the other apartment houses of Park Avenue, nothing remarkable distinguishes 515 Park, built in 1912 at the southeast corner of 60th Street.
But in a quiet way, the 12-story building stands to play a part in the long-term evolution of land use that has characterized Manhattan real estate since the start of the 19th century. 
 Now the latest episode in this transition may have begun. The building stands vacant and dark, part of a site for an office development project begun years ago. Eventually, office use may displace residential use, as it has often before.
The electrification of the railroad under Park Avenue in the early 1900's produced a sudden wave of residential construction on what had been a middling street. The first of the luxury apartment houses was completed in 1907 at 471 Park and by 1910 a dozen were finished or under construction.
In 1911, John J. Hearn, a developer who was living in one of his own buildings at 417 Riverside Drive, near 113th Street, filed plans for a 12-story apartment house on the southeast corner of 60th, adjoining the Mineola garage at the northeast corner of 60th.
There were two apartments on a floor, of seven and nine rooms. Advertisements promised "every up-to-date improvement and convenience known to the builder's art" and the "advantages of a private house with the comforts and conveniences of an apartment."
"Park Avenue itself," the advertisements said, "is an unusually wide street, planted with grass and kept in apple pie order by the Department of Parks."
Rents ran from $200 to $300 a month.
The design of Hearn's architects, Denby & Nute, followed very closely that of their building at 417 Riverside Drive.
"Modern Renaissance" was the term of the period, with classically derived details in a stone base, brick midsection and terra cotta crown. Early tenants were what you might expect: Harris D. Colt, a founding partner of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle; Dr. Byron Stookey, a prominent neurologist, and Harry Ward, head of the Irving National Bank.
In late 1927, 515 Park was acquired by the Apperson Realty Corporation, controlled by William Randolph Hearst (Apperson was his mother's maiden name). Hearst was active in midtown real estate, buying established properties like the Lombardy Hotel and the Ritz Tower in this period. But he apparently bought 515 Park Avenue for development because early in 1929 Apperson petitioned the Board of Estimate for a zoning change for the corner.
All four corners at 60th and Park had been restricted to residential in the 1916 zoning resolution. Apperson claimed that the garage "operates day and night with the resultant noises and odors" making it difficult to rent apartments at 515. The zoning change was opposed by the Fifth Avenue Association, the Park Avenue Association and neighboring property owners, but the Board of Estimate approved it.
The Park Avenue Social Review, protesting what it called a "zoning subterfuge," said, "When a single corner is so designated, leaving the remaining three corners thus residential, we question the legality of such a procedure."
But apparently no suit was ever instituted. Hearst continued to buy adjacent property through 1931, eventually acquiring the four adjacent brownstones on 60th Street. But the Depression killed any plans for new construction and the assemblage was later broken up.
The zoning remained in place, however, and in 1958 the Jewish Agency, a social services group, acquired the building for its own use and gutted its interior in an office conversion.
In 1989, William Zeckendorf Jr. bought the building from the Jewish Agency, which moved out that year, and he confirms that he is interested in developing the site for "an overseas client," but is unsure of the actual shape of the project. In any event, he calls 515 Park Avenue "very ugly."
Mr. Zeckendorf has not acquired the adjacent brownstones at 106 and 108 East 60th Street, but according to the New York Association of the Blind, he is negotiating with them for air rights from their building at 110 East 60th Street.
Diana Elrod, a spokeswoman for the Department of City Planning, said current zoning would permit an office building of as much as 180,000 square feet on a combined site of 515 Park Avenue and the two brownstones, rising as high as 36 stories, although a lower, bulkier configuration would probably be more economical.
And if the market for office space does not seem promising?
Ms. Elrod noted that, despite the commercial zoning, city rules would allow something besides an office building on the site -- an apartment house.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 20, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A Streetscapes column on Jan. 6 about 515 Park Avenue referred incorrectly to 471 Park as the first luxury apartment house on Park Avenue. The first was at 449. Because of an editing error, both the headline and the index misstated the subject of the article. In addition, the article misstated the location of the now-demolished Mineola Garage. It was at the northeast corner of 59th Street and Park Avenue.

HEADLINE: Mr. Klug Goes to Washington: Winning Was Easy

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Two months ago, Scott Klug of Wisconsin won an election to Congress and thereby entered an alien world. Now he grapples with what his chief aide calls "the monster" -- the letters, telephone calls, resumes and bureaucratic decisions that can engulf new lawmakers.
For Representative Klug, a 37-year-old former television anchorman who scored a stunning upset over the Democratic incumbent, Robert W. Kastenmeier, the pressure goes beyond just setting up an office in a new city and a new profession. 
 Mr. Klug says his performance in the 102d Congress is critical to his future in Washington. As a political novice and a freshman in the minority party, he has little influence. And the Democrats, he says, want his scalp.
"They've as much as said this is an aberration that will not stand," Mr. Klug said, referring to his election in a district that includes the liberal bastion of Madison. "The sandal crowd will be here forever, for better or worse, and I can never make them happy unless I become a Democrat, or more like a socialist."
 
'It's Culture Shock'
 While Mr. Klug's political challenges may be greater than those of some other newcomers, they have at least one thing in common.
"It's culture shock," said Rick Shapiro, director of the Congressional Management Foundation, a research organization that tries to help Congress operate more efficiently. "New members have been thrown into a new environment. And many of the decisions they make now are going to lock them on courses that they're going to follow for the rest of their terms."
Mr. Klug and the 43 other new House members were given guidance in seminars by the House Administration and Ethics Committees as well as a six-day program at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government.
But as helpful as the conferences are, Mr. Klug said, the work can be distracting. "It was not so much that I was running around as it was that I had to sit in a room for eight hours a day when there were 9,000 other things to do," he said, referring to the Kennedy School session. "There I was, in a room with my hands folded, listening to a lecture on micro-economics. It's sort of like taking exams when you're about to get married."
 
Deciding Over Pizza
 Before he decided to run, Mr. Klug planned to go into the business side of journalism and was working on a master's degree in business administration at Northwestern. One night over pizza and beer a friend suggested he run against Mr. Kastenmeier.
"I do have a certain entrepreneurial spirit, and I wanted to be the captain of my own ship," Mr. Klug said. "In a lot of ways, Congress will be fun; it's something I've wanted to do for a long time."
Among the tasks Mr. Klug faced were hiring a staff, selecting a telephone system, deciding where to open a district office. He has had to make decisions ranging from ordering carpet to how to spend the $475,000 each member is granted to pay up to 18 full-time and four part-time aides.
Through it all, he has had to cope with what he views as an antiquated computer he inherited from Mr. Kastenmeier. "I don't think that Bob has sabotaged us," he said. "But they haven't exactly given us the world. When we turn on the computer it says, 'Hi' and not much more."
 
What About the Issues?
 On issues, Mr. Klug said he planned to begin modestly by focusing on the needs of his district, but he added that he would work to create laws to limit the terms that members can serve. He said he also wants to see safer conditions for farm workers and their children, tougher penalties for environmental polluters and a cap on government spending.
His administrative assistant, Brandon Scholz, the former executive director of the Wisconsin Republican Party, will work most of the time in Madison with people who specialize in cutting red tape for constituents, Mr. Klug said. In Washington, Mr. Klug will keep a group of aides hired from other Congressional offices.
In addition to staffing his office, Mr. Klug must create a system to handle the flood of mail. The volume into Congressional offices has grown by 2,000 percent in the last 20 years, the Congressional Management Foundation says. Most members receive between 500 and 1,000 letters a week.
Asked how much mail he had got, Mr. Klug said: "I don't have any idea what's in there, and I don't want to look. I think they'll probably bring it into the office with a forklift truck."

HEADLINE: THE GUARD CHANGES; THE PROBLEMS REMAIN; Weicker Faces A Bumpy Road

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
ON Wednesday, as the last echoes from Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s 19-gun inaugural salute die away over the State Capitol, Connecticut will begin its great experiment in non-party government -- or multi-party government, or whatever it is that the Weicker administration finally decides to call itself.
Some of the pomp and pageantry will hold to tradition. The Governor's Foot Guard, which attended the inauguration of Samuel Huntington in 1791, will be on hand, resplendent in red Grenadier uniforms and plumed busby hats. 
But other elements will be new. Mr. Weicker and Lieutenant Governor-elect Eunice S. Groark will take their oaths of office outdoors on the north steps of the Capitol, barring catastrophic weather. Most previous governors, including William A. O'Neill in 1983 and 1987, have held the ceremony in the Hall of the House.
 Despite the innovations, Connecticut faces a hard road, as Mr. Weicker has pointed out repeatedly since he entered the race as an independent candidate for governor last March. The state's coffers have been battered, with many businesses earning lower profits, and thus paying less corporate taxes; and many residents spending less money on cars and appliances, and thus paying less sales taxes. The state budget, which totals just over $7 billion, is expected to have a revenue shortfall of $670 million during the next six months and another $1.5 billion shortfall in the year that begins on July 1. When the state's budget documents were signed last year, revenue from the 8 percent sales tax, which provides about 40 percent of Connecticut's general-fund tax money, had been projected to grow by 3 percent. Last week, the Comptroller's office said that those revenues are now expected to show a decline of 3 percent. Unemployment, which stood at 4.1 percent in November 1989, now stands at 5.2 percent, according to preliminary figures for November from the State Labor Department. A University of Connecticut poll published last week by The Hartford Courant found that state residents had the gloomiest outlook about the future since surveys began in 1981.
 Some state lawmakers have said that Mr. Weicker's first task as Governor should be to convey hope to residents that things will get better, and Mr. Weicker's supporters and staff members say that that will not be a problem. The self-assurance that he has displayed over the years, which some people have called arrogance, may be just what the state needs now, said the Governor-elect's staff director for transition, Peter W. Gold.
 "He's very sure of himself," Mr. Gold said. "He doesn't lack for confidence in any way, shape or form. That probably bodes well for Connecticut."
 Whether Mr. Weicker's bravura form will translate into legislative success in dealing with the General Assembly remains to be seen. The Assembly, which Mr. Weicker will formally convene with his State of the State address following the swearing-in ceremony, remains firmly in the control of the Democrats, although changes have been apparent there as well.
 In the House of Representatives, where Mr. Weicker served in the mid-1960's as a young Republican legislator from Greenwich, the Democrats gained one seat in the November elections and now hold 89 seats to the Republicans' 62.
 In the Senate, by contrast, the Republicans have moved closer to parity with the Democrats but still remain the minority party, with 16 seats to the Democrats' 20. Before the election, the Democrats held a 10-vote margin, controlling 23 seats to the Republicans' 13.
 With an independent Governor taking office, however, and an administration shaping up composed of people from both parties, no one is quite sure that the old formulas of majority and minority will apply.
 
'Sending a Signal'
 Mr. Weicker spent his entire career in the Republican Party until last year and will certainly receive at least some support from that caucus. And as a liberal, he has always drawn support across party lines. His choice as budget director -- William J. Cibes Jr., a Democrat from New London and a legislative veteran who spent the past two grueling years as co-chairman of the tax-writing committee -- was significant, many lawmakers said.
 Mr. Weicker "was sending a signal," said Representative Janet Polinsky, a Democrat from Waterford and Deputy House Speaker. "He was saying, 'Hey, we are going to have to work together.' "

HEADLINE: Civil War Games for Modern-Day Lees

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
THE climactic battle for the Shenandoah Valley, General Pickett's headlong charge at Gettysburg and the first and second battles of Manassas are the stuff Richard Berg has fashioned a business from. Mr. Berg, 47 years old, a former New York City criminal defense lawyer, is the inventor of more than a dozen Civil War games designed to give Civil War buffs an opportunity to change history.
"I think of the games as paper time machines that re-create the Civil War," Mr. Berg said. "We give players the battlefield, the soldiers and the basic rules. Then it's up to them to do what they will with them. For instance, take Gettysburg; if General Lee had not stopped early on July 1, because his troops were tired, even though he had a couple of hours of daylight left, the outcome of the battle and the Civil War might have been very different. You can see it on the board." 
 Explaining that Union forces had not yet established a defensive position that fateful day, on Cemetery Ridge and Culps Hill, Mr. Berg pointed out, had General Lee kept going, the Union troops might have been forced to withdraw.
 
One Was Voted Best Game
 Several editions of his game on Gettysburg, Terrible Swift Sword, have been strong sellers and one has been voted best game of the year by the game industry. "More than 50,000 people have bought the games to see if they can do better than General Lee," Mr. Berg said. "A third edition is in the works now."
Mr. Berg began designing games as a hobby when he was a high-school student at Poly Prep in Brooklyn. As an adult, he became a contributor to S.P.I., a military and history magazine. "A strategy and tactics game is included in every issue," he said. "My assignment was to come up with a game for them. The one I did on the Crusades is still in existence. The magazine grew rapidly and the games began to attract a following. Eventually, I began designing board games for the general market. Terrible Swift Sword was my second board game." Inventing games was his avocation, he said, until a few years ago when the pressure stemming from his job as a criminal defense lawyer began to get to him.
"It wasn't exactly burnout, but something close to it," he said. "On the other hand, I was getting a tremendous amount of satisfaction doing my games and I thought, well, maybe I can make money doing what I want to do," he recalled. "I recall being somewhat apprehensive about my colleagues' reaction to my announcement that I was leaving the legal profession to become a game designer full time, but I needn't have worried. When I made the announcement, they all wanted to join me."
 
How the Business Was Built
 However, Mr. Berg said he made the change slowly, a step at a time. "I resigned from my job, did a lot of research, and founded a company, Simulation Design, with a partner, Thaddeus Kubits, who furnished some of the start-up capital. Mr. Kubits is a former client of mine. I did legal work for him in a civil case."
Mr. Berg set up an office in his Scarsdale home and began producing his games. The first step, he said, in designing a game is to do the board.
"After the research, which I enjoy thoroughly, I draw the maps. Then I write the rules," he said. "The basic rules are the same. But before I had a computer, I used to do them on the typewriter and they took forever. With the computer, I can move them around with ease."
A well-designed game, he said, plays fair and square with the players. "It should allow the players to see the alternatives before they make a move. Some games last longer than others. Some can be played in two hours, others are good for an entire weekend."
Although there has been heightened general interest in the Civil War, thanks to recent television programs, Mr. Berg said Americans have always been fascinated by the conflict.
"It's a war that has always attracted a large number of history buffs. They support three hefty magazines published solely on the Civil War."
Mr. Berg, who ranks himself as an ardent Civil War buff who is familiar with every regiment General Lee had in battle, also designs games on other subjects, such as his "Lord of the Rings" games and sports games.
 
The Biggestv Expense
 "Almost any event lends itself to a game," he said, "I've designed crisis-management games, and now we're working on one that is a reflection of the times. Business is the theme, and each player is out of work and trying to get another job."
Mr. Berg, who uses the services of free-lance professionals, noted that his biggest expense was for printing the board games.
"Our printing costs are phenomenal," he said. "We shopped around and looked at plants overseas that do the work much cheaper. But we found quality control in the Far East to be somewhat haphazard, primarily because of language differences. The slightest alteration in the wording of the rules, for instance, blows the whole game. So we now print at a plant in Dallas, where our main distributor is located."
The games, which retail in the $35 to $50 range, are distributed to hobby shops in Westchester, he said.
"It's a peak and valley business. October to December are busy months, then we fall off until late February, when the large hobby shows are held. But you can make money as a games publisher if you have a good reputation and a fairly good inventory. I'm inclined to think games are pretty recession-proof because when people have less money to spend on entertainment they'll be home more often and perhaps they play more games. The biggest game moneymaker of all time, Monopoly, was invented during the Great Depression."
When asked what made a good game, Mr. Berg replied, "A good game is different every time you play it. I give players many choices. And they are Hobson's-type choices of the damned-if-you-do, damned-if-you-don't variety. I like to build chaos and random events into the game; it makes it more interesting."
Mr. Berg said he got fan mail and an occasional irate letter from game players.
"People who play games are very passionate about them," he said. "I know, I am one of those types myself. On the other hand, my wife is indifferent to games. But I know groups who have played regularly three or four times a month for years. Most games are designed to be played by two to four players."
War games are always popular, he noted. "Look at the number of chess players," he said. "Chess is perhaps the oldest war game in existence." Mr. Berg, who is also a frequent lecturer at schools and historic societies in the county, said games are much under-used as a teaching tool.
"I hope to expand into the school market with specially designed games," he said. "Games are a marvelous way to get kids interested in history. It helps them understand why and how events occurred."

HEADLINE: Classroom Innovations Encourage Students and Teachers to Excel

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
IN some schools, a visiting parent usually means that a student is in trouble. But J. Brian Lally, a teacher at the Tashua School in Trumbull, has parents in the classroom so often that the pupils take their presence for granted. Parents help Mr. Lally teach everything from computers to cooking.
"You can tap a wealth of experience when you get parents involved," said Mr. Lally, whose innovations in the classroom recently won him national recognition in a contest conducted by two professional publications, American School Board Journal and Executive Educator. 
 Another winner from Connecticut, Mary A. VanDerMeid, developed a curriculum to teach students at Andover Elementary School about heroes. The program incorporated history, sociology, science and other subjects to teach students about figures like the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and about the kind of heroes who emerge from emergencies like earthquakes, fires or floods.
 
Beyond Ninja Turtles
 "It was something to present a set of values to kids," Ms. VanDerMeid said. "Our goal was to broaden their outlook, so they didn't just think of Mutant Ninja Turtles when they were asked to name a hero."
Four Connecticut programs were among the 88 recognized by the contest. The other two were an oral-history project developed by John Vincenzo, a teacher in Newington, and a program to intoduce New Haven's high school students to colleges, begun by the district's supervisor of guidance and counseling, Cynthia Beaver.
"There's a great deal of creativity going on in our public schools, but it's not well communicated to the public," said the executive director of the Connecticut Association of Boards of Education, Terry P. Cassidy.
George A. Coleman, chief of curriculum and instruction bureau at the State Department of Education, said schools are finding new ways to capture children's interests. For instance, he said, he went to one school in Hartford recently that handed out calculators to kindergartners, so they could do more advanced, real-life problems, like as figuring how much change they would get back after making a purchase.
"The feeling is, once the students see an application for a concept, they get a lot more excited," Mr. Coleman said. "And once they understand the concept, they can use their time a lot more purposefully."
Trumbull's Superintendent of Schools, Dr. Edwin T. Merritt, said: "A combination of the recession we're in, which means there are fewer resources available to educators, and the situation in the world, where our kids are not performing as well as their counterparts in other countries, has scared parents and teachers into trying different ways of getting kids focused. Americans are creative, and when we're in a crisis we tend to do better. Clearly, we're in a crisis now."
In order for innovation to work, Dr. Merritt said, teachers have to know they have a relatively high degree of freedom in curriculum design. "When a system is tightly controlled from the top down, these things don't happen," he said.
 
Appreciation of Risks
 Mr. Coleman said the state has supported innovation as well, with its Teacher of the Year program, Celebration of Excellence awards, and awards of up to $25,000 from the Milken Foundation.
"As a department, we have looked for ways to appreciate those individual teachers and programs that are innovative and help students achieve," Mr. Coleman said. "It's given teachers more of an appreciation for taking a risk."
In addition to the support of administrators, the programs have been enthusiastically endorsed by parents, he said.
"There are parents who are concerned, they don't want us to give up on reading and writing," Mr. Coleman said. "But these programs are designed to enhance those skills, and once parents understand that, they become very supportive. "The kids come home from school excited, want to talk about it, and the parents are impressed."
Some of the innovations are originating outside the schools. The Windham Textile and History Museum, for instance, is testing a curriculum it developed that encourages students to research local history or family trees. The history lessons are more meaningful, because the children are learning about things in their own neighborhoods, said a spokeswoman for the museum, Linda Riquier.
"I wish I was a kid again, some of this stuff is so much fun," said Ms. Riquier. "The teachers who are using it are finding the kids are responding beautifully."
But most of the new ideas come from teachers. Mr. Vincenzo, a history teacher at Martin Kellogg Middle School in Newington, developed a program in which his students compile oral histories, which are published in a school magazine. Last year, the students learned about the Depression by interviewing people at a local nursing home. This year, the youngsters interviewed Vietnam War veterans at a local veterans hospital.
"Some of these veterans were on the verge of tears, even today, recalling what they went through," Mr. Vincenzo said. The interviews were much more emotionally charged, and more interesting, than reading a dry account of the war in a textbook, he said.
"A lot of the kids were quite apprehensive about going to the hospital, probably just because of the reputation of veterans' hospitals," Mr. Vincenzo said. "But the kids enjoyed it so much that the one student who was absent the day we went to the hospital found his own veteran to interview."
Mr. Lally said his award-winning program, Parents Getting Involved, was developed when he was teaching third grade. He had students and their parents write stories separately, then bring them to school to read aloud and critique.
It worked out so well, he said, that even when he switched to a kindergarten class this year, he continued to use the concept. Because the students are too young to write their own stories, though, he has parents keep a "Teddy Bear Journal," reading stories to their children and transcribing the children's reaction.
The more parents got involved with their children's schoolwork, the more they volunteered for other duties, Mr. Lally said. He now has parents coming in two or three days a week. Of 37 children in the two sections he teaches, parents of 21 come in regularly.
"It gives the parent a more realistic view of their own child's strengths or weaknesses," Mr. Lally said. "If the child is having a great deal of difficulty writing, the parent is going to be much more sensitive to the child's needs if they see that in the classroom.
"And another advantage is, in kindergarten, you need 13 arms and legs and about a thousand eyes. Just having another adult there can be a great help."
 
Finding Definitions
 Educators said that thematic teaching, as in Ms. VanDerMeid's program on heroes, is growing in popularity.
"When we surveyed kids in the beginning, the heroes were often rock stars and athletes," Ms. VanDerMeid said. But when those figures are caught using drugs or steroids, "kids get really disillusioned," she said.
"Our goal was not to give them one definition of hero," Ms. VanDerMeid said. "It's kind of like talking about love -- everyone has their own definition."
The program looked at heroes in history, at heroes in different countries and at how the definition of hero has changed.
"When you plan an all-school program, you have to have something that can cross all ages, all cultures," Ms. VanDerMeid said. "Schools get a lot of criticism nowadays that we're not doing enough. Whatever we do in education, we have to validate. But our kids are writing, are doing history, are doing oral presentations -- I don't think anyone can object to that kind of program."

HEADLINE: They're Not as Grabby as We Think

BYLINE: By Frank Gibney; Frank Gibney, the author of "Japan: The Fragile Superpower" and other books on Asia, is president of the Pacific Basin Institute in Santa Barbara, Calif.

 BODY:

JAPANESE TAKEOVERS
The Global Contest for Corporate Control.
By W. Carl Kester.
298 pp. Boston:
Harvard Business School Press. $29.95. 
 One chilly board-meeting morning in the mid-1970's, when I served as president of a joint-venture publishing company in Tokyo, I tried to amuse my Japanese colleagues with a story about the latest unfriendly takeover action in New York. They reacted with incredulity. "Takeover?" "Unfriendly?" These were fairly sophisticated Japanese businessmen -- from two major companies and one of the leading banks -- but they did not understand what I was talking about. That kind of merger did not fit the Japanese business thought pattern.
In the intervening 15 years Japanese executives have grown far more knowledgeable about the gang warfare of international business. They have bought into their share of companies around the world and even sustained the assaults of American takeover experts like T. Boone Pickens on their home ground. But their approach to the buying and selling of companies, at home or abroad, remains a very distinctive one, quite beyond the ken of the average Wall Street analyst. This distinctiveness, backed by the greatest cash reserves in the world and a very strong yen, has made them objects of considerable fear and superstition. After the purchases of Columbia Pictures, National Steel, Firestone and MCA, much of the American public is wondering where they will strike next.
W. Carl Kester, a professor at the Harvard Business School, gives us his answer in a coolly written and very informative book, "Japanese Takeovers." In the business of acquiring companies -- as opposed to purchasing more obvious targets like real estate and art masterpieces -- the Japanese, Mr. Kester says, are not nearly as grabby as is popularly supposed. Almost giving the lie to his subtitle, "The Global Contest for Corporate Control," he finds that a Japanese company or financial group will generally acquire another corporation only in pursuit of a product- or market-oriented business strategy, or to protect itself from either competition or the loss of a supplier. For the most part, the Japanese prefer to expand existing complementary relationships or make new ones. They tend to avoid mergers or acquisitions, intrinsically abrasive activities that are far harder on the cozy Japanese corporate culture than on the American.
Employing the business school case study approach, Mr. Kester backs up his conclusions with useful accounts of particular Japanese corporations -- Sony, Bridgestone and Dainippon Ink and Chemicals among them -- that have made acquisitions in the United States, as well as one American company, Merck, that has made a significant acquisition in Japan. He documents the very specific motives involved. But by far the most interesting part of his book is his discussion of the Japanese system of corporate governance, so totally different from ours.
After tracing the historic development of Japanese business, with its original close links to the 19th-century Meiji rulers, Mr. Kester depicts the contemporary Japanese company as the creature of various "stakeholders" rather than simply of shareholders and management, as is the case in the United States. These stakeholders include employees, the banks (which in Japan can hold shares in companies), related companies and affiliates, as well as the shareholders, who are not the top dogs they are in this country. Management, of course, plays a leading role. (My Japanese publishing company, for example, could not be sold without the consent of the management-dominated board of directors.) Corporate goals are the traditional Japanese ones of full employment, increased market share and long-term expansion. All this is well known.
Mr. Kester goes well beyond this picture, however, to show how, since the 1970's, a variety of factors have put heavy pressure on Japanese corporate patterns. These include the internationalization of business and financial markets, internal and external competitive pressures and excessive financial liquidity resulting from the massive corporate profits of recent years. Japanese companies are no longer as dependent on bank financing as they used to be. The acquisition of a company's stock by rich real estate and trading interests, ultimately with a takeover as the goal, has become more evident. At the same time, many companies have been forced into possibly unwise diversification in their efforts to hold on to their employees in the face of slowing growth.
Will these pressures edge Japan toward what one leading American investment banker, Joseph Perella of Wasserstein, Perella & Company, calls a "single standard of [merger and acquisition] dealmaking . . . the Anglo-Saxon standard"? Mr. Kester would like to say yes. "The genie is now out of the bottle," he writes, "as far as Japanese shareholder activism and contests for corporate control are concerned," and he expects some increase in takeover activity in coming years. But while he finds Japan's corporate governance system weakened, he understands that it is still very much in force. Foreigners ignore it at their peril. When he presents a hypothetical Japanese takeover drama, he cautiously dates it in 1997.
I would second such caution. The days of Japan's excessive liquidity are probably over. The Tokyo stock market has lost almost 50 percent of its value from its high point last year. The nation's big banks are potentially in as much trouble as their counterparts in the United States. And if the hugely inflated bubble in real estate values ever bursts, we shall witness the financial equivalent of the 1923 Tokyo earthquake -- in which case the reaction of Japanese business (and Government) will probably be to close ranks, regroup and charge again, in the traditional flying wedge formation. The corporate governance system -- which I would say pace Mr. Kester is as much cultural and political as economic -- will be vital to any such resurgence.
Nonetheless, despite my own rather different assessment of Japan's economic future, I would say that Mr. Kester has given us an excellent and lucid guide to Japanese corporate structure and behavior. His book has the added virtue of showing how financial deregulation, international trading and indeed Japan's very success have been changing Japanese business. Its present realities are quite different from the myths created about it. Mr. Kester show us how and why those realities are different, with an insight and a clarity rare in books on this well-worked subject.
 
PROBLEMS OF THEIR OWN

Japan has lost the advantage of being small. Few if any large Japanese companies can rely on export growth today as heavily as in the past to maintain full employment while implementing (or even deferring) a plan for restructuring over a long time horizon. Indeed, just the opposite is true. The rest of the world is demanding that Japan help other economies by shifting its consumption patterns to include more imported items, and the charge is to do so fairly quickly.
Nevertheless, the basic impulse of Japanese managers today remains very much as before: to continue growth of the enterprise as a means of fulfilling the expectations of some key stakeholders (labor, in particular) and avoiding, or at least forestalling, potentially divisive and costly recontracting among the broad coalition of stakeholders making up the corporation. But what are the alternatives? For manufacturers in mature industries such as Nippon Steel, growth opportunities in existing core businesses are few if any. . . .
Moreover, attractive investment opportunities in the growth businesses most frequently targeted for entry by restructuring Japanese corporations -- telecommunications, computer electronics, advanced materials, and biotechnology -- tend to be shared with other competitors around the world. If new Japanese entrants to these businesses are to avoid being pre-empted by competitors, they must acquire market share at home and abroad at a faster pace than is generally afforded by internal development of products, manufacturing, and marketing know-how. Confronted with this reality, Japanese managers are gradually overcoming their unfamiliarity with, and even distaste for, mergers and acquisitions. -- From "Japanese Takeovers."
